div.p: THE SECOND PART OF THE CHRISTIAN WARFARE; or the Contempt of the World: TENDING TO ARME AND CONFIRME THE WEAKE CHRISTIAN against the tentations of prosperitie, and to preserue him from the immoderate loue of earthly things; by prouing vnto him, that both the world and worldly vanities are so base and worthlesse, that they deserue not to be esteemed and loued of a Christian, in comparison of Gods spirituall graces and heauenly ioyes.

WRITTEN AS AN ANTIDOTE AGAINST THE POYSON OF WORLDLIE loue, with which in these daies so many are infected; and that it might reuiue that heauenly fire of spirituall and diuine loue, which is so much cooled and abated.
By I. DOVVNAME Bachelar in Diuinitie, and Preacher of Gods word.
div.q: Loue not the world, neither the things that are in the world. If any man loue the world, the loue of the father is not in him. 1. Ioh. 2.15.
div.p: AT LONDON Imprinted by FELIX KYNGSTON, 1611.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONORABLE, SIR THOMAS EGERTON KNIGHT, BARON OF Ellesmere, Lord high Chancellor of England, and one of his Maiesties most honorable priuie Counsell, I. D. wisheth all grace and prosperitie in this life, and eternall happinesse in the life to come.
div.p:
WHen I considered (Right Honorable) the great puissance, and preuailing strength, of these arch-enemies of our saluation, the world, and worldly vanities, manifested in their daily conquests, not onely of those, who voluntarily yeeld at the first onset, and are willingly content to become their vassals and slaues, for the vncertaine tenure, and base wages of earthly vanities; but also of such as hauing giuen their names to Christ, by receiuing his sacrament, professed themselues to be his souldiers
and seruants, and that amongst other enemies, they would valiantly fight his battailes, against the world, and worldly lusts: who notwithstanding their oath and promise, either yeeld subiection to the world vpon the offer of earthly profits, pleasures, and preferments, or stand in a cold neutralitie, desiring to doe seruice to the world and God too; but without all indifferencie, seeing he hath onely the seruice of their lips, and some outward deuotions, meerely complementall, and ceremoniall; whereas the other master hath the seruice of their hearts, and all their care, labours, and painefull indeauours imploied about him. And when as I saw the glorious trophees of the worlds victories erected, not onely in euery corner of the common-wealth, but euen in the temple and church of God, to his great dishonour, and the disgrace of his true religion; I thought I could not spend my strength in a better quarrell, then in opposing against this enemie of our saluation; to the end, that I might abate his preuailing forces, and weaken the very sinewes of his strength, wherein hee most glorieth and triumpheth; by
shewing that the wages of iniquitie whereby he inticeth men to leaue Gods standard, and to fight vnder his colours, is but base and counterfeite coine, being examined by the touchstone of Gods truth, and therefore not to be receiued of a Christian for good pay; much lesse to be preferred before that crowne of victorie, euerlasting glorie, and those all-sufficient treasures of our heauenly kingdome, which God promiseth to all those who fight his battailes, and valiantly ouercome. Neither did I thinke that I could more profitably spend my studies in any other argument, especiallie in these times, wherein the loue of the world so greatly preuaileth, that with Demas men daily fall from the profession of Gods truth, and imbrace the world, hauing onely so much loue of religion, as the loue of the world worketh in them; and either not seruing God at all, or only that they may serue their owne turnes, in worldly and carnall respects. For if by plaine testimonies of holy Scriptures, and by effectuall reasons (as it were a proclamation sent from the great king of heauen and earth) I could crie downe the high rates and
prices of these base and copper coynes, and bring them to their owne value; by shewing that there is no excellencie & true worth in them, but onely as they serue for the present necessitie of our earthly state, and to furnish vs in our trauaile towards our heauenly countrie; then would there many and great benefits bee hereby deriued vnto vs. For if we could contemne the world and worldly vanities, as things of small worth, then would they not be as heauie clogs to hinder vs from running the Christian race, and from ascending in our meditations into Gods kingdome, to take possession for the present of our heauenly inheritance with our mindes and thoughts, till our soules and bodies doe come thither: then would we not suffer them to take vp all our cogitations, care, studie, and labour, about the getting or preseruing them, so as wee haue little or no time left to performe seruice vnto God; or if at all wee doe it, yet with much distraction and perturbation: then would the tentations of the diuell haue no power to draw vs into sinne, wanting this wages of iniquitie, and these alluring baites, wherewith hee inticeth vs to
come into his nets of perdition: for who would serue satan for nought, or for such things as he contemneth, or but lightly valueth, leauing the seruice of his Creator and Redeemer, and thereby hazarding the eternall losse of those heauenly excellencies which he hath promised vnto his seruants in the life to come? Then should wee haue a true golden age, free from all oppression, bribing, extortion, fraude, wrongs, dissensions, treasons, rebellions, and innumerable other outrages, which are caused and occasioned through the immoderate loue of these earthly things; and perfect loue and charitie being entertained amongst men, they would striue who should exceed other in al good and Christian duties, louing vertue and goodnes for their owne sakes: then would not those who abound with these worldly things be euer the prouder, or with scornefull insolence ouerlooke their brethren; for who is proud of that which hee contemneth? Neither would those that want them be much troubled, hauing for the present Gods better gifts, euen his sanctifying and sauing graces, and for the time to come
farre more excellent hopes, life eternall, and the vnspeakeable ioies of Gods glorious kingdome. For who bewaileth the want, or lamenteth the losse of those things which he lightly esteemeth, especially hauing both in possession and hope, such things as are of farre greater worth and excellencie? Finally, if wee were perswaded to contemne the world and worldly vanities, and highly to esteeme of the ioyes of Heauen, then would we not feare the approach of death, but bid it welcome with a cheerefull countenance? seeing it taketh vs from the things which we doe not much regard, and entreth vs into the possession and fruition of our better hopes; euen a kingdome matchles, and glorie endlesse. Whereas contrariwise, when these worldly things bee ouerualued, and too much loued and desired, they wholly take vp mens meditations, and disable them for Gods seruice, they lay them open to satans tentations, and make them readie to perpetrate and commit any wickednesse, which may further them to the obtaining of the things which they affect; neither is there any stop in the way to hinder their headlong
course in sin, vnlesse it be when their worldly desires do crosse one another: they puffe men vp with pride when they inioy them, and consume them with griefe and discontent when they want them: and to conclude, they make death most terrible, because it plucketh thē violently from these delights, vnto which their hearts are fast glued, and forceth them to leaue the things which they dearely loue, hauing no assurance or hope of a better life. For the auoiding of all which euils, and for the furthering and aduancing of the former benefits, I haue laboured in this argument, euen aboue my strength, God shewing his power in my weakenes, and causing my desire to supplie that which was wanting in my health. Of which my labours I haue chosen your Lordship for patron, partly to shew my loue and dutie vnto you, from whom I haue had, both al the meanes of my maintenance which I enioy, wherewith I haue been enabled to labour; and opportunitie to exercise that poore talent which I haue receiued from my great Lord and master: and partly because I thought, I could not dedicate vnto you a booke of a fitter argument,
wherein your selfe may at your best leasure meditate; seeing on the one side the greatnes of your place, and height of your honors and preferments may (without your greater vigilance and circumspection) incline your affections too much to the loue of these earthly things, and on the other side your age (vnto which God adde many yeares for his owne glorie, the Churches good, and your owne euerlasting comfort) is not likely in course of nature to allow vnto you any long possession of these momentanie things. In regard of both which, your Honour cannot bee too well armed against the immoderate loue of these worldly vanities, nor haue your heart too much inflamed with that diuine loue of Heauen, and those most glorious ioyes in Gods presence, which you shall inherit for euermore; because hereby you shall inioy Gods blessings more securely whilest you haue them, when as your heart is not so fixed on them but that you can bee content to leaue them; and part with them also with ioy and comfort, when as you are assured, that you shall exchange them for those heauenly ioyes,
and rich treasures of Gods glorious kingdome, which infinitely exceede all earthly preferments in worth and excellency. Which if my poore labours, added to your better helps, and holy meditations, might any way further, I should much more reioice in being a poore instrument of your spirituall good, then in the inioying of those earthly benefits which I haue receiued from you. The Lord more and more inrich your noble heart with all spirituall and sauing grace, and after a long and happie life on earth, vouchsafe vnto you the euerlasting fruition of his glorious presence, and that fulnesse of ioy which is at his right hand for euermore. Amen.

closer.signed: Your Honours in all humble dutie most bounden, Iohn Downame.

div.head: To the Christian Reader.
div.p: THe Christian mans life is a continuall warfare, wherein hee is daily assaulted (I know not whether, with greater subtiltie or furie, policie or power) by three puissant enemies, the diuell, the the world, and the flesh; euery one of which haue many legions vnder their conduct, which are ready to second and succour them, when they giue signe of battaile. The diuell is the grand captaine, and generall of all these forces; the world and the flesh, are chiefe commanders vnder him, who haue many millions of spirituall enemies vnder their ensignes, that continuallie fight against vs. Satan ordereth the battaile, and guideth all these forces to his best aduantage, and our ruine; the world ministreth vnto him weapons and munition, whereby this fight is maintained; and the flesh like a wicked traitor openeth the gates of our soules when we are assaulted, and receiuing the pay of worldly vanities, ioyneth with these externall forces to work our final ouerthrow. The issue of this fight is either their, or our victorie; the former is accompanied with the diuels triumph, and our perpetuall captiuitie and thraldome in the chaines of darknes; yea with the most exquisite and ineffable torments of hell fire: the other, with the crowne of victorie which our great Commander, the Lord of hosts, hath promised to those that2. Cor. 4. 17. ouercome; euen that superexcellent and eternall waight of glorie reserued in the highest heauens.

The consideration whereof, as it should moue all Christians valiantly to fight the Lords battailes, to forget all labour,
and to contemne all danger, especially seeing they haue the power of God to assist them, and his gracious promise, that if they will bee his souldiers, they shall also bee conquerours; if they will but fight, they shall assuredly ouercome: so also should it incite all Gods faithfull ministers, who are appointed by him to bee in this spirituall warfare, not onely souldiers, to fight in their owne persons, but also the Lords captaines to teach, guide and direct, both by word and example, those who are committed to their charge, yea as much as in them lieth the whole armie of the Church militant; that they also be carefull and diligent to teach the ignorant the Lords march, the discipline of his warre, the order of his battels, and how to manage their spirituall weapons for their best aduantage: that they likewise incourage and harten the white liuered, and freshwater souldier to the fight; that they rouze vp the sluggish, by often sounding in their eares the terrible thunder of Gods threats, and the sweet tunes of his promises; that they moderate the heate, and mitigate and restraine the desperate boldnesse of those, who are ouercaried in their blind zeale, with spirituall wisdome and discretion, which are otherwise apt in themselues to bee intrapped with the subtiltie, and to fall into the ambushments of their enemies, to their vtter ruine and destruction.

Being therefore called through Gods vndeserued grace to this function, I thought it my dutie, besides my other labours in my ministerie, to attempt this worke; the which I acknowledge might haue been much better atchieued by some of the Lords great Worthies, vnto the least degree of whose strength and excellencie I haue not attained: but being by them either omitted, or but by the way, as some speciall occasion required, briefly touched; I thought it better, notwithstanding my great weakenesse, to vndertake it, then that it should be wholly neglected; and by doing in this the
Lords businesse what I could doe, to put others in mind who are of greater abilitie, what they should doe; drawing them on by my example to perfect that, which I haue but rud • ly attempted; wherein my poore labours shal but serue as foiles, to shew the greater glory of their surpassing excellencies, and but as courser wares, to make their finer stuffes more saleable and commendable. And hauing through Gods assistance finished and set foorth the first part of this Christian Warfare, wherein I haue laid open the subtiltie, power, politicke stratagems, and pernicious tentations of Satan our grand enemie; and withall haue armed and furnished the weake Christian with such means and spiritual weapons, as may by the blessing and assistance of Gods holy spirit strengthen him in the incounter, repell the enemie, and obtaine victorie; and hauing found that the Work, like course meate in the time of a great dearth, hath been esteemed of many hungrie soules aboue desert, their necessitie, and not any selfe excellencie, giuing worth vnto it, and making it, though in it selfe but homely fare, pleasing and acceptable to their sharpened appetites: I haue the rather bin incouraged to set vpon the second part of this Warfare, & to arme the Christian against all those assaults, which the second enemie of our saluation, the world, assaileth him with; which as the following discourse, and the experience of al times sufficiently shew, are no lesse dangerous and pernicious then the other. And because I hold a strange paradox in the conceit of worldly men, maintaining that these earthly things are base and of little worth, and therefore to bee contemned or lightly valued, which they so much magnifie in their iudgements, adhere vnto in their hearts and affections, and both get and keepe with so great care and labour, and lose with such bitter griefe; I thought it fit (besides my wonted order) not onely plentifully to confirme this truth by the holy Scriptures, but
also to alleage the sayings of the godly learned, and ancient Fathers, who haue liued in former ages, to shew the conformitie of our iudgements, and our vnanimous consent in expounding those places of holy scriptures, which serue for the clearing and proouing of those points, for which I alleage them; lest perhaps mine owne writings and assertions might seeme to haue proceeded out of some melancholicke or discontented humor, which might make me to contemne the world, because it hath alwaies contemned me, and so carrie no credit with them, if I were not backed with their better authoritie. And to the same purpose, I haue also more plentifully then is my vsuall custome, alleaged the sayings of the wisest Heathens, and most learned Philosophers; because hauing to deale with carnall worldlings, who notwithstanding make shew and profession of Christian religion, I might mooue and perswade them, if not in the feare of God, and for conscience sake, yet at least for shame to assent vnto that truth, vnto which Pagans and Infidels haue yeelded and subscribed, who haue had no other knowledge to guide them, but the light of nature. The which my labours, I humbly submit to the graue censure of the iudicious, learned, and godly Reader: the which I hope to find more fauourable; because my errours may more iustly be excused, seeing I doe not trauell in a path beaten by others, who haue gone before me, but in an vncouth and vnusuall way, where I haue not had the tract of other mens steps for my direction; there being none that I know of, especially of our countrimen, that haue purposely laboured in this argument. The Lord blesse these and all other my lab • urs, that they may bee powerfull and effectuall, for the aduancement of his glorie, the good of his Church, and the comfort and edification of all the particular members thereof, who shalt haue any vse of my poore
ministerie; that being armed and strengthened hereby, against the politicke furie, and powerfull cunning of our spirituall enemies, they may obtaine a full and finall victorie ouer them, and also the crowne of victorie, euerlasting glorie, and happinesse in Gods Kingdome. Amen.

closer.dateline: From Lothburie in London, the seuenth of May, Anno Dom. 1611.
closer.signed: Thine in the Lord, I. D.

div.head: THE CONTENTS OF THE FIRST BOOKE.
The chiefe points contained in the first Booke.

list.item:
CHAP. 1. Of the world, the second enemy of our saluation, and what it is.
§ 1. THat the world is sometimes taken in good part, and so to be loued as a friend. 2.
§ 2. In what sense the world is to be reputed our enemy. 4.
§ 3. How wicked worldlings are to be hated. 5.

CHAP. 2. Of the nature and qualitie of our enemy the world.
§ 1. That the world is euill and wicked in it selfe, yeelding obedience to Sathan as the Prince thereof. 6.
§ 2. That the world fighteth vnder Sathan against God. 7.
§ 3. That the world is a most dangerous enemie. 9.
§ 4. That the world is a malicious enemie. 10.
§ 5. That the world is a subtill enemie. 11.
§ 6. That the world is a powerfull enemy in regard of it owne strength. 11.
§ 7. That much strength is added to the worlds forces through our corruption. 13.
§ 8. The power of the world shewed by the experience of former times. 13.
§ 9. The power of the world shewed by the experience of these times. 15.
§ 10. That the world often preuaileth with Gods seruants. 17.

CHAP. 3. Reasons to moue vs to resist and fight against our enemie the world.
§ 1. God commands vs to oppose against the world. 18.
§ 2. The second reason taken from the passion of Christ. 19.
§ 3. The third reason taken from the necessity of this fight, seeing the friends of the world are enemies to God. 19.
§ 4. Ʋnlesse we renounce the world, we are not of the number of the faithfull. 21.
§ 5. Christian religion requireth that we should renounce the world. 22.
§ 6. The way of the world is the way of sinne. 22.
§ 7. We must fight against the world if we will be Christs disciples. 23.
§ 8 We become Apostates if we fight not against the world. 23.
§ 9. The fourth reason taken from our assured hope of victorie. 24.
§ 10. The last reason taken from our reward which accompanieth victorie. 25.
§ 11. How we are said to fight against the world, and to obtaine victorie. 25.

CHAP. IIII. Of the manner of the worlds fight, and how he assaulteth vs, on the one side with prosperitie, and on the other side with aduersitie.
§ 1. With what weapons the world assaulteth vs. 26.
§ 2. The manner how the world fighteth with vs. 26.
§ 3. That prosperitie is good in it owne nature. 28.
§ 4. That prosperitie in respect of our vse is of an indifferent nature. 29.
§ 5. That we are apt to abuse our prosperitie to sinne. 30.

CHAP. V. Of the dangerousnesse of worldly prosperitie.
§ 1. That the worlds tentations on the right hand are very dangerous. 31.
§ 2. That the state of prosperitie is much more dangerous, then the state of aduersitie. 3 • .
§ 3. That we are most carefully to take heed of the world when it fawneth on vs. 34.
§ 4. The fruits of affliction much better then of prosperitie. 35.
§ 5. The great danger of prosperitie shewed by examples of former ages. 37.
§ 6. The great difference betweene the same men in prosperitie and aduersitie. 38.
§ 7. That prosperitie hath corrupted and destroyed whole nations. 39.
§ 8. The danger of prosperitie shewed by the experience of these present times. 40.
§ 9. The reasons why prosperitie is so dangerous. 41.
§ 10. That a great measure of grace is required to the well managing of our prosperitie. 42.
§ 11. That we ought to keepe a narrow watch ouer our selues in the time of prosperitie. 42.
§ 12. How we are said to resist the tentations of prosperitie. 43.

CHAP. VI. Reasons which may moue vs to contemne worldly prosperitie.
§ 1. Prosperitie seldome bettereth our spirituall estate. 44.
§ 2. The meane estate is to be preferred before great prosperitie. 45
§ 3. That prosperitie is but one of Gods ordinarie gifts, which he best • weth also vpon the wicked. 46.
§ 4. Worldly prosperitie and heauenly happinesse are seldome bestowed on the same men. 47.
§ 5. Prosperitie abused increaseth their condemnation who abuse it. 50.

CHAP. VII. Of morall and ciuill vertues which are in worldlings, and that they are to be contemned being seuered from sanctifying grace.
§ 1. That ciuill vertues do not benefite, but hurt those that rest in them. 51.
§ 2. What is required to a vertue, or action, that it may be truly good. First, that the person be regenerate and ingraffed into Christ. 53.
§ 3. Our vertues must arise from the true worship of the true God. 55.
§ 4. Our vertues must be grounded vpon true godlinesse. 56
§ 5. Our vertues must arise from true charitie. 57.
§ 6. Our vertues must be grounded on true knowledge. 58.
§ 7. Our vertues must be ioyned with true faith. 58.
§ 8. All our vertues must be embraced and good workes done in obedience to God. 59.
§ 9. With all other vertues we must ioyne humilitie. 59.
§ 10. All our vertues and workes must haue Gods glory propounded to them as their chiefe end. 60.
§ 11. That worldlings in their ciuill vertues and workes obserue none of the former conditions. 61.
§ 12. That we are to contemne ciuill vertues, and to hunger after Christs righteousnesse. 63.

CHAP. VIII. Of spirituall wisedome.
§. 1. Of spirituall wisedome which is commended vnto vs in the Scriptures. 64
§. 2. Wherein spirituall wisedome consisteth. 66.
§. 3. Spirituall wisedome is alwayes ioyned with practise and obedience. 66
§. 4. Spirituall wisedome is to be learned only out of Gods word. 67
§. 5. The true properties of spirituall wisedome. 68
§. 6. That spirituall wisedome is to be highly esteemed. 69

CHAP. IX. Of ciuill and worldly wisedome, and how farre forth to be embraced, & in what respects to be contemned.
§. 1. Of ciuill wisedome and the cautions thereunto required that it may be good and lawfull. 70
§. 2. Of worldly wisedome which is wicked and vnlawfull. First, because it is ioyned with pride. 72
§. 3. Worldly policy is wicked when it is seuered from simplicitie and sinceritie. 73
§. 4. Worldy wisedome is to be contemned, first, because God esteemeth it not. 74
§. 5. That the diuell is the authour of worldly wisedome. 75
§. 6. Worldy wisedome resembleth Satan in malicious opposing against God. 75
§. 7. That the wisedome of the world is foolishnesse with God.. 76
§. 8. Worldly wisedome ioyned with lying and vntruth. 78
§. 9. Worldly wisedome grounded vpon dissimulation and deceipt. 78.
§. 10. Worldly wisedome is grounded vpon treachery and treason. 79.
§. 11. Worldly wisedome propoundeth wicked ends. 80
§. 12. That worldly wisedome hath bene alwayes embraced and much esteemed in the world. 80
§. 13. That worldly wisedome vnderstandeth not the spirituall things of God. 82
§. 14. The reason why worldly wisedome vnderstandeth not the things of God. 83
§. 15. Worldly wisedome doth not certainely assure men of the vain things of this life. 85
§. 16. God turneth worldly wisedome into foolishnesse. 86
§. 17. Worldly wisedome hindereth the fruition of spirituall benefites. 87
§. 18. Worldly wisedome doth not priuiledge men from Gods fearefull iudgements. 88
§. 19. That worldly wisedome bringeth with it much hurt. 88
§. 20. Other euils into which worldly wisedome plungeth men. 89
§. 21. That we are to contemne worldly wisedome, and to labour after that which is diuine and spirituall. 90

CHAP. X. That worldly learning seuered from true godlinesse is to be contemned.
§. 1. That learning in it owne nature is good and very commendable. 91
§. 2. That worldly learning becommeth euill vnto vs when it is abused. 92
§. 3. That worldly learning is to be contemned, because it doth not profite vs. 94
§. 4. That worldly learning is vaine, and of no excellency. 96
§. 5. Worldly learning helpeth vs not to the attaining of Gods spirituall graces. 97
§. 6. Worldly learning helpeth not to the attaining of life eternal. 99
§. 7. That worldly learning much hurteth those which set their hearts vpon it. 99
§. 8. That worldly learning is to be contemned in comparison of the true knowledge of God. 100

CHAP. XI. That worldly sciences are of no worth in comparison of spirituall knowledge and sauing grace.
§. 1. Arts and sciences in themselues good, and the gifts of God. 101
§. 2. How wordly sciences are abused. 102
§. 3. That worldly sciences are to be contemned. 102

CHAP. XII. That vnfruitfull knowledge of God, and his true religion, is vaine and vnprofitable.
§. 1. Knowledge of God and his truth in it selfe an excellent gift of God, but yet liable to the abuse of worldlings. 103
§. 2. That our knowledge is maimed and imperfect. 104
§. 3. That vnfruitfull knowledge is vaine, and to no purpose. 106
§. 4. That vnfruitf • ll knowl • dge is vnprofitable. 107
§. 5. That vnfruitfull knowledge doth much hurt vs, and first in respect of our bodies. 108
§. 6. Vnfruitfull knowledge much hurteth vs in respect of our soules; first, as it puffeth vs vp with pride. 109

CHAP. XIII. That beautie is to be contemned in respect of spirituall graces, or heauenly excellencies.

§. 8. Beautie is good rather to those that see it, then to those that haue it. 121
§. 9. Beautie is momentanie and mutable. 122
§. 10. That contemning this outward beautie, we must affect the inward beautie of the mind. 123
§ 11. Beautie too much affected, doth make the body tender, soft, and sickly. 124
§. 12. Beautie hindereth vertue, and furthereth vice. 124
§. 13. Beautie and chastitie seldome meete together. 125
§. 14. Beautie maketh proud, and causeth those that haue it, to neglect all holy duties. 127
§. 15. Beautie deceiueth, and allureth vnto sinne. 128
§. 16. Beautie oftentimes hurtfull to the friends of those who excell in it. 129
§. 17. That we should fixe our loue on diuine beautie. 130
§. 18. That the beautie of the soule is much more excellent then the beautie of the body. 131

CHAP. XIIII. Of the vanitie and wickednesse of painting the face.
§. 1. That the diuell was the inuenter of this art of painting. 132
§. 2. Painting both the effect and cause of sinne. 133
§. 3. That these painters deceiue and abuse others. 134

CHAP. XV. That bodily strength is not much to be esteemed, as being of small worth and excellency.
§. 1. That bodily strength being in it selfe good, is often abused through our corruption. 138
§. 2. That it is a great vanitie to glory in strength, seeing God esteemeth it not, and beasts excell in it. 139
§. 3. That bodily strength is moment any and but of short continuance. 140
§. 4. Bodily strength cannot deliuer vs from euils and innumerable dangers. 142

CHAP. XVI. That bodily health is but of small worth and excellency.
§. 1. Health in it selfe is a great blessing, but much abused through our corruption. 143
§. 2. That health is but a common gift, which is imparted also to the wicked. 143
§. 3. That bodily health is moment any and vncertaine. 144
§. 4. That bodily health is imperfect and full of infirmities. 145
§. 5. The manifold euils which vsually accompany bodily health. 146.

CHAP. XVII. That societie and neare familiaritie with wicked worldlings is to be shunned and auoided.
§. 1. That the world allureth vs by wicked company, to accompany them in sinne. 148
§. 2. That all societie with wicked men is not vnlawfull. 148

CHAP. XIX. That the friendship of wicked worldlings is to be contemned and carefully auoided.

div.head: The second Booke.
The chiefe points contained in the second Booke.

§. 4. That we ought not to reiect these worldly things, but their abuses. 179
§. 5. To the right vse of worldly things is required, first, that our persons be regenerate. 180
§. 6. That we must not ouer value these earthly things, or preferre them before Gods spirituall graces. 181
§. 7. That we are not to set our hearts and affections vpon these worldly things. 182
§. 8. That we must first seeke spirituall and heauenly things, and
these earthly things in the last place. 185
§. 9. That we must not seeke these earthly things for their owne sake. 186

§. 5. That we must first and principally seeke honor from God. 192
§. 6. That in the next place, we must seeke to be honored of the good and vertuous. 193
§. 7. Whether it be lawfull to desire praise of wickedmen. 194
§. 8. That honour is onely to be desired for vertues and good actions. 195
§. 9. That we ought to affect such honours as are moderate, and proportionable to our deserts. 197
§. 10. That honours ought not to be immoderately desired. 198
§. 11. That good meanes onely must be vsed for the obtaining of honours. 299
§. 12. That we must not propound our owne honour as our chiefe and maine end. 200
§. 13. We must not let honour rest with vs, but returne it wholly vnto God. 201
§. 14. We must employ our honours vnto good vses. 203
§. 15. That lawfull honours are to be desired for Gods glory. 203
§. 16. That we are to desire lawfull honors for our neighbors good, and first, because thereby he doth his dutie. 204
§. 17. We must desire lawfull honour that our neighbour may be
thereby edified. 205
§. 18. That we must preserue our honour and good name to auoide scandall. 205
§. 19. That we ought to desire honour for our owne sake, that it may reuiue and refresh vs. 206
§. 20. That we are bound by Gods commandement to preserue our honour and good name. 207

CHAP. III. Of riches, and that they are good in themselues, and indifferent in respect of their vse.
§. 1. That riches are good in their owne nature. 209
§. 2. That riches are mutably good and of no great excellency. 209.
§. 3. That riches are of an indifferent nature in respect of their vse. 210

§. 6. The reason of the following discourse. 213

§. 8. Why riches are called the mammon of iniquitie. 214

§. 10. The saying of Christ to the yong man expounded. 217

§. 10. Worldly things are esteemed more for their rarenesse then for their goodnesse. 292

§. 2. That worldly glorie is vaine and vnprofit • ble. 295

§. 1. In what respect worldly authoritie is good, and in what euill and sinfull.

§. 8. That worldly authoritie exposeth men to enuie and many dangers. 321

§. 3. That true nobilitie is much to be honoured and respected. 327
§. 4. That worldly nobilitie is of no worth or excellencie. 328
§. 5. That there is no cause why any should glorie in worldly nobilitie. 330
§. 6. That God respecteth not worldly nobilitie. 330
§. 7. That Christ neglected worldly nobilitie. 331
§. 8. That worldly nobilitie is momentany and mutable. 332

§. 9. Of the vngratitude of the people towards their gouernors. 353.

§. • . That worldly riches are to be contemned as vaine and worthlesse. 360
§. 2. Of the vanitie of great lands, and large Lordships. 361
§. 3. Of the vanitie of gold and siluer. 362
§. 4. The vanitie of rich iewels and costly furniture. 364

§ 5. That worldly things in steed of satisfying bring with them loathing satietie. 446
§. 6. From the insufficiency of worldly things to satisfie, proceedeth an endlesse desire and affectation of change. 448
§. 7. The former point cleared by some instances. 451

CHAP. XIX. Of the excellency of true contentment, and the meanes whereby we may attaine vnto it.
§. 1. That contentment is to be sought not in the world but in Gods spirituall graces. 452
§. 2. That spirituall contentment much exceedeth all contentment in worldly things. 454
§. 3. That contentment is a medicine for all miserie. 456
§. 4. That contentment is to be sought▪ not in outward things, but in the heart and mind. 457
§. 5. That we must seeke contentment, not by multiplying worldly vanities, but by moderating our desires and affections. 459
§. 6. If we would haue contentment in riches, we must lay aside couetousnesse. 461
§. 7. That contentment in pleasures, is had, not by multiplying them, but by restraining our appetites. 463
§. 8. The first and chiefe meanes of contentation is wholely to resigne our selues to the will of God. 464
§. 9. That Christians may safely and securely rest on Gods prouidence. 466
§. 10. The reasons why the Lord giueth worldly things to some of his children, and not to others. 468
§. 11. The reasons why the Lord maketh not all his children rich in all worldly benefites. 470
§. 12. The second meanes of contentment is to leade a godly life. 472
§. 13. The third meanes is to thinke of our benefites as well as of our wants. 473
§. 14. That perfect and full contentation is onely to be found in heauenly happinesse. 474

CHAP. XX. Of the vnprofitablenes of worldly vanities in comparison of Gods spirituall graces and heauenly ioyes.
§. 1. That there is no profite in worldly things to those who set their hearts on them. 476
§. 2. That worldly honours are vnprofitable. 477
§. 3. That there is no profite in worldly riches. 477
§. 4. That riches are most vnprofitable to sordidous misers. 480
§. 5. Of the vnprofitablenesse of worldly pleasures. 483
§. 6. That worldly things do not further the maine ends at which we aime, as first they do not make vs truly better. 485
§. 7. That we are not bettered by honors, riches, or carnall pleasures. 488.

CHAP. XXI. That worldly things profit not to the attaining of those things which are chiefly good, nor to the auoiding of our greatest euils.
§. 1. That worldly things helpe not to enrich our minds with vertue and Gods sauing graces. 491
§. 1. That worldly things do not make vs more fruitfull in good workes. 492
§. 3. That worldly things do not make them, who haue them, more merry and chearefull. 494
§. 4. That worldly pleasures are voide of true pleasure, and sound delight. 496
§. 5. That worldly things assure vs neither of the loue of God nor man. 497
§. 6. That worldly things do not helpe to free vs from our greatest euils: as first, they do not deliuer vs from dangers. 499
§. 7. Worldly things cure not the body of sicknesses & diseases. 500
§. 8. Worldly things do not profit in the day of Gods visitation. 505
§. 9. That worldly things profit not at the howre of death. 506
§. 10. That worldly things at the day of death bring much griefe and bitternesse. 509
§. 11. That worldly things profite not after our separation. 511
§. 12. That worldly things will not profite vs at the day of iudgement.
512
§. 13. The conclusion perswading to seeke after Gods spirituall graces, and heauenly ioyes; which alone bring true profite. 514

CHAP. XXII. Of the manifold miseries which do accompanie worldly vanities in the whole course of mans life.
§. 1. That all worldly benefits are imbittered with manifold miseries. 515
§. 2. The mis • ries of worldly things shewed by testimonies. 517
§. 3. The miseries of mans life in respect of sinne. 518
§. 4. That the things of this life are commended onely by necessitie 5 • 0.
§. 5. That mans life is a continuall disease, and worldly things medicines to ease it. 521
§. 6. Of the loathsome saciety which man findeth in worldly things. 523.
§. 7. Of the adherent euils which are incident to mans life. 523
§. 8. Of the miseries incident to man • estate. 525
§. 9. Of the miseries incident to a mans person, and first in respect of his body. 527
§. 10. Of the manifold miseries of man in respect of his soule. 528
§. 11. Of the miseries of man through the contrarietie and fight of his owne passions. 530
§. 12. Of the miseries of mans life in respect of his friends. 531

CHAP. XXIII. Of the miseries which are specially incident vnto all the ages of man.
§. 1. Of mans misery which he is subiect vnto in his mothers wombe 533.
§. 2. Of mans miserie in his birth. 534
§. 3. Of the miseries of infancie, childhood, and youth. 535
§. 4. Of the miseries incident to man in his perfect age. 538
§. 5. of the miseries incident to old age. 540

CHAP. XXIIII. Of the manifold miseries all estates of men are subiect.
§. 1. Of the miseries incident vnto single life and wedlocke. 541
§. 2. Of the miseries incident to diuers states publick & priuat. 543
§. 3. Of some special worldly miseries peculiar to true Christiās. 544

CHAP. XXV. Of the miseries which accompany worldly things, in respect of their getting, keeping, and possession.
§. 1. Of the euils which worldly things bring with them, and first honours and riches. 547
§. 2. Of the miseries which accompany pleasures. 549
§. 3. That worldly things are not gotten without great labour. 550
§. 4. That worldly men take their chiefe pains for superfluities. 551
§. 5. Of the miseries incident to the getting of honours, riches and pleasures. 552
§. 6. That mens paines in getting worldly things is accompanied with sinne. 554
§. 7. Of the wicked courses which ambitious and couetous men run into, to obtaine honours and riches. 556
§. 8. That worldly pleasures are seldome procured without sin. 560
§. 9. Of the miseries accompanying worldly things in respect of their possession. 561
§. 10. The cares and feares which accompany honors in their possession. 562
§. 11. Of the miseries which accōpany riches in their possession. 565
§. 12. That riches depriue their bodies of rest, and their minds of peace▪ which too much loue them. 568
§. 13. How we may in the possession of riches be freed from the former miseries. 570
§. 14. That riches are most surely preserued when they are giuen to the poore. 572
§. 15. An exhortation to almes deeds. 575
§. 16. Of the miseries which accompany worldly pleasures and their fruition. 576
§. 17. Of the miseries which accompany worldly things when they are lost. 577
§. 18. Of the miseries which are incident to men for the losse of honours, riches, and pleasures. 579
§. 19. The conclusion perswading all to seeke after Gods spirituall graces, and heauenly ioyes. 581

CHAP XXVI. That though with all our indeuours we seeke for worldly things, we are not sure to obtaine them,
§. 1. That worldlings often fa • le in their desires, and loose all their labour. 582
§. 2. That the world and the Prince thereof abuse their fauourites with false promises. 584
§. 3. That though men be often deceiued, yet they more trust Satan and the world, then God himselfe. 586
§. 4. That worldlings do often by their too earnest labouring loose the fruite of their labours. 589
§. 5. Of the vncertainty of obtaining worldly honours. 591
§. 6. That too earnest seeking honours makes men to loose them. 593
§. 7. The right way to seeke true honour. 594
§. 8. The great vncertainty of obtaining worldly riches. 596
§. 9. Of the vncertainty of obtaining worldly pleasures. 598
§. 10. That we may be assured to obtaine spirituall graces and heauenly ioyes if we truly seeke them. 599
§. 11. The certaintie of obtaining eternall ioyes by those that seeke them, proued. 601

CHAP. XXVII. That the world and worldly things are momentany and corruptible.
§. 1. That the world is corruptible and shall end. 603
§. 2. That we should not set our hearts on the world, because it is corruptible and neare an end. 605
§. 3. That all worldly things are momentany and corruptible. 608
§. 4. That we cannot securely enioy worldly things, and without feare of loosing them. 609
§. 5. That the corruptibilitie of worldly things should weane our hearts from their fond loue. 610
§. 6. That worldly honours are momentany and vncertaine. 612
§. 7. That worldly riches are momentany and transitory. 615
§. 8. That riches are daily in danger of loosing; and that the greater losse brings the greater griefe. 617
§. 9. The best way to preserue riches from loosing. 619
§. 10. That worldly pleasures are short and momentany. 621

CPAP. XXVIII. Of the mutabilitie and inconstancy of worldly things.
§. 1. That all things in heauen and earth are subiect to change and alteration. 623
§. 2. That we communicate with all creatures in their mutability, besides the changes vnto which our own estates are subiect. 624
§. 3. Of the mutability and vnconstancy of honors and preferments. 627.
§. 4. The causes why honors are so variable and vnconstant. 629
§. 5. Of the mutabilitie and vnconstancie of riches. 631
§. 6. That worldly pleasures are vnconstant and subiect to change. 633.

CHAP. XXIX. Of the momentany continuance and frailtie of mans life.
§. 1. That notwithstanding mans life is short and fraile, yet worldly men dreame of immortalitie. 635
§. 2. The breuitie of mans life proued by plaine testimonies of Scripture. 636
§. 3. The breuitie of mans life illustrated by similitudes. 637
§. 4. That mans short life is most fraile and vncertaine, being on euery side assailed by death. 639
§. 5. Of the innumerable dangers vnto which mans life is daily subiect. 640
§. 6. That euery man more clearely seeth other mens mortalitie then his owne. 642
§. 7. That from our birth to our death our liues are in a continuall consumption. 643
§. 8. The breuitie of mans life shewed by a speciall consideration of the parts thereof. 645
§. 9. That by reason of the vncertaintie of our liues all things are vncertaine vnto vs. 646
§. 10. That the things we possesse are not our owne, but the worlds heire-loomes. 649
§. 11. The shortnesse of their liues who are aduanced to honors. 650
§. 12. That the rich mans life is short and vncertaine. 651
§. 13. That the hope of worldlings is vaine and vncertaine, who thinke to leaue all things to their heires and children. 653
§. 14. That the liues of voluptuous men are short and full of frailtie. 656.
§. 15. A perswasion to the contempt of the world, and loue of heauen grounded vpon the consideration of our liues short and momentany continuance. 657

CHAP. XXX. Of the great hurt which worldly things bring to their owners when they set their hearts on them: and first, by weaning their hearts from God, and making them idolaters.
§. 1. That worldly things are hurtfull to those who immoderately loue them. 661
§. 2. That worldly honors bring much hurt to those that dote vpon them. 663
§. 3. That riches hurt those who immoderatly desire them, by drawing them into all sinne. 664
§. 4. That voluptuous pleasures hurt those who affect them, by being occasions of sin, and in themselues sinfull. 666
§. 5. 6. That worldly things withdraw our hearts from God. 669
§. 7. Preseruations against the f • rmer sinne. 674
§. 8. That worldly things immoderately loued are the causes of idolatrie. 675
§. 9. That ambitious, couetous, & voluptuous mē are idolaters. 677

CHAP. XXXI. That worldly things make men forgetfull of God, vnthankefull, proud, contemptuous, slothfull and negligent in the du • ies of Gods seruice.
§. 1. That worldly abundance maketh men forgetful of God. 679
§. 2. That worldly things abounding make me vnthankefull towards God. 681
§. 3. 4. That worldly abundance is the cause of pride against God. 684.
§. 5▪ That worldly things causing pride are also the causes of d • struction. 688
§. 6. That worldly things bring with them contempt of God. 690
§. 7. That worldly things bring contempt of spirituall grace, and heauenly glorie. 691
§. 8. 9. That worldly things immoderately loued make men slothfull in the duties of Gods seruice. 694

CHAP. XXXII. That worldly things immoderately loued are the causes of many euils in respect of our neighbours, as of iniustice, wrongs, pride, and insolencie.
§. 1. That worldly things immoderately loued are the causes of iniustice. 700
§. 2. That worldly things thrust men on to the committing of outragious wrongs. 704
§. 3. That worldly things procure enuie and malice. 707
§. 4. 5. That worldly things make men proud and insolent towards their neighbours. 708

CHAP. XXXIII. Of the ciuill euils which worldly things immoderately loued bring to their owners.
§. 1. That abundance of worldly things effeminate and soften the heart and mind. 713
§. 2. 3. That the fruition of worldly things make men to stand in neede of many things. 716
§. 4. to §. 11. That worldly things, and particularly honors, riches, and pleasures, bring them who immoderately loue them, into a grieuous seruitude. 721
§. 11. That abundance of worldly things brings enuie and hatred to their owners. 736
§. 12. That worldly things are the cause of enmity and discord. 740
§. 13. to §. 16. That worldly things, and particularly honours, riches, and pleasures, expose their owners to innumerable dangers. 743

CHAP. XXXIIII. Of the manifold spirituall euils which worldly things bring to those that set their hearts vpon them.
§. 1. That worldly things immoderately loued do choake the seede of Gods word. 750
§. 2. That abundance of worldly things impouerisheth vs in Gods spirituall graces. 752
§. 3. That earthly abundance doth infatuate the vnderstanding. 754
§. 4. That honours, riches, and pleasures, make men blind in finding the way to heauen. 758
§. 5. That worldly abundance makes men so ignorant they cannot know themselues. 762
§. 6. That worldly abundance maketh men ignorant of their friends. 763
§. 7. That honours, riches, and pleasures, make men able to discern friends from flatterers. 764
§. 8. That earthly abundance causeth securitie. 767
§. 9. That worldly abundance bringeth impenitencie and hardnesse of heart. 769
§. 10. That the immoderate loue of worldly things, takes away all true loue from our selues. 772
§. 11. That earthly abundance aggrauateth their sinnes that haue it. 774
§. 12. to §. 16. That worldly things, & particularly, honours, riches, and pleasures expose men to many tentations. 775
§. 15. That they expose men to Gods wrath and heauy iudgements. 783.

CHAP. XXXV. Of the euerlasting euils which worldly things immoderately loued do bring to those who haue them.
§. 1. That they hinder men from attaining the ioyes of Gods kingdome. 786
§ 2. The reasons why we cannot greatly loue both earthly and heauenly things. 788
§ 3. That the Lord will not giue the heauenly ioyes to them who more esteeme of earthly trifles. 791
§. 4. 5. 6. That worldly honours, riches, and pleasures, hinder those who set their hearts on them, from attaining heauenly glory. 792.
§. 7. 8. That the more we abound with worldly things, the greater shall be our reckoning at the day of iudgement. 800
§. 9. That worldly things immoderately loued increase their condemnation, who thus abuse them. 804
§. 10. A disswasion from the loue of the world vpon the former consideration. 806

div.head: The contents of the third Booke.

list.item:
CHAP. I. That we should not set our hearts on the world and worldly things, because we are but pilgrims and strangers on earth.
§. 1. That all the faithfull from time to time haue acknowledged themselues pilgrims and strangers. 809
§. 2. That this should weane our hearts from the world, because we liue as strangers in it. 811
§. 3. That the world is to be vsed as a passage, and not as a place of habitation. 813
§. 4. That we should not set our hearts and affections on the world, because it is the place of our warfare. 816

CHAP. II. That we should contemne the world and all worldly vanities, in regard that we are citizens of heauen and heires of better hopes.
§. 1. That we might easily contemne earthly things, if we would meditate on our heauenly priuiledges, and ioyes. 818
§. 2. That the loue of the world may well fit an ignorant worldling, but ill beseemeth a Christian who hath assurance of future happinesse. 820
§. 3. That it is seruile basenesse for a Christian who is the child of God and heire of heauen to set his heart on worldly things. 822.
§. 4. That earthly honours, riches, and pleasures, are base and of no worth, in comparison of the treasures, glory, and ioyes of heauen. 825
§. 5. That they who loue the world make a forfeiture of their heauenly hopes. 827
§. 6. That all the faithfull haue from time to time contemned the world. 828

CHAP. III. Of the ioyes of heauen, that they are ineffable and inconceiuable, and of the names and titles which in the Scriptures are giuen vnto them.
§. 1. That Christians are much to preferre heauen before earth, in regard that it is their owne countrey. 831
§. 2. That it is impossible to describe the ioyes of heauen in any perfection. 833
§. 3. What the ioyes of heauen are, and of the names, and titles, which in the holy Scriptures are giuen vnto them. 837

CHAP. IIII. Of the happinesse of the soule in the ioyes of heauen, and wherein it consisteth.
§. 1. That all defects and wants in the soule shall be perfectly supplied. 840
§. 2. That the soule shall be freed from all corruption, and first, the vnderstanding from ignorance and curiositie. 842
§. 3. That our wils shall be freed from their peruersenesse, and be made conformable to the will of God. 843
§. 4. That our memories and consciences shall haue in them no imperfection or corruption. 846
§. 5. Of the excellent faculties and qualities wherewith our soules shall be beautified and adorned. 848

CHAP. V. Of the speciall happinesse and felicitie of our bodies in the kingdome of heauen.
§. 1. That we shall be freed from all bodily wants and greeuances, as hunger and thirst. 849
§. 2. Of other worldly wants from which our bodies shall be freed. 851.
§. 3. Of the manifold euils from which our bodies shall be deliuered. 852
§. 4. Of the good things which shall be communicated to our bodies. And first spirituall qualities. 853
§. 5. Of some spirituall qualities wherewith our bodies shall be adorned. 856
§. 6. That our bodies shall be indued with great strength, and freed from suffering any hurt. 858
§. 7. That our bodies shall be beautifull and of a comely stature and proportion. 859
§. 8. That our bodies shall be shining and glorious. 860

CHAP. VI. Of the felicitie and blessednes of the whole man bodie and soule, consisting in freedome from all euil, and in the fruition of all good.
§. 1. That we shall no more be molested with our turbulent affections. 863
§. 2. That we shall be freed from all impotencie and sinne. 865
§. 3. That in our heauenly happinesse we shall be freed from al externall euils, as painfull labour, wicked companie, and the assaults of all enemies. 866
§. 4. Reasons to prooue that the ioyes of heauen must needes be most excellent and blessed. 868

CHAP. VII. That in heauen we shall abound with all happines both in respect of our persons and estates. And that there are degrees of happinesse.
§. 1. That the image of God shall be perfectly repaired in vs. 872
§. 2. That the ioyes of heauen shall fill vs without glutting, and satiate vs without loathing. 873
§. 3. That these ioyes shall be most excellent in regard of the things about vs. 875
§. 4. That there are diuers degrees of glorie and happinesse in the kingdome of heauen: the which is first prooued by testimonies
of Scripture. 877
§. 5. Diuers reasons to prooue that there are diuers degrees of glorie. 879

CHAP. VIII. That heauen is a place most glorious: and of our blessed societie with the Saints, Angels, and our Sauiour Christ.
§. 1. That the heauen of heauens shall be the place of our happinesse, which is most beautifull and glorious. 883
§. 2. Of the great felicitie which wee shall haue in the societie of the Saints and Angels. 886
§. 3. Whether we shall in heauen know one another. 887
§. 4. That it shall be a great part of our heauenly happinesse to enioy the company of our Sauiour Christ. 889

CHAP. IX. Of the fruition of God, and of those vnspeakeable ioyes which will arise from it.
§. 1. That as the Lord is the author, so also the chiefe matter of our heauenly ioyes. 892
§. 2. That all ioy and happinesse accompanieth our fruition of God, as being the perfection and accomplishment of them all. 893
§. 3. That the fruition of God must needs be the perfection of our ioy, seeing all goodnesse, beautie and excellencie, is contained and vnited in him. 895
§. 4. That all the heauenly ioyes, without the fruition of God, could not make vs perfectly happie. 899

CHAP. X. Of the vision and sight of God, and of that communion which we shall haue with him.
§. 1. Wherein the vision of God chiefly consisteth, and that it is not a darke sight, as in this life, but a cleere knowledge of him. 900
§. 2. That our vision of God shall be spirituall, and how far forth
we may be said to see him with our bodily eyes: and that in him wee shall haue the knowledge of all diuine mysteries. 903
§. 3. Of that communion which wee shall haue with God in the kingdome of heauen. 906
§. 4. That our communion with God shall be much more excellent and perfect then it is in this life. 908
§. 5. Of the excellent fruits which will accompanie our communion with God: and namely, that he will be vnto vs all in all. 909

CHAP. XI. Of our perfect loue of God; our vnwearied delight in praising him; our perpetuall Sabbath; continuall ioy and reioycing in the fruition of God: and of the eternitie of all this our happines.
§. 1. That we shall most perfectly loue God; and be most happie in this our loue. 912
§. 2. That all our delight shall be to sing continually the praises of God. 915
§. 3. That we shall keepe an eternall Sabbath vnto God. 917
§. 4. That in our heauenly happines we shal haue all ioy, comfort, peace, and reioycing in God. 918
§. 5. That the ioyes of heauen shall be eternal & euerlasting. 921

CHAP. XII. Of the vses of the former doctrine concerning the ioyes of heauen.
§. 1. That we should spend our time rather in getting assurance of these heauenly ioyes, then in curious inquiring after them. 923
§. 2. That the difficultie in obtaining the ioyes of heauen should not discourage vs, but make vs more couragious in taking paines. 925
§. 3. Of the meanes whereby we may be assured to attaine vnto our heauenly ioyes. 927
§. 4. The conclusion of the booke, enforcing, from that which hath been said, the contempt of the world. 930

1. In their owne nature, §. 3. to 6.
2. Vnto vs, when they are well vsed. §. 6. to 10.
Euil when they are abused, & thus men abuse them, when they make them their idols, by preferring them in their iudgements, affections and practise, before spirituall graces & heauenly ioyes, in cōparison whereof, they are to be contemned, vnto which cōtempt ye following treatise perswadeth, Chap. 6. where is propoūded,
1. The signs of this worldlie idolatry, & carnal loue wherby we may know whether we be infected with this disease Chap. 7.
2. Remedies. See C.
C. Remedies to cure vs of it, where of ye argumēts which persuade to the contēpt of the world, which tend to shewe that worldlie things are not to be esteemed and loued, in comparison of spirituall and heauenly: neither
In themselues:
First, because they bring not vnto vs anie true or certain good, because they are not
In their owne nature of anie great goodnes, though wee should obtain thē, and yt because they are
Vaine, and of no excellencie, from whence it followeth, that they doe not satisfie those that haue them: Chap. 8. to 20.
Vnprofitable, and mixt with manie miseries: Chap. 20. to 26.
Nor yet haue in thē any certaintie in respect either of our
Getting thē: Chap. 26.
Keeping thē: C. 27. to 30.
Secondly, because through our corruptiō they are causes of much hurt, being occasiōs and prouocations vnto all sinne, both against
God. Chap. 30. 31.
Our neighbour. Chap. 32.
Our selues as they deriue vnto vs manie euils, and that both
Temporal, which are either
Ciuill, and meerelie humane: Chap. 33.
Spirituall: Cap. 34.
Eternall: Chap. 35.
Not in respect of vs, because we are
Pilgrimes on earth: Lib. 3. Chap. 1.
Citizens of heauen, and heires of those eternall ioyes and happinesse which infinitely exceed all worldly things. Chap. 2. 3. &c.

div.head: THE FIRST BOOKE OF THE SECOND PART OF THE Christian Warrefare, containing diuers arguments, whereby wee may be armed against the tentations of prosperitie, and perswaded to contemne worldly vanities, in comparison of Gods spirituall graces and heauenly ioyes.
CHAP. I.
Of the world, the second enemie of our saluation, and what it is.
div.p:
THere is none shall be thought fit to§. Sect. 1. That there is none crowned, but he that dotle ouercome. Apoc. 3. 21. raigne with Iesus Christ in the kingdom of heauen, but those who haue bin conquerors here on earth; not of some small countrey or petite kingdome, for that great glorie shal neuer be the crowne of so meane a victorie; nor (like Alexander) of the greatest part of the earths knowne territories; for so a man may attaine to the height of this glorie, and yet remaine a slaue to his owne passions and ambitious lusts, and be a vassall after his victorie to that which he seemeth to haue ouercome. But he who will raigne with Christ, must conquer the whole world, not with the sword and arme of flesh, but1. Ioh. 5. 4. with the spirit of God, and the shield of faith, whereby hee repelleth all the tentations thereof; both the charming allurements whereby hee might be infeebled, and the fierie darts of affliction and persecution, whereby hee might bee
discouraged; neither so admiring the one, nor regarding the other, as that he should suffer them to hinder him in his way to his heauenly countrie. Yea hee must together with the world ouercome the prince of the world, and all the power of hell; and which is a victorie of greatest difficultie, he hee must ouercome himselfe, and his owne corruptions; which conquest whosoeuer obtaineth, hee putteth to flight these forraine forces at the first onset: whereas contrariwise it is in vaine to haue warres abroad, if in stead of peace and subiection there be nothing but treason, discord, and rebellion at home; these inbred enemies being alwaies readie to betray and lose, that which is recouered and wonne with great paine and difficultie, and to yeeld into the enemies power in a day, that which hath been got with a yeeres labour.

Concerning the meanes of resisting and ouercomming§. Sect. 2. That the world is sometime takē in good part, and so to be loued as a friend. our first and chiefe enemie Satan, I haue alreadie intreated in the first part of my Christian Warfare: And now it remaineth, that being assisted with the same spirit, wee encounter also the world, which is the second enemie of our saluation, and teach the weake Christian how he may so manage his spirituall weapons, as that he may be assured of a triumphant victorie. But lest whilest we fight against our enemie, wee should bend our strength against those that bee our friends, because they are intitled by the same name, let vs learne to distinguish the one from the other, and consider in what sense we are here to take the world, which is a word of ambiguous signification, and how it is to bee imbraced as a friend, and how to be auoided or withstood as a mortal enemie. To this purpose wee are to know, that the world in the Scriptures is sometimes taken in a good, and sometime in anAct. 17. 24. euill sense. In the former it sometime signifieth the whole vniuerse and goodly frame of heauen and earth, and so it is an excellent creature of Gods making, approoued as goodGen. 1. 3 • . by his owne testimonie, whereby the glorie, wisedome and power of the mightie Creator is manifested and declared, according to that of the Psalmist: The heauens declare the Psal. 19. 1. glorie of God, and the firmament sheweth the worke of his hands.
Sometime it signifieth the whole earth and sea, which is appointed of God to bee the place of habitation for his creatures; in both which senses it is taken, Ioh. 1. 10. He was in Ioh. 1. 10. the world, and the world was made by him: and in this signification also the world is good, sauing onely that it is defiled with mans sinne, as being the stage whereon hee acteth all his wickednesse. To this purpose one saith, that the world is 1. Ioh. 5. 19. Mundus in maligno positus, non quòd mundus ipse sit malus; sed quòd mala in mundo fiant ab hominibus, &c. Hieron. in 1. ad Gallat. said to lie wholly in euill, not because it selfe is euill, but because euils are committed in it by men: euen as the woods are infamed when they harbour theeues, and as wee hate the sword wherewith mans blood hath bin shed, and the cup in which poyson hath been tempered, not because of any faultinesse that is in them, but because of their wickednesse who haue abused them vnto euill. Sometime the world is taken for all mankind that liueth in the world, both good and bad, beleeuer and infidell; and in this sense the Apostle saith, that by one man sinne entred into the world, that is, into all mankinde,Rom. 5. 12. who were corrupted in Adam as sinning in his loynes. Neither are we to hate and fight against the world, being vnderstood in this generall signification, lest wee should be found (like that currish Timon) haters of humane societie, and enemies of our owne nature. Finally, the world sometime signifieth the faithfull onely; not because they are of the world; for being in the world, Christ hath chosen them out of the world; but because the world was created, and is continually preserued for their vse and benefit, namely, that it might serue as a place of trial, where they should be fitted for Gods kingdome, and a passage through which they might trauell into their heauenly countrey, the new Ierusalem. And in this sense it is said, that God so loued the world, that he gaue his only Ioh. 3. 16. begotten sonne, that whosoeuer beleeued in him should not perish, but haue euerlasting life. And the Apostle saith, that God was 2. Cor. 5. 19. in Christ and reconciled the world vnto himselfe, not imputing their sinnes vnto them. And Christ is said, to be a propitiation or reconciliation, not for the Apostles and Disciples only, but for the sinnes of the whole world, that is, for al in the world that1. Ioh. 2. 2: shall beleeue in him. Now in this sense wee are not to fight against the world, seeing it is reconciled and at peace with
God, nor to loath that which God so dearely loueth: yea we must loue those who are of this world, as our selues, as being subiects of Christs kingdome, and fellow members of his bodie.

But this word is also taken in the Scriptures in euill part,§. Sect. 3. In what sense the vvorld is to be reputed our enemie. 2. Tim. 2. 26. and that most vsually, and so it signifieth somtime reprobate, wicked; and vnbeleeuing men, who hauing yeelded themselues ouer, as voluntarie slaues vnto Satan, for the wages of worldly vanities, willingly yeeld obedience vnto him as their prince and soueraigne, and submit themselues to be ruled by the law of sinne, imprinted by him in their corruptRom. 7. 23. natures, which is flatly opposed to the law of nature, written in the hearts of our first parents, and afterwards in the tables of stone, by the finger of God; opposing with all their malice, power and policie, against God, and the kingdome of Iesus Christ; hindring as much as in them lieth the prosperitie, encrease & propagation thereof, & hating, enuying, and persecuting those, who will not be allured by any worldly baits to renounce the seruice of Christ, and to ioyne with them in the seruice of sinne and Satan. And thus the world is taken, Ioh. 15. 19. If yee were of the world, the world would Ioh. 15. 19. loue his owne, but because ye are not of the world, but I haue chosen you out of the world, therefore the world hateth you. And 16. 20. Ye shall weepe and lament, but the world (that is, the wickedand 16. 20. of the world) shall reioyce. And this is that world, which the Apostle Iohn saith lieth wholly in wickednes, and is therefore1. Ioh. 5. 19. excluded by our Sauiour Christ from hauing any part in his prayers, or benefit by his mediation: Ioh. 17. 9. I pray for them, I pray not for the world. Now these are called theIoh. 17. 9. world, because they are the worlds citizens, which mind only worldly things, and setting their hearts and affections vpon the earth and earthly vanities, doe in comparison thereof Dicuntur improbi mundus quoniam configurati sunt huic mundo. August. contemne God and his kingdome.

Somtime by ye world are signified worldly things, which Satan and wicked men vse as meanes to draw men from the seruice of God, to the seruice of sinne; whether they be alluring baits whereby they intice vnto wickednes, as pleasures,1. Cor. 7. 31. profits and preferments; or discouragements, whereby they
seeke to disharten and hinder them in the way of godlines, as troubles, afflictions, and persecutions.

And sometime both these are ioyned together, in which sense the Apostle Paul saith, that he was crucified to the world, Gal. 6. 14. and the world to him; where by world he vnderstandeth whatsoeuer in the world, whether men or other creatures, are opposed to the kingdome of Christ, all which were as little valued by this holy Apostle, as a crucified or dead man esteemeth of the things of the liuing. And so the Apostle Iohn ioyneth them, though not in the same word, yet in the same sentence, 1. Ioh. 2. 15. Loue not the world, nor the things of the world. And thus wee will take the world in this discourse; vnderstanding thereby whatsoeuer in the world▪ either in it own enature, or through abuse, allureth vs to the seruice of sinne and Satan, or discourageth and hindreth vs in the seruice of God, and the meanes of our owne saluation; whether it be wicked men, or the creatures abused by Satan and our corruption, as occasions and motiues vnto euill. Or more briefly thus: Whatsoeuer in the world is the instrument of the dixell, to draw vs vnto sinne.

Whereby it appeareth that wee are not to oppose against,§. Sest 4. How wicked worldlings are to be hated. as our enemies, and to pursue with our hatred, wicked men in the world absolutely, or as they are men, but respectiuely as they are wicked, and hating their sinne we may, yea wee ought to loue their persons, as being the creatures of God inCum hominibus pacem habebis, bellū cum vitijs. respect of their essence, who haue in them (how wicked soeuer) some good naturall parts, and common gifts of the spirit, which precious pearles are to be valued euen when they are found in these filthie dunghils. And as our hatred ought not to be generall and absolute in respect of the obiect, so in respect of the quality it should not be deadly and malitious, but it must bee mixed and sweetned with compassion and commiseration, yea with sorrow of heart, that they are no better, and with a desire of their conuersion and amendment, that so emnitie ceasing▪ they might become worthie of our loue. Our hatred must (like our Sauiour Christs anger)Mark. 3. 5. be ioyned with holy mourning, because their hearts are so hardned in sinne; and though we are to esteeme them enemies, yet our eyes (like Dauids) must gush out with riuers of Psal. 119. 136.
waters, because they haue not kept Gods law. The like also may be said of all other creatures in the world, abused by Satan and his wicked imps, as baits to allure vs vnto sinne; which are to be contemned and loathed, not in their owne nature, but in respect of the abuse onely, as afterwards shall appeare.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of the nature and qualitie of our enemie the world.
div.p:
ANd thus haue I shewed what the world is, and as§. Sect. 1. That the world is euill and wicked in it self, yeelding obed • ence to Satan, as the prince thereof. it were haue singled our enemies out of the companie of our friends; lest our loue of these should slacken and abate our zealous courage in opposing against our mortall foes; or our hatred of those should make vs to dislike and hate our wel-deseruing friends. In the next place we will consider of the nature and qualitie of our enemie; and then shew his weapons and forces which hee vseth in this fight, that so wee may know the better how to auoid his furie, and to arme our selues against the encounter. And for the cleering of the former wee will briefly shew what the world is in it selfe, and then respectiuely what it is to vs. In it selfe, the Scripture saith of it, that it is euill, yea so euill, that Christ Iesus spared not to giue his owne most preciousGal. 1. 4. blood, to deliuer his seruants out of this spirituall Egypt: and lest wee should thinke that this euill hath but a little tainted it, or that it is corrupted but in part only, the Apostle Iohn telleth vs, that the whole world lieth in wickednes,1. Ioh 5. 19. not a little sprinkled or dipped, but sourced and sunk into a deepe and bottomlesse gulfe of sinne. The which will more manifestly appeare if wee consider that this wicked world, like a rebellious traitor, hath denied and refused to haue the Lord and great Creator of heauen and earth for his Soueraigne and King, and will not yeeld any obedience vnto his lawes and commandements, but contemneth his promises and rewards, as also his threatnings and punishments. And contrariwise hath submitted himselfe to Satan
as his prince and gouernour, yeelding obedience vnto his will, and subiecting himselfe to be ruled by the law of sinne, for the wages of worldly vanities, as pleasures, profits, and preferments. Whereof it is that in the Scriptures the diuell is called the Ioh. 12. 31. and 16. 11. Ephes. 2. 2. prince of the world, and the Ephes. 6. 12. Ephes. 2. 2. gouernour therof; not because he is indeed the ruler and gouernour of heauen and earth, to dispose of all at his pleasure (for this is Gods royall prerogatiue; whose slaue and vassall Satan is, and forced to doe his will when he most opposeth it) but because he ruleth in the children of disobedience, hauing them alwaies 2. Tim. 2. 26. readie as his deuoted bond slaues to do his will: who are called the world, because they set their hearts and affections vpon it; it being the nature of loue to transforme as much as may be the louer into the nature of the thing beloued, and so to denominate the one according to the name of the other. Yea he not only as a king ruleth their outward actions, but also in their hearts and consciences, causing them to yeeld vnto him free, willing and absolute obedience: and therefore he is also called the god of the world,2. Cor. 4. 4. who with his mists of falsehood blindeth the eyes of infidels and worldings, so as they cannot see his vglie filthines and palpable lies, nor the diuine puritie and excellencie of their Creator, and the glorious light of his truth.

And as the world yeeldeth this subiection vnto Satan as§. Sect. 2. That the world sighteth vnder Satan against God. his king and soueraigne, so also it maketh choice of him for his captaine and chiefe commander, receiuing his colours and cognizance, marching vnder his conduct, and fighting vnder his standerd with like inueterate malice, both against God himselfe, and all his Church and children. Against God the world opposeth with such deadly and implicable hatred, that it is impossible for any to 1. Ioh. 2. 15. adhere vnto the world, but hee must necessarily be diuided from God; nor Matth. 6. 24. serue it, but hee must neglect and disobey the Lord; nor Iames 4 4. loue it, but God and he must be at emnitie. Neither doth it onely oppose against the diuine nature, but also against euery person of the Deitie; it rebelleth against God the Father and Creator, by refusing to serue him as his creature, but contrariwise disobeyeth his will, and desperately reiecteth
all his commandements, yeelding voluntarie obedience to his arch-enemie the diuell; it Ioh. 1. 11. receiueth not the Sonne Iesus Christ as it Sauiour and Redeemer, but treadeth vnder foote his precious blood, and maketh but a mocke of all his sufferings, neither doth it Ioh. 14. 17. receiue the holy Ghost the sanctifier, but checketh all his motions, and scorneth all his sanctifying and sauing graces, preferring before them worldly • oyes and base vanities of no value. Needs therefore must the world be exceeding wicked, which submitteth it selfe to bee ruled and guided by that wicked one Satan; needs must it be outragiously euill, which purposely and malitiously opposeth it selfe against God the author and fountaine of all goodnesse.

And thus we see what our enemie is in himselfe: now to§. Sest. 3. That the world is a most dangerous enemie. vs he is exceeding dangerous; for he is so malitiously subtile, so treacherously cruell, and armed with such forces and power, that vnlesse the Christian man be well sitted with the spirituall armour, and mightily strengthened and defended with the spirit of God, hee is sure either to bee vanquished and ouercome, or else to receiue shamefull foyles. This danger is by one thus described: There (saith he) is the world,
Mundus ergo est vbi malitiae plurimum, vbi sapientiae modicum, &c. Bernard. where as there is much m • lic • , little wisedome, where all things are limie and catching, all things slimie and slipperie, all things couered with darknesse, and beset with snares; where soules are endangered and bodies afflicted, where all is vanitie and affliction of spirit. Another saith, that the world is pitch, which defileth those who come neere it with the least touch: It is birdlime, Dugo Philonius, in Tiliano, de scient. benè morien. fol. 28. which intangleth his admirers with sin and eternall death; it is a snare, which with his pleas • res and riches, as it were offered baits, allureth and catcheth vnwarie men, and draweth them with it into the net of destruction: and therefore impossible it seemeth to me that hee who liueth according to the lawes of the world▪ should passe away hence pure and vndefiled▪ from the filth of the world. In respect of which danger the world is fitly compared to a perillous sea, in which howsoeuer some escape shipwrack, yet none escapeth danger. For with vaine hopes as with a prosperous gale of winde, men are allured to hoyse vp the sailes of their desires, and to enter into this▪ porillous
passage and course of worldlings, but before they can arriue at the wished hauen, they encounter a thousand desperate dangers; one while they are tossed with tempestuous stormes of troubles, crosses, and vexations; sometime lifted vp with their hopes, as though they should touch the heauens; sometime deiected and cast downe with feare, as though they should bee swallowed in the gulfe and (as it were) hell of despaire; now they are in danger to dash against the rockes of violence and oppression, and soone after to split their ship vpon the sands of treacherie and falsehood: sometimes they are carried into an vncouth vastnes in hazard to lose themselues in the bywaies of error, vnlesse following the aduice of their skilfull Pilots, Gods messengers and Ministers, they suffer themselues to be guided and directed with the Card of Gods word: sometime they are driuen into the straits, where they are beset with perils, heere Scylla, there Charybdis, being readie to fall into the one, whilest with improuident care they auoid the other. Which being passed, their danger is not past; for though the storme, rocks and sands spare them, yet are they beset with ten thousand wicked fiends, which like cruell pirats are readie to rob them of all those rich wares of Gods spirituall graces, and to enchaine them in their galleys of endlesse bondage. But say they are not encountred with these rough dangers of troubles and crosses, say that they haue a faire calme of prosperitie, and a comfortable shunshine of worldly fauours; surely howsoeuer their securitie may be much more, yet their danger is not abated, yea rather it is much increased. For being thus encalmed, they haue neither power nor will to go forward to the blessed hauen of eternall happinesse, but contrariwise being bewitched with those Syrens songs of carnall-alluring pleasures, they cast themselues headlong into the gulfe of perdition, they now deuouring them which before allured them. This danger by another is thus expressed: This world (saith he) is to Christians a dangerous sea: for as the Ambros. in Rom. 8. sea being stirred with aduerse stormes doth mount aloft, and causeth a tempest to the passengers; so the world being moued with the conspiracie of wicked men, doth trouble the mindes of the
faithfull, and with such diuersitie is this effected by the enemie, that a man can hardly know what is first to bee auoided: for if higher powers cease to oppose, it exasperateth the mindes of priuate men against vs; if their rage be also appeased, it setteth all on fire by those who are of a mans owne familie; and if this also be quieted, by his art hee setteth discord betweene brethren and neere kinred, that so tempestuously beating vpon the house on euery of the foure corners, he may on one side or other cause a ruine. For which cause it is with one consent to be fled from of all Christians, &c. And this he inforceth elsewhere: Flee (saith hee) the sea of the world, and thou shalt not need to feare shipwracke, Ambros. in Luc. 4. tom. 5. &c. In the sea when as the windes rage, though all be not cast away, yet all are subiect to great danger.

But how dangerous this enemie is, it will better appeare,§. Sect. 4. That the world is a malicious enemie. if we doe consider the will and abilitie, the malice and power thereof; which if they be in an high nature and degree ioyned together, the perill must needs be out of measure perillous.

Concerning the malice of this enemie, it is exceeding great and vnreconcilable, inueterate and perpetuall. For as taking part with our arch-enemie Satan, it malitiously opposeth against God, so also against all those who professe themselues his children and seruants. And as the Libbard so hateth man, that with furious malice it will flie vpon his picture or image, so this Serpents brood the world, as it maligneth God himselfe, so also with like hate it pursueth those in whom the image of God is repaired. And as with outragious malice and deadly outrage it persecuted our head Iesus Christ, so with equall furie it rageth against all the true members of his bodie. Of this our Sauiour gaue vs warning, Ioh. 15. 18. If the world hate you, you know that it hated me before Ioh. 15. 18. 19. you. 19. If ye were of the world, the world would loue his owne; but because ye are not of the world, but I haue chosen you out of the world, therefore the world hateth you. 20. Remember the word that I said vnto you, the seruant is not greater then his master. If they haue persecuted me, they will persecute you also. And this appeareth by continuall experience euen from the beginning of the world. Caine a wicked worldling persecuteth
and murthereth his religious brother Abel, as soone as hee saw that God respected him.
