The sonnes of men with giant like furie oppresse the sonnes of God, the Sodomites maligne holy Lo • , Ismael persecuteth Isaac, Esau Iacob, the idolatrous Egyptians cruelly oppresse Israel, the people and Church of God, with more then barbarous furie, Saul pursueth Dauid, I • sabel the true Prophets, the heathenish Gentiles the Church of the Iewes, the Scribes and Pharisees, Christ and his Apostles, and the vnbeleeuing Pagans, the beleeuing Christians. In a word, there was neuer any escaped, but assoone as they haue been friends with God, they were presently accounted the worlds enemies; and no sooner doth God receiue them into fauour, but the world pursueth them with malice and hatred.

But as the world is exceeding malitious, and therefore§. Sect. 5. That the world is a subtill enemie. Luke 16. 8. willing; so also it is very powerfull, and therefore able to hurt vs, seeing neither policie nor strength is wanting vnto it; for the children of this world are wiser in their generation then the children of the light, as the wisest of men, and wisedome of God, giueth testimonie; and a thousand cunning sleights they haue to deceiue vs, and tenne thousand subtill policies to betray and circumuent vs. So that Christian wisedome which dares not exceed the bounds of simplicitie and truth, seemeth vnto them doltish sottishnes, and sillie foolishnes; and in regard of their aduantages of dissimulation, lying, and base treacherie, it were most easie for them to ouermatch and goe beyond them, did not the Lord by his infinite wisedome and power defeate their policies, and conuert the wisedome of these Ahitophels into meere foolishnes.

So also it is exceeding strong both in it owne strength,§. Sect. 6. That the world is a powerfull enemie in regard of it owne strength. and in respect of the great forces which our owne corrupt flesh doth minister vnto it. In it selfe it is so puissant, that Satan maketh choice of it as his chiefe champion to fight against vs; it is his right hand wherewith he striketh vs; it is the armorie which affoordeth vnto him all those mortall weapons wherewith hee woundeth vs; it is the treasurie which yeeldeth vnto him all that wages whereby he hireth
vs to offend God, and all those alluring baites wherewith he inticeth vs vnto sinne: neither could Satan hurt vs with his sharpe hookes of hellish tentations, vnlesse they were couered with the sweete baites of worldly vanities; he could not get vs stoope, and intangle our selues in his nets and limetwigs of sinne and wickednesse, vnlesse he vsed stales in our owne likenes, and betraied vs by the example and perswasions of men like vnto our selues. Thus he inticed Eue with a faire apple, the sons of God with the beautie of the daughters of men, Lot with the pleasures of Sodom, Achan with the wedge of gold, the chiefe of the Iewes with the glorie of the world: yea in these haires of worldly vanities his strength so mainly lieth, that when he was to vse all his policie, and imploy all his forces, to get the victorie of the sonne of God himselfe, hee maketh choice of these worldly weapons, and inticeth him to sinne by offering vnto him the baites of worldly necessaries, honours and preferments;Matth. 4. 11. with which when hee could not ouercome, hee fleeth from him as despairing of victorie. So that wee may here learne, that Satans chiefe strength consisteth in the worlds aides, and that in the conflict of tentations hee will flee, when the world cannot ouercome, as despairing of the conquest when his chiefe forces faile him.

Neither doth Satan with his owne soule hands offer vnto vs these baits and bribes to allure vs vnto sinne, but hee chuseth as his messengers and deputies those who are in our owne likenesse, and couered with the same flesh. He inticeth chast Ioseph to commit vncleannes, by the perswasions of his wanton Mistrisse; the Israelites to filthinesse, by the wicked Moabites; the people of God to Idolatrie, by the example of the cursed nations, and Salomon by his outlandish wiues. Whereby it commeth to passe that his counsailes haue more free audience, his perswasions greater authoritie, and his gifts wherewith he allureth vs to commit sinne, are lesse suspected and mistrusted. By all which it plainly appeareth that the worlds forces are not weak, seeing in them consisteth Satans chiefe strength, and that his power and policies are not securely to be contemned, seeing our arch-enemie
the diuell placeth in them his chiefe confidence for the obtaining of victorie.

But no little are these forces strengthened for our ouerthrow,§. Sect. 7. That much strength is added to the vvo • lds forces through our corruption. through the aide and helpe which our owne corrupt flesh ministreth vnto them. For as the world is Satans wildfire, wherewith he inflameth vs; so our flesh is the tinder which receiueth and nourisheth this fire, as soone as it is cast into it; and such a neere league of friendship there is betweene our flesh and worldly vanities, that Satan can be no more readie to offer, then it to receiue this wages of sin: whereof it commeth to passe, that when by the word of God, or the motion of his holy spirit, we thinke vpon these earthly vanities, that wee may learne the better to flee and contemne them, they sticke to our fingers when wee would throw them away, they catch vs when we would flee from them; and being insnared with these worldly lime-twigs; (like the sillie bird) the more wee struggle to get out, the more we are intangled and disabled. So that it fareth with vs as with the foolish louer, who fondly louing, but yet worthily disliking his ill-deseruing mistresse, groweth to a seeming resolution to forsake her companie, and armeth himselfe with many forcible arguments to strengthen him in his purpose; but at the next meeting he is so allured with her lookes, and so bewitched with the least apparance of a proffered fauour, that he doteth on her againe with more wonted fondnes. The reason hereof is, because it is as naturall for our corrupt flesh to loue the world, as for the loose youth to loue the cunning harlot, for the water to runne downe the hill, the fire to ascend vpward, or for the tender hearted mother to loue her deare bought and only babe. So that it needeth no arguments to perswade vs to imbrace his sinfull vanities, for only the sight of them is sufficient to allure vs, our own affections more violently drawing vs, then the inticing eloquence and well framed reasons of the best perswading Oratour.§. Sect 8. The power of the world shewed by the experience of former times.

But if wee would haue yet a more plaine and euen palpable demonstration of the great power and puissance of this our enemie, let vs propound the experience of former times,
and of our owne daies, and take a view of those trophies of victorie, which the world hath erected in all ages for the eternizing of his owne glorie; and you shall finde that the greatest Potentates of the earth, the great Commanders of conquering armies, they who haue most excelled in wisedome and policie, in power and fortitude, in temperance and in all other ciuill and morall vertues, haue after all their victories, bin vanquished by the world, fettered in the chaines of his vanities, tied to his triumphant chariot; offering themselues euen after they haue subdued the greatest part of the earth, to become the worlds slaues and sworne vassals, for the base and contemptible wages, either of windle honors, vncertaine riches, or carnall pleasures. Neither hath this bin the case of the worlds deuoted seruants onely, but of the stoicall contemners of the world, who hauing cast downe the gauntlet of defiance, and as it were challenged to fight with it in single combat; haue at vnawares receiued foyles, in the very time of challenge, with their owne weapons, affecting the praise of the world by their dispraises of it, and being tickled with vaine pleasure, whilest they haue declaimed against the vanitie of pleasures; and when as by the waight of their arguments they haue ouercome their epicurish aduersaries, themselues haue been ouercome with pleasure no lesse vaine and carnall, although more subtile and refined. Yea this puissant enemie hath not only conquered the heathen multitude, and ruled amongst them as an vniuersall Monarch, (for if this were all, his power were not so terrible, seeing they wanted a Captaine to guide them, spirituall eyes to direct them, and the shield of faith which might beate backe the force of the worlds furies) but not contented with his owne territories and dominions, he hath made fearefull inrodes euen into the holy land, and hath fought many fierce battels in the middest of Gods visible monarchie, vanquishing some of Gods professed seruants through their owne treacherie or cowardize, and leading them captiue to doe his will; foiling many euen of his great Worthies, through their secure negligence; and finally murthering and killing (though not ouercomming)
others, who resisted his furie and would not yeeld. In the formost ranke was Saul, whom of Gods elected and anointed king, he made his owne deuoted vassall; Absalon, whom of the sonne of a holy and religious king, he made with the baite of honour a bloodthirstie rebell, and (it is to be feared) the sonne of perdition; Demas, who of a disciple became an apostate; and Iudas, who being hired with the wages of iniquitie, of an Apostle became a diuell. In the second was iust Noah foiled with intemperance, righteous Lot defiled with filthie incest; the tenne Patriarkes, some of which were ouercome with lust, some stained with blood, and all ouerborne with pride •• d bitter enuie; holy Dauid, first defiled with lust, and then embrued with innocent blood, the feare of God for a time being beaten back with the feare of losing his credit in the world: religious Ezechias swolne with a cruell blow of vainglorie which the world gaue him, through his great conceit of his riches and treasures; a disease much more dangerous then that swelling sore, of which through the mercie of God he had recouered. And to these we might adde the strong Sampson, and the wise Salomon, whom the world ouercame by his female forces; and the Disciples themselues, enuying one anothers greatnesse, and contending for superioritie there, where the meanest inferiour is much more glorious then the earths greatest Monarch. In the last march that armie of glorious Martyrs, against whom the world raged with barbarous crueltie, and so farre preu •• led in the fight, that hee foiled, yea murthered their bodies, though hee could not hurt their soules, they being inuincible and immortall.

But leauing former ages, let vs come vnto our owne,§. Sect. 9. The power of the world shewed, by the experience of these present times. where we may obserue a world of victories, which the world hath through his force and cunning obtained, euen in these latter times, which are still fresh in our memories and daily subiect to our view. And to say nothing of the barbarous Heathen and wilde Indians, who scarce acknowledge any other master (vnlesse it bee the prince of the world) nor expect any other wages but what is paid vnto them out of the worlds exchequer; to passe by the Turkes and Saracens, the
worlds denoted vassals and sworne souldiers, waged by him to fight continually against the kingdome of Iesus Christ; and not to speake of the whole kingdom of the Romish Antichrist, whose whole religion is nothing else but a mixture of superstition, hypocrisie, and worldly policies, of purpose inuented and contriued, that they may attaine their worldly ends, and maintaine their glorie and authoritie, inrich their chests, and wallow themselues in the filthie sinke of voluptuous pleasures; euen amongst our selues who haue giuen our names to Iesus Christ, and doe make profession of his holy Gospell; how many are there, who hauing in their baptisme taken vpon them the badge of Christian profession, do make apostasie from their saith, and in the whole course of their liues shew, that they are professed worldlings, seruing this wicked master with all their thoughts, words & works, for the wages of worldly vanities; minding onely earthlie things, and being in their cogitations and hearts fast glued vnto the ground, so as they haue neuer any leisure to lift them vp in any holy and heauenly meditations; talking of nothing but of their worldly businesses and delights, and how they may compasse & atchieue their worldly designes; and all their actions aiming at this marke how they may increase or continue their riches, pleasures or preferments? How many are there (who not daring for feare of that hellish condemnation, which they heare is so terrible, to giue themselues ouer wholly to the seruice of the world) do notwithstanding vnequally share themselues betweene God and Mammon, giuing the world their hearts, yea and their bodies too, sauing that they doe an houre or two in a week, make (as it were) a tender of them to the grand Lord▪ offering vnto him the small pepper corne of their outward deuotion, for feare of forfeiting the tenure of their saluation? How many disguized hypocrites are there, who offer vnto God more seruice, but with as small deuotion, and professing religion, oftentimes with shew of zeale more then ordinarie, doe notwithstanding secretly reconcile themselues vnto the world, swearing vnto him their alleageance for the hire of earthly trifles? who offer vnto the Lord only the sacrifice
of their lips, and take vpon them the vizard of religion, that their shew of godlinesse may increase their gaine, and set forward their worldly ends; but when God and the world, religion and their pleasure, profit and preferment, are so diuided, that they cannot together be imbraced, then they vnmask themselues, cast aside the Lords liuerie; and openly professe that if they must haue but one, then the world alone shall be their Lord and master.

And all these proclaime the worlds force and power by§. Sect. 10. That the world often preuaileth with Gods seruants. their vtter ouerthrow and base slauerie. But how many are there besides who in the sinceritie of their hearts serue the Lord, and fight vnder his standerd, who feele often the force of the worlds blowes, and receiue deepe and grisly, though not mortall wounds, in this conflict? How many are there who hauing escaped out of the diuels slauerie, and had the vpper hand in many combats of tentation, after they haue put him to flight, and obtained a glorious victorie, are pursued and ouertaken by the world, which encountring and closing fast with them, either casteth them downe, or grieuously foileth them, by wounding their consciences with some knowne sinne, or maketh them to stand still, or at least exceedingly hindreth their race in the course of Christianitie? How many are there who haue lost their first loue, and are much abated in their zeale, becomming cold and negligent in the duties of Gods seruice, and in the workes of mercie and charitie towards their brethren, after that the world hath combated with them? And yet alas so secure we are, that though this enemie be much more dangerous and pernicious then Satan▪ himself, ouercomming more through his treacherous flatteries, then his grand captaine by his open violence, yet the most thinke not of it, as of a mortal foe, but as though it were a kinde friend, they impart vnto it a great share in their loue and affection, esteeming it aboue Gods spirituall graces whilest they haue it, and mourning with sorrow and bitter griefe when they are forced to part from • t. And howsoeuer they professe emnitie against the world, as being commonly reckoned for one of the enemies of our saluation, yet their quarrell is but against an idle
name: for as for the nature of the world, what it is, and the dangerous effects which it worketh, they know it not, much lesse doe they with any care furnish themselues with such spirituall weapons as might enable them to fight against it. Whereof it commeth to passe that they are vanquished by the world at vnawares, and liue in subiection to this dangerous enemie, and neuer feele the burthen of their bondage, because it is sweete and pleasing to the flesh.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Reasons to moue vs to resist and fight against our enemie the world.
div.p:
ANd thus haue I shewed the dangerousnes of this§. Sect. 1. God commandeth vs to oppose against the world. enemie, both in respect of his malice and power, by the first whereof is inferred the necessitie of the fight; for such is his malice that he will hearken vnto no peace, but if we will not ouercome him, he will surely ouercome vs; by the other carnall securitie is taken away, and wee stirred vp with all diligence to prepare our selues against the encounter; seeing wee are not to fight against a weake and contemptible enemie, but against a politike and powerfull champion, with whom few haue combatted, but either they haue been shamefully foyled, or vtterly ouerthrowne. But that we may the rather be incouraged to proclaime warre against the world, with which we are too too prone in our owne corrupt nature to be in league and amitie, let the reasons following induce vs. First, the Lord hath by speciall commandement inioyned vs to haue no amitie or correspondencie with the world and worldly vanities, but to renounce and contemne it, both in our actions, and also▪ in our hearts and affections, as being vnworthie both our labour and our loue. The former, Rom. 12. 2. Fashion not your selues like vnto this world but be ye changed by Rom. 12. 2. the renewing of your mindes. And elsewhere he willeth vs, to vse this world as though wee vsed it not, as being a false and treacherous friend, who will deceiue and betray vs when
we most trust it, because (saith he) the fashion of this world goeth away, or as the words may more fitly signifie, be cause the beautie and glorie of this world doth seduce vs, and like a false guide misleadeth in directing. The other, 1. Ioh. 2. 15. Loue 1. Ioh. 2. 15. not the world, nor the things that are in the world, &c.

The second argument may be taken from the passion of§. Sect. 2. The second reason taken from the passion of Christ. Christ: for hee shed his precious blood to cleanse vs from these worldly and wicked lusts, and victoriously triumphed ouer the world vpon his crosse on our behalfe, not that wee should yeeld our selues to the subiection thereof againe, being thus dearely redeemed from it, not that wee should still haue our hearts and affections fast nailed to the earth, and glued as it were vnto worldly vanities, but that wee should contemne and tread them vnder our feete, as being partners in his victorie, and that being risen with Christ, in glorious triumph ouer them, we should seeke those things that Col. 3. 1. 2. are aboue, where Christ sitteth at the right hand of God, and set our affections on things that are aboue, and not on things which are on the earth. And though our abode be vpon the earth, yet our conuersation should be in heauen, from whence wee looke Phil. 3. 20. for a Sauiour euen the Lord Iesus Christ; in comparison of whose infinite worth we are with the Apostle Paul to esteem all earthly things drosse and dung, yea euen losse that wee may vers. 8. gaine him. And this argument the Apostle Peter vseth to encourage vs to fight against and forsake worldly lusts: 1. Pet. 4. 1. For as much as Christ hath suffered for vs in the flesh, arme 1. Pet. 4. 1. 2. your selues likewise with the same minde, which is; that hee which hath suffered in the flesh, hath ceased from sinne. 2. That hee hence forward should liue (as much time as remaineth in the flesh) not after the lusts of men, but after the will of God. 3. For it is sufficient for vs that wee haue spent the time past of the life after the lust of the Gentiles, walking in wantonnes, lusts, drunkennes, in gluttonie, drinkings▪ and in abominable idolatries, &c. amongst which one of the most hamous and commonest is, to set vp the world as an idoll in our hearts, which should bee the temple of the holy Ghost.

The third argument is taken from vnauoidable necessitie:§. Sect. 3. The third reason taken from necessitie of this fight, seeing the friends of the world are enemies to God. for first it is necessarie that we fight against the world; or else
we shall fight against God, there being opposition between them without meane, and therefore no neutralitie admitted, but whosoeuer ioyneth not with God, is on the worlds part, whosoeuer loueth the world hateth God, and who so loueth God hateth the world. This is plaine, Iam. 4. 4. Know you not that the amitie of the world is emnitie with God? Whosoeuer Iames 4. 4. therefore will be a friend of the world, maketh himselfe the enemie of God. And the Apostle Iohn vseth it as an argument to disswade vs from the loue of the world, because wee cannot loue the world and God too. If any man (saith hee) loue the 1. Ioh. 2. 15. world, the loue of the father is not in him. For as soone as the loue of God is shed abrode in our hearts, it moueth vs to loue him againe, who hath thus dearely loued vs, and louing him to loue his friends also, & to hate his enemies. As soone as we are reconciled vnto God and become his seruants, we presently oppose against all those who make opposition against our Lord and master, and when as wee are made his sonnes by adoption and grace, we cannot chuse in our filiall affection, but take our fathers part, breaking off all friendship with those which are his enemies, and making warre against those who fight against him▪ To this purpose the Apostle saith, that as soone as the grace of God, that is, the doctrine ofTit. 2. 11. 12. grace and reconciliation, doth appeare, it teacheth vs to denie vngodlines, and worldly lusts, and to liue soberly; and righteously and godly in this present world. So that the loue of the world and the loue of God, peace with the world, and peace with God, will not stand together. And therfore the Apostle Paul saith, that Demas forsooke him, and together with him the2. Tim. 4. 10. seruice of God, when he began to imbrace the world. And our Sauiour telleth vs plainly, that no man can serue these two masters, being so opposed one against the other, for either he shall hate the one, and loue the other, or else he shall leane to the Matth. 6. 24. one, and despise the other: yee cannot (saith he) serue God and mammon. As well then may we reconcile fire and water, light and darknes, righteousnes and vnrighteousnes, Christ and Belial, as God and the world: and therefore when Iehosaph •• , though otherwise a godly King, would haue bin friends to both, the Lord sendeth Iehu the Prophet vnto him with
an ambassage of sharpe reproofe. Wouldest thou (said he) help the wicked, and loue them that hate the Lord? therefore for this thing, the wrath of the Lord is vpon thee. 2. Chro. 19. 2.2. Chron. 19. 2. §. Sect. 4. Vnlesse vve renounce the world, we are not of the number of the faithfull.

Secondly, of necessitie wee must renounce the world, and flying out of this spirituall Babylon adioyne our selues vnto the kingdome of Iesus Christ, or else we cannot be reckoned in the number of the faithfull, nor haue any part in their priuiledges. Wee must bee sheepe of Christs flocke seuered from the goates, or else we shall haue no share in the benefit of his death and intercession. For Christ hath chosen his faithfull ones out of the world, and hath disfranchised them of all the carnall liberties thereof, as soone as he made them partakers of that glorious libertie of being the sonnes of God. So hee saith, that because the faithfull are not of the Ioh. 15. 19. world, but he had chosen them out of the world, therefore the world hateth them. And more plainly elsewhere: They (saithIoh. 17. 16. he) are not of the world, as I am not of the world. And as those who adhere to the world cannot be reckoned in the number of the faithfull, so can they haue no interest in the death and mediation of Christ, or in any other benefits which are appropriated vnto them, as their peculiar priuileges. For Christ laid downe his life for his owne sheepe, and not for goatesIoh. 10. 15. Ioh. 15. 13. and wolues, he best • wed his life for his friends alone, and therefore not for worldlings, who are strangers, or rather professed enemies; hee gaue himselfe for his Church, and consequentlyEph. 5. 25. those who are seuered from the communion of Saints, and adhere to the world, which is the synagogue of Satan, haue no interest in this gift▪ And as they haue no part in his death, so neither any benefit in his intercession; for himselfe hath excluded them in that diuine prayer which he made to his father: I pray (saith he) for them, I pray not Ioh▪ 17. for the world, but for them which thou hast giuen mee. Heere therefore wee are put to our choice; either wee must▪ renounce the world, or renounce our part in Christ; we must with the blessed Apostle be crucified and die to the world,Gal. 6. 14. or else wee can haue no benefit in the death of Christ; wee must cease to be citizens of the world, and disclaime our interest in his sinful vanities, or we shall haue no part in Christs
mediation and intercession. Take then which you will, for both you cannot haue; and thrice blessed is he that chuseth the better part, for that shall neuer be taken from him.

Thirdly, of necessitie wee must vndertake this combat against§. Se • t. 5. Christian religion requireth that we should renounce the vvorld. the world and worldly vanities, because our religion in a great part doth consist in abandoning of them, whereof it is that at our first entrance into the course of Christianitie, when as in our baptisme we take vpon vs the name of Christ, wee renounce the world with all the vaine pompe and glorious vanities thereof, and professe that we will couragiously fight against them vnder the standerd of Iesus Christ. As soone therefore as wee cease this fight, and become friends with the world, setting our hearts and affections more vpon worldly vanities then vpon spirituall things, we steale out of Christs campe like runnagate souldiers, we cast aside Christs liuerie, we slide back from our religion in truth, whatsoeuer wee professe in words, and ioyning in league with Christs enemie wee traiterously make warre against him. To this purpose the Apostle Iames saith, that pure religion and vndefiled Iames 1. 27. before God, euen the Father, is this, to visit the fatherlesse and vidowes in their aduersitie, and to keepe a mans selfe vnspotted of the world. The which we cannot doe vnlesse we abandon and renounce it; for this pestiferous aire infecteth all that liue in it, and as impossible it is to haue familiar conuersation with this wanton harlot, and not to bee inueigled in her bands, and defiled with her vncleannes, as to liue in a mill and to keepe our selues cleane from meale and dust.

Fourthly, the necessitie of leauing the world and renouncing§. Sect. 6. The vvay of the world is the way of sinne. carnall vanities hereby appeareth, in that whilest we continue in the way of the world, wee are in the way of sin, and the way of sinne is the way of death and destruction. So the Apostle saith, that Christ hath quickned vs that were dead Ephes. 2. 1. 2. in trespasses and sinnes, wherein in time past we walked according to the course of the world▪ and after the prince that ruleth in the aire, euen the spirit that now worketh in the children of disobedience, &c. And the Apostle Iohn saith, that the whole world 1. Ioh. 5. 19. lieth in wickednesse. If therefore if wee will not breake off companie with the world, wee walke with it in the way of
sinne and death. If wee make the world our bedfellow, well may our corrupt flesh thinke our bed soft as downe, and sweete as roses, and so cause vs to sleepe a dead sleepe in carnall securitie; yet in truth like filthie swine wee wallow in the sinke and puddle of sinne and wickednesse; and if euer wee awake out of this spirituall lethargie, we shall see our estate most desperate and damnable, ti • l we be seuered from this companion, and cleansed from that filthinesse, wherewith hee hath defiled vs. So that wee may conclude where the holy Psalmist began, Psal. 1. 1. Blessed is the man that doth not walke in the counsell of the wicked, nor stand in the way of sinners, nor sit in the seate of scorners.

Fiftly, if wee will be the seruants and Disciples of Iesus§. Sect. 7. We must fight against the world if we will be Christs disciples. Christ, we must of necessitie make warre against the world, for it will haue no peace with vs, but as soone as it discerneth that we are chosen by him, it will pursue vs with mortall hatred; so that wee must fight against▪ it, or it will fight against vs, and so destroy vs for want of resistance; vnlesse wee can be content to renounce the seruice of our Sauiour, and yeeld our selues as slaues to the world, sinne and Satan, who will reward vs for the present with the wages of vanitie, and afterwards with the wages of death. And this argument the Apostle Peter vseth, 1. Pet. 2. 11. Dearely beloued, I 1. Pet. 2. 11. beseech you as strangers and pilgrimes, abstaine from fleshly lusts, which fight against the soule.

Sixtly, if we doe not fight against the world, but suffer our§. Sect. 8. We become apostats if vve fight not against the vvorld. selues to be againe defiled with worldly lusts, after that Christ hath shed his blood to wash and cleanse vs, wee shall fall into a fearefull relapse, and make our latter end much worse then our beginning; we shall like filthie dogges returne to our vomit, and with the sow that was washed, to our wallowing in the mire. And this the Apostle Peter plainly affirmeth, 2. Pet. 2. 20. For if they (saith he) after they haue 2. Pet. 2. 20. 21. escaped from the filthinesse of the world, through the knowledge of the Lord, and of the Sauiour Iesus Christ, are yet tangled therein againe, and ouercome, the latter is worse with them then the beginning. 22. For it had been better for them, not to haue knowne the way of righteousnesse, then after they haue knowne
it, to turne from the holie commandement giuen vnto them, &c.

The fourth argument to incourage vs to this fight against§. Sect. 9. The fourth reason taken from our assured hope of victorie. the world and worldly vanities, is our assured hope of obtaining victorie: for howsoeuer (as hath been shewed) the world is a malitious, politike, and puissant enemie, and we (being considered in our selues) are altogether vnable to make resistance, seeing our nature is weake, and our forces fraile, and which is worst of all, that weake strength we haue being diuided, and ciuill warres at home, our selues contending against our selues, and the flesh which is our greater and stronger part, rebelling and lusting against the spirit, and traiterously ioyning with the world to worke our ouerthrow: yet being by a liuely faith knit vnto Christ, assisted with his spirit, and armed at all points with the spirituall armour of his sanctifying and sauing graces, there is no doubt of getting victorie. For we doe fight against but a conquered enemie, whom Christ alreadie hath subdued, not onely for himselfe, but also for all vs that are true members of his bodie. And this argument of incouragement our Sauiour vseth, Ioh. 16. 33. In the world (saith he) ye shall haue affliction, Ioh. 16. 33. but be of good comfort I haue ouercome the world. Yea this conquest Christ obtained at an high rate, for he gaue his life to free vs from the worlds thraldom, as the Apostle witnesseth, Gal. 1. 4. which gaue himselfe for our sinnes, that he might deliuer Gal. 1. 4. vs from this present euill world. And therefore hauing so dearely bought this victorie, and our freedome, he will not suffer his paines to be spent in vaine, but hauing all power in heauen and earth committed vnto him, he will giue vs also strength to ouercome, if we will lay hold on Christ by faith, professe our selues his souldiers and seruants, and valiantly fight vnder his standerd, against these spirituall enemies of our saluation. And this comfort and incouragement the Apostle Iohn giueth vs: All (saith he) that is borne of God ouercommeth the world, and this is the victorie that ouercommeth the world, euen our faith. Who is it that ouercommeth the world, but he that beleeueth that Iesus is the sonne of God? 1. Ioh. 5.1. Ioh. 5. 4. 5. vers. 4, 5.

The last argument to moue vs, is the great reward which§. Sect. 10. The last reason taken from our reward which accompanieth victorie. 2. Tim. 4. 8. Apoc. 3. 21. accompanieth this victorie, for hauing fought this good fight, we may assuredly expect, with the blessed Apostle, a crowne of righteousnesse; and to raigne with Christ in glorie, as himselfe hath promised: Apoc. 3. 21. To him (saith he) that ouercommeth, will I grant to sit with me in my throne, euen as I ouercame, and sit with my father in his throne. Yea we shall enioy all blessednesse and happinesse, for we shall haue the fruition of God himselfe, and together with him enioy all good things. For so he promiseth, Apoc. 21. 7. He that ouercommeth shall inherit all things, and I will be his God, and he shall be my sonne. What therefore though in this conflict we lose, or be driuen to forsake houses, or brethren, or sisters, or father, or mother, Matth. 19. 29. or wife, or children or lands, for Christs names sake, seeing wee shall haue the worth of these benefits redoubled vnto vs a hundred fold, euen in this life in Gods spirituall graces, and in the world to come shall inherit euerlasting life? What if we be driuen for a moment of time, to beare the easie burthen of some light affliction, if wee shall afterwards be rewarded2. Cor. 4. 17. with a farre most excellent and an eternall waight of glorie? Yea what though in this fight wee lose a temporarie life, if we may be rewarded with life eternall, and thatLuke 9. 24. glorie and happinesse which doth accompanie it?

And these are the reasons which may incourage all Christians§. Sect. 11. How we are said to fight against the world, and to obtaine victorie. to encounter this spirituall enemie of our saluation: now if we would know how wee may thus fight against the world, and be assured also that wee haue obtained victorie; we are said thus to combat with it, when we resist and ouercome all worldly tentations, which moue or draw vs vnto sinne; and more especially, when being allured to commit sinne, or to neglect any dutie which God requireth, by the worldly baites of riches, pleasures, and preferments, wee doe renounce these worldly lusts, and contemne these base offers, preferring farre before them our obedience towards God, and the reward thereof, his loue and fauour in this life, with all other his spirituall gifts and graces, and the eternall ioyes of his kingdome, reserued for vs in the life to come. And contrariwise when being discouraged in our course of
Christianitie, or vrged and enforced to commit any sinne, with crosses, troubles, afflictions and persecutions which the world and wicked worldlings raise against vs, wee arme our selues with patience to beare the brunt of the worlds furie, accounting sinne the greatest euill, and the burthen of Gods wrath due vnto it the greatest torment; and therefore chuse rather to endure any extremitie, yea to haue our liues taken away, with most exquisite tortures, then wee will be forced to make shipwrack of a good conscience, or incurre the displeasure of our most gratious God by committing any sinne.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
Of the manner of the worlds fight, and how he assaulteth vs, on the one side with prosperitie, and on the other side with aduersitie.
div.p: THus hauing discouered the worlds forces, and§. Sect. 1. With vvhat weapons the world assaulteth vs. incouraged euerie Christian souldier to the fight: let vs in the next place consider of the chiefe and most preuailing weapons which hee vseth to ouerthrow vs, and obtaine the victorie, and the maner of his warring with vs in the day of battell. His weapons and munition are of two sorts, either his allurements and baits, wherewith hee inticeth vs vnto sinne, reserued against the day of battell in the storehouse of prosperitie; or his weapons of affliction and persecution, whereby hee seeketh to daunt and discourage vs in our Christian march, & cause vs to make a stand, or retire back, and shamefully flee away, which he storeth vp in the armorie of aduersitie. The former may bee called his bullets and gunshot, which kill at vnawares, we not seeing or knowing who hurt vs: the other his swords and speares, more terrible in • ight, but lesse dangerous in their vse, because being plainly subiect to our view, wee may better defend our selues against them, and repell their force, either by warding, or declining.

The manner of his warring with vs, is either by perswading§. Sect. 2.
in a cunning and deceitfull parley, or by encountring The manner how the world fighteth with vs. 2 King. 18. 31. 32. vs with all his forces: in the one playing the dangerous traitor, in the other an open enemie. In the former like a subtile Rabshakeh, in his master Satans name, hee offereth vnto vs peace, and maketh many faire promises of great plentie and securitie vnder his protection, if wee will be content to lay aside our armes, and subiect our selues as slaues and vassals vnto his gouernment. And lest these allurements might not preuaile, he mixeth threatnings, and boasteth of his great strength, whereby hee is able to ouercome by force, if fairer meanes will not perswade a yeelding; blasphemously disabling the power of our mightie God, the Lord of hosts, as though he were not able so wel to prouide for vs, or to shield and defend vs against his furie. But if his bewitching eloquence will not moue vs, then hee marcheth against vs with all his forces, and imployeth all his strength and policie to worke our ouerthrow; sometimes hiding the troupes of his temptations in the ambushments of worldly vanities, that is, either behind the high hils of ambitious honours, or in the low delightfull medowes of voluptuous pleasures, or else in the pricking thickets of thornie riches, that so he may assault vs in our greatest securitie, and obtaine an easie victorie; and sometimes hee draweth out his forces in open view, and marcheth against vs with a terrible armie of afflictions and persecutions, presuming to ouercome vs through force and violence. And this is the manner of the worlds fight, wherein as you see hee leaueth no meanes vnassaied to worke his owne will, and our ouerthrow: forbeing resolued to catch and make a pray of vs, like a cunning fisher man, he either allures vs to swallow the hookes of sin with the baits of worldly vanities; or if he cannot so preuaile, he assaieth to driue vs by force into his nets of perdition, beating vs forward with the slaues of trouble and affliction; or like a dangerous theefe intending to spoile vs of the rich treasures of Gods graces, either he cheateth and deceiueth vs, by perswading vs to exchange with him these precious iewels, for some counterfeite trifles and base worldly vanities; or if his cosening cunning preuaile not, like a strong
theefe by the high way side, hee will cruelly assault vs, and endeuour to •• bbe vs by force and violence. So that it behoueth the Christian man alwaies carefully to watch and to stand vpon his guard, both in the time of prosperitie and aduersitie, that he be not either allured with the one, or oppressed with the other, either inticed with worldly baits to Nec prospera vita eligenda est, & sola aduersa deuitāda, sed vtsaque cavenda est; illa ne corrumpat, ista ne frangat. August. enar. in Psal. 74. fall into the nets of destruction, or discouraged in his course of Christianitie, with troubles and afflictions.

And thus haue I shewed how the world on euery side assaulteth vs; on the right hand with prosperitie, on the left hand with aduersitie; before vs he setteth the bewitching baits of worldly vanities, to intice vs forward in the broad way of destruction; behinde, hee pursueth vs with terrors and feares, that so we may not dare to looke backe; and if§. Sect. 3. That prosperitie is good in it own nature. we seeme but to make a stand, he whippeth vs forward with the sharp and many stringed whip of crosses and afflictions. Now let vs more specially descend to speake of the▪ worlds tentations, and of the meanes to arme our selues against them, beginning with the tentations of prosperitie, and then afterwards descending to the tentations of aduersitie. And lest wee should vndescreetly cast away the sound with the rotten, and declaime against Gods blessings, because of the worlds abuse; let vs consider what this prosperitie is, and how we are to esteeme of it in it owne nature, and how it becommeth the worlds assistant, through his abuse and our corruption, to worke our ouerthrow. Prosperitie therefore is nothing else but a confluence or concurrence of al earthly and temporall benefits; as the fauour and friendship of men, health, wealth, peace, libertie, honour, pleasure, and the like. Now if we would know how to esteeme of it, we must consider what it is in it owne nature, and what in our vse. In it owne nature it is good, because it is the gift and blessing of God, which hee bestoweth vpon his owne seruants, as a reward of their loue and obedience. So the Psalmist saith, that Psal. 119. 165. they who loue Gods law shall haue great prosperitie, and they shall haue no hurt. And the Lord exhorteth the people of Israel Deut. 29. 9. and 6. 18. 2. King. 2. 3. to keepe the words of his couenant, that they might prosper in all that they should doe: to the same purpose are diuers
other places. The giuer therfore doth sufficiently commend the gift, and comming from him as a reward it must needes be good. Secondly, the Lord loueth and taketh Psal. 35. 27. delight in the prosperity of his seruants, as the Psalmist plainly affirmeth; and it is the good of his Saints, and not their hurt, wherewith he is so well pleased. Thirdly, prosperitie in it self is a motiue cause to make vs rēder to the Lord praises & thanksgiuing, and is the subiect matter of our Hymnes and religiousPsal. 116. 12. • 3 songs, as may plentifully appeare in the booke of Dauids Psalmes: now as it is good to praise God, so that is good for which wee praise him. Fourthly, the seruants of God haue prayed vnto him for this prosperitie, and that both for themselues, and also for the whole Church. Of the former wee haue an example: Psal. 118. 25. O Lord I pray thee saue Psal. 118. 25. now: O Lord I pray thee giue now prosperitie. Of the other: Psal. 122. 7. Peace be within thy walles, and prosperitie within Psal. 122. 7. thy palaces. Lastly, it is made a signe of Gods fauourable presence with his seruants, and thus the Lord is said to haue been with Ioseph, for whatsoeuer he did he made it to prosper. SoGen. 39. 2. 23. it is said of Dauid, that he prospered and grew, for the Lord God 2. Sam. 5. 10. of hosts was with him. And of Ezechias, that the Lord was with him, and he prospered in all things which he tooke in hand.

And thus it appeareth that prosperitie in it selfe is good:§. Sect. 4. That prosperitie in respect of our vse, is of an indifferēt nature. but being considered in our vse, it is not absolutely good, but indifferent, both in respect of the subiect and the vse; for it is good to the good, euill to the euill; good to those who well vse it, and euill in those who abuse it vnto sinne. In the former respect prosperitie is good when it is enioyed by a faithful man, who being in Christ, hath recouered that right in all Gods blessings which we lost in Adam. In the other, when it commeth vnto him by lawfull meanes, as the gift and blessing of God; and being enioyed, is sanctified vnto him by the word of God and prayer: as also when as it is moderatly loued and desired, with a willingnes to hold it, as long as God will, and wee may by lawfull meanes; and with contentednes to leaue it, when it pleaseth God to takeIob 1. 21. it from vs. Finally, it is good when as it is vsed and imployed for the aduancement of Gods glorie, who is the fountaine
and giuer of it, the benefit of the faithfull, and the furthering of our owne saluation. And if any such enioy prosperitie and thus vse it, in this manner, and to these ends, it is to bee accounted vnto them Gods singular blessing, and as a temporall pledge of eternall happinesse. But contrariwise, prosperitie is euill to the wicked and vnregenerate, who haue no right vnto Gods creatures, as also when it is vnlawfully compassed, and naughtily vsed, as when it is immoderately loued and desired, namely, aboue God, his heauenly blessings, and spirituall graces: for as one saith, it is the concupiscence
Plus concupiscentia mundi quaus substantia nocet. Bernard. in▪ Mat. 19 of the world, and not the world it selfe that hurteth vs. So also when as we so dote vpon it, that we cannot with patience thinke of leauing it, and immoderately mourne when it is taken from vs; which carefull possession and not simply the vse is condemned. To this purpose the Heathen man speaketh diuinely: A wise man (saith he) would haue these
Ait ista debere contemni; non ne habeat▪ sed ne sollicitus habeat; non a • iget illa à se, sed abeuntia securus prosequetur, &c. Senec de vita beat. cap. 21. things contemned, not that they should not be had, but that they should not be possessed with care; he will not driue them away from him, but if they be going he will follow them securely, &c. He loueth not riches, but he had rather haue them then be without them; hee receiueth them not into his heart, but into his house; neither doth he refuse them being possessed, but keepeth them, and desireth to haue more large matter or fuell ministred to exercise his vertue. Finally, prosperitie is euill to those who are thereby made more forgetfull of God, and negligent in performing the duties of his seruice, more iniurious to men, and more slack in vsing the meanes of their saluation. But of these points I shall haue occasion to speake more hereafter when I intreate of the chiefe parts of this prosperitie.

And thus wee are to distinguish betweene prosperitie it§. Sest. 5. That we are apt to abuse our prosperitie vnto sinne. selfe which is good, and the abuse thereof which is euill; in which respect alone we are to esteeme it the worlds friend and assistant, whereby he tempteth vs, and our enemie, which we must labour to ouercome: and therefore for distinction sake, let vs, if you please, in this discourse call it worldly and carnall prosperitie, because it is abused as a tentation of the world, to inflame our corrupt flesh with
concupiscence and sinne. Vnto which abuse we are naturally exceeding prone: for as fruite is vnto a childe, libertie to the licentious, cockring loue to an vndutiful sonne, a sword to a mad man, beautie to the lasciuious, and good drinke to a filthie drunkard, such is worldly prosperitie vnto vs. And hence it is that the Lord like a wise Physition (feeling our pulse, and finding that our nature inclineth vs to this pluririsie of prosperitie, whereby our braines are so intoxicated, as wee forget God and all goodnesse) doth purposely labour to preuent it, and maketh wholesome preseruatiues of admonitions to keepe vs from it, in many places of holie Scriptures, as hereafter we shall see. In the meane while we may obserue the exceeding corruption of our vile nature, which so poysoneth and infecteth Gods good gifts & blessings, that they become causes and occasions of euill: and whereas the Lord through the infinite goodnesse of his nature, bringeth good out of euill, and by afflictions, which are ill in their own nature, worketh our good euen our conuersion, sanctification & saluation, we contrariwise through the diuellish tainture of our sinne turne good into euill, and out of Gods benefits, and rich blessings, worke our owne woe, and hasten and set forward (vnlesse God preuent vs with his grace) our owne destruction and damnation.

div.head: CHAP. V.
Of the dangerousnes of worldly prosperitie.
div.p:
NOw hauing seene what this worldly prosperitie is,§. Sect. 1. That the worlds tentations on the right hand are very dangerous. and in what respect it is our enemy, namely, when it is a tentation of the world to allure vs vnto sin, (as it is vnto all those who immoderately loue and set their hearts vpon it, more then vpon heauenly and spirituall things) let vs in the next place consider of the dangerousnes of these worldly tentations which are on the right hand, that accordingly wee may prepare our selues to make resistance. The danger of worldly prosperitie is exceedingSeneca. great; for as by Hippocrates rule the height of health is the
first degree to some dangerous sicknesse; so when our worldly estate seemeth most healthie, strong, and vigorous, then is our corrupt nature prone to fall into the perillous diseases of sinne, which are attended vpon with eternall death and destruction. And therefore the wise man saith, that ease slaieth the floolish, and the prosperitie of fooles destroyeth them. WhereProu. 1. 32. by fooles hee vnderstandeth sinners and wicked men, who abuse their prosperitie, by setting their hearts vpon it, louing and trusting in it more then in God, and strengthening themselues thereby to commit all manner of sinne and wickednesse. So that worldly men enioying prosperitie, and taking all their delight and felicitie in it, are not vnfitly compared to the little infant, who sitteth at the hole of the Aspe, and plaieth with the Cockatrice, whose pastime is their ruine, and their pleasure death. Or like the childe playing with the fire; who no sooner toucheth it with his finger but is burnt, and changeth his sport into teares and crying; sauing that herein they are much more foolish then little children, for they feeling the smart doe euer after dread the fire; but these being often burned with the bright shining flames of worldly prosperitie, are not warned, nor made more warie by their owne harmes, but as being besotted in their loue, they still imbrace their ruine, and hunt after that which most hurteth • hem; like vnto the foolish flye, which is so delighted with the light of the candle, that it regardeth not the heate of the flame, but burning one legge after another, taketh no warning till he be wholly destroyed and consumed. And so doth the doting loue of these fond worldlings bereaue them not onely of all religion, but also of the vse of reason; yea it so stupifieth the senses that they are deafe to all admonition; insensible of their owne smart, and in no possibilitie of being ruled, and gouerned, ordered, or contained by any law: in which respect Chrysostome compareth them to such a man, as dwelling with a faire maid whom he fondlyChrysost. in Matth. 12. homil. 41. affecteth, is by strict order inioyned, that hee presume not to looke vpon her with lasciuious and wanton glances; a thing to him no lesse vnpleasant then impossible.

But the great danger of worldly prosperitie will more§. Sect. 2.
plainly appeare, if wee doe but consider, how farre it exceedethThat the state of prosperitie is much more dangerous then the state of aduersitie. the danger of the state opposed thereunto, aduersitie and affliction. For whereas affliction being an open enemie, terrible in appearance, and making shew at the first sight of all his forces, and sometimes of more then he hath, setting before vs shadowes, in stead of substantiall enemies, doth make vs more carefull and watchfull to prepare and arme our selues, that wee may make resistance: Prosperitie is a secret traitor, which hideth hatred and hostilitie, vnder the vizard of loue and friendship, and thereby maketh vs so retchlesse and secure, that in stead of opposition, wee are readie to receiue this serpent into our bosome, and when he incountreth vs with all his forces, so bewitched we are with the pleasing sight of this glorious enemie, that we cleere all the passages, and set wide open the gates of our soules, to giue him entertainment, voluntarily offering our selues to digge in his mines, and in most slauish manner to row in his galleys, so as we may be assured to enioy his companie. And the reason hereof is, because hee deceiueth vs with his treacherie: for at his first comming he displaieth not his bloody ensigne, but setteth vp a flagge of friendship, hee assaulteth vs not with open force and violence, nor marcheth against vs in a terrible and hostile manner, but like a subtile serpent he cunningly glideth and insinuateth himself into our companie; neither doth he as a martiall enemie strike at vs with downe right blowes, but rather like a craftie witch he besotteth vs with his pleasing charmes, and with cunning inchantments before he conquereth vs, he maketh vs willing to be ouercome. He doth incline, and not constraine, perswade, and not ouercome, or rather ouercommeth by perswading, and most forcibly constraineth by mouing and inclining. He doth not vse against vs any outward terrible forces when hee doth besiege vs, but (Sinon like) with bewitching eloquence, and counterfeit gifts, hee allureth vs to breake downe the walles of our strength, and with our own hands to make a cleere passage for our owne ouerthrow. He doth not when hee commeth to execution, vse the dreadfull sword, but rather sweete and well-tasting poysons, which
hurt with delight, and whilest they seeme to nourish, cast vs into a lethargie or dead sleepe of deepe securitie. Finally, he inflicteth on vs no griefly wounds, nor bringeth vs to our end by a foule death; but as it were tickleth vs to death with inueigling pleasures, making vs most to laugh when wee are most tormented, and in a chariot of gold, strawed with roses, he swiftly carrieth vs into hell.

Let vs therefore learne to contemne and hate the world§. Sect. 3. That we are most carefully to take heed of the world when it fawneth on vs. our wicked enemie, as well when hee fawneth as when hee frowneth, when he allureth by flatterie and deceit, as when hee constraineth by force and violence: for though hee be then more amiable in view, yet is hee no lesse malitious in truth; and because hee is then lesse suspected, hee is much more dangerous, as hauing better opportunitie to vse all his forces, and to effect all his malitious designes. Why then, alas, should wee giue eare to the worlds flatteries? why should we beleeue this dissembling Ioab who will mortally stab vs, whilest hee professeth friendship, and offereth in kindnesse to embrace and kisse vs? why should wee listen to this sweete singing Syren, seeing he bewitcheth in delighting, and maketh vs leape into the sea of destruction? why should his flattering perswasions, ioyned with crocadile teares, moue vs, seeing he either weepeth for ioy to think on his pray, or for spite because his hopes are so long deferred? why should the glorious beautie of his golden cup allure vs, seeing we know that the potion within it is full of deadly poyson, which whosoeuer drinke shall eternally perish? why should we be moued with his inticing gifts to admire his kindnes, seeing by these baites he allureth vs to swallow the hookes of sinne, and offereth these carnall toyes and earthly trifles, no lesse vaine in themselues, then momentany in their continuance, that he may cosen vs in the exchange, mouing vs to giue for them the precious iewels of Gods graces, and our heauenly patrimonie in his kingdome. To this purpose one fitly speaketh: How great things (saith he)August. enarrat. in Psal. 67. tom. 8. doth the world speake vnto thee? how great things doth it clamour behinde thee to intice thee to looke backe, that is to say, that thou maist place thy hope in things present (if at least they may be
said to be present, which are alwaies moueable and mutable) and maist turne thy minde from that which Christ hath promised, and not yet giuen (but will giue because hee is faithfull) and rest thy hopes vpon this neuer resting and perishing world? Whereof it is that God mixeth bitternes with the sweetnes of earthly felicitie, that we may seeke after another felicitie, whose sweetnes will not deceiue vs. And in another place: O world (saith he) filthie,
O munde immunde fallax & proditor, nunquid non periculosior blandus quam m • lestu • ? August. serm. de fallacia mundi, tom. 10 serm. 31. Idiota inter orthodoxogr. lib. depatient. ver • contemplatione, cap. 1.
fraudulent and trecherous; art thou not much more dangerous when thou art kinde, then when thou art troublesome? art thou not much more to be feared whilest thou allurest, then whilest thou despesest? art thou not much more odious whilest thou dissemblest loue, then when thou professest mortall hatred? To the same purpose speaketh that learned Idiote; Although (saith he) euery estate is to be feared, yet rather the prosperous estate then the afflicted, because this, whilest it rageth, informeth and teacheth vs, the other whilest it flattereth, seduceth vs; this sharp • eth a mans sight, but the other maketh him starke blinde. O my God, exceedingly art thou incensed against that sinner, vnto whom thou permittest all things to succeed according to his wish, and afterwards makest him to beare deserued punishment. Let vs therefore bee alwaies watchfull ouer our selues, but especially when the world fawneth vpon vs in the time of prosperitie, for it is more dangerous being our friend, thenAugust epist. 144. tom. 2. being our enemie, and more to be taken heede of when it inticeth vs to loue it, then when it forceth vs to contemne it; for it smileth that it may rage, it flattereth that it may betray
Arridet mundu • vt s •• iat bland • tur vt f • llat, illicit vt occidat, extollit vt deprimat. Cyprian. Hieronym. ad Heliodorum, tom. 1. pag. 3. vs, it inticeth that it may kill vs, and exalteth that it may ouerthrow vs. Although therfore this dangerous sea looketh smooth, and as it were smiling vpon thee, like a standing water, and hath scarce a wrinkle raised on it by the winde; yet this large plaine hath great hils, the danger is within included, within the enemie lurketh. Weigh therefore your ankers, hoise vp your sailes, let the crosse be fastned to the saile-yard, for this calme will proue a tempest.

But how farre the state of prosperitie is more dangerous§. Sect 4. The f • uits of affl • ction much better then of prosperitie. and pernicious then the state of aduersitie, it may hereby more cleerely appeare; in that whereas affliction commonly maketh vs carefull of our waies, increaseth Gods spirituall
graces, causeth vs to be more respectiue of our dutie, and either preuenteth or mortifieth our sinnes: Prosperitie most vsually worketh in vs the contrarie effects; for it makes vs proud, insolent, forgetfull of God, and of all duties which we owe vnto him, it choketh and extinguisheth, or at least cooleth and abateth the heate and vigour of all grace and vertue in vs; and as the Iuie whilest it embraceth the oake, sucketh the sap from the roote, and in time maketh it to rot and perish; so worldly prosperitie killeth vs with kindnes, whilest it sucketh from vs the sap of Gods graces, and so maketh our spirituall growth and strength to decay and languish; neither doe men euer almost suffer an eclipse of their vertues and good parts, but when they are in the full of worldly prosperitie. And as it staieth our course in godlines, and quencheth our vertues, so also it increaseth our corruptions, corrupteth our manners, and maketh vs prone to fall into all sinne, if we be but a little rouched with the least tentation. And as the fertill soile being more fat and slipperie, is apter to giue a fall to those that walke vpon it, then that which is grauellie and barren; so this rich and fruitfull ground of prosperitie is much more slipperie, then the barren heaths of aduersitie and affliction, and not one of a thousand doth goe long vpon it, but hee catcheth many downfalles, not only into sinne. but also into danger and punishment which border fast vpon it. To this purpose one of the ancients speaketh fitly, that abundance of prosperitie, is a notable Ambros. de Interpell. lib. 2. cap. 5. baite to draw vs vnto sinne, for it puffeth vs vp with pride, and maketh vs to forget the author of our welfare. And in this respect another saith, that felicitie is more to be feared then miserie, August. enarrat. in Psal. 67. seeing miserie for the most part bringeth good fruite. from the bitter roote of tribulation; whereas felicitie corrupteth the soule with peruerse securitie, and maketh way for Satan the tempter. By which it appeareth that our danger is far more when the world allureth vs with the baites of prosperitie, then when it threatneth and afflicteth vs with trouble and aduersitie: from whence an ancient father obserueth, that Christ comming into the world that he might shew vs the way to heauen, both by his doctrine and example, made choice rather
of the afflicted way, then of the faire passage of worldly prosperitie, that we might follow his steps, as being farre the safest way, to bring vs to our heauenly countrie. Our Sauiour Gregor. pastoral. curae, 1. par. cap. 3. Christ (saith he) might by best right haue raigned ouer them as King, whom himselfe had created: but because he therefore appeared in the flesh, that hee might not only redeeme vs with his passion, but also might teach vs by his conuersation, shewing himselfe an example for vs to follow, hee refused to be made a King, and contrariwise voluntarily offered himselfe to suffer on the crosse, hee auoided the glorie of regiment, and embraced the punishment of a shamefull death; to this end, that his members might hereby learne, to flee the worlds fauours, and little to feare his threats and terrors, to loue aduersitie for the truth sake, and fearing prosperitie to auoid it; because this oftentimes defileth the heart with swelling pride, and that helpeth to purge it by repentance. In that the minde doth exalt it selfe, by this after it is thus exalted, it is againe humbled; In that a man forgetteth himselfe, in this whether he will or no, he is forced to remember that which he had forgotten; in that good things before done perish, in this faults cōmitted long ago are cleansed and purged. For oftentimes with the tutillage of aduersitie, the heart is kept downe vnder discipline, whereas if it rush vp to the sterne of gouernmēt, forthwith it is changed in pride through vse of vaine glorie.

But this may yet more plainly appeare, if we consider the§. Sest. 5. The great danger of prosperity shewed by examples of former ages. effects of both, in the examples as well of former ages, as of our owne times. For how difficult, and almost impossible it is to walke in this sunshine of prosperitie and not be tanned, to breathe this infected aire and not to bee corrupted with noisome and carnall lusts, it is euident, both on the one side, by the huge multitudes of those who in abusing it, haue bin abused by it; and on the other side, by the exceeding raritie and paucitie of those, who by the good vse thereof, haue bin made more vertuous, and better fitted for the seruice of God. For if you take a computation of both, you shall finde a greater disparitie betweene them in their number, then betweene the seruants of God and the seruants of Baal, according to Elias account; the one exceeding the starres in multitude, the other being as rare as black swans, vnlesse we
will reckon of some sew, who had their prosperitie tempered with a great measure of affliction, which as an antidote expelled the poyson of the other, and like a cold frost nipping their rancknes, made them to become more fruitfull. How many haue we read and heard of, that haue valiantly resisted the assaults of aduersitie, and haue patiently endured pouertie, and that which is worse, losse of wealth, sicknesse and diseases, banishment, and imprisonment, yea death it self, and horrible tortures, much worse then death? But shew me enow to intitle a number, of those who haue by worldly prosperitie, riches, honours, and pleasures, been made more religious and zealous in Gods seruice, more vertuous, wise, humble, temperate, and more carefull & watchful ouer their waies, that they might not offend God the author of their welfare. Yea shew me almost ye man, that hath not by worldly prosperitie bin made worse, more forgetfull of God, more negligent in Christian duties, & vicious in his whole course and conuersation. Whereas contrariwise a whole age were too little to reckon vp those who haue come out of the fire of affliction more purified, profited vnder this schoolemaster, and by these fatherly chastisements haue increased in their loue towards God, and in their care to please him by their holie obedience.

Yea let vs if you will obserue the same men, and you shall§. Sect. 6. The great difference betweene the same men in prosperitie and aduersitie. 1. Sam. 10. 22. see them not the same, but exceedingly differing from themselues in these different estates: look vpon Saul in his meane condition, and you shall see him modestly hiding himselfe, as vnworthie to be King; but being once seated in ye throne, and swelled with drinking this royall poyson, how proud he is and insolent, disobedient and rebellious, louing his kingdome better then his God, and against his knowledge and conscience, making warre with heauen, rather then hee would not haue it continued to him and his posteritie, though he were iustly deposed for his sinne. See also how in the entrance into his raigne he spareth his enemies, and deliuereth1. Sam. 11. 13. offenders from deserued punishments, but afterwards with deadly and implacable malice persecuteth his friends,1. Sam. 22. 17. and tyrannically murthereth the guiltlesse and innocent.
But if worldly prosperitie were only powerfull with wicked worldlings, it were no great wonder: see therefore how it hath also preuailed against Gods Saints. Behold holy Dauid, who in his afflicted estate exceeded all in pietie, and was esteemed by God worthie that praise, to bee pronounced a man according to Gods owne heart; how foully hee was foiled with ease and prosperitie, and after many famous victories, now enioying secure peace, was assaulted and vanquished with his owne lusts. See here his great humilitie, comparing himselfe to a dead dogge and a flea; and there1. Sam. 24. 15. (not content with the royalties of a kingdome, vnlesse hee knew ouer how many hee commanded) enioyning, yea forcing, in pride of heart, his seruant Ioab to number the people. In this consider his tendernesse and pious mercie, sauing his enemie when hee had him in his power, his conscience checking him for cutting the lap of his garment, when hee spared his throate; but in that, murthering his faithfull and well deseruing souldier, for no other fault but because his wife was too beautifull for a subiect, yea rather then hee1. Sam. 11. would not haue him dispatched, adioyning others of his innocent seruants in the cruell massacre. Which bloodie sinne hee was now able to disgest without remorce for a long space, and stifly to stand vnder this intollerable waight, whoPsal. 38. 6. before was very crooked with the farre lighter burthen of his infirmities. So looke vpon Ezechiah in his bed of sicknes, and there you shall see him humbling himselfe before God, and praying; and then behold him being recouered to his health, and you shall finde him glorying in his wealth, and in pride of heart boasting of his treasures.

And if these single victories ouer these great Worthies do§. Sect. 7. That prosperitie hath corrupted and destroyed whole nations. not sufficiently shew the strength of this enemie; see what conquests this worldly prosperitie hath made of whole nations: and to say nothing of heathenish people, nor of the foure great Monarchies, who hauing conquered all others, were themselues ouercome by their prosperitie, which first made them licentious in all manner of sinne, and afterwards slaues to their conquered enemies; looke vpon the Israel of God, in the whole time of the Iudges and Kings, and you
shal see them in the time of aduersitie, religious and deuout, forsaking their sinnes and seeking the Lord; but being restored and repossessed of Gods blessings, and florishing in prosperitie, you shall finde them polluting Gos house, erecting idolatrie, forsaking God, and worshipping diuels. And this good Ezra obserued and confessed, namely, that the people hauing obtained but a little breathing time fromEzra 9. 8. 10. their afflictions, did take occasion thereby to forsake Gods commandements. And Nehemiah acknowledgeth that the people abounding wth all plentie did eate, fill themselues, and became fat, and then grew rebellious and disobedi • nt, committing all manner of sinne and outrage; for which being deliuered into the hands of their enemies and afflicted, they humbled themselues and cried vnto the Lord for mercie and deliuerance, but hauing againe obtained rest, theyNehem. 9. 25. 26. 27. 28. returned to doe euill before him.

But vnto the experience of ancient ages, wee may adde§. Sect. 8. The danger of prosperitie shewed by the experience of these present times. our owne times: for who seeth not that commonly where there is most affliction, there is also most deuotion, religion, and obedience? and contrariwise where there is prosperitie and plentie of all things, there is most want of the feare of God, and greatest penurie of grace and vertue. For the cleering of this, compare the prison with the Court, and the house of mourning with the house of feasting and reioycing; and whereas in the one you shall heare religious discourses, prayers to God, and inuectiues against the worlds vanities; in the other you shall finde nothing but riot and ribauldrie, vaine iesting and blasphemous swearing, surfetting and drunkennes, chambring and wantonnes, audacious boldnes in euill, and shamefastnes in nothing, vnlesse at vnawares, being among their wicked consorts, they haue said or done something that sauoureth of religion, as though there were neither God, nor diuell, heauen, nor hell, and as though they had sold themselues vnto sinne, and had exchanged the eternall ioyes of Gods kingdome, with the temporarie vanities of the world. But lest this dissimilitude of behauiour should seeme to arise from the difference of the persons, and not of their estates, let vs consider the diuers
effects of these two estates in the same men. And leauing worldlings to the world, who seeth not that those who make profession of religion, are exceedingly cooled in their zeale, and corrupted in their liues and conuersation, through the prosperitie of the world? and that not only counterfeit Christians, but euen such as in their meaner and more poore estate, would rather haue suffered any persecution, euen to the taking away of their liues, then they would disgrace their profession by offering any scandall, or bee drawne to slacken their pace in the way of godlinesse, are by degrees so carried away with the inticing baites of prosperitie, that first they abate of their heate, and afterwards become lukewarme, or keycold in their religious profession and practise? And howsoeuer they retaine still the name of Christians, lest they should bee branded with that dreadfull badge of apostasie, yet come to the touchstone of their liues, and to their carriage and demeanour in their particular places and callings, and you shall finde many of them, as worldly, couetous, and niggardly in contributing to religious and charitable vses, yea as proud and vaine in apparell, as deceitfull in their dealings, and riotous in needlesse and idle expenses, as professed worldlings. So that whereas aduersitie could not foile them with his sharpest incounters, when hee purposely bent all his forces against them; prosperitie hath subdued them, and made them captiues to the world, as it were in play, taking no great paines to obtaine the conquest.

Now the reasons why wee are so easily foiled and ouercome§. Sect. 9. The reasons why prosperitie is so dangerous▪ by worldly prosperitie, are, because it doth soften and effeminate our mindes, so as they can indure no labour, nor sustaine the least force and violence: for as the lute string being softned in water swelleth much in bignes, but loseth all his strength; so our hearts being moistned and mollified with these waters of prosperitie, exceedingly swell in pride, but in the meane time lose all their strength and Christian fortitude, so as they cannot indure the least incounter of an enemie. Or else it is because it maketh vs retchlesse and secure, so as we fearing no assault neuer muster vp our forces, that we may haue them in a readinesse, and so being taken
at vnawares, and vnprouided, we are not able to stand or make resistance: for whereas the cold of aduersitie gathers and vnites all the powers of the soule, and by vertue of this vnion inables them to make resistance, when they are incountred, so the heate of prosperitie dissipating and scattering them, maketh them much more easie to be ouercome. Or which is most probable, because prosperitie puffeth men vp with pride, and making them leaue their dependancie on God, causeth them to trust in themselues and their owne strength; and so God resisteth them in their pride and forsaketh them, who had first forsaken him: and therefore no maruell it is if being left of God, they be easilier ouercome of the weakest enemie. Whereas contrariwise affliction maketh vs flee vnto God for helpe, and distrusting in our selues to relie on his power and promises; and so though we haue to deale with a mightie enemie, yet being shrouded vnder the shadow of his wings, we become safe through his protection.

And thus haue I manifested the great power of this monarch,§. Sect. 10. That a great measure of grace is required to the well managing of our prosperitie. by the greatnes of his victories, and haue shewed how much more dangerous he is then affliction and persecution. Whereby it appeareth, that a farre greater measure of grace and Christian resolution is required, to beare and resist the encounters of worldly prosperitie, then of the other which seemeth to flesh and blood so terrible and vnresistable. For as it is much more intollerable to indure a tickling itch then a smarting paine; so it is much more impossible to retaine a Christian constancie in the course of godlinesse, when the world tickleth vs with this itch of prosperitie, then when wee feele the smart and paine of troubles and afflictions;Vbi plus sortunae licentia, ibi plus virtutis negotium. for where there is greatest libertie of estate, there vertue hath the greatest imployment. To this purpose one saith fitly, that it is a note of singular vertue, to striue and contend with worldly felicitie, that it may neither allure, corrupt, nor ouerthrow August. s • rm. 13. tom. 10. vs, and great vnhappinesse to be ouercome of this earthly happinesse.

The consideration whereof should make vs to keepe a§. Sect. 11. That we ought to keepe a narrow watch ouer our selues in the time of prosperitie. narrow watch ouer our selues, as at all other times, so especially
in our florishing prosperitie, because (as hath been shewed) this enemie is much more dangerous, and wee, through our retchlesse securitie, and carnall loue of earthly things, much more vnable to make resistance. To this purpose one saith, that when the persecution of enemies ceaseth, our Gregor. lib. 40. Homil. hom 32. heart is much more vigilantly to be obserued: for in the time of peace whilest we haue libertie to liue, wee take libertie also to couet, and compasse our ambitious ends. The which was practised by another, as himselfe professeth: I feare no lesse (saith he) prosperitie then aduersitie; for prosperitie maketh me with his Bernard meditat. cap. 14. sweetnes retchlesse, and so deceiueth me; but aduersitie, because it hath some mixture of bitternes, like vnpleasant potions, makes me fearefull and suspitious. Whose practise let vs also follow, casting aside carnall security, and carefully arming our selues against the tentations of prosperitie, which are pleasantly pernicious, and most hurt vs, when they most delight vs, and seeme to threaten least danger. Now if wee would know how to fight against this enemie, where our chiefe strength lieth, and what are the best weapons to be vsed for the obtaining of victorie, wee must consider that the Christian champion must not vndertake this combat, nor enter the lists in his owne name, but (as Dauid against Goliah) we must come out against him in the name of the Lord; we must not relie vpon our owne strength, but vpon the Lords assistance, and vpon the power of his might, through which alone we are inabled to ouercome; neither must our comfort and confidence be grounded vpon any conceit, that wee are able in our selues to subdue this enemie, but in this, that our Captaine Iesus Christ hath ouercome him for vs. And this mustIoh. 16. 33. make vs to flie vnto him by earnest and effectuall prayer, desiring the helpe and assistance of his holy spirit, whereby we may bee deliuered in the day of tentation, and may haue these worldly lusts killed and crucified in vs.

With which our prayers wee must ioyne a Christian care§. Sect. 12. How we are said to resist the tentations of prosperitie. to arme vs for the fight, not with Sauls carnall armour, for this being vnfit and combersome, will rather betray vs to the enemie, then defend vs from his force; but with the spirituall armour of a Christian, euen the gifts and graces of
Gods sanctifying spirit. And being armed, we must obserue the best maner of fight for obtaining the victorie: to which purpose let vs know, that wee proclaime warre against prosperitie and worldly vanities, and manfully resist in the combat of tentations; when wee thrust them out from hauing a chiefe place in our hearts, making them as slaues to follow and obey vs, and not as Lords to rule and raigne ouer vs. When as wanting them, wee doe not greatly desire their companie, much lesse vse wicked and vnlawfull meanes, for the obtaining of this vnprofitable societie. When as hauing them we do not set our hearts vpon them, but esteeme them base and contemptible, in comparison of the rich iewels of Gods graces, & the eternal ioies of his kingdom; being contented to lose thē, rather then in the least degree to hazard the other. And when wee immoderatly grieue not, but rest well contented, if it bee the pleasure of God to take them from vs; yea when wee our selues can willingly cast them away for Christ sake, and renounce and forsake them, when as they will not stand with our profession and practise of religion; being content to leaue all the worlds glorie, and to take vp our crosse and follow Christ. In a word, wee fight against worldly prosperitie, when we defie it; we kill it, when we contemne it; we obtaine the victorie when we flee from it, and renounce it; as often as it is the diuels solicitour to perswade vs vnto sinne, or a corriuall with God or his graces wooing vs for our hearts; or an alluring baite which inticeth vs to swallow the hooke of tentations, and to giue entertainment to the wicked suggestions of the diuell.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
Reasons which may moue vs to contemne worldly prosperitie.
div.p:
NOw that wee may not thus set our hearts and affections§. Sect. 1. Prosperitie seldome bettereth our spirituall • state. immoderatly vpon worldlie prosperitie, but may despise and contemne it when it commeth into comparison with Gods fauour and grace, or the
glorie of his kingdome, or allureth vs vnto sinne; there are many arguments which may perswade vs. As first, because prosperitie doth very seldome better our spirituall estate, and further our saluation, but almost alwaies maketh vs worse, more prone vnto sinne, and further off from God and godlinesse.
