Finally, he sinneth against himselfe, in making his condemnation more iust, and his fault more vnexcusable; for if the sinnes of the GentilesRom. 1. 20. became vnexcusable, because they were committed against the light of nature; then how much more are their sinnes without excuse, who haue much more perfect knowledge of Gods will, as it is reuealed in the holy Scriptures?

And thus doth this vain & idle knowledge hurt those that§. Sect. 8. Vnfruitfull knowledge increaseth our reckoning at the day of iudgement. haue it in this life: in the life to come, they shall find it much more pernicious. First, because it shal increase their bils of account, when at Gods great audit they shal giue a reckoning, how they haue vsed and imploied that rich talent of knowledge, which God vouchsafed to lend vnto them; how much they haue excelled those, who wāted of their great measure, in true obedience, how much by it they haue glorified God, edified their brethren, and reformed their owne liues and conuersations: for according to the measure of Gods gifts must our accounts be, and he that hath receiued the greatest portion, and hath either vnprofitablie buried it, or abused it vnto sinne, the greater and more fearefull shall his condemnation be. And this is the last and greatest euil which our vnfruitfull knowledge will bring vnto vs, namely, that as it aggrauateth our sinne, so also it will increase our punishment;Luke 12. 47. for as our Sauiour saith, the seruant that knoweth his masters will, and doth it not, shall be beaten with many stripes. And hence it is, that he threatneth more heauie condemnation against Tyre and Sidon, then against Sodom & Gomorrah; because the light of the Gospel, encreased and confirmed by admirable miracles, did much more clearely shine vnto them, thenMat. 11. 21. 22. vnto the other: and the Apostle Peter affirmeth, that it had bin better for them (against whom he inueigheth) not to haue knowne the way of righteousnesse, then after they haue knowne it, to turne from the holy commandement giuen vnto them.

Seeing therefore this idle, and vnfruitfull knowledge is§. Sect. 9. That we are to labour after sauing knowledge. not onely vaine and vnprofitable, but also exceeding hurtfull, both in this life, and the life to come; let vs not esteeme and rest in it, but contemne and despise it, labouring after that fruitfull knowledge, which alone will make vs wise to2. Pet. 1. 5. our saluation. And as the Apostle Peter exhorteth, let our knowledge bee lincked in the chaine of all other vertues, seasoned with pietie, and the true feare of God, and fruitfull in all holy obedience; and then, though it make not so great a flourish in worldly discourses, nor winne the applause and praise of men; yet shall it make vs approoued vnto God, and will certainely guide vs in that way, which in the end will bring vs to endlesse ioy, and heauenly happinesse.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
That beautie is to bee contemned in respect of spirituall graces, or heauenly excellencies.
div.p:
ANd thus much concerning the tentations of§. Sect. 1. That beautie is good, as being the gift of God. worldly prosperity, arising from the faculties and properties of the mind. In the next place wee are to intreate of such, as haue their beginning and growth from the properties and qualities of the bodie; as for example, from beautie, strength, and health. For howsoeuer these are all good in themselues, as I shall particularly shew, yet they are abused through the malice of the diuell, and our owne corruption, as baites to allure, and draw vs vnto sinne. Concerning Pulchritudo corporis est congruentia partium, cum quadam coloris s • auitate. August. ad Nebridium. the first; Beautie (as Austin defineth it) is a proportionable cōgruity, and fit agreement of all the parts of the body, ioined with a certaine sweetnesse of colour and countenance. The which in it owne nature is good, as being a gift of God, the which hee bestowed in greatest measure vpon our first parents in their creation, and farre aboue any of their posteritie, whom sinne defaced and deformed, as wel in their body as in their soule; and reserueth a far most excellent degree and portion thereof
for the glorified Saints of heauen. And this is acknowledged both by Heathens and Christians; for euen the Ethnicke Poet could say that, Beautie is the gift of God. AndForma dei munus. Ouid. with him agree the Ancients of the Church. One saith, that beautie is a part of the bodies felicitie, a bountifull aduantage, or Tertul. de cult. foemin. lib. Haec tua sun • , bona sunt, qui • in bonus ista cr • asti, &c. August. de ciuit. dei lib. 15. cap. 22. A • s desit, nullum est crimen decoris, &c. Ambr. lib. 7. epist. 44. Ambr. offic. lib. 1. cap. 19. accession of the diuine creation, and a ciuill and comely garment and ornament of the soule. And another: These gifts O Lord are thine, and are good, because thou the chiefe goodnesse hast created them; and there is nothing in them ours, but our sinne in ouerlouing them; for neglecting al order, we are readie to preferre th • creature, aboue thee who hast created it. And Ambrose saith, that there is no fault in beautie, if it be free from counterfaiting art; and if allurement cease, fauor and the grace of beauty, are to be esteemed innocent and faultles. Yea, it is a fit habitation for vertue, modestie, and shamefastnes to dwel in; and as a good workman vsually worketh best when he hath fit matter, so modestie doth most excell, when it is seated in a beautifull bodie, so that this beautie be not affected, but naturall and simple. Yea, the spirit of God himselfe doth take notice of it, in those vpon whom it was bestowed, and affordeth vnto it, due and fit commendations. Thus Sara, Rebeccah, Rahel, Gen. 12. 14. & 24. 16. & 29. 17. &. 39. 6.
Ioseph, and many others are said to haue bin very faire and beautifull; and when God restored and augmented the prosperitie of Iob, it is specially noted as an extraordinarie blessing, that he had not only many children, but that in all Iob 42. 15. the land were no women found so faire as the daughters of Iob. But we shall not need to say much of this point, seeing by instinct of nature, all men owe a kind of homage to beautie weere they find it, and being much delighted therewith do extraordinarily fauour and respect it. And therefore one beingAristor. apud Stobaeum. asked, why beautifull things were so much loued, answered, that none but a blind man need to aske such a question. But to say nothing of Heathens, euen the Saints and seruants of God haue bin mooued thereby to loue and liking. This made Iacob to preferre Rachel before Leah; this madeGen. 29. 30. Moses mother to fauour and respect him, and in sauing him aliue because he was faire, to hazard her owne life. And holieExod. • . 2. Samuel being affected with Eliab •
beautie, concluded hereupon
upon that the Lords annointed was before him; yea the Lord1. Sam. 16. 6. himselfe is said to take pleasure in the beautie of his Church;Psalm. 45. 11. vnto whom nothing agreeth that is euill, not so much as by an allegorie or similitude.

Beautie therefore being good may be moderately loued§. Sect. 2. What is required to make beauty good vnto vs. Gratior & pulchro veniens in corpore virtus, adi • uat. Ʋirg. Ae • e • d. lib. 5. and esteemed, when it is in a good and vertuous subiect, the outward beautie of the bodie, and the inward beautie of the mind being ioyned together: seeing it helpeth to adorne vertue to the outward sense, and causeth it to be accepted with more applause and liking, when it is sound in a beautifull bodie, then in one il-fauoured and deformed; euer▪ as a precious iewell is more graced when it is kept in a rich cabinet, then in an vnseemely box. As also when it is well vsed by those that haue it, that is to say, when first it is not too much affected and vnnaturally forced: to which purpose one saith, that as an artisan worketh better when he hath fit matter▪ Bernard. lib. de ordin • vitae. to worke vpon; so also modestie doth shine more clearely, when it is in a comely bodie: yet so, that this beautie of the bodie be not too much affected, but naturall, simple and neglected, rather then ouer earnestly desired: not supported and helped with ouer pretious and glorious garments, but with such as are ordinarie, that so neither any thing be wanting to necessitie and honest comlinesse, nor any thing added to cleanely neatnesse. Secondly, when it is ioyned with modestie and shamefastnes; for nothing is more opposed to vertuous beautie, then immodestie and bold impudencie. Thirdly, if the beautie of the bodie be an effectuall reason to moue them that haue it, to a more diligent care of adorning their minds with vertue and true piety, and to keep a vigilant watch ouer all their actions, that they do not commit any thing foule and faulty, misbeseeming such a beauty.Lucius Apul • ius de Magia. lib. 1. And thus the wise Socrates is said to haue perswaded his scholers, that they should often looke themselues in their glasses, that he who was pleased & delighted with his beautie, might earnestly indeuour not to disgrace the dignitie and comlinesse of his bodie with euill conditions; and that he who found himselfe il-fauoured should striue to couer his deformities with his vertues and good manners. To which purpose also an ancient Father demandeth, Art thou (saith
he) of excellent beautie? why then let it moue thee to this care,
E • imia forma est? id agat, vt animi pulchritudo, corporis pulchritudini splendore respondeat. Nazianzen in Maximum. that the beautie of thy mind may be of answerable brightnesse to the beautie of thy bodie. Finally, this beautie is vsed aright, when as we do not rest in it as being fraile and momentanie, but vse it as a little streame to conduct and bring vs to God the fountaine of all beautie and goodnesse; and be mooued thereby to this meditation, that if a sparke of this beautie imparted to the creature, worke such loue and admiration; then how much more is that infinite flame of beautie in our Creator, from which this is deriued, to be admired and loued! If this heauenly Sun reflect a shadow so full of brightnesse vpon earth and clay, then how infinitly glorious is he in his owne nature and perfections! Finally, if we esteeme it a part of our earthly happinesse to haue our selues and neerest friends adorned with this beautie; then how much more happie shall wee bee, when being in those heauenly ioyes, we shall not only our selues exceed the Sun in the firmament in beautie and brightnes; but also shall haue the vision and fruition of our gratious and glorious God, in comparison of whose purity the heauens are filthy and vncleane, and in regard of whose infinit beautie and glorie, the Sunne it selfe is grosse darknesse, and the most excelling beautie in heauen or earth but meere deformitie?

And thus haue I shewed that beautie in it owne nature is§. Sect. 3. Beautie of the bodie without the beautie of the mind is of no worth. Leu. 21. 19. 20. good, and a gift and blessing of God to those who haue also a right vse of it: euen as contrariwise deformity is in it owne nature euill, as being a fruit of sin; and therefore such as were crooked, lame, or blemished, are by God forbidden to offer his sacrifices. But if we consider it as it is in our nature corrupted with sin, it is not absolutely good, but to be numbred among things indifferent, the which (as all other the benefits of prosperitie) is more often abused, then well vsed, and so becommeth vnto vs, through the malice of our spirituall enemies an inducement vnto sinne, and the ground of many dangerous tentatiōs. And thus this gift of God is abused, when as we rest in it alone, and content our selues with this shadow neglecting the substance, vertue and true godlinesse, and thinking it enough to haue beautifull bodies,
though in the meane time our minds and soules be vglie and deformed: for the inward beautie of the mind ought not to be seuered from the outward beautie of the bodie, seeing (asPlutarch. Amator. Tom. 2. pag. 452. Enripid. in • dipo. one saith) beautie is the flower which springeth from the root of vertue, and therefore being parted from it, it must needs wither and come to nought: to which purpose another saith, that the mind is more to be regarded then the bodie; for the outward beautie profiteth not, when a good mind is not ioyned with it: neither is that to be esteemed a perfect beautie, but lame and most vnperfect, which consisteth in the outward colour of the skin; when the mind and soule is vglie and deformed: for what is this better then a faire cabinet full of filth and rubbish, and a goodly sepuchre full of stench and rottennes? which is not indeed truly beautifull, but only seemeth so, through the imperfection of ourAristot. apud Boëtium de Consol. lib. 3. pros. 8. sight; for if (as one saith) our eies like the Linxes could pierce into the inward parts; or rather if we could see as God seeth, the secrets of the heart and reines, then should wee more loathe and abhorre them for their inward vglinesse and filthinesse, then admire or like them for their outward feature: and therefore it is not their owne naturall excellency, which intitleth them to the name of beautie, but the weakenesse of our sight which can pierce no deeper then the outside of the skin: and therefore of such it is said, not absolutely that they were beautifull, but only that they were faire to looke vpon, 2. Sam. 14. 27. Let none then content themselues with thisIam. 1. 10. 11. painted scabard, which hath in it but a woodden or leaden dagger, nor take delight in this flower which hath a faire colour, but no sweetnesse: but seeing we are all as the flowers of the field, let vs labour to become roses in Gods garden, hauing the beautie of colour ioyned with the sweetnes of vertue, that so when the outward complexion is faded, the odour and perfume of a godly life may still remaine.

Againe, this beautie is abused, when as in conceit thereof§. Sect. 4. Beautie becommeth euill when w • are proud of it, or set our hearts vpon it. those that haue it are puffed vp with pride, and so forget God who gaue it, and all dutie which they owe vnto him, and despise their neighbours, as comming farre short of their excellencies; for howsoeuer this beautie be vaine and of small
worth, momentanie, and oftentimes but of a daies continuance; yet there are many so destitute of all goodnesse, that for want of better matter in them, they are proud of this vaine shadow; and being void of vertue, by their beautie alone do seeme vnto themselues glorious. Moreouer, it is thus abused, whenas we do too much affect & set our harts vpon it, and spend ouer much time and labour either in getting, preseruing, or increasing it, neglecting in the meane time things of more necessitie and greater value: vnto which abuse vaine worldlings, (especially of the weaker sex) are much addicted, who superstitiously abstaine from those things which they most loue; and are content to vse those things which they loathe, to get or recouer this vanity; thinking no paines too much, no punishment which they take on themselues too great, nor their precious health too deare, to giue for the purchase of this fading trifle; and spending more time in the combing and curling of their haire, in washing, sweating and bathing, dressing and trimming, and in many other their hidden mysteries, (of which wilfull ignorance is no sinne, and thereof I am not ashamed herein of my simplicitie) then in all their spirituall deuotions towards God, or their duties of Christianitie towards their neighbours; so that no bodie that is wise would enuie vnto them their supposed happinesse, consisting in this vaine beautie, if he did but consider at what deare rates it is bought, and how much more excellent things they do in the meane time lose, whilest they are procuring or preseruing this trifling vanitie. Finally, those abuse it vnto sinne who ouer value it in themselues or others, preferring it before the gifts of the mind, vertue, Gods sanctifying graces, and the meanes of their saluation; yea more esteeming of this perishing fauour, then of the eternall fauour and loue of God, for howsoeuer this gift of beautie be good as proceeding from God; yet it is incomparison of the former of no excellencie, being a good temporall, carnall, and of the meanest and lowest degree, and therefore it is impiously loued (as one saith) when in respect August. de Ciuit. Dei. lib. 15. cap. 22. thereof, the eternall God, our internall and sempiternall goodnes is neglected; but as righteousnesse is forsaken, and gold loued of
couetous man, not through the fault of the gold, but of the man, so is it in this. Now lest any should thinke that but few fall into this follie, let them know, that as many are guiltie of it, as vse greater care and labour, and spend more time in procuring, or preseruing this fading beautie, then in attaining Gods fauour, the graces of his spirit, or in vsing the meanes of their owne saluation; for as we preferre our ends, so also the meanes accordingly which leade vnto them.

And thus haue I shewed how this gift of God is abused§. Sect. 5. Beautie is but a gift, common with the brutish creatures. vnto euill, and becommeth the ground of diuers tentations, wherby Satan and the world, through the corruption of our flesh, allureth vs to sinne; against which, that we may be armed, let vs not, if we want it, immoderately desire it, and if we haue it, let vs take heed that wee be not ouertaken with pride, nor set our hearts and affections vpon it, preferring it before spirituall and sauing graces, and the meanes of our owne saluation. Yea, when it commeth in comparison with these, let vs learne to despise and contemne, lothe and abhorre it, as becomming through abuse, a snare of the diuell; whereby he bindereth vs from going forward in the way of saluation. But because the most that haue it, doe thus abuse it, and in stead of being made better, and more thankfull vnto God, become more vain and proud, wanton and wicked, let such know, that whatsoeuer beautie is in it owne nature, to them it is of no worth or excellencie, altogether vnprofitable; yea, very hurtfull and pernicious, both to themselues and others. And first that it is of no value, or excellencie, being seuered from vertue and true godlinesse; it may appeare, in that it is common to man with the brutish creatures; and what excellencie is in that, in which the horse and greyhound, the peacocke and swan, doe also excell as well as he? yea, of what worth is it, seeing euen the flowers of the field, as the rose and lilie, doe in the beautie of colours goe farre beyond him? and therefore mans excellencie is not in this, wherein he is exceeded by such meane creatures, but in the right vse of sanctified reason, and in the hidden vertues Nibil in best ijs plus reperias quam quod videtur, in homine nihil est inferius. Ambros. de Institut. virg. cap. 3. tom. 1. of the mind. For as there is nothing more excellent in beasts, then that which is outwardly seene and discerned, so in man there
is nothing inferiour to that which lieth open to the view, and is subiect to the senses; for whereas he consisteth of soule and bodie, the bodie which is seene doth serue and obey, and the soule which is not seene doth beare rule and gouerne; and therefore man is not to be so admired for his beautie and outward parts, as for his secret vertues, and hidden operations of his mind. Neither in truth doth the excellencie of the outward parts, which doe chiefly intitle a beautie, consist herein that they are beautifull, which is onely their ornament, but in their seuerallChrysost. in 1. Tim. 1. Homil. 4. in Mor. offices and functions, for which they were ordained: as for example, this is not the excellencie of the eies, that they are gray or black, glancing or rolling, but that they excell in the acutenes and vigour of seeing; it is not the excellencie of the nose or eare, that they are of this, or that colour or fashion, but in their perfection of hearing and smelling; nor of the hand that it hath a fine proportion, or white colour, but in that it is a readie and expert instrument of all our actions; nor of the teeth to be white and euen, but that they be fit to prepare conuenient nourishment for the stomacke; in all which excellencies, the deformed and beautifull exceed not one another, but are both equall.

But the worthlesnesse of this beautie which is seuered§. Sect. 6. The vanitie of beautie prooued by testimonies. from vertue and true wisedome, may more plainely appeare both by testimonies and reasons. The wisest among the sons of men saith, that fauour is deceitfull and beautie is vanitie, but a woman that feareth the Lord, she shall be praised. And such ill harmonie he thinketh to be betweene beautie and folly, thatProu. 31. 30. Prou. 11. 22. Diogenes apud Laertium devit. & mo. rib. Philos. Isocrates. Now pu • chritudinem corporis, honestatem. mentis requir • , &c. Chrysost. in Psalm. 50. Homil. 1. he iudgeth it as absurd and ridiculous, to see a faire woman lacking discretion, as a iewell of gold in a swines snout. Another compareth a beautifull bodie with euill conditions to a faire house, and a bad inhabitant; and another, to a good ship that hath a bad pilot. To which purpose also Chrysostom saith, that he doth not so much require the beautie of the bodie, as the honestie of the mind. For what (saith he) is a beautifull woman? a painted sepulcher, vnlesse she be sober, chast and modest; and beautie without these vertues, is an open gulph, and a poison compounded for fooles to drinke, &c. And therefore if thou seest a man or woman beautifull, doe not admire them; for the loftie and
strong okes, although they be thicke with faire greene leaues, and tall in stature, yet they beare no fruit fit for men, but only meate to feed hogges: whereas the vine creeping on the earth bringeth foorth pleasant grapes.

The reasons why wee should esteeme it base, and of no§. Sect. 7. The worthlesnes of beautie prooued by reasons: first, because God esteemeth it not. worth without vertue, or in comparison of spirituall graces, are, first, because God doth so esteeme it; for he looketh not to the outward shape and countenance, but principally regardeth the heart, and the inward beautie of the mind. And this the Lord shewed to Samuel, when he was so much in loue with Eliabs beautie, and goodly personage; willing him not to looke on his countenance, nor on the height of his 1. Sam. 16. 7. stature, seeing he had refused him: because God seeth not as man seeth; for man looketh to the outward appearance, but the Lord beholdeth the heart. But how little the Lord valueth his gifts of beautie and outward shape, may appeare by his manner of bestowing them; for he reserueth them not, as special and chiefe iewels for his owne children and seruants, but as trifles of small value, he maketh them common to the wicked and reprobate, who are but slaues and enemies. And thus he inriched Saul with a large portion thereof, of whom it is said, that he was a goodly young man and a faire, so that among 1. Sam. 9. 2. the children of Israel, there was none goodlier then he: so Adoniah had this gift in great measure, who is said to haue bin1. King. 1. 6. a very goodly man. And Absolon, though hee had not the birthright, nor the blessing; yet in this had a double portion, for in all Israel, there was none to bee so much praised for beautie 2. Sam. 14. 25. as he; from the sole of his foote to the top of his head, there was no blemish in him. From whence it appeareth, of how small Pulchritudo corporis bonum quidem dei donum, est: sed propterea id largitur etiam malis ne magnum bonum videatur bonis. August. de ciui • . dei. lib. 15. cap. 22. worth in comparison, this beautie is, seeing it hath bin so plentifully bestowed on such worthlesse men: to which purpose one saith, that the beautie of the bodie is indeed the gift of God, but hee hath therefore bestowed it on the euill also, l • st it might seeme to the good, to be of any great value. Yea, hee hath bestowed it on the brute creatures, as well as men; and therfore howsoeuer it be good, yet it exceedeth not a brutish excellencie. To this purpose one demandeth: art thou (saith he) faire and beautifull? why, this is the glory of dawes, and not
of men. Thou art not fairer then the peacock or the swan; and oftentimes Chrysost. ad pop. hom. 40. tom. 4. base boies and girles, harlots and effeminat mē, haue had a great share in this glorie. And is this therefore of such worth, that for it thou shouldest be exalted and extolled? Seeing therefore Gods estimate, which being grounded on infinit wisdome and iustice, crieth downe the value of this vaine beautie, which is raised vp by carnall men to such high rates, let vs learne to conforme our iudgements vnto his, slightly accounting of this outward forme and colour, to which mans vaine opinion hath giuen it chiefe excellencie, and highly valuing the inward beauties of the mind, the vertues and sanctifying graces of Gods spirit, which, how vnhandsom soeuer we seeme before men in our outward feature, wil make vs to appeare beautifull in the sight of God, and of our husband Iesus Christ, whom if wee please, it little skilleth, though we be vnpleasing in the eies of men.

Againe, the worthlesnesse of beautie may hereby appeare,§. Sect. 8. Beautie is good rather to those that see it, then to those that haue it. in that if it bring any delight, it is rather to those who see it, then to those that haue it; or if at all it be pleasing to the owners, it is in regard of the liking and admiration of the lookers on, hauing nothing in themselues to rest vpon for their contentment, but depending vpon the iudgement and censure of others, either to be extolled by their commendations, or to be abased by their dispraises; and what worth is in that, which riseth and falleth at euery ones deuotion? or how cannot that be esteemed vain, which hath it being and subsistence in the vaine breath of the vulgar multitude? Neither in truth would they at all admire it, or though they should, yet would not their idle breath puffe vs vp with the wind of pride, if either they or we did but consider, what loathsome matter lieth hid vnder this faire skinne. For if our eies cannot pearce any deeper then the outside only, yet looke what filthie excrements issue out of the nose, cares, pores and other passages, and iudge what the fountaine it selfe is, from which proceed such loathsome streames: consider what wee were before our birth, and what afterwards, then placed in the middest of excrements, and now made the receptacles of dir • and filth. And therefore when the beautie
of the skinne doth most exalt vs, we should be sufficiently humbled, if we would but consider the vgly loathsomnes of that which it containeth.

But though this beautie were of some excellencie whilest§. Sect. 9. Beautie is momentanie and mutable. Prou. 31. 30. Anceps forma bonum mortalibus exiguum do • um, breui temporis momento capitur▪ &c. Senec. in Hippoly to. 1. 760. it continueth, yet is it to bee esteemed of little worth, in regard that it is so momentanie and so mutable. In respect whereof the Wise man saith, that it is not only vaine, but deceitfull also, giuing men the slip when they thinke that they hold it fastest, like a shadow that vanisheth whilest one thinketh to embrace it: for if man himselfe be so momentanie, what shall we thinke of beautie which is but an accident of this subiect, and commonly vanisheth, the substance still remaining? if he be but a flower of the field, which is but of a day or weekes continuance; then how fraile and fading is the colour of this flower which often fadeth a great while, of this small time, before the flower dieth? If man bee but a cloude, then surely beautie, may bee fitly resembled to the bright lightning which issueth out of it, and vanisheth in the twinckling of an eye. Whereof it is that the kingdome of beautie is said to be a tyrannie, which is violent for the time, Socrates vocabat formam modici temporis tyrannidem. Bruson. lib. 2. cap. 44. Hieron. Epist. ad Cyprian. Tom. 3. Et repentè d • m nescit, incanescit caput, rugatur facies, &c. but of short continuance. To this purpose one saith, that as the hearbe springing with his beautifull flowers, doth delight the eye, and by little and little fading loseth his beautie, and is turned into hay; so all the beautie of men buddeth in the spring of childhood, flowreth and florisheth in the summer of youth, and perfect age, and suddenly when the winter of age commeth, the head vnwittingly groweth gray, the face wrinkled, the skinne writhled, and so farre is he now from beautie, that hee hath scarce the vse of his limmes for the slowest and weakest motion. But as it is momentany, so also is it mutable, and vncertain to continue this short time; for this flower of beautie is subiect to be blasted with innumerable accidents, a little scratch impaireth it, and a greater wound doth quite deforme it; a daies sicknes much abateth it, and if it bee but of a weekes continuance, doth quite deface it, yea so fading it is that a little sunshine robbeth vs of it, this earthly beautie being not able to endure that heauenly brightnesse. Or though it be preserued from the violence of extraordinarie accidents, yet time, which by
little and little brought it vnto vs, till attained to the height Florem decoris siaguli carpunt d 〈…〉 . Senec. in Octauia. of it perfection, doth then as stealingly take it away; neither is it more possible to preuent this decay of beautie, then to stop the course of time; for euen whilest it is admired and praised, it secretly fadeth & declineth. And though (through the strength of art and nature conspiring together) it were possible to preserue this beautie vnto old age; yet then behold the vtter ruine of this faire building; for when age commeth it ploweth deepe furrowes in the most beautifull visage, it changeth the colour, rotteth the teeth, tainteth the breath, wrinkleth the brow, bleereth and dimmeth the eyes, crookneth the backe, writhleth the hands, stifneth and lameth the ioynts, deaffeneth the eares, and maketh the voyce hoarse and vnpleasant, which before was sweete and tunable. In a word, it worketh such a change and alteration, that if after some long distance of time, a man should behold his visage in a glasse, he would seeme a stranger to himselfe, and scarce acknowledge that he is still the owner of the same bodie wherewith formerly he was delighted. Or let it bee imagined that through the extraordinarie vigour of nature, there doth a kinde of comely beautie remaine euen in the elder age; yet remember what will become of it in the next houre that death hath seazed vpon it, and hath thrust the soule out of her possession, till his lease also be expired. Call to minde that the most amiable face and countenance after two or three daies buriall, will bee so vgly and deformed, that none would now more loath it, then those who before did most admire it; and were it not priuiledged with that only benefit of senselesnes, and want of vnderstanding, selfehorrour would make it breake open the prison of the graue, and cause it to striue by flight to escape and auoide it owneIob 17. 14. companie.

And thus haue I shewed the worthlesse vanitie and vnprofitablenes§. Sect. 10. That contemning this outward beautie, we must afflict the inward beautie of the minde. of worldly beautie; which ought to moue vs to despise and contemne it, as being of no value, when as it is seuered from true godlinesse. And because naturally wee are affected with beautie, let vs turne the edge of our loue from this earthly trash, to spirituall and heauenly treasure,
setting our hearts on that inward beautie of the mind which Pulchrius est pul • hrum fieri quam nasci • illud enim casus, hoc st • dij est. Petrarch. consisteth in vertue, and the sanctifying gifts of Gods Spirit, and on that glorious beautie, which shall adorne our bodies and soules in the kingdome of God; for as this beautie is in it selfe ten thousand times more excellent then the other, so shall it be of euerlasting continuance; for old age can neuer make any wrinckles in the face of vertue, sicknesse cannot hurt it, violence cannot deface it, griefe and sorrow cannot impaire it, yea death it selfe cannot blemish or disgrace it, yea rather it shal be a meanes to crowne this beauty of grace with the beautie of glory, which as it shal be full of vnspeakable excellencie, so shall it be free from all outward iniurie, and from all inward causes of decay, and consequently vnchangeable and euerlasting.

But if this will not weane our hearts from the loue of§. Sect. 11. Beauty to • much affected doth make the bodie tender▪ soft and sickly. worldly beautie, because it doth not profit vs: let vs further consider yt it doth also bring much hurt both vnto our selues and also vnto our neighbours: it hurteth our selues both in our bodies, soules and names; our bodies thereby are made more tender, soft and effeminate, yea also more weake and sickely, and that not onely through the vse of vnwholesome medicines, and the neglect of wholesome food, both which are ordinarie with those who ouermuch affect the praise of beautie, but also because they neglect that conuenient labor and exercise which preserueth health & increaseth strength, and giue themselues ouer to sloth & daintines, the ordinarie enemies & impairers of thē both: and this needeth no other proofe but common experience, and by comparing the ordinarie sort, who feed wholesomely, and diligently imploy themselues in the duties of their calling, with the gentilitie of the land, who no more exceed the cōmon people in forme and beautie, then these surpasse them, in health and strength.

But howsoeuer this worldly beautie doth much hurt the§. Sect. 12. Beautie hinder • th vertue, and furthereth vice. body, yet nothing in comparison of that hurt which it bringeth vnto the soule, which it much hindreth in the course of vertue, and also plungeth into many vices: in both which respects this tentation of worldly beauty hath ouercome the most that haue had it, whom it hath first effeminated and
made wantonly delicate, so as they could not endure the paines of climing the high hill of vertue, nor of trauelling in the strait and afflicted way of true godlinesse, but rather desire to go downe the easie-declining hill of vice, and to walk in the plaine and faire way that leadeth to destruction: and those whom it hath not ouercome, it hath thoroughly exercised all their strength in making resistance; and very valiantly haue they behaued themselues in this conflict, if they haue not had in the way of vertue many rubs, and receiued many foiles. To this purpose one fitly saith, that they who hau • beautie, Petrarch. de remed. lib. 1. dial. 2. •
haue a couer for their eyes, a snare for their feet, and birdlime for their wings; so as they cannot easily discerne the truth, nor follow vertue, nor flie à loft in heauenly meditations: and many hath it made barren in the duties of pietie, stopped in the course of vertue, and turned aside into the by-paths of vice: in respect of which vnfruitfulnesse in goodnesse, the beautifull person is compared to the tall faire oake, which bringeth only acornes for hogs; and they who want it, and are indued with the beautie of the mind, are likened to the vine,Chrysost. in Psal. 50. homil. which being deformed in shape, bringeth grapes and wine fit for kings.

The truth whereof wil more clearely appeare in some particulars:§. Sect. 13. Beautie and chastitie seldome meele together. Rara est ad •• concordia formae, at{que} pudicitiae. luuenal. Satyr. 10. Cum pertculo magno custoditur quod multis pla •• t. for if wee take a view of former times and of our owne daies, we shall find that beautie and chastitie are often at oddes, and do seldome dwell together, not because those who are beautifull may not be in their owne nature and inclination as chast as others, if (as I said before) they doe not mollifie and effeminat their minds with sloth and daintines, and so grow light and wanton in their desires; but because they are more exposed to the tentations & assaults of worldly wicked men, who are set on fire with their brightnes, and allured to lust with the bait of their beautie. Now that is most hardly preserued, which is of so many loued and desired, especially when it cannot be hidden, but is subiect to open view, like vnto a rich treasure which is carried vncouered Depredari desiderat, qui th •
s • urum p • blice in vid portat. Gregor. by the high way side, which offereth a kind of violence to their desires that see it, and causeth them to offer violence to the owners, and to seaze vpon by force, that which had first
seazed on their concupiscence. And thus the beautie of Bethsabe 2. Sam. 11. 2. and 13. • . 2. Gen. 12. and 20. and 39. 7. betrayed her chastitie vnto Dauid, and Thamars vnto Amnon, and thus also did it endanger Saraes vnto Pharaoh and Abimel • ch, and Iosephs vnto his mistresse. And therefore one saith, that although beautie be not to be accused, as being the Tertull. de cultu foeminarum lib. felicitie of th • bodie, &c. yet it is to be feared in respect of the iniurie and violence of the beholders; as it also caused Abraham, the father of the faithfull, to feare, because of the beautie of his wife, and faining that Sara was his sister, redeemed his safetie with a reproch. Whereas contrariwise wee shall finde them who want this beautie, easily freed from many impediments; for th • se Chrysost. in 1. Tim. 1. Hom. 4 faulkners for beautie are not very earnest in bringing them to their lure of lust, but like the simple lambe they feed in quiet and in silence, in the presence of their shepheard, there being no wolfe to disturbe their peace. And thus it appeareth true which one saith, that beautie hath made many adulterers, but neuer any
Multos forma fecit adulteros, castum nullum. Petrach. de Remed. lib. 2. dial. 1. chast; and hath been often the bawd and bai • e which hath betraied chastitie, but neuer a patrone to defend it. And though there be some that haue been innocent of this fault, and haue been rich in beautie and in chastitie too, yet few of them haue with all their skill and innocencie kept their names vnblemished, and free from the spots of suspition and iealousie. For whereas (as one saith) those who are not Chrysost. in 1. Tim. 4. Homil. 4. adorned with this beautie, are not only free from fault, but also from suspition; the beautifull woman, vnlesse she vse great care, and much modestie and honestie, though she be innocent in fact, yet will easily make way to an ill opinion. Let vs therefore not so much affect this earthly beautie, which oftentimes is an occasion of sinne, and seldome freed from the suspition thereof; but rather set our hearts and affections on vertue and spirituall graces which adorne the minde with inward beautie, which is not only free from danger of sinne, but also preserueth vs from the least suspition and ielousie of euill; and place all our loue on that heauenly beautie and diuine glorie, of which wee shall haue the sight and fruition after our dissolution; which (as one saith) is not burthensome to Tertul. de cultu foemin. the owners, nor pernicious to them that loue and affect it, nor dangerous to those who are neere vnto vs, nor exposed to tentations,
nor compassed with scandales; but bringeth much ioy to them that behold it, and endlesse happinesse to them that haue it.

Finally, this worldly beautie much hurteth those that haue§. Sect. 14. Beautie maketh proud, and causeth those that haue it to neglect all holy duties. Fastus in est pulchris, sequitur superb a formā. Ouid. 1. Fast. it, by making them proud and insolent, and consequently forgetfull of God and of all good duties which they owe vnto him; neither is there any thing so vaine that maketh so proud, of so small worth, that doth cause the heart to swell more in loftines of conceit, or doth more fill it with selfe loue and admiration of their owne excellencie; nothing of such slight importance that causeth greater negligence in the duties of Gods seruice, seeing it vsually hindreth those that haue it, or that desire to haue it, from comming to the exercises of religion, their time being wholly taken vp in decking and adorning of their bodies, that so their beauties may be set out to the shew; and also much distracteth them when they come, carrying away their thoughts from the exercises of • eligion, and fixing them vpon that which they haue made their idoll: for when they looke vpon others, they either view their forme and beautie, disdaining those who are inferiour, vying with those who are equall, and enuying those who being superiour, seeme to robbe them of the title of excellencie; or else they obserue their habites and attires, that out of this glasse of vanitie they may learne to deck themselues more curiously against their next comming. And as it maketh them proudly to neglect all dutie to God, so also insolent towards men, as appeareth in the example of Vashti, who being puffed vp with pride, because the King was so rauished with her beautie, that hee desiredHest. 1. 11. 12. to make shew of it to his Princes, refused to yeeld obedience vnto his commandement, making no question but that her beautie would haue made peace betweene them at the next parley. Whereby it appeareth, that as nothing more then it adorneth the bodie in the eyes of men▪ so nothing more deformeth the soule in the sight of God, seeing it spotteth and polluteth it with this filthie leprosie of pride, which of all other vices he most loatheth and abhorreth. Whereof it is that the Lord denieth vnto them his sanctifying graces,
which he vouchsafeth only vnto the humble, and opposeth himselfe against them, punishing them oftentimes in that wherein they glorie, and catching them in their owne inueigling nets, which they spred ou • for others; like Absalon who was hanged with his own haire, that wherein he chiefly gloried, being made by God the instrument of his ruine.

But as this worldly beautie is hurtfull to them that haue§. Sect. 15. Beautie deceiueth and allureth vnto sinne. it, so also to others that behold it: for first, it serueth for nothing being seuered from vertue and true godlinesse, but for a curious vaile to hide vnder it all sinne, and to make wickednesse it self, when it is disguised with it, to passe vnsuspected. And this was that vizard wherewith that notable hypocrite Saul was so adorned, that hee deceiued both good Samuel, and all the people, causing him to extoll him, as not being to be matched among all the rest, and mouing them1. Sam. 10. 24. to shoute for ioy, and to crie aloude, God saue the King. But much more doth it hurt, as it is vsed by the diuell and the world for a baite to allure men vnto sinne; and as a shining flame to set their hearts on fire with vnlawfull lusts. In which respect a beautifull woman without vertue, is compared toFormosa meretrix dulce v •
nenum. Vultus veneris, habet ictum scorpionis. a sweete poyson which killeth with delight, and their glancing lookes to the stroke of Scorpions, or the sting of Vipers, which bringeth death in a sweete slumber; or else to a burning coale, which being it selfe first kindled, inflameth those also that are neere vnto it; or as Salomon compareth it, to a sword, which, whilest it glittereth, woundeth, yea a two edged sword, the one hurting those that haue it, with pride,Prou. 5. 4. the other those which behold it, with lust and wantonnes. And thus were the sonnes of God wounded, whilest they beheld the beautie of the daughters of men; thus was Putiphars Gen. 6. 1. 2. Gen. 39. 2. 2. Sam. 13. 1. 2. wife inflamed with the sight of Ioseph; thus was Amnon sick of lust, hauing suffered his eyes to drinke their fill of this sweete poyson; yea and with this snare was holy Dauid 1. Sam. 11. 2. caught, whilest his eyes wantonly wandred and beheld the beautie of his seruants wife. And hence it is that Salomon seeking to preserue his youthfull scholler from the sinne of vncleannes, thinketh it not enough to haue him so farre off from the beautiful harlot, that he cannot heare the bewitchingProu. 5. 24. 25.
eloquence of her flattering tongue, but also that he stand aloofe, and keepe himselfe as it were out of the gunshot of her deadly wounding eyes. The consideration wherof madeIn quaest. ex vtro{que} mixtin • . 115. the beautifull Thuscan (as Augustine recordeth) to deforme his ouer-louelie face with grieflie wounds, lest it should become a snare to intangle the beholders with vnlawfull lusts; being herein, as I take it, as blind in zeale, as he was bright in beautie; seeing it might haue sufficed to haue couered it with the chast vaile of a sober and graue countenance, which by taking away al hope of obtaining, would also haue quenched the heate of wanton desires; neither ought he to haue kept others from abuse, by abusing it himselfe, nor to haue reiected Gods gift which to him was good, for feare lest others should abuse it vnto euill. But as we are not to ioyne with him in this extreame, so let vs as carefully auoid the other: and hauing beautie, let vs not wantonly discouer it as though we brought it to the market; or being in others, let vs either with Iob turne away our eyes, that we do not behold it, or at least let vs looke vpon it through the glasse of modestie, chastity and sobrietie, and so this Cockatrice shall neuer hurt vs. And this counsell the Sonne of Syrach giueth vs: Turne away (saith he) thine eye from a beautifull woman, and looke not on others beautie, seeing many haue perished by the beauty of women, for through it loue is kindled as a fire. To whichBasil. Admonit. ad filium spirit. accordeth the admonition of another: Let vs shun (saith he) these pernicious beauties, lest they inioyne vs to commit all manner of euill, &c. Take heed my sonne of viewing those formes, by which thou seest many haue perished; do not drinke, I pray thee, of that cup wherewith so many haue been poysoned, feed not of that meat whereon such multitudes haue surfetted, rush not vpon that rocke, whereupon so many haue suffered shipwracke, and carefully auoid those hidden snares wherein thou hast seene so many taken.

But as this worldly beautie is hurtfull to strangers, so oftentimes§. Sect. 16. Beautie oftentimes hurtfull to the friends of those who excell in it. to neerest friends; for it is a common occasion, and the vsuall fuell, wherewith the consuming fire of iealousie is kindled, whilest the husband beholding his wiues beautie with the eye of loue, groweth in feare of riuals, and considereth the great difficultie of appropriating that to his owne
vse, which is of so many affected and desired; the which feare making him fit to entertaine all suspitions, and many suspitions seruing to his iealous mind for an euident demonstration, do make way for rage against his wife, the ouerflowing of loue turning into the gaule of furie, for enuie and hatred against his supposed riuall, and for torment and vexation to his owne soule. Againe, this worldly beautie seuered from vertue doth often expose neerest friends to many dangers, as sometimes to secret poysons, and sometimes to open violence, because they stand in the way, and hinder those who are intangled with it, from satisfying their lusts, and enioying their wanton and lasciuious desires. For if this beautie had these dangerous and deadly effects in Sara, who thereby vnwillingly exposed Abraham to the hazard of his life; & in Bethsabe, whose beautie was the cause of her husbands ruine, both which notwithstanding were vertuous women, and feared God: how much more pernicious is it in those who are destitute of vertue, modestie and sobrietie, who are not only occasions, but also accessaries and helpers forward of these mischifes, being allured hereunto by their wicked louers?

Seeing then this worldly beautie hath in it no worth or§. Sect. 17. That we should fixe our loue on diuine beautie. excellencie, but is altogether vnprofitable, yea hurtfull and pernicious, both to them that excell in it, and to those that are neere vnto them: let vs weane our hearts from the loue of this vanitie, and learne to contemne and despise it both in our selues and others; and if we will needs be inamored with beautifull obiects, let vs fixe our hearts vpon God, who is not only beautifull, but beautie it selfe, and so infinit in this and all other perfections, that all the beautie of all the creatures in heauen and earth is but as a small sparke in comparison of the glorious brightnesse of this Sunne: and therefore let the beautie of the creatures serue but as a scale, whereby our meditations may ascend to contemplate the infinite beautie of the Creator: for neglect of which vse of the creatures excellencies, the Author of the booke of Wisdome condemneth men: Surely (saith he) all men are vaine by nature, and are ignorant of God, and could not know him that is, by the good things
that are seene, neither consider by the workes the worke-master, &c. though they had such pleasure in their beautie, &c. yet should they haue knowne, how much more excellēt he is that made them; for the first author of beautie hath created these things.

And if we will needs be in loue with any thing in our§. Sect. 18. That the beauty of the soule is much more excellent then the beautie of the bodie. Chrysost. in Matth. 10. homil. 35. selues, let vs place our chiefe affection next vnto God vpon our soule, as being in it selfe much more excellent in beautie then our bodies, & the cause also of all bodily beautie; for according as the soule is affected, so is the beauty of the body encreased or abated: if the mind be merrie, the face is beautified with a cheerefull countenance; if touched with griefe and sorrow, presently all outward beauty vanisheth: if the mind be terrified and affrighted, presently this astonishment appeareth in the gastly palenes of the visage; if it be in peace and quietnesse, then the face also is pleasant and amiable; if the mind bee affected with enuie, it maketh the body and face leane and wan; if with loue which is honest and moderate, it maketh the face also to looke with a louely sweetnes; if the mind be inraged, the looke also is furious, if well pleased, contentment appeareth in the very countenance; if the soule be adorned with modestie, it will shew it selfe in the bashfulnesse of the looke, but if it be impudent, the face also is bold and shamelesse: so that the chiefe beauty of the body is deriued from the soule, and hereof it is that many haue no gracefulnesse in their countenance, who haue no blemish in their face, nor imperfection in their fauour; and contrariwise, that many who haue little excellencie either in their fauour or complexion, doe neuerthelesse exceed in a louely gracefulnesse, which they haue not from the bodie, but from some secret operation of the soule: but most clearely this appeareth in the vnion and separation of the soule and bodie; for whilest they are ioyned together their beauty also flourisheth and continueth; but no sooner are they diuided, and the bodie parted from the soule, then the beauty also is parted from the body, so that that face which not an houre ago was admired and loued for beauty and excellencie, is now abhorred and loathed forvglines and deformitie. And therefore seeing the body hath nothing but what it borroweth,
and only yeeldeth a place or roome wherein the soule may shew forth his excellencies: let vs not dote vpon this bodily beauty, but set our hearts and affections on the inward beauty of the soule, labouring more and more to adorne it with vertue and Gods sanctifying graces, which will not fade and perish, that so also we may attaine vnto the fruition of that eternall beautie and goodnesse, which will bring with it fulnesse of ioy and happinesse, that shall endure for euermore.

div.head: CHAP. XIIII.
Of the vanity and wickednesse of painting the face.
div.p:
ANd thus haue I shewed that worldly beauty is§. Sect. 1. That the diuell was the inuenter of this art of painting. to be contemned of Christians, and the reasons which may induce them to despise it: I will adde something of the counterfeit thereof, painting and colouring of the face, commonly vsed by vaine women, that hereby they may get the praise of beauty by their art, which nature hath denied vnto them. The which is not like the other, euill onely in regard of abuse, but vtterly vnlawfull, wicked and abominable in it owne nature, and in the generall practise thereof; as offending not only against the law of God, but also the light of nature; seeing they who haue not a dram of grace, nor a sparke of true knowledge, doe brand it with the note of ignominie and reproach wheresoeuer it is discouered; yea euen those who practise it doe condemne it in their owne consciences, and would be much ashamed (if long custome hath not made them impudent) to be taken with the fact. But that all Christians may be moued to detest and abhorre this wicked practise; let them consider that God is not the author of this beauty, but the diuell himselfe, who bringeth Haec non sunt membra quae Deus fecit, sed quae diabolus infecit. Cyprian. de Velan. Virgin. lib. the works of God into disgrace, not only by counterfeiting them, but by labouring to excell them. With this accordeth the iudgement of that godly Father, and blessed martyr Cyprian, who thinketh that when the wicked angels (professing • oue to lewde women that they might destroy them) abused
their bodies to filthinesse, for the hire and wages of their wickednesse, they taught and instructed them in this art of painting; and thereof inferreth, that these painted parts are not of Gods making, but of the diuels staining and corrupting; now what impietie is this in those who professe Christianity, that being formed by God, they should seek to be reformed and perfected by the diuell? To the same purpose Tertullian saith, that the diuell hath certainely deuised these
Ille indubit •
tè huiusmodi ingenia concinnauit, vt in nobis quodam modo manus deo inferret. De cult. foemin. pag. 514. arts, that he might in vs oppose himselfe against God. And affirmeth that to be Gods worke which is borne, and that the diuels which is counterfeited: and what hellish wickednesse is this, to ad vnto Gods workes the diuels arts and ornaments? our seruants borrow not from our foes, the souldier desireth nothing from the enemies of his chiefe commander; and shall a Christian desire helpe of that wicked one, who is Gods and their professed enemie?

Againe, let them consider, that as it hath an euill author,§. Sect. 2. Painting, both the effect and cause of sinne. so it is in it selfe euill, as springing from the roote of sinne, and bringing foorth abundance of these cursed fruits. The roote from which it springeth, is sometimes pride, which moueth them, when they cannot match others in naturall beautie, to vse these artificiall helps, that thereby they may excell them in that which is counterfait. And sometime it springeth from lust, and the inward vncleannesse of the hart, which moueth them to vse these inueigling arts, that by seeming more beautifull then they are, they may ensnare the affections of those who looke vpon them. And as it is bred of these cursed parents, so it self is exceeding fruitful in bringing foorth the impious off-spring of manifold sinnes committed both against God, their neighbour and themselues. Against God they offend; by presuming to adulterate his worke, and by taking vpon them to amend that, which, (as they suppose) he hath made amisse; for they secretly reprehend the workman, when they are displeased with his work, and seeme to taske him for want of wisdome and cunning, when they take vpon them to correct and make better that which he hath left vnperfected. To this purpose is that ofCyprian: tract. 2. de habit. virg. pag. 109. Cyprian: God saith, Let vs make man according to our image
and similitude, and dare any presume to change and alter that which God hath made? In so doing, they offer violence to God, when as they striue to reforme, and transforme that which hee hath formed; for that which is borne, is the work of God, and that which is changed, the worke of the diuell. If a skilfull painter, hauing cunninglie limb'd the portrature of a mans bodie, and seeing another take vpon him to mend his workemanship, would be mooued to anger, and thinke himselfe much iniured; doest thou thinke to goe vnpunished for thy rash boldnesse, in presuming to amend the worke of God?

They offend also against men, by deceiuing and abusing§. Sect. 3. That these painters deceiue and abuse others. Fucum facere, id est, decipere. Absque fu • o, id est, candidè & apertè. them, making them to admire a painted picture, in stead of the worke of God; and so notable is this cousenage, that in the Latin phrase, they are said to colour or paint, who by their words or actions deceiue another, and to vse no painting or colouring, who deale ingenuouslie, truly, and in simplicitie. But much more doe they sinne against them, whilest by these diuellish arts counterfeiting beautie, they inflame the hearts of those, who behold them, with filthie and vnlawfull lusts; the which was (as I take it) the chiefe cause why Satan inuented it, and wicked women practise it. And hence it is, that one calleth this painting, and counterfeit beautie, the fire of youth, the fuell of lust, and the signe which Hiero • ym. sheweth where an vnchast heart dwelleth.

But most of al do they, who vse this art, wrong themselues,§. Sect. 4. That they most of all offend against themselues: in being ashamed of their owne person. and sinne against their owne bodies and soules: for if they offer great iniurie to their friends, who when they come into companie, are ashamed of them; then much more do they thus offend, who are ashamed of themselues? and therefore being displeased with their owne colour and countenance, like players, they come disguised in the similitude of other persons, and for want of a better, they act their part in the habit of an harlot. Now what is this but vnnaturally to denie themselues, and to thrust (as it were) another into their owne place? what is it but to make themselues counterfeit idols, that vnto them lust may offer the sacrifices of vncleannesse? what is it, but to expose themselues to the scorne and laughter of those, who hauing seene their glorious beautie
which they counterfeited, shall afterwards happen to see them in their owne complexion and naturall foulenesse; like a Player, who hauing acted a kingly part, and put off all his gorgeous ornaments, doth now appeare in his owne person and attire; sauing that herein it is much more absurd, in that they professe this disguising, and these dissemble it, desiring that it should be taken in good earnest, which the other doe in iest to make sport.

Againe, whilest they labour to attaine vnto this counterfeit§. Sect. 5. That they destroy their naturall beautie, and disgrace their names. complexion, they lose that true beautie which they haue by nature; for with their medicines and minerals which they vse to this purpose, they make their colour pale and wan, they wrinckle the face, yea, oftentimes poison the skin, and dimme the eiesight, and so ouergreedily seeking false beautie, they get true deformitie, and make themselues loathsome indeed, that they may appeare beautifull in shew. And yet this is but the least part of their losse: for as they blemish their skinne, so they blot and disgrace their names, whilest following the practise of harlots, they deseruedly gaine for all their labour, their reputation; and to bee ranged and esteemed in their fellowship, whose maners they imitate. For this outward painting of these earthly houses, maketh men thinke that they are to be let; and by hanging out this signe of lust, they seeme to inuite customers, and to offer their honestie to the sale at easie rates. Of which fault, though some may be free, (as falling into this follie by the example of others, and through the corruption of the times) yet few or none escape iust iealousie and suspition; (and Christians should auoid not onely euill, but the appearance thereof) for who▪ would buy this vaine beautie with the hazard of their soules, but they, who mind to sell that which they haue thus dearely bought, when they haue fit occasion? Neither in truth is it likely that they De adulterio vultus meditantur adul ••
rium Castitatis. Ambros. de virginib. lib. §. Sect. 6. will long stand firmely vpon this slipperie ground; but vsing the meanes, will come to the end, and (as one saith) hauing adulterated their face, they will soone after thinke of adultering their chastitie, and defiling their bodies.

Finally, as they disgrace their names, so also their profession
of religion, whilest professing themselues the membersThey that vse it slander their profession of religion. of Christ, they behaue themselues like the limmes of Satan. For what a shame is this, that there should bee no difference betweene a Christian, and a Pagan, a matrone and a strumpet, the spouse of Christ, and a filthie harlot, betweene one that professeth her selfe, bought with the precious blood of Christ, and another, that is sold ouer to worke wickednes, and is branded with ye marke of impiety to acknowledge the sale? but that both alike should vse the same light habit and attire, and the same diuellish arts to commend themselues by a false beautie? The best beautie of a Christian woman is modestie and shamefastnesse, and their best ornament is simplicitie, and humility; but how farre are they1. Cor. 5. 8. from simplicitie and truth, who lie and dissemble, euen when they say nothing▪ speaking in a reall language falshood and dissimulation, euen with their very countenance, to as many as looke vpon them? vnlesse they thinke that onely verball vntruth is forbidden, and actuall falshood permitted; or that it is a greater fault to dissemble in speeches, then to deceaue in deeds and actions. And how farre are they from this Christian humilitie, who rather then they will not shew their pride, vaunt themselues of a counterfeit beautie, and for want of better matter, grow high in their owne conceit, because they haue this false shadow of true beautie, which indeed is it selfe but a shadow, in respect of any substantiall good? How farre are they from that graue decencie, which the Apostle requireth in Christian matrons, seeing they cannot1. Pet. 3. 1. 2. content themselues with gold, pretious iewels, and broidred haire, vnlesse they also adorne their heads with the spoiles of the dead, and grace themselues with a gracelesse and whorish beautie? But let such know, that they deceaue themselues with a title of Christianity, seeing they denie the truth thereof in their liues; and that howsoeuer they adorne themselues with the profession of Christians, yet (as one saith) they can neuer put on the true garment Christ Iesus: Cyprian. de cult • virginum. lib. neither will the oyle of his sanctifying graces, and these beautifying waters, and minerall dust euer mix together.

div.head: CHAP. XV.
That bodily strength is not much to be esteemed, as being of small worth and excellencie.
div.p:
ANd thus haue I spoken of those worldly tentations,§. Sect. 1. That bodily strength being in it selfe good, is often abused through our corruption. which are grounded vpon beautie. Now wee are to speake of those which arise from strength and health, both which are in themselues the good blessings of God, whereby we are the better inabled to serue him in all good duties; for in them our first parents excelled in the state of innocencie, and wee also shall much excell them in the state of glorie; for our bodies are sowne in corruption, but they shall 1. Cor. 15. rise in vncorruption, they are sowne in weakenes, but they shall be raised in power, as the Apostle telleth vs; and therefore being the gifts of God, wherewith he most inriched vs in the state of innocencie, and will crowne vs in the state of glorie, they must needs be good in their owne nature, and to those who
haue a right vse of them. But yet through the malice of our spirituall enemies these gifts of God (like all other benefits of prosperitie) are vnto vs the grounds of their tentations, wherewith they draw vs vnto sinne; and their nature being infected with our corruption, they are oftentimes abused vnto euill; as when hauing them we glorie in them, or preferre them before spirituall graces, and the meanes of eternall glorie; or finally, when as by them wee are hindred in the course of godlinesse, or furthered and strengthened in the way of wickednesse. And therefore in the next place we are to arme the Christian, yt he may not be ouercome of his own strength, & that his health be not vnto him the meanes of bringing him to death eternall. But I shall not need to speake much of this▪ seeing that armour which was brought out to defend vs against the assaults of worldly beautie, may by the wise reader be easily fitted against these incounters also; and seeing also this decrepit age of the world (which now seemeth almost quite abandoned of that strength and vigorous health wherein the former ages haue excelled; and to be fully replenished with all manner of infirmities, sicknesse, and weaknesse) needeth not so much to be confirmed and preserued against the tentations which are grounded on this lionlike strength, as against those which arise from serp • ntine subtiltie, and foxlike wilinesse.

And yet because strength is no more abated, then pride§. Sect. 2. That it is a great vanitie to glorie in strēgth, seeing God esteemeth it not, and the beast • excell in it. increased; and men are apt to glorie in these things, though nothing in themselues, yet when being compared they exceed others of our owne times; it shall not be amisse to vse briefly some reasons whereby wee may be preserued against these tentations. And first concerning strength (vnder which I also comprehend, actiuitie, nimblenes, swiftnes, and such like esteemable properties of the bodie) wee are not, as the Lord exhorteth vs, to glorie in it; nor ouerweening theIer • m. 9. • 3: worth of it, to preferre it before things of much better value; because being thus compared, it is of no great excellencie, and vnto vs oftentimes vnprofitable, and sometimes also hurtful and inconuenient. It is of no great worth, seeing the Lord himselfe doth little esteeme it: for as Elihu saith,
he regardeth not them that excell in strength: and as the PsalmistIob 36. 19. Psal. 147. 10. speaketh, he hath no pleasure in the strength of an horse, neither delighteth he in the legges of man. And therefore hee maketh this also one of his common gifts, which he giueth to the reprobate, as well as to the elect, and vnto beasts (and that in farre greater measure) as well as vnto men. How vaine therefore are those who are proud of such base vanities? wherein many wicked men match them, and many beasts doe farre excell them; how little good haue they in them, when they are faine to glorie in that, in which when they haue attained vnto the greatest measure which possibilitie incourageth them to desire, yet they come farre short of giants among men, and of the horse, bull, lion, and many other among the brutish creatures? To this purpose Chrysostome demandeth; Art thou strong (saith he) and art thou therfore proud? why the thing wherein thou gloriest is base, for the lion is
Fortis es, & altum sapis? At res vilissima; nam & leo est teaudacior, & aper fortior, &c. Homil. ad pop. 40. tom. 4. hardier then thou, and the bore stronger; yea robbers, theeues, and ruffians, and thine owne seruants herein excell thee, and doest thou think this a thing esteemeable or praise worthie? The like also may bee said, of nimblenes, actiuitie, and swiftnes. For when in nimblenes and actiuitie thou exceedest all men, yet an ape doth farre surpasse thee; and though thou couldest runne as swiftly as Asahel, yet the sillie Hare would far outstrip thee. Seeing therefore God hath vouchsafed thee the honour of a man, glorie not in that wherein the beasts excell thee, and seeing he hath made thee a Christian, abuse not so much the worth of thine owne excellencies, as (setting aside all thy better parts) to be proud of that wherein Pagans and Heathens haue ouermatched thee. But (as one saith) when
Isto bo • o vtere dum adsit, cum absit ne requiras. Cic. de Senect. thou hast this strength, vse it whilest it is present; and when it is absent, neuer much desire it.

Againe, let vs consider that if it were of any worth and excellencie, yet it is not much to be esteemed, because it is§. Sect. 3. That bodilie strength is momentanie, and but of short continuance. momentanie, and of such short continuance; for oftentimes it is by a weekes sicknes weakened and impaired, euen in the prime of youth, and so forsaketh vs, as soone as it hath but saluted vs, as though it had only come to take leaue: our youthfull yeeres and perfect age remaining as weake and decrepit,
as if we had continued the time of the • ongest liuer. But say that sicknesse spareth vs, yet as old age approcheth, strength decreaseth, after which death hasteneth, which doth wholly abolish it, making the strongest giant & the weakest wretch both alike. Consider further, that this huge strength of the body, is commonly ioyned with great weaknes of the mind; and where there is the greatest bone, there vsually is the least wisedome and vnderstanding. In which respect Themistocles Plutarch. compared the Eretrienses, a people more strong then wise, to the Swordfish, which hath a weapon but wants a heart. Neither doth it helpe to furnish the minde with any vertues, or maketh it more readie to any vertuous actions; but as those trees which are most great and strong, are commonly most vnfruitfull; so oftentimes those who excell in strength, are most barren in bearing the fruites of vertue, and least forward in such actions as sauour of goodnesse. Nor doth this bodily strength assist the soule in moderating of our affections, and in ouer-ruling of our passions; it doth not helpe to asswage anger, to bridle lust, or to stoppe our course, when wee runne to take reuenge; yea contrariwise being abused by our corruptions, it pricketh forward our rage with the spurres of armed furie; it maketh men more able slaues to their owne filthinesse, and in stead of stopping vs in reuengefull courses, it rather hasteth vs forward with headlong swiftnes, and putteth a sword of violence into our hands, whereby wee may not only requite old iniuries, but also reuenge apparances of wrongs with extreame crueltie. Yea it not only encourageth those that haue confidence in their owne strength, without reason or conscience, to oppresse and tyrannically to tread vnder foote those whom they find themselues able to ouermatch; but so puffeth them vp in pride in regard of their owne abilities, that they are readie with desperate furie to make warre against heauen, and hauing gotten the victorie ouer men, to set vpon and encounter God himselfe. As appeareth in the example of that mightie Nimrod and his associates; and in Goliah, whoGen. 11. not onely insulted ouer all Sauls armie in confidence of his
owne strength, but also was at defiance with God himselfe,1. Sam. 17. 45. and railed on the holy one of Israel.

Finally, let vs consider that this vaine strength wherin men§. Sect. 4. Bodily strength cannot deliuer vs from c •• ls and innumerable dangers. Psalm. 33. 16. trust, cannot deliuer them from those innumerable dangers and euils vnto which our fraile life is daily subiect: for as the Psalmist saith, The King is not saued by the multitude of an host, neither is the mightie man deliuered by his great strength: it cannot defend them from the iudgements of God in the day of his visitation, no • from the furious assaults of their spirituall enemies when they encounter them: it cannot keepe away sicknesses and diseases, much lesse deliuer them from the power of death: yea rather it exposes men to danger, their strength ministring vnto them more incouragement and boldnesse to run into perils, then power and abilitie to escape or ouercome them; for seldome is there any so strong, but that at one time or other he meetes with one as able as himselfe; and though there be none to match him, yet (like Milo) he may be catched in his owne trap, and his owne strength may be the cause of his ruine, whilest his pride maketh him to vndergo a greater burthen then hee is able to beare, & to attempt matters which are aboue humane power to accomplish and performe. And therefore seeing this bodily strength is vaine and momentanie, vnprofitable, and oftentimes hurtfull and dangerous: let vs not glorie in it, nor too much value and esteeme it, but rather let vs desire to be powerfull in the inner man, and to waxe stronger in all vertues and spirituall graces; but especially let vs carefully desireEphes. 6. 10. to bee strengthened with the power of Gods might,Philip. 4. 13. whereby (as the Apostle speaketh) we shall be inabled to do al things, and to stand manfully in the day of battaile against all the cruell assaults of our spirituall enemies, with assured hope of victory: which will easily ouercome vs notwithstanding our bodily strength, if this spirituall power and secret vertue of Gods spirit do faile and forsake vs in the time of triall.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.
That bodily health is but of small worth and excellencie.
div.p:
ANd thus much cōcerning bodily strength. The§. Sect. 1. H • al •• it selfe is a great blessing, but m • ch abused through our corruption. Eccles. 30. 15. 16. like also may bee said of health, which in it own nature is the good blessing of God, and a notable helpe to those that vse it well, for the better performance of all good duties: in which respect the Son of Syrach saith, That health and strength are aboue gold, & a whole body aboue infinit treasure, there is no riches aboue a sound body, & no ioy aboue the ioy of the heart. Yea in truth there is scarce any earthly blessing to bee compared with it, seeing it much lessens all our sorrowes and afflictions, and sweetneth all other comforts and worldly benefits, which being seuered from it, become tedious & loathsome. Howbe it this blessing of God through our corruption is continually subiect to great abuse, as when we esteeme it aboue Gods spirituall graces, and the health of our soules, and do set our hearts so vpon it, as that we will not sticke to vse wicked and vnlawfull meanes, to preserue it whilest we haue it, or recouer it when we want it; or finally, when thereby we are not furthered in the seruice of God, and in all good and Christian duties. For howsoeuer whilest we haue it, we are with all thankfulnesse to esteeme it, as being a great blessing of God; and when we want it, to desire it moderately, and to vse all good meanes for the recouery of it: yet when it commeth in comparison of Gods sanctifying§. Sect 2. That health is but a comm •• gift, which is imparted also to the wicked. Sanita. • m corporis neputes magn • m b num esse, quod habet & malus. A •
gust. S • rm. 12. tom. 10. col. 57. gifts, or the spirituall health of the soule, which is accompanied with eternall life, it is to be contemned and despised, as being light, vaine, and of no value.

To which purpose let vs consider, that howsoeuer health be good, yet it is but a common good, which the Lord imparteth to the wicked, as well as to the godly: and therefore (as one saith) we are not to esteeme bodily health a great good, which euen wicked men also enioy: and oftentimes in a far greater measure then Gods dearest seruants: for as the Psalmist
obserued, The wicked are lustie and strong, they are not in trouble Psal. 73. 4. 5. 7. as other men, neither are plagued with other men, their eyes stand out with fatnes, and they haue more then heart can wish. Yea it is communicated vnto the bruit beasts, many of which enioy it longer, and in a much more perfect and excellent manner then man doth. To which purpose one saith, Why do August. Serm. in festo paschae. de Alleluia. tom. 10. c. 1533. Psalm. 36. 6. ye wonder because these men inioy health, when as ye heare the Psalmist saying, O Lord thou makest whole, or conseruest men and beasts? that men might not waxe proud because they haue temporall health, the beasts are ioyned with them: why therefore doest thou reioyce O man because of health, seeing this benefit is common to thee with thine asse. &c, and therefore rest not in this, but rather seeke to obtaine the speciall benefits which are promised to the sonnes of men: for to what purpose serue reason and the excellent wit of man, if he attaine vnto nothing better then that which is common to him with the beasts?

Againe, how worthlesse and void of excellencie this bodily§. Sect. 3. That bodily health is momentanie and vncertaine. health is, it may appeare, first, in that it is momentanie and vncertaine; for euen when it is at the height, euery trifeling accident doth ouerthrow it; too much heat, or too much cold, want of nourishment or a little excesse, ouermuch labour or too much ease, besides a thousand secret and inward causes, ouerturne health and make way for sicknesse and diseases. In which respect one saith, that this which wee vsually Gregor. Moral. lib. 8. cap. 20. call health of the bodie, is in truth sicknesse; seeing ease it selfe is sufficient to bring it into a consumption, and labor also doth cause it to faile: being spent with fasting, it is refreshed with meat, that it may continue, and being tired and wasted with ouermuch eating, it is relieued with abstinence, that it may grow stronger: the bodie is washed with water, that it may not be ouer drie, and then wiped with clothes, that it may not be too much moistned and softned; it is refreshed with labour, that it may not grow sluggish with case; and cherished with rest, that it may not sinke vnder the burthen of labour; it is wearied with watching, and repaired with sleepe, and being oppressed with too much sleepe, this sluggishnesse is shaken off with watchfulnesse, lest it should be spent and wearied more with rest then with it labour. It is couered with clothes, that it may not feele the iniuries of the weather, and fainting with
ouermuch heate, it is refreshed with the fanning of the coole aire. And hauing found troubles and griefes in that wherein it thought to haue auoided them, being sore wounded (as I may say) it languisheth, and waxeth weaker with the very medicine, that should haue cured it. Though therefore feauers be absent, and griefes of bodie cease, euen our very health is no better then a sicknes, vnto which necessitie of cure is neuer wanting: for looke how many helpes and comforts we seeke out for the vse of life, euen so many medicines doe we find to free vs from diseases; and oftentimes the salue it selfe turneth to a wound; because vsing an excellent remedie a little too long, we are much impaired by that, which wee prouided for our cure. To the same purpose another saith, that August. in Psal. 37. enatrat. tom. 8. that which is called the health of this life, to them that vnderstand it aright, and do compare it with that which we shal inioy in our eternall rest, it is not esteemed worthie the name of health. For if we doe not eate, hunger vexeth vs, and what is this hunger, but a naturall disease? because nature it selfe by Gods iust vengeance is made vnto vs a punishment; and that which to the first man was punishment, is vnto vs turned into nature, &c.

Secondly, it is most imperfect, our whole life being like§. Sect. 4.
