That bodily health is imperfect, and full of infirmities. a continuall ague, which, euery second or third day, interchangeth health with sicknesse; neither is there any so strong and healthie, that hath not some griefes and infirmities which often vex him; although the pleasures and businesses of the world giue him not leasure to take great notice of them; and the youth and strength of his bodie doth enable him to beare his burden with more ease and cheerefulnesse. Or though it should be granted, that a man were quite free from all these bodily infirmities; yet if he hath many diseases in his soule, hee cannot bee said to haue any perfection of health, when as his best part is thus affected: for as it were ridiculous, if a man should glorie in his health, because hee is sound in his outward lims, when in the mean time he hath the megrim in his head, the consumption in his lungs, and incurable diseases about his heart, and other chiefe and vital parts; so is it no lesse absurd to be proud of our bodily health, when as our soules which are the chiefe part of man, and the life of all the rest, are desperately sicke in the diseases of sin.
For what is this, but to haue a faire skinne, and sicke hart, a beautifull outside, full and faire, and within, a desperate dropsie, or vnrecouerable pleurisie? like vnto an apple, which is faire to the eie, and rotten at the core. But so long as wee carie about with vs the old man, and dwel in these houses of clay, we are continually subiect to these diseases of the soule, and will we nill we, we shall often wound our consciences, and make our selues sicke with sinne; the which our bodilie health is so far off from helping and curing, that oftentimes it occasioneth, and most commonly increaseth these spirituall diseases; in regard whereof one saith, a sicke mind dwelleth Nusquam peius quam in sano corpore, aeger animus habitat. Petrarch. lib. 1. Dial. 4. no where worse then in a sound bodie. And therefore little cause haue we to bragge of this bodily health, being in it selfe vaine, fraile and imperfect, and besides alwaies accompanied with the soules sicknesse, which is so dangerous and grieuous, that nothing can cure it but the blood of Christ.

But as this bodily health is not much to be esteemed, in§. Sect. 5. The manifold euils which vsually accompanie bodily health. respect that it bringeth vnto vs little good; so much lesse in regard, that through our corruption, it is often the cause of much hurt; for who seeth not, that where there is the most healthfull bodie, there commonly is the sickest soule? who seeth not great difference betweene them, who lie in their sicke beds, and those whose health is neuer impaired with any dangerous sicknesse? Yea, who findeth not great dissimilitude betweene himselfe being sicke, and himselfe inioying perfect health? how deuout he is then, how fearefull to offend God, how watchfull ouer his waies, how readie he is to cal himself to a reckoning, that he may set things straight betweene God and himselfe. And contrariwise, how negligent hee is now, how hard harted and carnally secure, putting away from him the euill day, and together with it the day of repentance; presuming vpon his health and strength, and thinking that he may haue time enough hereafter to repent, and make euen his reckonings with God. Whereby it appeareth, that the health of the bodie, is oftentimes a cause of the soules sicknesse; euen as contrariwise, the bodies sicknesse is often a meanes of the soules recouerie, and seldome
shall we find them both in any great measure in the same man; vnlesse the corruptions which vsually attend vpon health, be purged away with some other bitter potion of affliction. To which purpose one saith, that God foreseeing
Quosdam presciens deus peccare posse, in salutem flag • llat cos iufirmitate corporis ne peccent. Bernard. de interior. domo, cap. 46. that some would fall through the abuse of their health into sinne, doth correct them for their profit with weakenesse of bodie, that they may not offend; and maketh it more profitable vnto them to he broken with griefes to their saluation, then to remain in health to their condemnation. For that health is pernicious which leadeth to disobedience, euen as that sicknesse is wholesome, which by Gods correction, doth break and humble the hardnes of the hart. Finally, nothing more then this bodily health doth naile mens hearts to the earth, or make them more in loue with the world, and worldly vanities, nothing more causeth men to giue themselues ouer to voluptuous pleasures; from which weakenesse and infirmity weaneth them; which being intertained, like vnthankful guests, thrust out of the doores their host that gaue them their best welcome; for as nothing more easilie moueth vs to admit and imbrace these voluptuous pleasures of the flesh, then bodily health, so nothing more impaires, and banisheth health then they, when they are intertained. And therefore seeing this bodily health through our abuse, doth more often hurt, then helpe vs in our spirituall estate; and doth much more weaken the soule, then strengthen the body; let vs not too much dote on it whilest we haue it, nor much bewaile our losse, when it is taken from vs; but seeing it is so subiect to abuse, let vs keepe a speciall watch ouer our selues whilest we inioy it, that we may so vse it, that God who gaue it, may bee more glorified and better serued, & we who haue it, may be helped forward in all good duties, and grow more & more in grace, and in the assurance of our saluation. For otherwise it wil rather be a curse vnto vs Admonendi sunt incolumes vt salutem corporis exerceant ad salutem mentis, &c. Gregor. pastoral. par. 3. cap: 13. then a blessing, which wee were much better profitably to want, then so hurtfully to inioy. And (as one saith) let vs being in health be admonished, that we so vse this bodily health, as that it may further the spiritual health of our soules, lest peruerting the benefit of our health to the practise of wickednesse, we be made worse by Gods gift; and so receiue more grieuous punishments
hereafter, the lesse wee haue feared to abuse so bountifull blessings of God vnto sinne.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.
That societie and neere familiarity with wicked worldlings is to be shunned and auoided.
div.p: ANd thus much concerning such worldly tentations,§. Sect. 1. That the world allureth vs by wicked companie, to accompanie them in sin. as haue their ground and foundation on some thing which is in our selues. Now it followeth that I intreate of such, as are caused and occasioned by somwhat that is without vs; for as the world, and the prince thereof seeke to ouercome vs, by causing our selues to betray our selues, and to become the instruments of our owne ruine; so if they faile of this, then they busilie muster against vs forren forces, and with them besiege the fort of our soules, that so they may sacke and spoile vs of all spirituall graces, and may leade vs captiue to destruction. Now these forces consist either in the persons of worldlings themselues, or in worldly things, which they vse as their baites and allurements, wherewith they intice vs vnto sinne. In the former respect the world tempteth vs, when it draweth vs into the fellowship and societie, or neere familiaritie, and inward friendship of wicked men, that being corrupted with their company and friendship, we may either bee hindred in our course of godlinesse, or allured to goe with them in the broad way of sinne, that bringeth to destruction:

Which tentation that wee may ouercome, let vs arme§. Sect. 2. That all societie with wicked men is not vnlawfull. our selues against it; and lest wee should reiect the good with the euill, in the first place let vs consider in what respects societie with worldlings is permitted as lawfull, and how it is condemned as vnlawfull and euill, that so neither going aside on the right hand, nor on the left, we • may hold on in that straight way which the word of God prescribeth vnto vs. For the former we are to know, that not all mannerQuaerit solitudinem qui vult cum innocentibus v • uere. of societie with wicked men is forbidden, nor yet to almen: For (as one saith) he must goe into the solitary deserts, who will
liue only with those who are innocent. And the Apostle telleth vs, that if we will not at all come into the companie of fornicators 1. Cor. 5. 10. of this world, or with the couetous, or with extortioners, or with idolaters, we must then leaue the world also. And therfore we must not follow the foolish dotage of Popish Hermits and Anchorists, who make it a high degree of their perfection to liue alone, and to sequester themselues from al societie of men; for as the Heathen man could say, he that wilArist. de rep. lib. 1. cap. 2. content himselfe with himselfe, and leaue the companie of all others, had need to be either a God, whom none can mend, or a sauage beast, who hateth humane fellowship, and will not come neere them, vnlesse it be to destroy or hurt them.

It is lawfull then in some cases to keepe companie with§. Sect. 3. In what cases it is lawfull to come in companie with wicked men. wicked worldlings. As for example, when humane societie, and common ciuilitie doth require it; neither is it possible to liue in a common wealth, vnlesse we obserue the rules of ciuilitie, and performe mutuall duties of citizens, and neighbours one to another, whether they be professours of religion, or but meere worldlings. For without this, not only all trading, buying, selling, and such other commerce, wherewith the Common wealth is maintained and preserued, decaieth, and quite ceaseth; but euen duties required necessarily to the preseruing of life, and of our being in the world, should also be neglected. As then euery man ought in the time of a common plague, to preserue his health, by keeping himselfe from comming amongst infected persons; and yet in some cases, his comming neere them is nor onelie lawfull, but also necessarie, as to quench a fire, to helpe a woman in her labour and childbirth, and to minister vnto them such necessaries, as may preserue their liues; so is it lawfull in these, and such like cases to come into the company of those who are spiritually infected with the plague of sinne. But the company of wicked men is to be auoided, in respect of neere friendship and familiar conuersation, when as wee take delight to frequent their company, as it were, of our owne choice, neither ciuill conuersation, nor humane necessitie vrging vs thereunto. To this purpose one saith, that
we ought to flee the companie of wicked men, in respect of priuate
Malorum censortia fugere debemus, quoad priuatam consuetudinem, non quoad publicam conuersationem: corde non corpor • . Ambros. Offic. lib. 1. c. 20 2. Chro. 18. 1. and 20. 35. 37. fellowship, and not in respect of publike communion; and that rather with our hearts and affections, then with our bodies and outward actions. And this is that familiar acquaintance which good Iehosaphat had with Ahab, Ahaziah, and the rest of that familie, for which hee is so often taxed and censured in the booke of God.

But as it is lawfull for all men in some cases, to come into the companie of wicked worldlings, so for some men especially more frequently, namely such as hauing a calling of God hereunto, are furnished also with such a measure of§. Sect. 4. That it is lawful to company with wicked me that we may conuert them vnto God. grace, knowledge, and sanctification, that they may iustly conceiue more hope of conuerting them vnto God, then there is feare that the other should peruert and corrupt them with sin; if withall in sinceritie & vprightnes of heart they propound vnto themselues this as their chiefe & maine end, & not worldly & sinister respects. For as it is lawfull, yea laudable, for the Physitians of the bodie, to frequent the companie of them who are sicke of infectious and contagious diseases, that they may cure and recouer them, especially when as they doe not goe armed onely with their desperate boldnes, but vse good preseruatiues and wholesome meanes, to preuent and repell the infection; so also it is lawfull for the spirituall Physitians of the soule, to come into the companie of those who are sick of the leprosie of sinne, and the plague of a scandalous life, if they vse the good meanes of meditation, prayer, and such other wholesome preseruatiues, whereby they may be kept sound from the tainture of this spirituall infection. And for this we haue our Sauiour Christ himselfe for our president, who being the Physitian of our soules, frequented the companie of publicans and sinners, who had most neede of his helpe. For howsoeuer it is not so fit for vs, as it was for him, to come into such companie, because he was free from sinne, and from the tainture of al corruption, and therefore needed no preseruatiues, but what he had in himselfe; and also because through the puritie of his nature he was able purely, and without any worldlines and wickednes, to propound those ends of doing others good,
and of sauing them from their sinnes; whereas wee being full of the corrupt humours of sinne, and of the seedes of all wickednesse, are apt to receiue the outward infection; neither can wee purely without the mixture of our corruption, propound such good ends to our workes and actions; yet seeing it was done by our Sauiour Christ, it is not absolutely vnlawfull in vs; so that we endeuour to do it in his manner, and to the same ends, vsing all good meanes to preserue our selues from hurt, whilest wee labour after others good. For seeing by the rule of charitie wee are bound to loue our neighbours as our selues, it followeth that we may lawfully hazard a slippe or foyle (in the meane time vsing all good meanes whereby we may be enabled to stand vpright) if we haue any hope that by our helpe our brother may be pulled back from the gulfe of destruction whereinto he is falling. Howbeit in this case circumspection is to be vsed, lest whilest wee labour to raise others vp, wee our selues doe catch a downfall, and whilest wee endeuour to cure their diseases, we our selues be tainted and infected with their contagion. For such is our pronenes to fall into this sicknes of the soule, that vnlesse wee vse all good preseruatiues, they will not bee bettered, and wee shall become much worse, and bring our selues into grieuous, but yet vnpitied, diseases. For as the sonne of Syrach saith, who will haue pitie of the charmer that is Eccles. 12. 15. stung of the serpent? or of such as come neere the beasts (to • ame their wildnesse?) so is it with him that keepeth companie with a wicked man, and wrappeth himselfe in his sinnes.

And thus haue I shewed in what cases the companie of§. Sect. 5. In what cases the companie of wicked worldlings is to be condemned. worldly and wicked men is lawful and warrantable; whereby also it is easie to gather in what respect it is vnlawfull and condemned; namely, when it is vsuall and familiar, voluntarie and not of any necessitie, or vrgent occasion, rash and desperate, without vsing any meanes whereby we might be preserued from being corrupted by their societie. And finally, when as wee doe not in vprightnes of conscience, propound as our maine end their spirituall good, and conuersion vnto God, but our owne worldly ends; as for example, when wee aime by our familiar acquaintance with
them, at our owne priuate profit and aduantage, or at the satisfying of our owne voluptuous pleasure, as when we delight in their sharpnes of wit, merrie conceits, and in their pleasing conuersation; which oftentimes are baites to allure vs to enter into, and insnare our selues in the nets of perdition: for with this sweetnes is mixed the poyson of worldly prophanenes, ribauldrie, blasphemie, and such like wicked discourses, all which being in their companie we must needs heare, (vnlesse we will stop our eares) and hearing must of Caueamus ne dum relaxare animum volumus, soluamus omnem harmoniam, quasi concentum quendā bonorum operū. Ambros. Offic. lib. 1. cap. 20. necessitie either be corrupted or offended. In which regard one admonisheth vs to take carefull heed, lest whilest by such companie we desire to recreate our mindes, we doe not lose all harmonie and concord of good workes, because custome oftentimes doth incline nature.

In all which cases and respects, the companie of worldlings is a notable tentation to draw vs vnto sinne, and to hinder vs in the course of vertue and godlinesse, and therefore is most carefully of all Christians to bee shunned and§. Sect. 6. That the company of the wicked is forbiddē and condemned. Prou. 23. 20. auoided. To which purpose let vs consider, first, that this societie with the wicked is often forbidden, and condemned in the word of God. So the Wise man especially chargeth vs not to keepe companie with drunkards, or with gluttons; and generally, neither to be enuious against euill men, nor to desire Prou. 24. 1. to be in their companie, because their hearts imagine destruction, and their lips speake mischiefe. And thus the Lord commandeth the Israelites to haue no manner of societie or friendshipExod. 34. 16. Deut. 7. 3. 4. with the wicked nations, lest by their example and prouocation they should be moued vnto idolatrie and sin. And the Apostle Paul willeth vs in the name of the Lord, to come out from among wicked men, to separate our selues from them, and 2. Cor. 6. 17. Leuit. 7. 19. to touch no vncleane thing; for if the touching of a thing vncleane ceremonially defiled a man, how much more the familiar acquaintance of those, who are defiled with sinne? But with greater care and circumspection are we charged to auoid the company of those who making profession of Christian religion, doe disgrace the same with their wicked and vngodly liues and conuersations, because of all other their societie is most dangerous, their sinnes being more scandalous,
and their example more forcible to allure vs vnto sinne. If any (saith he) that is called a brother, be a fornicator or couetous, 1. Cor. 5. 11. or an idolater, or a railer, or a drunkard, or an extortioner, with such an one eat not. And thus he commandeth the Thessalonians, in the name of our Lord Iesus Christ, that they should 2. Thess. 3. 6. w • thdraw themselues from euery brother that walketh inordinatly, and not after the instruction which he had receiued from him. And thus the voice from heauen crieth vnto all the seruants of God, to come out of the spirituall Babylon, that they be not Apoc. 18. 4. partakers in her sinnes, and that they receiue not of her plagues.

And as the Lord hath forbidden this society with the wicked;§. Sect. 7. That Gods Saints haue carefully shunned the companie of the wicked. Psal. 26. 4. 5. so also ha • e the Saints carefully auoided it. Thus Dauid professeth, that he had not haunted with vaine persons, neither kept company with the dissemblers; yea that he hated the assemblie of the euill, and had not companied with the wicked: and when through his grieuous persecutions he was forced whether he would or no to haue this wicked fellowship, he grieuously complaineth hereof, crying out; Woe is me that I remaine Psalm. 120. 5. • . in Meshech, and dwell in the tents of Kedar. Whose example let vs learne to imitate, approuing our selues to bee true Israelites by our abhorring all fellowship with these filthie swine, who take delight to wallow themselues in the loathsome puddle of sinne and wickednesse. And to this end let vs further consider, that there ought to be no communion or fellowship betweene the faithfull and these worldly infidels: for as the Apostle saith, what fellowship hath righteousnesse 2. Cor. 6. 14. 15. with vnrighteousnesse? and what communion hath light with darknesse? and what concord hath Christ with Belial? or what part hath the beleeuer with the infidell? With which accordeth the saying of the Sonne of Syrach, All flesh (saithEccl. 13. 16. 17. he) will resort to their like, and euery man will keepe company with such as he is himselfe: how can the Wolfe agree with the Lambe? no more can the vngodly with the righteous. And to the same purpose another demandeth, What (saith he) hast thou Ambros. ad Virgin. deuo • . lib. cap. 1. to doe with worldly men, or what commerce canst thou haue with them? to what purpose doest thou desire to know with them the way of perdition, which they follow? If thou seekest for chastitie, they haue it not; if for faith, who is faithfull among them,
whom thou shouldest imitate? If thou seekest for Christ, hee remaineth not in them, &c.

Secondly, let vs cal to mind that this societie with wicked§. Sect. 8. That wicked companie is a notable inducement to draw vs into sinne. Psal. 119. 115. worldlings doth bring vnto vs much hurt, as being the cause both of the euill of sinne, and the euill of punishment; for it is a speciall meanes of the transgression of all Gods law: and therefore the Prophet Dauid being resolued to yeeld his obedience thereunto, saith, Away from me yee wicked, for I will keepe the commandements of my God. Implying that there was no hope of yeelding such obedience as he desired, vntill he had freed himselfe from wicked mens company. For this wicked societie doth exceedingly corrupt and defile those that frequent it, like vnto a gangrene, which hauing tainted one member, neuer resteth till it haue runne ouer the whole bodie; or like vnto the spreading leprosie or plague, which beginning in one house proceedeth to another, vntill it haue infected the greatest part of a towne or citie. In which respectEccles. 13. 1. the son of Syrach compareth wicked company to pitch, which by touching defileth vs; and the Apostle, to leauen, a1. Cor. 5. 6. little whereof soureth the whole lumpe of dough: and by others wicked men in this regard are compared to scabbed sheepe, one of which is enow to infect the whole flocke; and to rotten apples, which taint and corrupt all the sound ones that lie about them: whereby it appeareth that it is a thing of great difficultie to conuerse with wicked men, and not to be tainted with their corruptions: for besides that they are apt to infect, we also are most apt to receiue the infection, hauing the seeds of sinne remaining in vs, which are readie to spring and sprout vp, when they are (as it were) watred with the breath of euill company: we are in our owne nature prone to go downe the hill of vice, how then shall we keepe our selues from running headlong, when we are thrust forward with these wicked associates? In our selues we are sluggish in trauelling the way of righteousnesse which leadeth to life eternall: and therefore what will become of vs when these briars and thornes catch hold of vs and hinder vs? Surely they will either cause vs to make a stand, and to proceed no further in our Christian race, or will scratch and rent vs
when we seeke to breake from them. So that it is a thing of great difficultie to continue doing well, amongst those who are euill; or not to bee hindred in our course of godlinesse, when as wicked companions doe as it were hang on our neckes, and with all their power and policie labour to stay vs. And this that wise Heathen obserued in his owne experience: I confesse (saith he) mine owne weakenesse: I neuer bring Senec. epist. 7. home those manners which I caried abroad; but something which I had well composed is disturbed and put out of order; some of those vices which I had put to flight, againe returne: and as it befalleth them that haue been vexed with a long sicknesse, who remaine still so weake, that they cannot without some danger come abroad into the open aire; the same happeneth vnto vs, whose minds are somewhat recouered out of the tedious sicknesse of vice and sinne: the conuersation of the wicked multitude is a great enemie vnto vs, euery one being readie to commend vnto vs, or to thrust vpon vs some vice, or at least to taint and infect vs therewith at vnawares, &c. So that I alwaies returne home either more couetous, ambitious or voluptuous, yea more cruell and inhumane, because I haue been amongst men. As therefore it is hard to dwell with a colliar and not be smutted, to haue our conuersation amongst theeues, and not, one time or other, to be robbed of our rich treasures: so and much more difficult it is to keep familiar company with wicked worldlings, and not to be collowed with their corruptions; to liue amongst these spirituall theeues, and not to be spoiled of the riches of Gods grace: in which respect they are so much more hurtfull and penicious vnto vs, then theeues and robbers; as§. Sect. 9. That in the former respect we are carefully to shun wicked company. Ante circumspiciendum est cum quibus edas aut bib • s, quam quid • das & biba • . Senec. epist. 19. much as the soule exceedeth the bodie, and Gods spirituall graces and heauenly ioyes which they steale from vs, exceed in worth, earthly gold and momentanie treasures, of which time will rob vs, though theeues spare vs.

And therefore seeing it is a thing of so great danger, to haue our conuersation among wicked worldlings, lest wee should be tainted with their corruptions, let vs be exceeding warie and carefull in making choice of our company: and as one saith, let vs be no more respectiue what we eate and drinke, then amongst whom we eat and drinke: for as vnwholesome
meates and drinkes may poison the bodie, so vngodly company poyson the soule, vnlesse wee bee preserued with some soueraigne antidots ministred vnto vs by Gods word and holy Spirit: and seeing this is a strong temptation to draw vs vnto euill, let not vs who daily pray that wee may not bee led into tentations, wittingly and willingly runne into them. Neither let vs, vnlesse wee haue a calling hereunto, and bee furnished and prepared with a great measure of grace and strength, presume vpon our owne abilities, and flatter our selues with a conceit, that we can by keeping them company draw them to vertue and goodnesse, and in the meane time receiue no hurt, seeing it is much more likely, vnlesse wee be very skilfull Physitians, that they should infect vs, then that we should cure them: For (as one saith) this is the ordinarie course of humane affaires,
Rerum natura sic est vt quoties bonus malo coniungitur, non ex bono malus melioretur, sed ex malo bonus contaminetur. Chrysostom. Hag. 2. 13. 14. that when the good and euill are ioyned together, the euill man is not made better by the good, but the good rather is corrupted by the euill. And this was signified by the ceremoniall law, in which the holy flesh carried in the skirt of the garment did not make it holy, but the polluted person touching any holy thing, with his filthines did make it vncleane, as the Prophet Haggai sheweth; to note vnto vs, that it is a matter of farre greater difficultie to cleanse and purifie, then to defile and make vncleane. The reason whereof is cleare and manifest; for they are wholly flesh, and we but in part spirituall and regenerate; so that they pull vs with full swinge of will, and with all their power and might: whereas both our will and power being diuided, cannot haue such force and vertue. Againe, they run swiftly downe the hill and streame of vice, but we with great labour and difficultie creepe softly forward in the way of vertue, and as it were vp the hill, and against the streame of our corruptions, which naturally carie vs another way; and therefore if by familiar companie, we catch hold to stay them, and graple with them, it is a thousand to one, if we be not assisted with a power farre superiour to our owne, they will rather carie vs away with their violence, or at least naturall motion; then that we shall make them stay, or force them backe by true repentance.

Neither are wee alone corrupted and infected with the§. Sect. 10. That it is ha • d to keepe company with the wicked, and not to be accessary to their sinnes. tainture of their sinnes, and become euill by imitating their wicked examples; but also we are made either accessarie to their sins, which they commit in our company, or else we acquit our selues with much griefe & trouble; for hearing their blasphemies, ribauldrie and prophanenes, we either beare with them, and passe al ouer with silence, or els we admonish and reproue them for their sins; by the former wee become accessaries, for whilest we beare with, & winck at our friends faults, wee make them to become our owne, by our silenceVitia amici si feras facis tua. giuing a secret consent to their wickednesse; and so whilest we labour to haue our societie pleasing vnto men; wee doe much dishonour and displease God; whilest we shew a false loue to our companions, we make it manifest, that there is but little true loue of God remaining in vs: for if no louing sonne can indure to heare his father disgraced, if no good feruant can abide to heare his Lord and master dishonoured and abused; and therfore wil shew their dislike, either by rebuking the offenders, or by forsaking their company: then those that can with delight frequent the company of wicked men, who in all their words and actions, do nothing else but dishonour God, doe plainly shew, that they neither loue the Lord as their Father, nor reuerence him as their Lord and Master. But if hearing and seeing these abuses, they doe reprooue them, then doe they become to their companions irkesome and tedious, moouing them, when they feele themselues gaulled with reprofes, to bitternesse and anger, yea, sometime to rage and furious reuenge; and so whilest by their absence they might haue had them friendly strangers, by this neerer acquaintance, they become knowne enemies. And both these should be carefully auoided, either to displease God by pleasing of men; or willingly to displease, and to bee at enmitie with men, when as we may auoid it, without Gods displeasure.

But as wicked company defile vs with their sinnes; so also§. Sect. 11. That keeping wicked company brandeth our names with infamie. they subiect vs to their punishments; for they brand our names with the blacke marke of infamy and reproch, whilest keeping them company, we are reputed and censured to bee
of the same disposition and conuersation. For seeing euery like is delighted with his like, and seeing similitude in manners and affections, and delight in the same pleasures and recreations, is the vsuall bond that lincketh men together in the same society, they receiue no wrong (although they may haue some goodnesse in them) who frequent the company of wicked men, when as they are thus censured; seeing they are either presently euill, or will bee euill within a while; it being the nature of companie, either to find men alike, or to make them alike. To which purpose one saith; that the good
Bonus sic malo connectitur, vt aut pares reddantur, aut citò ab inuicem separentur, &c. Chrysost. super Matthaeum. and bad are so ioyned together; that either they become like one another, or else they are quickly seuered and disioyned, for friendship findeth or maketh this similitude. Iustly therefore is he reputed euill, who taketh delight in frequenting euill companie; for though he be not yet come to the height of sinne, yet he fast climeth therunto, and is euen at the very next degree of being himselfe wicked, when with a quiet and contented mind, he can be a daily beholder of other mens wickednesse; for as the wise man saith, A wicked man is an abomination Pro. 29. 27. to the iust, and he that is vpright in his way, is abomination to the wicked.

Finally, wicked company is carefully to be shunned and§. Sect. 12. Wicked companie maketh vs liable to Gods iudgements. Pro. 13. 20. 21. auoided, because they make euen the deare seruants and children of God, liable and subiect to common iudgements. For as the wise man saith, he that walketh with the wise, shall be wise; but a companion of fooles shall be afflicted. Affliction followeth sinners, but to the righteous, God wil recompense good. And thus was righteous Lot led away in that common captiuitie with the Sodomits; and dearely bought the pleasuresGen. 14. 12. of the Countrie, by partaking in the punishments of the people. Thus whosoeuer adhered to Dathan and Abiram, Numb. 16. 26. were also with them swallowed of the earth aliue, and as they consorted with them in their rebellion, so they bore them companie into the gulph of destruction. And thus was Iehosaphat discomfited, and hardly escaped with his life being1. King. 22. 32. in the company of wicked Ahab, and afterwards had his ships broken, and his works and enterprises frustrated and2. Chro. 20. 37. destroied, because he ioyned himselfe with Ahaziah. From
which iudgements and punishments, when God would haue his seruants priuiledged and preserued, he calleth vnto them with a voice from heauen, saying, Goe out of her my Apoc. 18. 4. people, that ye be not partakers in her sinnes, and that ye receiue not of her plagues. Implying their danger of being tainted with the sinnes of the whore of Babylon, and the impossibilitie of escaping her punishments, if they did not forsake her wicked fellowship.

But as all societie with wicked worldlings, is a very dangerous§. Sect. 13. That affinitie with the wicked is most dangerous. tentation to draw vs vnto sinne, and to subiect vs vnto punishment, so especially when we enter into the nearest bonds of affinitie and marriage with them; for they who are thus vnequally yoked with vnbeleeuing worldlings, are sure either to goe quietly with them in the way of sinne, or to be shrewdly gaulled, whilest they make resistance, and draw another way. And for this fault, good Iehosaphat had his reputation blemished, of whom it is said, that he had riches 2. Chron. 18. 1. and honour in abundance, but he was ioyned in affinitie with Ahab. The which bond of alliance made him professe to the enemie of God, desiring his assistance, I am as thou art, and vers. 3. my people as thy people, and we will ioyne with thee in the warre. And this is the reason which the holy Ghost rendreth of Iehorams 2. King. 8. 18. idolatrie, because the daughter of Ahab was his wife; and also why Ahaziah did euill in the sight of the Lord, vers. 27. like the house of Ahab, because he was the sonne in law of the house of Ahab. Yea, with this snare was wise Salomon catched, being drawne by his idolatrous wiues to leaue the Lord (who had in extraordinarie maner blessed him aboue1. King. 11. 4. 5. all the Kings of Israel) and to serue the idols of the Heathens.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.
That the companie of the wicked is verie dangerous, by reason of euill examples, and corrupt communication.
div.p:
ANd thus haue I shewed the manifold euils,§. Sect. 1. Wicked examples allure and perswade vs vnto sinne. which come of frequenting wicked company. In the next place let vs consider of some speciall meanes, whereby principally this societie becommeth vnto vs thus hurtfull and pernicious; and these are either by their examples, or by their allurements and perswasions. For the first, the societie of wicked worldlings is exceeding hurtfull vnto vs, because thereby there are daily set before vs examples of euill, whereby wee are either allured to imitate and follow their wicked and vngodly practise, or at least, are much vexed and grieued, to see God so dishonoured by their sinnes. In the former respect, looke how many euill examples are before our eies, and so many stumbling blockes are laid before our feete, to hinder vs in our spirituall race, and to stop vs in our way, as we are trauelling to our heauenly countrie; and such is the corruption of our nature, that we need no other perswasions to draw vs vnto sinne, for euen the sight thereof is a baite sufficient to allure vs to imitation. And hereof it is, that euen the Heathen man reckoneth this as
Inter Causas malorum nostrorum est quod viuimus ad exempla: nec ratione componimur, sed consuctudine abducimur, &c. Senec. Epist. 123. a chiefe cause of all our euils, because we liue after the example of the multitude, and are not composed and ruled by reason, but are carried away with custome; and whereas if few should doe it, we would not imitate them, when as many begin to doe it, we follow for company, as though it were more honest, because it is more common; and so error, when as it is made publicke and customable, is esteemed of vs in the place of truth. Whereby it appeareth, that seeing examples are admitted of vs in place of rules and precepts, therefore the examples of wicked worldlings must needs be very powerfull, both in weaning vs from that which is good, and in alluring vs vnto euill. In the former
respect one saith, that men oftentimes desire to heare Gods Greg. Sup. Ezech. lib. Hom. 13. word, but whilest they behold others contemptuouslie turning away their eares, they also neglect the sauing hearing of the truth. And many also desire to rest contented, and to cease turmoiling in worldly businesse, and resolue not to subiect themselues to earthly desires; but whilest they behold others by vnquiet labouring to come forward in the world, and to bee aduanced vnto riches and honours; being not as yet firme and well setled in the way of truth, by the euill example of others, they slide backe into the way of wickednesse. And as they eneruate and weaken our good resolutions, so also they corrupt vs with sinne; in regard wherof one saith, that the tender mind which is vnsetled in that
Subducendus populo est tener animus, & parū tenax recti: facile transitur ad plures, &c. Senec. epist. 7. which is right, is to be withdrawne from beholding the multitude; because we are proue to goe with companie; and euen Socrates, Cato and Laelius, might change their mind, and bee brought to alter their good resolution by the dissenting multitude; so vnable is any of vs, when as our disposition is best composed, to beare the assault of vices, when as they come against vs strengthened with so great a troope. And if one example of luxuriousnesse or couetousnesse doth much hurt; if one delicate, nice and wanton companion doth by little and little weaken and effeminate vs; if one rich neighbour doth kindle our concupiscence; and if a malicious companion doth rub off his rust, euen vpon him that is innocent and ingenuous, what thinke you will befall them, against whom
Dum spectant laesos oculi laeduntur et ipsi. Ouid. combined wickednesse doth make a common assault? As therefore those who haue sound eies, doe carefully refraine looking vpon theirs which are sore and bleared, because euen by seeing them, a secret poison and infection is transmitted, whereby they also are tainted; and as men in time of the plague, do carefully make choice of their aire and company, and auoid them who are infected, and haue running sores vpon them; so with no lesse care are we to auoid the sight of wicked examples, and the fellowship of such as are infected with the plague of wilfull and presumptuous sinne, because a poison and infection secretly commeth from them (as from the crampfish to the hand of the angler) by the contagion whereof we also are tainted and infected. For sinne▪ like the plague or leprosie, is of a spreading nature, going from one
to another, vntill it haue infected a whole countrie; and as a stone cast into a great water, troubleth not only that part into which it fell, but stirreth vp certaine circled wrinckles in the face or superficies of the water neere about it, and these being moued, doe also after the same manner moue those parts which are contiguous the one to the other, till it extend to the very bankes; so wicked suggestions being cast into the mindes of worldlings, are thence produced into act, and so being made examplarie to those that are about them, doe not rest there, but by contagion spread themselues ouer all the countrie. To which purpose one saith, that no man erreth to himselfe alone, but doth disperse and communicate
Nemo errat vni sibi, sed dementiam spargit in proximos, accipitque inuicem &c. Senec. epist. 94. his follie to his neighbours, and interchangeably receiueth the like from them. And therefore the vices of the people are in euery particular man, because the people communicates them, and is made worse it selfe whilest it maketh others worse. It learneth ill things, and then teacheth them, and so wickednes groweth to a monstrous greatnes, that being all cast into one heape, which euery one knoweth to be worst.

Now as these euill examples are in all very hurtfull; so§. Sect. 3. Euill examples of superiors are most pernicious. they are most pernicious when they are obserued in superiours: for seldome doe these tall cedars fall, but they beate downe also all the low shrubs that stand about them. And thus doe masters by their euill examples corrupt and poyson their seruants, parents children, Magistrates the people, Ministers their flocks, and most of all Princes their subiects, seeing all the countrie is readie, either for feare, or flatterie, Ea conditio est principis, vt quicquid faciat praecipere videatur. Quint. to conforme it selfe to the example of their King; in regard whereof (one saith) that Princes actions stand for precepts, and their examples haue the power of a law to draw their subiects to imitation.

But as these euill examples are very hurtfull, as they corrupt§. Sect. 4. Euill examples nourish pride, and hinder repentance. vs with sinne, so also in nourishing pride and securitie, and in hindring of repentance; whilest comparing our selues with others, which haue burst out into greater wickednes, wee are readie through selfeloue to conceit our owne excellencies; and so whilest we are wholly taken vp in thinking how farre wee exceed them in vertue and goodnesse, we
neuer thinke how farre short we come of that which God requireth of vs. To say nothing of that incouragement which men take vnto themselues, of committing wickednes, when they see others doe the like, and yet scape vnpunished and florish in the world. For as the Wise man saith, because sentence against an euill worke is not executed speedily, therefore Eccles. 8. 11. the heart of the children of men is fullie set in them to doe euill. And therefore seeing wee are so greatly endangered with wicked societie, by beholding their euill examples, let vs carefully auoide them; or if at vnawares wee happen to come into such companie, let vs (as one exhorteth) be very Basil. Ascetica. watchfull ouer our selues, that wee doe not suck in these inticing baits of sinne, neither by our eyes, nor by our eares, lest by little and little we be inured to it, and lest certaine figures and characters of those euils, which wee haue seene and heard, doe remaine still in our mindes to our ruine and destruction. And because we cannot sufficiently with our owne watchfulnesse, preserue our selues from being ouertaken with this deceitfulnes of sinne, let vs with Dauid (hauing set a watch before our eyes and eares) desire the Lord that he will not suffer our hearts to be inclined vnto euill, that wee should commit wicked workes Psal. 141. 3. 4. with the men that worke iniquitie.

And thus it appeareth that euill examples of wicked§. Sect. 5. Euill examples of the wicked vex and grieue Gods seruants. worldlings are very hurtfull and pernicious as they corrupt and infect vs with sin: but though we were so preserued by Gods spirit yt there were no danger of taking hurt by this contagion, yet many other euils are incident vnto vs, if wee be daily beholders of these wicked examples. For being the children of God it must needes bee grieuous vnto vs to see our heauenly Father thus dishonoured; being faithfull seruants of the great King of heauen and earth, it cannot chuse but much vex and trouble vs, when wee see the glorie of our Lord and master impeached by wicked miscreants; yea and seeing we are of the same flesh and blood with these worldly men, the workmanship of the same Creator, yea people of the same countrie, and as it were children borne by the same mother; it must needs afflict our soules with griefe and bitter sorrow, when wee behold them daily running on in a
course, which will bring them to eternall destruction, both in their soules and bodies. And thus was righteous Lots soule 2. Pet. 2. 7. 8. grieued, when he saw the filthie conuersation of the wicked Sodomites. For he being righteous and dwelling among them, in seeing and in hearing, vexed his righteous soule, from day to day, with their vnlawfull deeds. And holy Dauid professeth that his eyes Psal. 119. 136. 139. gushed out with riuers of waters, and that his zeale euen consumed him, because his enemies kept not Gods law, but forgot his words. Yea thus our Sauiour Christ himselfe being conuersantMat. 3. 5. among the wicked Iewes, mourned when he saw the hardnes of their hearts.

Finally, by being with wicked men, and not doing as they§. Sect. 6. If we doe not follow the euill examples of the wicked, we procure their hatred. doe, nor following their examples, wee doe thereby exceedingly prouoke their malice and hatred: for it is a sufficient quarrell for a wicked man against those yt feare God, if they be innocent, and seeme to make conscience of those sinnes which they see them commit, because their abstinence from euill seemeth to proclaime their wickednesse who do commit it, and awakeneth their sleeping consciences when as they are galled with their refusall. Whereby oftentimes it commeth to passe that the godly being spectators of these euill examples, and denying to ioyne with them in their enormities, doe not onely thereby endanger their names to be branded with their obloquies reproches, and disgraces, but also their persons to their violence and furie; as we may see in the example of Lot, who though he did in most louingGen. 19. and humble manner refuse to communicate with the Sodomites in their sinnes, yet so incensed them to rage hereby, that they would haue laid violent hands vpon him, had not God miraculously deliuered him from their furie. And as it moneth them to hate vs, so through our naturall corruption wee are readie to extend our hatred beyond it due limits, abhorring not only their sinne, but their persons also. All which euils as they ought, so they may easily be auoyded, if wee will shunne the societie of wicked men, and frequent the companie of the vertuous; for so shall we neither be allured nor grieued by their examples, nor yet nourish this open hostilitie betweene vs, but may liue like strangers
one to another, seeing we cannot liue as friends. To this purpose Necesse est ant imiteris aut oderis: vtrun{que} autē deuitandū est: ne vel similis malis fiar, quia multi sunt: neue inimicus multis, quia dissimiles sunt. Senec. epist. 7. §. Sect. 7. That the euill speeches of wicked men doe much corrupt vs. one saith, that if we be spectators of the euill conuersation of wicked men, we must of necessitie, either imitate or hate them; both which are to be auoided, lest thou shouldest either be like to wicked men, because they are many, or an enemie to many, because they are vnlike: and therefore it is best for a man either to be conuersant with himselfe, or to keepe companie with those who may better him, or that he may better.

And thus haue I shewed the manifold euils which come of wicked company, through their bad examples: vnto which we may adde the hurt which we are apt to receiue by their speeches and communication. In which respect the societie of wicked worldlings is dangerous and hurtfull: first, in regard that by their speeches they corrupt vs; for being either worldly or prophane, and spent either about earthly things, as profits and preferments, or in vaine mirth, ribauldry, filthines, foolish iesting, and such like wicked discourses, it commeth to passe that by frequenting their company we become as worldly as they, hauing not only our hearts fast nailed to the earth, but our tongues tuned to the same key, vttering nothing but that which sauoureth of the world and worldly vanities; or which is worse, being corrupted with their filthie communication, we in the end grow, if not to imitate, yet at least to like, or not so much to dislike them as we ought: for there is a secret poison in worldly and wicked speeches, which when they are admitted into our eares, infuseth it selfe into our minds, whereby they being corrupted, do taint also all our speeches and actions; of which the Apostle Paul warneth vsto take heed, Be not (saith he) deceiued, 1 Cor 15. 33. euill words corrupt good manners: or if they doe not thus corrupt vs, then of necessitie they do much vex and grieue vs, when as we heare our heauenly Father thus dishonored, and see those, whose company we frequent, running swiftly the§. Sect. 8. That wicked men with their allurements and persuasions withdraw our hearts from God. way to destruction and condemnation.

Secondly, the speeches and familiar communication of wicked worldlings, are hurtfull and pernicious; as they are the diuels spokesmen to wooe our hearts from God, perswading, alluring and inticing vs to withdraw from him all true
obedience, by neglecting the duties which he requireth, or committing the vices which he hath forbidden: for we are to know that in this regard worldly men are very impudent, not sticking in plaine tearmes to blow the trumpet of rebellion against God; and when they cannot catch vs with their wicked company, nor allure vs by their euill examples, they stay not heere, but in direct speeches solicite the diuels suite, either discouraging vs from vertuous actions, by telling vs that they are needlesse, or too troublesome, either that they will not stand with our credit, but traduce our names, and impeach our reputations, or that they are against our profit and preferment in the world, or else prouoking and perswading, yea alluring and incouraging vs to commit with them sin and wickednesse by all manner of perswasions, inticing speeches, faire promises and kind vsage: by which baits they labour to draw all who frequent their company into the snares of destruction and perdition. An example whereof we haue in Putiphars wife, who laying aside all modestie, inticedGen. 39. 12. Ioseph vnto sinne; in the harlot alluring the yong man to folly; and in wicked Ahab, who gaue vnto Iehosaphat andPro. 7. 13. his followers bountifull entertainment, that he might hereby intice him to goe vp against Ramoth Gilead. Against2. Chron. 18. 2. which perswasions and inueigling baites, the Wise man armeth vs, saying, My sonne, if sinners doe intice thee, consent thou not: If they say, come with vs, we will lay wait for blood, and Pro. 1. 10. 11. 13. 14. lie priuily for the innocent without a cause, &c. Wee will find all precious riches, and fill our houses with spoile. Cast in thy lot among vs, we will haue one purse: my sonne walke not thou in the way with them, refraine thy foot from their path, &c.

The which counsell that we may follow with the greater§. Sect. 9. That these wicked allurements are very dangerous. care, let vs consider that these tentations are exceeding dangerous; being vrged by men in our owne likenesse vnder colour of loue, with pretence of our owne profit and aduantage; seeing the Orator which perswadeth, and the theame whereon he discourseth, are so pleasing and well accepted of our corrupt nature. But that we may resist such wicked allurements, let vs know that they are but Syrens songs which intice to leape into the sea of destruction, and but the worlds
inchantments, whereby conspiring with Satan, it laboureth to carry vs swiftly vnto hell; like vnto that pleasing discourse vsed by the old serpent to our first parents, which promised to equall their estate with Gods, but in truth made them in as bad case as the diuell, had not the Lord in mercie deliuered and restored them. And therefore let vs stop our cares against these worldly allurements, whereby wicked men intice vs vnto sinne, and like the diuels aduocats perswade vs to by the hazarding of our soules, to obtaine worldly vanities; or rather let vs, because we wil not heare their bewitching tunes, abandon their company: for as one saith, We are in good forwardnesse
Magna pars sanitatis est, bortatores insaniae resiquisse, &c. Senec. Epist. 94. towards the obtaining of our soules welfare, when as we leaue the companie of those who perswade vnto wickednesse, and go farre off out of this hurtfull societie. And though they would still tie vs vnto them in the bonds of loue; yet let vs abhorre their company and breake off from them, esteeming them of all others our most dangerous enemies; seeing vnder colour of good will, they expose our soules to vtter destruction; and our most pernicious persecutors, who by inticing vs vnto euill,Greg. Moral. lib. 3. cap. 11. do not kill the bodie alone, but plunge both bodie and sould into euerlasting death.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.
That the friendship of wicked worldlings is to be contemned, and carefully auoided.
div.p:
ANd thus haue I shewed the dangerousnesse of§. Sect. 1. That true friendship is much to be esteemed. the worlds temptations, which haue their strength from wicked companie. In the next place we are to speake of those which are grounded on worldly friendship, and to propound some reasons which may moue vs to contemne and auoid it. Where first we are to know that the following discourse tēdeth not to the disgrace of true friendship, or to take way this neere loue and kindnesse betweene man and man; for this is not only one of the chiefe comforts which sweetens worldly miseries, but a notable helpe and
furtherance in the course of godlinesse. And as the Sonne of Syrach saith, A faithfull friend is a strong defence, and he that Eccl. 6. 14. 15. &c. findeth such an one findeth a treasure. A faithfull friend ought not to be changed for any thing, and the waight of gold and siluer
Solem è mundo tollunt, qui tollunt amicitiam. Ambros. de amicit. cap. 7. Sine amici • omnis cogilatio esset taedium, omnis operatio labor, omnis terra peregrinatio. &c. Cas. sian. in epist. is not to be compared to the goodnes of his faith. A faithful friend is the medicine of life and immortalitie, and they that feare the Lord shal find him: who so feareth the Lord shal direct his friendship aright & as his owne selfe, so shall his friend be. Which who so take away from amongst men, they take away (as it were) the Sun out of the firmament, and spoile them of their chiefe comfort: for as one saith, without friends all our cogitations are tedious, our workes toylesome, euery countrie is an exile or pilgrimage, all life a torment, and without their solace life were no better then death.

Of this true friendship which is only among those that are§. Sect. 2. In what respects friendship with the wicked is to be auoided. Amicus verus diu quae • itur, vix inuenitur, difficile seruatur. Hieron. epist. ad Ruff. tom. 1. good, in good, & to good ends and purposes we do not here speake; yea rather we ought earnestly to wish, that this vertue no lesse excellent then rare and hard to be found, might againe returne to the sons of men from heauen, vnto which it seemeth fled, that their comfort in this sweet fruition of their mutuall good might be inlarged and increased. But the following discourse tendeth to the contempt of that worldly, wicked, false and counterfeit friendship intertained among men, which is betweene the euill alone, or the good and bad together in euill things, and for the accomplishment of euill ends: in which respects whē this friendship is admitted, it quite excludeth the true loue of God. Neither would I haue Gods seruants to withdraw themselues from worldlings in respect of ciuill kindnesse, and to professe open emnity against their persons, but only from hauing neere friendship and familiaritie with them, or any communion and fellowship in that which is euill. For howsoeuer we are to hate their sins, yet wee must loue their persons, and though wee may not in respect of the former euils intertaine them as friends, yet if it be possible, and as much as • n vs lieth, we are to Rom. 12. 18. haue peace with all men: and to further with our best indeuours their conuersion vnto God, that so being of one familie, we may loue them as our brethren and fellow seruants:
and for the present seeing we cannot haue them our friends, Paucis sis charu • , multis ignetus, nemini otiosus, &c. Hos omnes amicos habere operosum est: satis est inimicos non habere. Senec. epist. 14. §. Sect. 3. That we cannot hold friendship with worldlings, and peace with God. let vs not willingly haue them (if we can by lawfull meanes auoid it) our foes and enemies.

But to come to our purpose: wee are carefully to take heed of worldly friendship, when it is an occasion to breake off our friendship with God (as it is, when as it prouoketh or allureth vs to the committing of sinne, or to the neglect of any good duety) and labour to please God rather then men, when wee cannot please both together: esteeming such kind of friendship the most hatefull emnitie, and such carnall friends, to bee no better then trecherous enemies, who doe vs much more mischiefe then those who openly discouer their malice, and shew their hatred by offering all outward violence. Whereof it is that one thus exclaimeth against this wicked friendship: O friendship (saith hee) too much our enemie, as being a seducer not easilie to bee discerned; from which proceedeth an appetite and greedie desire of doing hurt, and endamaging others, as it were by way of sport and play, without any desire of gaine or reuenge; but whilest companions Aug. Confes. lib. 2. cap. 9. say, let vs goe together, let vs doe it, and they are ashamed not to be as impudent as their setters on. With which wicked friendship that we may not be abused and inueagled, let vs consider, first, that wee cannot hold this friendship with worldlings, but wee must breake our league and couenant with God, and as it were proclaime warres against him; for as the Apostle Iohn telleth vs, he that loueth the world, the loue 1. Ioh. 2. • 5. of the father cannot abide in him: and Iames plainely affirmeth, that the amitie of the world is emnitie with God; and therefore whosoeuer will bee a friend of the world, maketh himselfe the enemie of God: into which sinne when Iehoshaphat fell, hee isIam. 4. 4. sharpely reproued by the Prophet, Wouldest thou (saith he) helpe the wicked, and loue them that hate the Lord? therefore for this thing the wrath of the Lord is vpon thee.

Secondly, let vs consider that this friendship with wicked§. Sect. 4. That friendship with worldlings is false and counterfeit. worldlings is not true, but false and counterfeite. For there is no true friendship, but that which is betweene the vertuous and faithfull, and grounded vpon the true loue and feare of God; for whose sake they also loue their brethren,
whereby they helpe one another forward in vertuous actions, Ʋera amicitia tantum inter bonos oritur, inter bonos proficit, inter optimos consummatur. Cassian. super. Psal. Aug. epist. ad Macedon. 52. tom. 2. and further their good ends and indeauors. To which purpose one saith; that all true friendship ariseth and beginneth betweene those that are good, encreaseth among the good, and is most perfect among those who are best and most vertuous; and another affirmeth, that we cannot be true friends vnto men vnles we be first friends vnto the truth. With whom also a third agreeth, saying, that all loue of the flesh is corrupt, and that all worldly friendship is false and counterfaite, which is not knit together with the bond of Gods feare; there being no true fidelitie in Chrysost. in Mat. 10. Homil. 24. tom. 2. cap. 908. the seruants of the diuell. Neither is it the fruit of true friendship, that our faith towards God should through it bee violated; for he cannot bee a true friend vnto man, who hath shewed himselfe vnfaithfull vnto God: nor yet can it bee in Pietatis custos amicitia est. Basil. Homil. 9. de ira. euill, seeing (as one saith) friendship is the keeper and preseruer of pietie; and therefore that friendship which is with wicked worldlings, is to be contemned and abhorred, as being false Amicitia in malo esse non potest. Aug. ad Consent.. and counterfeite, seeing it is with the euill, in euill, and for euill ends, and not grounded vpon the loue of God, but vpon worldly respects to serue their owne turnes; and vpon selfe loue that they may haue profit or pleasure by them; in eating, drinking, discoursing, gaming, sporting, and such other carnall delights. Whereupon it followeth that it is deceitfull and inconstant: for whereas true friendship is immutable and perpetuall, because it is grounded on vertue, and on the loue of God, which is vnchangeable; this worldly friendship is flickering and vnconstant, lasting no longer then these worldly respects and ends of pleasure and profit last, whereupon it wholly resteth and relieth. And therefore (as one saith) hee foully erreth, who seeketh for a
Errat antē qui amicum in atrio quaerit, in conuiuio probat, &c. Senec. epist. 19. friend in the court, and trieth him at a banquet; neither can a worse thing befall a man much imployed in the world, and flourishing in prosperitie, then that he imagineth them to be friends vnto him, vnto whom he is not; thinking that his benefits are powerfull enough to procure friends: whereas some men the more they are obliged, the more they maligne their benefactors: for small moneyes lent make debters; but great summes, enemies; because all hope is taken away of requitall, and pride maketh them
to hate those, vnto whom their necessitie enforceth them whether they will or no, to stand indebted and beholding.

Such friends therefore as are tied vnto vs in these worldly§. Sect. 5. These worldly friends forsake vs in time of triall; when we most need their helpe. bonds, are not to be esteemed, for when the bonds are broken the friends are scattered; like chaffe or some such light matter, which lieth with the good wheate in the sunshine and calme, but separateth it selfe and fleeth away when the least blast of wind bloweth: or like vnto the reed which standeth vpright, and seemeth stiffe and strong in faire weather, but boweth and bendeth any way when the storme commeth: so these worldly friends whilest the sun of prosperitie shineth, do adhere vnto vs and seeme firme and constant, as though they would neuer leaue vs; but when the least tempest of trouble commeth, and when the world seemeth to frowne, they either hang downe the head and will not see vs, or frame idle excuses why they cannot helpe vs; or like Iobs miserable comforters they make pouerty a crime, and argue and inferre our guiltinesse and faultines, because we are fallen into this miserie and affliction. And therefore let vs not make choice of such friends if wee haue them not, nor trust vnto them if wee haue them; for like the reed they will bow and flee from vs, when being almost drowned in miserie, we labour to catch hold of them, or else breaking in our hands will wound vs, when as wee rest and relie vpon them: or finally like the brier they will fleece vs of our wool when we flee vnto them for succour: or like an old ruinous house, when we come vnto them for shelter and protection against the storme, they will fall vpon vs and beate vs to the ground with their oppressions. Let vs therefore follow the aduice of the sonne of Syrach: If (saith hee) thou gettest a Eccles. 6. 7. 8. 9. &c. friend, proue him first, and be not hastie to credit him: For some man is a friend for his owne occasion, and will not abide in the day of thy trouble, &c. Againe, some friend is but a companion at thy table, and in the day of thine affliction hee continueth not, but in thy prosperity he wil be as thou thy selfe, & will vse liberty ouer thy seruants; if thou be brought low he will be against theè, and will hide himselfe from thy face. Depart from thine enemies, and beware of thy friends.

Yea, these worldly friends do not only become in time of§. Sect. 6. Worldly friends in time of aduersitie oftentimes become enemies. Eccles. 6. 9. aduersitie, as vnprofitable as strangers, but also as hurtfull as enemies, their kindnesse and loue degenerating into malice and hatred: and this the former author also obserued. There is some friend, saith he, that turneth to emnitie, and taketh part against thee, and in contention he will declare thy shame. And in another place: There is some companion, which in prosperitie reioyceth with his friend, but in the time of trouble he is against Cap. 37. 4. him. Of which the Prophet Dauid hauing experience, complaineth, My familiar friend (saith he) whom I trusted, which did eate of my bread, hath lift vp his heele against me. So that inPsal. 41. 9. this worldly friendship the prouerb truelie taketh place; Too much friendship maketh way for hatred; yea, in truth there is no emnity so dangerous, as that which hath it foundationAmicitia nimia facit odij locum. vpon the ruines of loue; and as in nature, the purest substance is turned into the most loathsome corruption; so the hottest loue, which hath no other ground but carnall respects, degenerates oftentimes into the most deadly hatred, and hurtfull emnitie. For being priuie to all their friends secrets and counsels, and well acquainted with their state and condition, they are the more enabled thereby to doe them the greater mischiefe when their loue is turned to spite and malice. Euen as a traitor is much more dangerous then a professed enemie, and a fugitiue souldier more pernicious in time of warre, then he that assaulteth with open violence. To Inimicus vitari potest, amicus non potest si insidiare velit, &c. Amb. offic. lib. 3. cap. 13. which purpose one saith: that an enemy may be shunned, but a friend cannot, if he meaneth to be treacherous; and we may easilie take heed of him, vnto whom wee haue not committed our counsels, but it is scarce possible to preuent his mischiefes, to whom we haue entrusted them.

But as this worldly friendship is very dangerous and hurtfull§. Sect. 7. Worldly friēdship pernicious to our soules. to our outward estate when it breaketh off; so it is much more pernicious to our soules, and spirituall estate whilest it lasteth and continueth; as being one of the most forcible meanes, which either Satan or the world hath to poison and corrupt vs with sinne; and one of the most pearcing arrowes in al their quiuer of tentations, wherewith they inflict deepe and incurable wounds into our consciences: whilest
on the one side we frequent their company, see their euill examples, heare their wicked speeches and discourses, and giue them audience, when as they allure and intice vs vnto sinne; and on the other side are readie to yeeld vnto them in all their desires, for feare of displeasing them; and to like of all they doe, because wee affect their persons. In regard whereof one saith, that that friendship is very harmefull, which
Noxiae sunt amicitiae quae cum malitia contrahuntur, &c. Basil. Hom. 9. de ira. is contracted with maliciousnesse. For it is the law and condition of this friendship, by a similitude and likenesse of nature to infuse wickednesse into those who are in amitie with them. For as in pestilent places, the aire stealingly and by little and little attracted, doth infect the bodie with an hidden disease; so through wicked acquaintance, we sucke in manifold euils, although wee doe not presently perceiue the discommoditie of it. In which respect wee are to contemne, yea, to hate this friendship of wicked worldlings, as being but like sugar, which inticeth vs to drinke the poison of sinne; and the diuels most preuailing orator, in perswading vs to neglect all dutie, and to set our hearts open for the entertaining of sinne.

And thus haue I shewed the manifold euils which come§. Sect. 8. Their obiection answered, who say they haue had no hurt by the friendship of the wicked. vnto vs, through the familiar society & friendship of wicked worldlings. Against which, if any shal obiect their owne experience, namely, that they haue frequented such company, and intertained such loue and amitie, and yet feele themselues neuer the worse: to such I answere, that either they are so bad alreadie, that they cannot be made much worse; or haue but a while bin lincked in this fellowship, and so the poison hath not as yet his operation; or if longer time they haue consorted with them, and yet feele no ill, it is because wickednesse hath growne on them by degrees, and hath therefore through their negligence bin insensible, they hauing Sanè nemo repente fit turpissimus, et vix aliquis in hunc affectum nequitiae nisi praua consuetudine pertransiuit. Bernard. declamat. in Mat. 19. rather declined by little and little, then suddenly fallen into these mischiefes. But let not this incourage them in their course, their case herein being common with those who are deepely plunged into sinne; For there is not any man that is suddenly outragiouslie wicked, but commeth to the height of this diuellish habit, by degrees, and through a continuall euill custome. Great floods doe not suddenly rise, but after much
dropping; mettals are not presently melted, as soone as they are put into the furnace; greene wood doth not forthwith flame out, as soone as it is laid on the fire: but yet within a while with much and often raining the waters arise, with great and continuall heate the mettals melt, and the greene wood after some weake resistance is burned and consumed. And so although the fire of Gods grace burning in vs is not quenched at first (as it were) with this water of worldly wickednesse; yea rather perhaps it may through opposition, make it to gather his strength, and burne more hotly; but yet if it be much and often cast vpon it, it will in the end put it cleane out. Although (saith one) thou were made of iron, Isidor. lib. 2. soliloqu. yet standing continually before a great fire, thou wouldest at last be dissolued and softned; and he that still dwelleth at the next dore to danger, cannot long be safe. By assiduitie a man is often deliuered ouer as captiue to sin, and oftentimes familiaritie hath intangled men, and ministred vnto them occasion of sinning; and what the euill at the first could not, that lingring assi • uitie and custome hath atchieued. At the first, it may be a Christian mans heart riseth, and his soule abhorreth the wickednesse which he seeth committed euen by his dearest friends, but at the second time he is not so much mooued, and when he is a little inured thereunto, the loue of his friend weakening the hatred which he beareth the sinne, he is content to winke at it, and then to tolerate it, and after to like it, and by and by to imitate it, and within a while after to approoue, defend, and boast of it. At the first hearing of blasphemie, ribauldrie and corrupt communication, it may bee for the present wee feele not our soules hurt and infected, but yet (as one saith) it leaueth seeds in the mind, and euen after we are departed from Senec. epist. 123. them, euill sprouteth vp. And as those who heare pleasing musick, haue, when the melodie is ceased, the tunes still sounding in their eares; so the talke of wicked men doth longer continue with vs, then it is in hearing: and it is not easie to forget a sound which is so sweet to our corrupt flesh. Neither doth the lingring growth of our corruptions, which by degrees creep vpon vs lessen our hurt and danger, but rather much increaseth them, seeing it ouercommeth vs, before wee feele our
selues incountred, and inthralleth vs in the deepe dungeon of sinne, before we perceiue our selues taken prisoners. As therefore those diseases which grow vpon vs by degrees vpon small and not apparant causes, are of all others most dangerous and incurable: so these spiritual diseases of the soule, which steale vpon vs by little and little, are not easily cured, and most endanger vs, because they are not discerned, vntill custome hath giuen them full possession, and as it were, turned them into nature. And as men are no lesse fearefull of a lingring consumption, then of a hot burning ague, because it doth more certainly destroy vs, though it doth not assault vs with like violence; so that corruption, which stealingly infecteth vs through the familiaritie and neere friendship which we haue with a ciuil worldling, doth oftentimes more endanger vs, then all the violent prouocations of men notoriously wicked, whereby they labour suddenly, and all at once to plunge vs headlong into wickednes.

div.trailer: The end of the first Booke.

div.head: THE SECOND BOOKE: WHEREIN THE CHRISTIAN IS armed against those tentations of the world, which are grounded, on the alluring baits, of Honors, Riches, and Pleasures.
CHAP. I.
Of those tentations generally which are grounded vpon worldly things.
div.p:
ANd thus much concerning those worldlie§. Sect. 1. That these worldly things are Satans chiefe baits to draw our harts from God. tentations, which arise from the persons of wicked worldlings, both in regard of their societie and friendship. Now wee are to proceede vnto those which are grounded vpon worldly things; al which by the Apostle Iohn are referred to three heads, to wit, voluptuousnes, whose obiect are vnlawfull and immoderate pleasures; couetousnes, whose obiect are riches; and ambition, whose obiect are honours and preferments. All (saith he) that is in the world, as the lust of the flesh (that is, voluptuousnes) the lust of the eyes (that is, couetousnes) and the pride of life, (that is, ambition) is not of the Father, but is of the world. And these are the chiefe things which Satan, and the world vse, as their alluring baites and inueigling snares, wherewith they allure vs vnto sinne, and withdraw our hearts from God, and the loue of spirituall things: these are those bands wherewith they tie our hearts fast vnto the earth; these are the Idols which they set vp in our harts with which worldlings (forsaking the true God) commit grosse idolatrie, by louing and trusting in them more then vpon Gods power
and promises. Finally, these are the rewards & wages, wherwith Satan and the world hire men to doe them seruice, and to tire themselues, spend their strength, and consume their life, in the works of darknesse.

Against which tentations it behoues vs to bend all our§. Sect. 2. That these worldly things honours, riches, and pleasures are in their owne nature good, and the gifts of God. strength, if we would not be ouercome; and to put on all the spirituall armour prescribed in Gods word, wherby we may be inabled to make resistance. But lest in auoiding one extreame wee runne into another, reiecting the creatures of God, because of our owne corruption, and leauing the lawfull vse, because of the vnlawfull abuse; I will shew what these things are in themselues, and what vnto vs; in what respects they are to be loued, desired, and vsed as good; and in what respects to bee contemned and reiected as euill; how they are to be accounted Gods blessings, & how the worlds baits to allure vs vnto sinne. All which I will shew, first generally, & then particularly. For the former we are to know, that all these three, to wit, honours, riches, and pleasures, are in their owne nature good; for they are the good creatures and gifts of God, which were approued by his owne testimonie; where it is said, that God saw all that he had made, and Gen. 1. 30. loe it was very good. And lest we should thinke that together with man, they also haue lost all their goodnesse through his fall; the Apostle speaking of the creatures, as they are now in their owne nature, saith, that euery creature of God is good, and nothing ought to bee refused, if it bee receiued with thanksgiuing. To this purpose one saith: These things O Lord 1. Tim. 4. 4. Haec tua sunt, bona sunt, quiae tu bonus ista creasti nil nostrum est in ijs, &c. Aug. in ciuit. dei. lib. 15. cap. 22. Pro. 22. 4. are thine, and they are good, because thou the chiefe goodnes hast created them; there is nothing of ours in them, but that we sinne in ouermuch louing them, inordinately preferring the creatures before thee who hast created them. Yea they are not only creatures of Gods making, but also blessings which he promiseth vnto those that serue him, as temporall rewards of their loue and obedience. For so the Wise man saith, that the reward of humilitie & the feare of God, is riches, & glorie, and life; where pleasures also are inferred, without which life is no life. Neither hath any but the faithfull any true right vnto these gifts of God, but are meere vsurpers, seeing they do not performe
the condition of Gods donation, in louing, fearing, and seruing him; and to those only belongs the right of inheritance, vnto whom the blessing also appertaineth. Finally, the Lord hath bestowed these his gifts vpon his seruants to good vses and ends, namely, that he might be glorified in them, and they furthered and incouraged in the performance of all good duties. And therefore needs must these things be good, seeing they are good creatures, gifts and blessings, created and bestowed by our good God, on good and faithfull men, and that to good ends and purposes.

But yet howsoeuer these things are good, yet not absolutely§. Sect. 3. That these worldly things are mutablie good, and therefore subiect to abuse and corrupti •• . Rom. 8. 19. 20. 21. and immutably, seeing they are subiect vnto corruption, and to be abused by man; in regard whereof the Apostle saith, that the feruent desire of the creature waiteth when the sonnes of God shall be reueiled; because the creature is subiect to vanitie, not of it owne will, but by reason of him who hath subdued it vnder hope; because the creature also shall be deliuered from the bondage of corruption, into the glorious libertie of the sonnes of God, &c. And to the same purpose Augustine saith, that these things mutably good, are therefore good, because
Bona mutabilia propterca bona sunt, quoniam a summ bono facta sunt, &c. Aug. in Aduersar. le. gis et p • ophet. lib. 1. cap. 5. they are made by the chiefe goodnesse, and therefore mutable, because they are not made of his owne substance, but of nothing; in regard whereof they are subiect to corruption, and apt to degenerate, vnlesse they be continually preserued by the same powerfull goodnesse, by which they were at the first created. By reason of which mutabilitie they are not good in any high degree of excellencie, but to bee reputed among such good things as are of meanest esteeme, as being of an indifferent and low qualitie and nature, in comparison of spirituall and heauenly things. Neither doe they vnchangeably hold this degree of goodnesse which they haue, but as the Chameleon changeth her colour according to the thing vnto which it adioyneth; so they hold their vertue and goodnesse whilest they are in the possession of the good and vertuous; but become euill to the euill, and readie instruments of all manner of sinne and wickednesse, whilest they are vnder the gouernment of the wicked and vngodly. So that in respect of vs these things are neither good nor euill,
but of an indifferent nature, good to those who vse them well, and euill to those that abuse them vnto sin, and accordingly they are bestowed of God indifferently both to the good and euill. To which purpose one saith, that God would Aug. in Psal. 66. enarrat. tom. 8. haue these temporall things lie out in common betweene the godly and the wicked, because if he should giue them only to the good, the euill would thinke that for their sake the righteous serued God: and if he should giue them only to the euill, those who are weake in goodnes would feare to be conuerted, lest these things should be wanting vnto them, &c.
