Againe, we see by experience, that the heauier a body is, the slower it naturally is, and vnfit for motion, and the lighter it is, the more swift and nimble; and yet who seeth not, that a mans body which is leane and weake, though it be light, yet moueth slowly; and that his body who is in good liking, strong and vigorous, though it bee more heauie, is quicke and swift in motion? If therefore health can worke this great difference, and make that which is heauie to be caried by another, light to be caried by it selfe; euen as the want thereof maketh that heauie to it selfe, which is light vnto another; how much more shal this be effected by immortality, and the quickening vertue of Gods powerfull spirit? But
whether this motion shall be equal in swiftnesse to our souleAugust. de Spirit. & anima lib. cap. 65. Erunt quippe ula corpora vt animus agili • , vt sol perspicua. August. de cognit. verae. vitae lib. cap. 45. Thom. Aquin; Supplem. quaest. 83. art. 1. and thoughts, and whether our bodies shall be able in an instant to passe from place to place, as some do iudge; or whether they shall onely moue with great and extraordinarie speed, passing whither they wil, though it bee in great distance, in a very short time, wee cannot determine; howsoeuer I thinke this latter much more probable. Finally, our bodies being freed from their earthly grosnesse, shal bee subtil and of a much more fine and pure substance, not by diminution of their quantitie, for in this respect it shall retaine al his dimensions, not by reason of any rarefaction, as water is made subtill, in the mists and clouds; for then our bodies could not be felt, as our Sauiour Christs was after his resurrection; but in respect of the compleate perfection of it, in it essence and kind, which perfection it hath from the dominion of Gods spirit dwelling in it, and of the glorified soule which doth informe it, vnto which it is subiect; and by reason of this perfection which it hath from them, is fit and able for the performing of all actions and motions of the soule wherein it will imploy it; for otherwise it would still be a burthen and hinderance to the soule as it is in this life. And in respect of this subtility; whereby it is fitted to be subiect, and as it were the ready instrument of the soule, it cannot bee hindred in it motion▪ by the opposition of any solid body, nor yet included, imprisoned, or violently detained in any place. Of which wee haue an example in our Sauiour Christs body after his resurrection, which by reason of the subtility thereof did suddenly appeare vnto his Apostles, andLuk. 24. 31. presently againe disappeared, and also did come amongst them into the roome where they were, the doores beingIoh. 20. 19. shut; not by penetrating their substance, which is against the nature of a body, consisting of flesh and bones; but by their inuisible yeelding to giue passage to this most perfect body, that it might hereby bee imployed in such actions as his holy spirit, and most diuine soule thought fit. Finally, to this subtiltie we may also referre that most acute, quicke, and exquisite perception and comprehension of the senses, which the glorified body shal haue, and the puritie of the affections,
whereby (notwithstanding they communicate with the body) they shall bee most obedient and seruiceable to the mind, and no more trouble and disturbe it with their grosnesse and impurity.

Vnto these spiritual qualities we may adde diuers others,§. Sect. 6. That our bodies shall be indued with great strength, and freed from suffering any hurt. as namely, they shall bee indued with great power and strength, and enioy for euer most perfect health: and whereas now the soule being a spirit, mighty, and powerfull, cannot shew it strength, because of the weaknesse of the body, which is it organ and instrument; in respect whereof we see by experience, that it exerciseth it functions and actions more strongly or weakely, according to the measure of bodily strength and health which it vseth and imployeth: in our heauenly countrie our bodies shall enioy such perfect health, and bee indued with such powerfull strength, that they shal match the ability of the soule, and become so fit for it in vigour and might, that it shall not as it doth now hinder the actions thereof with it weaknesse, and wearines, but become a perfect and sufficient instrument for all imployments. And this quality the Apostle attributeth vnto it, where he saith, that it is sowne in weakenesse▪ but is raised in power. 1. Cor. 15. 43. So also they shall be indued with impassibility, and bee freed from suffring any hurt or detriment from any outward agent, to which in this life they are so much subiected; and consequently they shall bee freed from all alteration, diminution, and corruption: for seeing all passion or suffering proceedeth from an ouerbearing power of the agent ouer the patient; and for as much as nothing can thus ouerrule, but by ouercomming the forme of the patient, which resisteth all outward force as long as it hath any ability: and finally, seeing our humane bodies shal be perfectly subiected vnto our soules, by which they are informed, euen as the soule also is perfectly subiected vnto God; by whose vertue and power they are defended from all outward violence, hurts and iniuries; therefore necessarily they become impassible, and free from euill, because there is no outward agent able to ouercome our powerfull soules, and the more powerfull spirit of God; nor so strong and mighty to hurt
our bodies, as they are to preserue and defend them.

Finally, they shall bee adorned with most compleat and§. Sect 7. That our bodies shall be beautifull, and of a comely stature and proportion. perfect beautie, and that both in respect of the comely and due proportion, and symmetrie of al the parts and members, and fit quantity and stature of the whole body; and also in respect of the colour and complexion. So that then our bodies shal be freed from al maimes, defects, and monstrous shapes, from all deformities, blemishes, and disgraces; from al disproportion, and vnseemely shape of the members one with another, and in themselues: and the whole man shal bee adorned and graced with a goodly shape, feature and comelinesse. And as there shal bee perfection of al the parts of the body, so also of the whole in respect of age and stature. For although wee can gather little concerning this point directly and plainely out of the Scriptures, yet may it be inferred by consequence, and concluded by good reason; for if old age and childhood be the infirmities and imperfections of man, the one not hauing attained the perfection of nature, and the other being past it, and the middle age most compleat and perfect, and seeing both a giantlike and dwarfish stature, are the aberrations of nature, and much more imperfect then a proportionable person, and a body of a conuenient and comely quantity; then it wil follow hereupon that al the saints of heauen shal bee of a middle and perfect age, and though not of an exact equality, yet of a comely and goodly stature, for as much as in the state of blessednesse al imperfections and infirmities shal bee taken away, and that which is most perfect and excellent shal be receiued and inioyed. And of this I am the more certainely persuaded, because God in the first creation, making man his most perfect creature, did make him neither a child nor old man, but of a middle and perfect age, nor yet of huge stature (for giants came long after, through that monstrous and vnequal matching of the sons of God with the daughters of men) nor ofGen. 6. 4. dwarfish smalnesse, in which there is no maiesty or comelinesse; but of such a meane and conuenient stature, as might make maiesty and beauty meet to gether; and therefore seeing our resurrection shal be a renouation, and (as it were) a
new and more perfect creation, then the first in Adam; it is more then probable, that there will bee a conformitie, and likenesse betweene them, sauing that the latter shall be much more perfect and excellent, God then purposing to shew his extraordinarie goodnesse, mercie, wisdome and power, in aduancing the blessed estate and condition of the vessels of grace, whom he hath chosen to honour and euerlasting glorie. Againe, if the Lord promiseth to his Church, euen in the state of imperfect regeneration, such a vigorous and flourishing condition, that there should bee neither child nor oldEsa. 65. 20. man amongst them, in respect of the infirmities and weakenesses of these ages, but all should bee of full and perfect strength; how much more will he conferre and bestow vpon vs this vigorous perfection and strength in our renouation and state of glorie? Finally, we know that our Sauiour Christ continued in this life to his perfect age, and before ye time, wherin according to the common course of nature, his bodie shuld haue declined, he laid it aside by death, and after rising againe, he ascended with it into glorie in this perfect age. From which some not improbably doe gather, Credibilius accipitur & probabilius plenas • tates resurrecturas, vt reddatur munere quod accessurum erat tempore. August. de resur. corporum serm. 4. tom. 10. serm. 147. §. Sect. 8. That our bodies shall be shining and glorious. Exod. 34. 30. that seeing we shall be made conformable vnto our head in glorie, we shal not be vnlike him in this vigorous maturitie and perfect age; but shal, if we die in our infancy, attaine vnto that perfection and ripenes, by the vertue and power of God, which time & continuance here would haue brought vs vnto; and if wee die in old age, shall by the same diuine might, bee freed from al the infirmities thereof, and be renewed and restored againe to our perfect, vigour, strength and beautie.

Vnto this symmetrie and fit proportion of al the members and parts, shall be added the other part of beautie, consisting not onely in the pleasing mixture of those two liuely colours of white and red, but also in the bright shining, and glorious maiestie of the body. For if Moses mortall and earthly bodie, being but a while conuersant with God, did so participate of his glory, that his face did shine, when hee returned into the congregation, so as Aaron and the people could not looke vpon him, till he had cast a vaile ouer it; how much more shal ours, being glorified, immortall, and heauenlie,
when they shall be continually conuersant with God, and inioy his glorious presence for euermore? And if our SauiourMatth. 17. • . Christ, before he was glorified, in his temporary transfiguration, did shine like the Sunne in his glorious brightnesse, and had euen his clothes made as white as the light, then shall we also the members of his bodie, be conformable to Christ our head, & be like vnto him in this glorious quality, though not in equalitie. And this also the Scriptures plainely testifie; for so Daniel saith, that they who be wise, shal shine as the Dan. 12. 3. brightnes of the firmament, and they that turne many vnto righteousnes, shall shine as the stars for euer and euer. Which is to be vnderstood comparatiuely, namely, that these shal as much excel other of the Saints in glorious brightnes, as the firmament the earth, or the starres the firmament: for when Christ simply speaketh of the shining brightnes of ye Saints, he saith of them all, that the iust men shal then shine as the Sunne in the Matth. 13. 43. kingdom of their Father. The which glorie and brightnes shal extend euen to their very garments, and robes of immortality and righteousnes; for, as ye Apostle saith, the spouse of Christ, the Church, shal be arraied with pure linnen and shining. To thisApoc. 19. 8. August. de rectitud. cathol. conuers. tract. tom 9. purpose one saith, that men in the kingdom of heauen shal be like vnto the Angels, not in substance, but in blessednes; and the iust shal shine like the Sun in the kingdō of their Father: and if the brightnesse of the bodie shal match the light of the Sunne, what doe you thinke shal be the glory of the soule? Now if we further adde, that this beautie and brightnesse, shal be ioyned with great maiestie and glorie, what can bee added to this excellencie and perfection? but herein we shal us much excell the Sunne, as a liuing reasonable, and glorified creature excelleth another which is destitute of life, senseles and meerely natural; at which the Apostle aimeth, where he saith, that though our bodie be 1. Cor. 15. 43. sowne in dishonour, base and contemptible, yet it is raised in glorie. The which may further appeare, if we consider that the Scriptures in many places teach vs, that in the resurrection to this heauenly happinesse, our bodies shal be like the glorified bodie of our Sauiour Christ; for so the Apostle telleth vs, that Rom. 8. 29. God hath predestinate vs to be made like to the image of his Sonne, that he
might hee the first borne of many brethren. So elsewhere hee saith, that such 1. Cor. 15. 48. 49. as is the earthly Adam, such are they which are earthly; and such as is the heauenly Adam, such are they also that are heauenly. And as we haue borne the image of the earthly, so shall we beare the image of the heauenly. And in another place he affirmeth, that 2. Cor. 3. 18. we all behold, as in a mirror, the glory of the Lord with open face, and are changed into the same image, from glory to glory, as by the spirit of the Lord. And againe he saith, that when Col. 3. 4. Christ, which is our life shall appeare, we shall appeare with him in glory. But most plainely in the Epistle to the Philippians hee teacheth vs, that Phil. 3. 21. Christ Iesus shall change our vile body, that it may be fashioned like vnto his glorious body, according to the warking, whereby he is able to subdue all things to himselfe. And with him agreeth the testimonie of the Apostle Iohn, as being both guided by the same spirit; 1 Iohn 3. 2. We know (saith he) that when he shall appeare, wee shall be like vnto him. And as this is confirmed with plentifull testimonies, so it standeth with good reason; for seeing Iesus Christ is our head, and we the members of his body, decorum and comlinesse requireth, that wee should bee conformable and like vnto him; for ill would it beseeme a glorious head, to haue an inglorious bodie, and not to haue the rest of the members sutable with it in maiestie and perfection. Now if we further inquire, what is the glorie of the bodie of Christ our head, the Apostle Iohn, who did behold it but through these dim spectacles of mortalitie wil tel vs, that his face shine Apoc. 1. 16. as the Sunne shineth in his chiefe strength; and yet this was but a glimpse of his glory, such as this blessed Apostle was capable of in this fraile condition, and could behold with his weake sight; and therefore our Sauiour himselfe further saith, that at the last iudgement, the Sonne of man shall come in Matth. 16. 27. the glorie of his Father. In comparison of whose shining brightnesse, and most glorious maiestie, the Sunne is but a shadow, yea grosse and palpable darkenesse. Seeing therfore Christ shall be like vnto his father, and we like vnto Christ, how beautifull and glorious shal we be at the day of his blessed appearing? Now if we would know by what meanes our earthly bodies shal be made thus beautifull, and full of glorious
maiestie, it is by that communion which we shall haue with Christ our head, by his spirit, and by that communion which we shall haue. with God through him. For he being vnited to the Godhead, and we vnto him, it followeth herevpon, that as he communicateth with his father in glory and maiestie, so wee also communicate with him, and by this conduit pipe, haue the streames of glory and happinesse from God, who is the fountaine of al maiestie and blessednesse, deriued vnto vs.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
Of the felicitie and blessednesse of the whole man, bodie and soule, consisting in his freedome from euill, and fruition of good.
div.p:
ANd thus haue I shadowed out the ioyes, which§. Sect. 1. That we shall no more be molested with our turbulent affections. we shal attaine vnto in our bodies and soules seuerally, when we come into our heauenly countrie. Now wee are to speake of those which concerne the whole man, consisting both in our freedome from euils; and in our communication of that positiue good, and those vnspeakable ioyes which are there prepared for vs. The euils from which wee shal then be deliuered, are either internal, or external; the former are such as are inherent in our selues, and the other adherent and accidental; from al which we shal be freed in this day of our ful redemption. As first, we shal be deliuered from the corruption, and troublesome disorder of our turbulent affections; some whereof, being in their owne nature euil; and some vnprofitable, and of no further vse, shal be vtterly abolished; and the rest which are stil necessarie, shal be perfectly sanctified, and made so holy and pure, that they shal in al things be subiect to Gods wil, and to the rule of holy reason, and fit and readie to serue and glorifie God. Then shal malice cease, seeing there shal bee no enemie to maligne: there pining enuie shal haue no place, because our owne desires shal be fullie satisfied, and we shal be as glorious
and happie as we would be; and if any haue more glorie then we, our ioy shal be the greater because we shal communicate with him therein, by reason of our perfect loue▪ There shal be no place for scorneful contempt, and proud disdaine▪ because euery one shall bee glorious and happie, and ye • haue no greater happinesse and glorie, then euery • ther of the Saints shal like and approoue. Neither then shall wee haue any doubts, or bee subiect to despaire, because alo •• hopes shal bee fully satisfied, and we shal haue secure assurance of Gods loue. There shall be no need of desiring, longing, and wishing, because we shal inioy al which wee can desire; and all that we can wish is, that (if it were possible) we might more glorifie God, who of his infinit grace and mercy hath thus glorified vs. There we shal not bee distracted betweene hope and feare, for our hopes shal be fully satisfied, and all cause of feare shal bee taken away, so that those passions of dull stupiditie, pale wannesse, and trembling horror, shal no more annoy vs, seeing we shal be freed from al danger of losing our heauenly happinesse, and of being circumuented by the malice of any enemy: then shall our hearts no more boile with anger, nor burne with desire of cruel reuenge; seeing there shal be no euil to offend vs, nor any foe to oppose against vs; for the Lambe of God, and the Lion of the Tribe of Iuda▪ wil at that day haue al his and our enemies subdued and trodden vnder soote: There shal bee no place for zeale, seeing we shal al alike loue God, and chearefully ioyne together in his worship and seruice; nor yet for hatred, seeing sinne shall be abolished both in our selues and others; there shal be no shamefastnesse, because no guiltines; nor no need of mercie, because there is no sense of miserie. There shal be no ielousies and suspitions, because our hearts being transparent, we shal clearely see, and bee certainely assured of one anothers loue; nor contēding emulation, vnlesse it be, who shal loue God best, and shew most loue, both to Christ our head, and al our fellow-members of his glorious bodie. Finally, in this heauenly ioy, there shal be no place for sorrow, heauinesse, griefe and mourning, no sighing and groning, weeping and sobbing: for at that day the Lord wil
Esay 25. 8. Apoc. 7. 17. wipe away the teares from all faces and e • es, and there shal in this new Ierusalem, Apoc. 21. 4. Esay 65. 29. & the voice of we • ping be no more heard, nor the voice of crying; and because death, griefe and paine, shal haue no place, the 60. 20. daies of sorrow and mourning shall then bee • nded. But the other affections which are of necessarie vse, shal then being purified and perfitted, bee made seruiceable for the glorifying of God. For there we shal haue perfection of loue, and no more affecting the world, and worldly things, nor the sinfull pleasures of the flesh, but contemning the one, in comparison of our heauenly excellencies, and being quite wained and purged from the other, wee shall with all our hearts, minds and soules, loue the Lord aboue all things, and his holy Saints and Angels, our brethren, and copartners in ioy, as our selues. There shall we haue perfect affiance in God, securely resting, and wholly depending vpon his loue and power for our preseruation, and the continuance of our ioy; and then shall our hearts and minds be full of holie admiration, and rauishing wonder, to see and inioy the glorious Trinitie, and the vnconceiueable pleasures of this heauenly happinesse. Then shall we be full of ioy and gladnesse in the fruition of God, and that eternal felicitie, yea we shall triumph with ioy, and with an holy boasting glory in our gladnesse. And finally, we shal then haue peaceful minds, and full contentment, hauing what wee will, and not hauing what we will not. Neither shall there at this day be any reluctation or repugnancie betweene our passions and affections, the one crossing the other, as they doe in this life, but then, they being all subiected to holy reason, shall haue conformitie,§. Sect. 2. That we shall be freed from all impotencie and sinne. Hic preceptum est vt non peccemus: ibi praemium est non posse peccari, &c. August. ad Bonifac. lib. 3. cap. 7. tom. 7. peace, and concord among themselues.

Furthermore, in these heauenly ioyes wee shall bee freed from all weakenesse and impotencie, and shall bee indued with power and abilitie to doe whatsoeuer we wil; for (as I haue said) our wils shal be perfectly conformable to Gods wil, so that he shal wil whatsoeuer we wil, whose wil and power nothing can resist. So also we shal be freed from al sin, not onely in respect of the guilt and punishment, but also the corruption and power of sinning. For (as one saith) here wee are commanded that we doe not sinne; there we are rewarded
that we cannot sinne; heere we are inioyned not to obey our sinful concupiscence, there our reward shal • e, not to haue any concupiscence vnto sin. So elsewhere: we shal not then sin, not only in act and deed, but not so much as in concupiscence and desire, when as we shal behold the face of God, which subdueth al concupiscence vnto euil: for so sweet Satietas crit insatiabilis, nullum fastidium: semper esuriemus, semper saturi erimus. August. de Tempore, Serm. 1. Dominic. in 70. Tom. 10. is he and beautiful, that when we see him nothing else can delight vs; but there we shal haue an vnsatiable satiety, without lothing, and being alwaies ful we shal stil hunger. Now what can be more cōfortable then this, to be freed not only from sin, but from power of sinning▪ to be deliuered not only from the wrath and dispeasure of God, but from committing any thing which might deserue it? what can be more effectual to make vs loath this world; and with longing desire to seeke this heauenly and holy kingdome, and with the Apostle Paul to be dissolued, and to be with Christ, seeingRom. 7. 24. then we shal be freed from this bodie of sin, and be vnburthened of this massie and heauie load of wickednesse? the sense whereof made the Apostle Paul lamentablie to complaine:2. Cor. 12. 8. O wretched man that I am, who shall deliuer me from the bodie of this death; and to labour so earnestly with God by heartie prayer, that he might be freed from these buffettings of Satan, and this pricke in the flesh? Finally, as we shal at this day be freed from sinne the cursed mother, so also from death the dreadful ofspring of that wicked parent; for then being made equal with the Angels, Luke 20. 36. we shal (as our Sauiour saith) die no more, neither Apoc. 21. 4. shal there be there any more death, seeing Esay • 5. 8. 1. Cor. 15. 26. God will destroy death for euer, as the Prophet speaketh; so that it being swallowed vp in victorie, we may with the Apostle triumphingly say, O death where is thy sting! O graue 1. Cor. 15. 54. 55. 57. where is thy victorie! and conclude with that grateful praise of Gods mercie and goodnesse; Thankes be vnto God which hath giuen vs victorie, through Iesus Christ our Lord.

And as we shal be deliuered frō these internal euils, so also§. Sect. 3. That in our heauenly happinesse we shall be freed from all externall euils: as painfull labour, wicked companie, and the assaults of all enemie • ▪ &c. frō those which are external & accidental: as for example, we shal be freed from our painful labors, wherin we heere spend our liues, & cōsume our strength; & shal obtaine eternal rest, and keepe a perpetual Sabbath vnto God: & whereas in this
life we cānot lawfully eat our bread, vnlesse we earne it with the sweat of our browes; nor purchase vnto our selues any thing which is good, without the coine of painful labour; in this estate of blessednesse this troublesome toile shal cease▪ and we shal attaine vnto whatsoeuer we can desire, with rest and quietnesse. So also in this heauenly happinesse we shal be freed from the societie and company of worldly wicked men, and shal no more be corrupted and poisoned by their euil example, whilest either we are drawne to imitate them, or to giue some approbation to their sins by word or countenance, because we would not incurre their displeasure, or1. Pet. 2. 8. lose some worldly aduantage: nor yet be offended when by their euil conuersation they dishonor God, and vex our righteous soules, making vs often to crie out with Dauid: Psalme 120. 5. Woe is me that I remaine in Meshech, and dwell in the tents of Kedar: for being deliuered from this sinful world, we looke 2. Pet. 3. 13. for new heauens, and a new earth, according to Gods promise, wherein dwelleth righteousnesse, as the Apostle speaketh. Againe, as we shal be deliuered from the companie, so also from the crueltie of wicked worldlings, and be no more endangered to their iniuries, oppressions, and bloodie persecutions. For then we shal haue the vpper hand of al who assault vs; and triumph in victorie ouer them, who haue formerly troden vs vnder foot: then shal our noisome prisons be changed into a paradise of heauenly pleasures: then shal our bands and bolts, be turned into most glorious and precious ornaments of ioy and happines: then for mens railings and proud menaces, we shal haue the approbation of God; and applause of the Saints and Angels: then our reproches and disgraces shal be turned into heauenly honor, and euerlasting glorie; and for our bitter sufferings, and sore combats we shal haue a crowne of victorie, and a ful recompence of reward. Furthermore, we shal then be deliuered from the cruel assaults of our spiritual enemies, and attaine vnto, after a ful and final victorie, a glorious triumph, and euerlasting peace. In this world we are exercised and turmoiled in a continual conflict against the cruel enemies of our saluation, Satan, the world, and our owne flesh: and sometime Amelek, sometime Israel
hath the vpper hand: but then we shal be freed from these troubles and dangers, so as we shal no more need to feare the assaults of Satan, the allurements and persecutions of the world, not the frailtie and treacherie of our owne flesh; neither shal they then be able to ouercome and foile vs, nor so much as to assault vs, or once by al their power and malice to disturbe our ioyes: for in the heauenly happines (as one saith) In coelestibus gaudijs nullus perit amicus: nullus admittitur inimicus. August. Apocal. 21. 25. Iob 11. 16. no friend perisheth, nor enemie entreth: and therefore the gates of this heauenly citie need no shutting, because no enemie can approch vnto them. Finally, by this heauenly happinesse we shal be exempted and freed from all miseries and afflictions, with which this mortal life is made bitter and irkesome, and then (as Zophar speaketh) we shall forget our miseries, or remember them as waters that are past: for there Benè regnum Dei aestati comparatur▪ quoniam tunc moeroris nostri nubila transeunt, & vita dies aterni solis claritate fulgescunt. Gregor. lib. 40 Homil. Homil. 1. shal be no thunder, lightnings, and earth-quakes, no stormie tempests, scorching heate, nor extremitie of cold; there shal be no nakednesse, famine, warre, or plague; no griefe for the departure of true friends, nor discontent for the treacherie and infidelitie of those which are false. But I shal not need to insist in particulars, seeing I haue alreadie more largely expressed them; vnto which, if need were, I doubt not but euery Reader may adde a great number out of his owne feeling and experience.

But as the whole man shal be freed from al euils; so also he§. Sect. 4. Reasons to proue that the ioyes of heauen must needs be most excellent and blessed. 1. Cor. 2. 9. shal be replenished with al good, and haue the fruition of those heauenly ioyes; which as they are vnconceiueable and infinit, so also they shal be endlesse and euerlasting: the former point the Apostle expresseth, where he saith, that the things which the eye hath not seene, neither eare hath heard, neither euer came into mans heart, are which God hath prepared for them that loue him. For if this be true of the great worke of our redemption, and of the hidden mysteries of Christian religion; how much more of that greater worke of our glorification, and of those vnspeakeable and incomprehensible ioyes, which God hath prepared for his Saints and Angels? which though they be vnto vs inuisible, and in themselues infinite, yet it shal not be amisse according to that smal measure of knowledge which we haue receiued, to adde something
of them, that by the consideration hereof, we may 〈◊〉 our affections weaned from the immoderate loue of these base and earthly vanities, and may haue our hearts so inflamed with these diuine and heauenly excellencies, that w • may vse al good meanes whereby we may attaine vnto them. And that we may the better conceiue of the greatnesse of▪ these ioies which are in themselues vnconceiueable, and may haue some little glimpse of this glorious light, I wil first set downe some reasons which may necessarily proue, that though in this place of banishment and time of ignorance, we cannot perfectly know and distinctly expresse what these ioyes are, yet it must needs be that they are most excellent; and afterward in some darke description shadow out this blessednesse and vnconceiueable glory, by setting downe (though but darkely) some particulars wherein their excellencie and perfection doth consist. The arguments to proue this point may be taken from the lesse to the greater, wherein we are to vse the best things of the world, as steps wherby being raised we may obtaine some dark prospect of this glorie, as it were a farre off; and as foiles to set out the better the incomparable beautie of that inualuable iewel the blessednesse of the Saints, and ioyes of heauen: for thus we may reason and necessarily conclude, that if the Lord who is infinite in al goodnes, wisdome and power, hath in this life prouided such a world for the good and bad together, for strangers as wel as his friends, yea for Turkes, Pagans, Infidels, Atheists, blasphemers, and persecutors, who are his professed enemies, as wel as his faithful seruants and deare children; what glory and happinesse hath he prepared for them alone in the world to come? If al haue in common such profits and delights, how glorious and great is that peculiar portion reserued for the Saints? if this world destinated to destruction, haue such a goodly vaulted roofe, adorned in the day with such a glorious Sunne, and in the night with the Moone, shining with such beautie and brightnes, bespangled also with such a multitude of starres, as it were precious shining iewels and rich diamonds, and such a goodly floore as the earth is, beautified with such variety of beasts, birds, trees, plants,
wholesome hearbes, and odoriferous flowers, no lesse delightfull to the sight for their admirable colours and figures, the • to the smel for their pleasant and sweet sent, and watred with so many crystal springs, and cleare streames, riuers and brookes; if we haue heere such musicke to delight the eare, the natural melodie of sweet singing birds, and the artificial harmonie of instruments and voices made by men; such delightful meats and drinkes to please the taste, and such soft 〈◊〉 beautiful rayment, goodly houses, and downe lodgings to delight the feeling; such orchards, such gardens, such walkes, such groues and shades, such fields, such medowes, such iewels and such treasures, in al which Gods enemies and reprobate men haue for the most part a far larger share, then the deare seruants of God; then how incomparably more excellent is the kingdom of heauen, the place of Gods owne residence, appointed to continue for euer, and purposely prepared for the holy Saints, the vessels of Gods mercie, ordained to life and glorie, whom God loueth as the apple of his eye, and for whose sake he made the world and al these creatures, and gaue his Sonne of infinite more worth then many worlds, to worke the worke of their redemption and saluation? If this world, which in comparison is but a cottage, prepared, not for lasting habitation, but as it were for present vse, like a shed to beare off a storme, be so stately built and so richly furnished, what shal we think of the state, beautie, and glorie which is reserued for vs in our manour and mansion houses, which are the chiefe seates of our heauenly inheritance? if the out-borders of Gods kingdome be so rich and beautiful, how much more excellent is the Kings Court, the great Monarch of heauen and earth, where he chiefely sheweth his glorie and Maiestie? If the Lord in his rich bountie, hath appointed vnto vs a place of such profit and delight for our exile and banishment, how rich and ful of al pleasures is his own countrie, which he reserueth for his own vse, to shew therin his own glorious presence; and for the reward of those whom he most graceth with his fauour? If the place of our pilgrimage haue so many delights & comforts, what pleasure and contentment shal we find in our heauenly
home? If we haue so many causes of ioy and reioycing in this valley of teares, and time of mourning for our sins; how shal we triumph with ioy, and be euen rauished with delight, on our mariage day, when as al our sins being forgiuen, and we reconciled and restored to the fauour of God, we shal haue the wedding betweene vs and our husband Christ solemnized,Luke 12. 36. 37. when as girding himselfe about, and making vs to sit downe at the table, he will come forth in great maiestie and glorie, and minister vnto vs at his feast; and afterwards carie vs into the bridall chamber of rest and happinesse, that we may eternally solace our selues with him in heauenly delights? If the world, which is but as it were a prison, wherein we are kept in safe custodie, til we be brought forth to appeare before Gods tribunal seat at the day of iudgement, be so excellently adorned, and so richly furnished with varietieIohn 14. 3. of delights, that worldly men could find in their hearts to remaine in it for euer; how excellent and absolute in al perfection, is that kingdome which he hath prepared to be the countrie and citie of the Saints, and his owne kingly palace which he hath built to be the seat of his Maiestie, and as it were the throne and theater of his glorie? Finally, if there be so great varietie of profits and pleasures in this world, where the Lord would haue his elect afflicted and corrected for their faults, that they might amend them, what infinite and incomparable treasures, ioyes and delights, hath he prouided for them in heauen, where he purposeth to reward them, to communicate vnto them the ful streames of his bountie and goodnes, to set vpon their heads crownes of glorie, and to cloth and compasse them about with ioy and happinesse? Surely the ioyes of this place are so infinit and incomprehensible, that the Apostle Paul who had seene them in vision only, was so delighted and euen rauished with them, that it was needful that he should haue a pricke in the flesh, and the2. Cor. 12. 7. messenger of Satan to buffet him, that he might not be exalted aboue measure, through the excellencie and abundance of reuelations. And therefore if Paul so triumphed in ioy, because he had for a short time beheld that heauenly happines in vision only, what vnspeakeable rauishing delight shal the
elect attaine vnto, who shall not only see it, but enioy it, and that not for a short time alone, but for euer and euer.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
That in heauen wee: shall abound with all happinesse, both in respect of our persons and estates. And that there are degrees of happinesse.
div.p:
BVt let vs not rest alone in generalities, and§. Sect. 1. That the image of God shall be perfectly repaired in vs. only know and beleeue, that such excellent ioyes are prepared for vs in heauen, as doe without all comparison exceed all the pleasures and comforts which this world affoordeth; but also let vs descend to some specials, and so (according to the darke measure of knowledge which we haue in this place of ignorance) let vs shadow out, and make as it were some rude draught of these diuine ioyes and heauenly happinesse, by setting downe some particulars, that so hauing some dim sight, and small taste of them, wee may thereby the rather be incouraged to seeke after their full fruition. And for order sake let vs distinguish them into either those ioyes the matter whereof we shall haue within vs; or those which are grounded on such things as are with vs and about vs. And first wee are to know that the image of God, which was wholly defaced and blotted out by sin, and is but in part only repaired by regeneration in this life, shall be perfectly renued and restored in the life to come. For as in our first creation we were made according to this image and similitude; so shall wee in farre greater perfection be restored vnto this diuine beautie in our regeneration at the last day; for then in our soules shall be a liuely resemblance of the wisedome, holinesse, and righteousnesse of God, and our bodies also shall carrie some similitude of him, not in their matter and substance (for they are corporall, and hee spirituall) but in their beautie, brightnes, and glorious maiestie. So that then wee shall not grope in the darknesse of ignorance, as we now doe, knowing little of God and his works,
or of our selues; but wee shall haue a cleere knowledge of these diuine excellencies, as we haue in part shewed, and shal more fully set downe hereafter. Thus also both in our bodies and soules we shall be throughly purged and cleansed from all filthinesse of sinne, prophanenes▪ and impietie, and we shal be holy as our God is holy, not in equality of measure which is impossible, but in similitude and resemblance. For now we shall be glorious, not hauing spot or wrinkle or any such thing, Ephes. 5. 27. but holy and without blame, as the Apostle speaketh▪ By reason of which puritie and holinesse of our natures, wee shall take all our delight in the seruice of God, glorifying and praising his holy name without ceasing for euermore. So shall we also in this life of glorie bee freed from all manner of vnrighteousnes, and be made throughly conformable both in our wils, affections, and actions to the most perfect will of God, which is the exact rule of all iustice, so as wee shall not in the least thought and desire decline or digresse from it on the right hand or on the left. Finally, our bodies shall be induced with diuine beautie, and haue such an excellent and heauenly maiestie shining in them, that these glorious beames shall easily with their likenes and resemblance, bring any that behold them to that sunne of perfect beautie, from whom they haue receiued all their light, and these little sparks of diuine excellencie, may guide them with their similitude to that glorious and infinite flame by which they haue been kindled.

Secondly, we shall be replenished with fulnes of ioy without§. Sect. 2. That the ioyes of heauen shall fill vs without glutting, and satiate vs without loathing. glutting, with satietie without loathing, and haue a perpetuall continuance of heauenly delights without cloying. For at the same time our desires shal be satisfied, and not decreased, our wils and longing shal be accomplished, and yet continued, and wee shall still thirst, and still haue out fill; so that by enioying our desires, we shall haue contentment, and by louing and desiring that wee enioy, all loathing shall be auoided. So Dauid saith, that in Gods presence there is fulnes of ioy, and yet notwithstanding this fulnes, there it a • his right Psal. 16. 11. and 17. 15. hand pleasures for euermore. And elsewhere, I will behold thy face in righteousnes▪ and when I awake I shall be satisfied with
thy image. Vpon the occasion of which words one obiecteth, that glutting and loathing followeth satietie: and then answereth,Gregor. Moral. lib. 18. cap. 2 • . that it is not so in this heauenly fulnes; for that there may be no griefe and vexation in the minde, desiring, they are satisfied; and lest there should bee any loathing in this fulnes, they desire this satietie. And therefore they desire without any trouble, because satietie accompanieth their desires, and they are satiate without cloying, because their satietie is still kindled and sharpned by their renued desiring. And this shall be our estate and disposition when wee haue this fruition of this fountaine of life; for at the same time we Satietas erit insatiabilis, nullum fastidium. Semper • suriemus, semper satari erimus. August. de tempore, serm. 1. in 70. Tom. 10. shall haue a satisfied thirst, and a thirsting satietie, hauing in our thirst not the least necessitie, nor in our satietie, any loathing, because being satisfied we shall thirst, and thirsting we shall be satisfied. So that wee shall haue in these heauenly ioyes an insatiable satietie, fulnes without loathing, and alwaies hungring, wee shall alwaies be satisfied. The which though it may seeme a riddle, yet wee may easily resolue it, if we consider that we haue this thirsting fulnes of ioy frō the fruition of God himself, who being infinite in all perfection, must needs fully satisfie all those who enioy him; & because he is thus infinite there can be no tedious cloying, or loathsome glutting, seeing they haue in him continuall and endlesse varietie of ioyes and delights; and being satisfied with the fruition of some, they see others after which they thirst and hunger. Neither must we thinke that they are wearie of the old, when they affect new, for this is only incident to worldly ioyes, which being imperfect doe not bring contentment; but euen the same heauenly ioyes, at the same true, worke both satietie and thirst, because being absolute in all perfection, they giue full contentment, and contenting vs they inflame our loue, and because wee loue them, they kindle still in vs a thirsting desire, to haue still the fruition of that which wee loue no lesse dearely then deseruedly. Now furthermore hauing this pleasing satietie not only in our appetites, affections, and desires, but also in our wils, and vnderstandings, and in al other powers and faculties of our bodies and soules, being perfectly ioyned in a bond of felicitie
one with another, and with their seuerall functions and operations; there will from hence follow such full and perfect contentment vnto euery one with their owne state and condition, that none will desire to be other then he is; nor wish to change with another, though he haue a superiour degree in glorie.

And this is that ioy and blessednes which we shal haue in§. Sect. 3. That the ioyes of heauen shall be most excellent, in regard of the things about vs. Rom. 8. 18. respect of our own estate, & the excellent parts & properties wherewith we our selues shall be indued: besides which we shall haue infinite cause of ioy and contentment in respect of that glorie, excellencie, and al-sufficiencie of those things which are about vs. In regard whereof it is truly said by the holy Apostle, that the afflictions of this present time are not worthie of the glorie which shall be shewed vnto vs. For as hee saith elsewhere, our light affliction which is but for a moment, 2. Cor. 4 17. causeth vnto vs a farre most excellent, and an eternall waight of glorie: and againe; the things which eye hath not seene, neither August. Soliloqu. cap. 35. & meditat. c. 18 Quicquid boni est ibi est, & quicquid mali est ibi nunquam est. August. de conflictu vitiorum, lib. cap. 26 eare hath heard, neither came into mans heart, are which God hath prepared for those that loue him. For there (as one saith) is ioy without sorrow, which causeth eternall gladnesse; there shall be all good, and shall not be any euill; there shall be whatsoeuer we will, and shall not be, what we will not; there our life shall be truly vitall, sweete and louely, being eternall and eternally blessed. There shall be no assaulting enemie, nor any alluring baite of tentation, but chiefe and certaine securitie, secure tranquillitie, peaceful pleasure, pleasant happinesse, happie eternitie, eternall blessednesse, the blessed Trinitie, of the Trinitie Vnitie, of the Vnitie Deitie; and of this Deitie a happie vision and fruition, which is the chiefe part of our Masters ioy. So elswhere hee hath this holy and heauenly meditation: What (saith he) louest thou ô my body?August. Manual. cap. 3 • . Tom. 9. what desirest thou ô my soule? whatsoeuer it is that you loue and desire; there shall you surely finde it. If beautie delight thee, the iust shall shine like the sunne in his brightnes; if such swiftnes, power, and freedome of the body that nothing can hinder or resist, wee shall bee like the holy Angels; if a life long and healthie, there is eternall health, and healthfull eternitie; if satietie, wee shall be satisfied with Gods
image when hee appeareth; if melodie, there shall be a full quire of Saints and Angels singing praises vnto God; if pleasure, God will make vs drinke of the riuer of his delights; if wisedome, we shall be taught of God; if friendship, we shall loue God more then anything, and our neighbours as our selues; if concord, it shall be our meate and drinke, to haue one minde and one will, because we shall all be conformable to the will of God; if power, we shall be omnipotent in our will, because it is also Gods will; if we take pleasure in honour and riches, God will make his good and faithfull seruants rulers ouer much, & they shall be the sons of God and heires of his kingdom: finally, if we desire true securitie, we shall be so sure that we shall neuer lose these ioyes, as we are sure that we would not willingly be depriued of thē, neither wil our louing God, who prouided for vs these ioyes when we were strangers & enemies, take thē away from vs against our wils, being reconciled, and become his friends. In a word, so many and excellent shall these ioyes of heauen be, that the heart of man shall not be able to containe and comprehend them; for we shall haue abundant ioy and glorie within vs, and round about vs; and because we cannot compasse them, being infinite and incomprehensible, they shall inclose and compasse vs. Vnto which (as some thinke) our Sauiour in the parable alludeth; for whereas in this world Hoc gaudium iusti intrare scrihuntur, quia ineffabile gaudium non capientes in eo quodammodo obuoluuntur. August. de cognit. verae vitae, lib. cap. 44. ioy is said to enter into vs, because it is not so great but that it may easily be comprehended; he biddeth the faithfull seruant to enter into his masters ioy, because these heauenly ioyes are so ineffable and vnconceiueable, that the Saints of God cannot containe them, but are contained, and on all sides compassed and inclosed with them. No maruell then if these ioyes cannot in this time of ignorance and miserie be expressed or conceiued, seeing they cannot be comprehended when they are enioyed; hee being infinite and incomprehensible who is the chiefe cause and obiect of all our ioy. Only they may be darkly shadowed by some earthly similitudes and resemblances which are within the compasse of our capacitie. As for example, some compare this heauenly happinesse, to the state of such an one, as being vniuersall
Monarch ouer the whole world, should enioy a long, peaceable,Chrysost. in Hebraeos cap. 4. Homil. 6. and prosperous raigne, without any warres, care, trouble or vexation, louing all, and being beloued of all his subiects. Or to an i •• ginarie aduancement of a Kings child out of his mothers wombe to sit on the throne of the kingdome, not according to the ordinary maner, by degrees, when he commeth to age, but attaining vnto age and soueraigntie together, and all vpon a sudden. Or as if a man should in the same houre lie in a darke and noisome dungeon, hungrie, naked, and comfortlesse, continually expecting a cruell and shameful death, and instantly be aduanced to a kingdome, and to the fruition of al delights which it could yeeld him. Others expresse them by making a proportionable comparison betweene the mothers wombe, the world, and the kingdome of heauen: namely, that this heauenly kingdom as much exceedeth this world in glory, beauty, & variety of al delights, as the world herein excelleth the mothers wombe; in which comparison if there be any disproportion, it is because our heauenly ioyes being infinite and without the mixture of any miserie, doe by innumerable degrees excell the pleasures and maiestie of the world, more then the world excelleth that darke and close prison of the mothers belly.

By all which it appeareth that these heauenly ioyes be vnspeakable,§. Sect. 4. That there are diuers degrees of glorie and happines in the kingdome of heauen: first proued by testimonies of Scriptur • . and in themselues infinite and incomprehensible, but yet in respect of vs who shall enioy them there are (I take it) diuers degrees of them. For whereas in these heauenly ioyes there are two things to be considered; the first is the cause or obiect of this ioy and happinesse; the other the application, comprehension, and fruition of them: it is true in the former respect, one cannot be more happie and blessed then another, because al shal inioy God, as their summum bonum, and chief good, and those heauenly ioyes which he will communicate vnto them; but in respect of the other, there are diuers degrees, as one more then another is more capable and comprehensiue of this infinit goodnesse, whereby he is fitted and disposed to a more large and perfect fruition of God, and so becommeth more blessed, because hee
more inioyeth his summum bonum. Euen as diuers vessels being filled in the same sea, there is no difference in the water, wherewith they are filled, which is sufficient to fill them, though they were neuer so great; but yet one of them may hold more then another, according as they exceed in bignes and largenes of capacitie. And this (as I take it) is cleere enough in the Scriptures. In the twelfth of Daniel it is said, that they that be wise shall shine as the brightnes of the firmament, Daniel 12. 3. and they that turne many to righteousnes shall shine as the starres for euer and euer. Both which though they be vnderstood of the same Preachers of righteousnesse which shall conuert men to the faith, and therefore there is no comparison made betweene the wise, and such as conuert others, not betweene the brightnes of the firmament, and the brightnes of the starres; yet I doubt not, that in both these they are preferred before other men, who haue not that excellencie of wisedome, and fruites of their ministerie; and that it is the meaning of the holy Ghost there to shew, that as they excell others in these gifts and fruitfull labours, so also they shall excell them in glorie and happines. The Apostle also seemeth to signifie this, where hee saith, that as there is another glorie of the Sunne, and another glorie of the Moone, and 1. Cor. 15. 41. 42 another glorie of the Starres, one Starre differing from another Starre in glorie: so also is the resurrection of the dead. Againe, our Sauiour Christ appropriateth this to his Apostles as a speciall priuiledge and prerogatiue in regard of the dignitie of their office, their paines, and faithfulnes, that they shall sit vpon twelue thrones, and iudge the twelue tribes of Israel. Matth. 19. 28. 1. Thess. 2. 19. And the Apostle seemeth to speake of a peculiar crowne laid vp for him in regard of his extraordinarie sufferings and labours. Finally, whereas the Scriptures promise not onely eternall life in generall to all the faithfull, but also speciall wages and rewards according to their workes, and that faithfull seruice which they haue done vnto God, thereby it appeareth that according to the measure of our graces and obedience in this life, wee shall haue a proportionable degree of glorie in the life to come.

Vnto these testimonies we might adde diuers reasons; as§. Sect. 5. Diuers reasons to proue that there are diuers degrees of glory, and some obiections answered. first, seeing the Lord doth in this world giue his gifts and graces in a diuers and vnequal proportion, to some a greater, and to others a lesse measure, it is more then probable that he wil accordingly giue vnto the Saints a diuers measure and proportion of glorie and felicitie, in the kingdome of heauen, when as he wil reward and crowne these his gifts according to his gratious and free promises: and this our SauiourLuke 19. 16. 17. Christ seemeth to intimate in the parable: where the Lord maketh his faithful seruant, who by wel vsing his ten talents had gained other ten, ruler ouer ten cities; and according to the same proportion, he giueth vnto him, who with his fiue talents had gained fiue more, the gouernment of fiue cities. Againe, the punishments of the wicked and reprobate shal be diuers in their measure and proportion, according to the qualitie of their sinnes; in which respect our Sauiour Christ saith, that it shal be easier for Sodom and Gomorrah in theMatth. 10. 15. day of iudgement, then for that citie which contemneth the preaching of the Gospel; and for Tyre and Sidon, then for Corazin and Bethsaida, who were not conuerted by Christs doctrine & miracles. For whereas it may be obiected, that the reason followeth not, because the wicked are punished for their sinnes, but the faithful are not saued for their merits, but by the obedience, righteousnesse, and death of Christ, which equally appertaineth to al the faithful: To this I answere, first, that God hath not only in general promised vnto all euerlasting life, for the death and merits of Christ, but also that he will of his free grace, and infinit bountie reward men according to their own works which they haue done in the flesh; for so the Apostle saith, that we must all appeare before 2. Cor. 5. 10. the iudgement seate of Christ, that euery man may receiue the things which are done in his bodie, according to that he hath done, whether it be good or euill. Secondly, howsoeuer euerlasting life belongeth to al them who haue their part and interest in the death and obedience of Christ, yet for as much as these are diuersly applied, by some more weakely, by others more strongly, according to the diuers measure and degree of their faith; so answerabiie these diuers degrees, shal haue diuers

rewards, and a different measure of glorie fitted vnto them: for as al the faithful haue their part in Christ, and one and the same Sauiour equally belongeth to them al, but in respect of the application (howsoeuer he is truly applied to all) yet all apprehend him not alike, but some weakely by their little faith, and others more strongly by their ful perswasion; and according to their strength of apprehension, and diuers measure of faith, bring forth proportionable fruits of good workes, godlinesse, and righteousnesse in their liues and conuersations: so in like manner al the faithful haue the same ioyes of heauen common to them al; but yet in regard that those who haue had a greater measure of faith, and other sanctifying gifts and graces on the earth, shal answerablie haue a more large & strong apprehension of these ioyes, and haue as it were a greater and more ample capacitie to receiue and containe them, there shal be diuers degrees of glory and happines: euen as those who are at one feast or banquet, haue all the same meate and dainties set before them, but yet haue different degrees of comfort and fruition in feeding on them, according to the goodnesse or weakenes of their stomackes; in which respect though al be equally satisfied, yet he who hath the sharper appetite, and stronger digestion, hath the largest share, and the fruition of it with most pleasure and delight. Finally, in the inchoation and beginning of our glorification, which is in this life, when as being sanctified we are endued with peace of conscience, and ioy in the holy Ghost, there are diuers degrees of grace, holinesse, and spirituall ioy and comfortt, some hauing a greater, and some a lesse measure; and therefore the Lord being constant, vniforme, and immutable in his courses and proceedings, we may conclude, that he wil obserue the same tenure in accomplishing and perfecting our glorification, giuing vnto those a greater measure, and higher degree of glorie and happines in his kingdome, who in this life had the greatest beginning, and largest proportion of grace and sanctification. But against this is obiected the parable of the labourers in the vineyard, where all are said to haue equality of reward, and the last as well as the first to haue receiued a penic. To which
I answere, that the scope of this parable is not to shew, that there shal be equalitie of rewards in the kingdome of heauen, but that God in his inf •• t mercle wil giue vnto those who are called at the last houre euerlasting life, as wel as vnto them who are first called; therefore those who are first called, haue no cause to triumph and insult ouer those who are called last: but hereupon it followeth not, that because they haue the same kingdome, glorie, and happinesse, therefore they shal haue the same degree; seeing we may all haue the freedome and general priuiledges of the same citie, and yet haue therein diuers offices and preferments. Al shal haue indeed the same life, glorie and happinesse, in respect of the obiect which is the Lord himselfe and the ioyes of heauen; but al shal not (as I haue shewed) haue equal application, apprehension, and capicitie in conceiuing and comprehending of these obiects, by reason whereof one shal containe more ioy and happinesse then another, though al shal be full and perfectly replenished. Others obiect, that all shall haue the fruition of our summum bonum and chiefest happinesse; and therefore if al haue the chiefest happinesse, none can be superiour vnto other. Vnto which the same answere serueth: for al shal equally enioy the summum bonum, the obiect and cause of our happinesse; but not in equalitie, in respect of the application and comprehension of this infinit good and chiefe happines, which (as I haue said) shal be in diuers measures and degrees. Finally, whereas they obiect, if some haue a greater measure of ioy and happines then others, then they shal want who haue not so much as they; and wanting shal not be fully satisfied and contented, but contrariwise shal be apt to enuie those who excell them, and to wish their owne aduancement; al which argue insufficiency and imperfection, from which that heauenly happinesse is exempted. To this I answere, that though there be not equalitie of ioy, yet there is sufficiencie, seeing euery one shal be filled, and haue as much ioy and happines as he can containe or yet desire; and consequently being fully satisfied and contented they shal not enuie any superiour, or desire to change. For as a lesser por needeth not, nor (if it had reason) would desire, to haue
as much powred into it, as into a greater, because it is insufficient to containe it, and being full, the ouer plus would but spill and run ouer; and as no man, but a glutton, being filled and satisfied at a daintie banquet, would enuie his fellow because his stomacke containeth more; and none but a foole, being of a low stature would once desire to be apparelled in the cloths of a taller mā, but rather such as are fit for his own personage; so euery Saint being filled and fitted with a sufficient measure of glorie and happines, is wel contented with his estate, and desireth not such a proportion as is vnmeete and vnfit for him. Againe, being fellow-members of the same bodie, whereof Christ Iesus is the head, we shal be content with that proportion of glory and happines, which is fit for vs in our seuerall places, as being most comely and conuenient both for the part it selfe, and for the whole body; for as the members of the naturall bodie are contented with their owne beautie, proportion, and place; because if they should be greater or lesser, higher or lower, or not themselues, but the same with others, or finally any other way disposed, then as they are in their owne nature and creation, it were vnto themselues a deformitie, and would make the whole bodie monstrous; and therefore the hand or foot, desire not to be the head or heart, nor enuie vnto them their greater honor and dignity: so the members of this heauenly body, are contented with that they are, and desire to be no other, nor enuie their superiours in glorie, their greater aduancement; because al haue receiued such a measure of glory as is most conuenient and comely, both for themselues, and for the glorious perfection of the whole body; and to be higher or lower then Gods wisdome hath disposed of them, would but deforme and disgrace the whole, and euery seuerall part. Finally, though there be inequality of glory, there can be no discōtent in any, because he hath not so much, nor enuy towards another, because he hath more; seeing like the members of the same bodie they receiue their greater excellencie and perfection, not for themselues alone, but for the good of all their fellow-members, and of the whole bodie: and moreouer, because through that perfection of loue which shall be
amongst them, they shall communicate with one another in all their happinesse, reioycing as much in their glory and felicity, as in that which they themselues haue receiued; therfore there can be no place to enuie or discontent.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
That heauen is a place most glorious; and of our blessed societie with the Saints, Angels, and our Sauiour Christ.
div.p:
ANd thus haue I (though but in darke maner)§. Sect. 1. That the heauen of heauens shall bee the place of our happines, which is most beautifull and glorious. described the ioyes of heauen, both which concerne the excellent condition of our owne persons, and also those things which are about vs. Vnto which we may now ad the excellencie and glorious beautie of the place where, and of the society with whom, wee shal inioy al this happinesse. And first for the place of our happinesse, it is not the earth, aire, or firmament, wherein the starres are fixed, but the heauenHeb. 7. 26. of heauens, or the supreme and highest heauen, into which Christ as hee was man ascended, and so was made higher then all the visible heauens, as the Apostle speaketh;2. Cor. 12. 2. which is also that which the Apostle Paul calleth the third heauen, into which he was taken vp. Howsoeuer some think that after the resurrection, the blessed saints shal not be confined to any place, but haue the vse both of heauen and earth for their habitation, in both which they shal enioy the presence of God, and al diuine and heauenly happinesse. The which their opinion they ground vpon those places of Scripture, where it is not onely said, that there shal bee newa Esa. 65. 17. and 66. 22. Apoc. 21. 1. heauens and new earth; but also that therein shal dwel righteousnesse, that is, the holy and iust who shal execute righteousnesse,b 2. Pet. 2. 13. and that the saints being Apoc. 5. 10. made kings shal reigne vpon the earth. But concerning this point I can determine nothing; only let vs know this to our ioy and comfort, that wheresoeuer the situation of this seat of blessednesse shal be, it is certainely most glorious and maiestical. Neither must
we thinke that the Lord hath onely prouided for vs goodly and rich furniture, but also stately palace • and glorious mansions. For if earthly kings will haue habitations answerable to the greatnes of their maiesty, wherein they keepe their chiefe residence; then how glorious and ful of stately maiesty is this heauenly palace, which is the chiefe seat of the King of kings, where he communicateth himselfe to his chiefe nobles and courtiers, the holy Angels, and blessed Saints? But hard and impossible it is to describe in a liuely maner, the excellencie and statelinesse of this glorious mansion, and city of the saints, in al the particulars thereof; only this we may conclude, that it is; first, of most large and almost infinite extent and circuit, seeing it is to be the seat and habitation of innumerable Saints and Angels, vnto the maiesty whereof is required that it be most ample and spatious, that they may haue liberty and roome enough. For as it is one part of the wickeds disgrace and punishment, that they shal be thrust together in a straite roome, and like stincking tares and noisome weeds bee crusht together, and tied inMa • . 13. 30. bundles that they may bee cast into the fire: so contrariwise it is more then probable, that the seat of the blessed is most ample and spatious, that so it may bee the more glorious, stately, and magnificent. And this appeareth also by euidence of reason: for if the visible heauens be so many and innumerable degrees greater then the earth; then how much more ample and spatious is the heauen of heauens, which doth inclose and compasse them; as they doe the aire and earth? Secondly, we may be assured that this place is most holy and pure, seeing it is the seat, not only of the holy Saints and Angels, but also of the Lord, who is holinesse it selfe. For if that place of his temporall and momentanie presence, when as he appeared vnto Moses, was holy; how much more holyExod. 3. 5. are the heauens, which is the place of his continuall residence? In respect of which purity and holinesse it wil not admit of any impure guest; for as it is said, no vncleane thing shall enter in thither, neither whatsoeuer worketh abomination Apo • . 21. 27. and lies. Finally, we may be assured though wee cannot describe it according to it worth and excellencie, that it is a
place most glorious and maiesticall. For if the Tabernacle when God gaue some such visible signes of his presence, as the people in their frailty and mortality were capable of, was filled with glory; how ful of glory and maiesty are theExod. 40. 34. highest heauens, where God keepeth his chiefe residence, and manifesteth his glory and greatnesse, in a farre greater measure to his Saints and Angels, which are incorruptible and immortal? And this royal excellency being in it selfe ineffable and vnconceiueable; the Apostle describeth accordingApoc. 21. 10. 11. to our weake capacitie, by such visible and earthly things as are most precious and glorious. And first he saith, that this new Ierusalem and city of God, is ful of Gods glory, and her shining like vnto a stone most precious, and as a Iasper stone, cleere as crystal: that it hath a wall great and high, and twelue gates, and at the gates twelue Angels; that it is both in length and in bredth twelue thousand furlongs; that the building of the wall of it was of Iasper, and the city of pure gold, like vnto glasse, cleere and transparent, pure and glorious: that the foundations of the wall of the city are garnished with all maner of precious stones: the first foundation of Iasper, the second of Saphire, the third of Calcedonie, the fourth of an Emerald, the fifth of a Sardonyx, the sixth of a Sardius, the seuenth of a Chrysolite, the eight, of a Beryl, the ninth of a Topaz, the tenth of a Chrysoprasus, the eleuenth of a Iacynth, ye twelfth of an Amethyst. That the twelue gates were twelue pearles, and euery gate of one pearle, and the street of the city pure gold, and like shining glasse. All which if it be to bee vnderstood (as some would haue it) of the glory of the Church here on earth, when as Iewes and Gentiles shal be ioined together before the comming of Christ to iudgement; it is no lesse forcible to proue that the heauen of heauens is a place most glorious; for if there be such glory, beautie, and maiesty in the Church militant, how innumerable degrees shal it be increased and inlarged in the Church triumphant? if there be such excellency to be seene on earth, what shal wee thinke of the heauen of heauens? And surely, if these outcases of this emperial heauen, the starrie firmament, daily subiect to our view, bee so
glorious? how much more maiestical is that place reserued for Gods saints? If the roofe of our prison and earthly habitation be so curiously vaulted, and so richly garnished and bespangled with bright shining lights, and beautiful starres; what workmanship, what maiesty, and incomparable excellency may we expect in the palace of the great king, and the heauenly habitation of the Saints and Angels? If the very porch and first entrie bee so stately and glorious; how full of maiesty, beautie and glory, are the chiefe roomes, and the presence-chamber of this great and glorious monarch of heauen and earth.

Vnto this glory and happinesse of the place, we may adde§. Sect. 2. Of the great felicity which we shall haue in the society of the saints and Angels. Mat. 8. 11. that felicity, ioy and contentment which wee shal take in our companie; for first, wee shall haue the societie and fellowship of the Saints and blessed Angels, according to that of our Sauiour Christ, many shall come from the East and West, and shall sit downe with Abraham, and Isaac, and Iacob, in the kingdome of heauen. And because there shal bee perfect loue and charity among vs, euery one louing another as themselues, and reioycing as much in their happinesse and felicity as in their owne; hereof it wil come to passe that according to the innumerable number of the Saints and Angels, so infinitely shall our ioyes be doubled and redoubled; and that which one hath not of this glory and happinesse in himselfe, because he is not capable of it, hee shall inioy it through his perfect loue in the rest of this holy and heauenly society; they being mutually one to another storehouses and treasuries of these euerlasting ioyes, to keepe for their vse and comfort, that which themselues cannot containe and comprehend. So that this ioy of loue and perfect charity, shall infinitely exceed al other heauēly ioies which belong peculiarly vnto any one; seeing therby euery one perfectly enioyeth all the happinesse and blessednes of the whole society of the Saints and Angels, whose glory as it is most excellent, so their number numberlesse. Now if these heauenly ioyes bee so vnspeakeable and so incomprehensible in euery one, that he can scarce containe them, how shall we be ranished with ioy and delight, when wee shall communicate in the glory
and happinesse of so great a multitude? And if there be such ioy and sweet content on earth, whilest two or three liuing in all prosperity, dearely loue one another, who notwithstanding loue imperfectly, and spend the least part of their time in their mutuall fellowship with their beloued friends; what infinite ioy and reioycing shall there be, when all the saints shal be ioyned in their hearts with the bond of perfect charity, and in their persons in a neere fellowship and society, neuer againe to be separated and diuided? Neither shal heere (as in the earth) propriety vnto these spiritual ioyes, and heauenly treasures be any cause of difference, by reason that the ones hauing them, is the cause why others want them; seeing all these vnualuable riches, and vnspeakeable happinesse shal lie out in common, for the vse and comfort of al the inhabitants. And as al shall ioyntly enioy this kingdome of glory in an holy communion, so euery one shall enioy it wholly to himselfe; euen as the sun serueth for the vse and benefit of the whole world; & yet euery one indued with sight inioyeth it wholly, as though no other were partner with him. And therfore because the ones hauing of this heauenly ioy and blessednesse, is so farre from hindring of another, that contrariwise through that communion and perfect loue which is amongst them, euery one enioyeth anothers happinesse, and so by this fellowship hath his ioyes infinitely multiplied; from hence will spring vnspeakeable ioy in one anothers loue, and vnconceiueable loue by reason of this ioy.

But here it may bee demanded, whether in this heauenly§. Sect. 3. Whether we shall in heauen know one another. societie, we shall know euery one their earthly friends, kindred and acquaintance. To which I answere, that it were better if we would learne to know, and to bee assured, that wee our selues shall be happie members of this heauenly societie; for what will it profit a man to know, that the Saints shall haue this knowledge one of another, if he be ignorant of the meanes whereby he may come to be in this number? Secondly, I answer, that if this particular knowledge, which here we so much desire, would after that manner which we desire it, any whit aduance our ioy and heauenly happinesse; then
most certainely we shall attaine vnto it, and shall euery man know his neere & deare friends, as wife, husband, father, mother, sisters, brethren, children, and familiar acquaintance, seeing nothing shal be wanting to that felicitie and blessednes, which may make it perfect and compleate; and contrariwise if it will not, we haue no reason greatly to desire it. Finally, I answere more plainely and directly, that in the heauenly ioyes, we shall all know, and knowing loue one another, but yet not after a carnall and worldly manner. The former point is more then probable; for being plentifully indued with Gods spirit, and hauing thereby our minds illuminated with all knowledge and spirituall wisdome, we shall be inabled to know, not onely those who haue been formerly of our acquaintance, but euen strangers, whom we neuer saw. For if Adam before the fall, had his mind so inlightned withGenes. 2. 23. wisdom and knowledge, that he knew Eue, and from whence she came, at the first sight; and if the Apostles accompanyingMatth. 17. 4. Christ in his transfiguration, and hauing but a small beginning, and a little tast of their glorification, were able thereby to know Moses and Elias, whom they had neuer seene: And (as some adde) if Diues (as it is in the parable) knew Abraham, Luk. 16. and Lazarus in his bosome in so great a distance; then how much more shall they, who are perfectly glorified, and indued with all knowledge, through the illumination of Gods holy spirit, know all their friends and kindred, with whom formerly they haue been acquainted? But yet this knowledge, both in respect of the cause and manner thereof is not worldly and carnall, neither shall we know them by their outward shape and fauour; for this is impossible, in regard of the great difference betweene a bodie mortall, and immortall, earthly and glorified, which, as I said, shall bee freed from all blemishes and imperfections, either of age or stature; nor by the helpe of our naturall memorie, which in such length of time, and greatalterations, which in the mean time shall happen, must of necessitie faile vs; but by that diuine illumination of Gods spirit, which maketh acquaintance and strangers all alike knowne vnto vs. In both which respects, the Apostle Paul saith, that from henceforth we know 2. Cor. 5. 15.
no man after the flesh; yea, though we had knowne Christ after the flesh, yet now henceforth know we him no more. Whereby is meant, that the knowledge which we haue one of another, is not in outward and worldly respects, but diuine and spirituall, as we know them in Christ, by the inlightning of the spirit. And the like also may be said of our loue towards them, which shall no more be, in regard of our earthly kindred, acquaintance and friendship, all which shall be abolished, but in respect that they are the members of Iesus Christ, copartners of the same ioyes, and fellow members vnited one to another by the same spirit. Neither shall we more reioyce in the societie of our earthly kindred and acquaintance, or better loue them in these earthly respects; for this would not augment and increase, but diminish and detract both from our loue and ioy; seeing this shall be the perfection of them both, to be towards all in the highest degree, louing and reioycing in the happinesse of euery one of Gods Saints, much more then the tenderest mother can loue her child, or wife her husband, and as much as they loue themselues, and reioyce in their owne happinesse. And if there bee then any difference in our loue, it shall bee in diuine and spirituall respects, euen as our loue shall be diuine and spirituall, namely, as we shall more loue them, who haue greatest excellency of gifts, and measure of glory, hauing a more perfect apprehension of God, and that heauenly blessednesse, and the greatest proportion of that holy spirit, which shall be the bond of our vnion, and cause of our loue.

But as we shall haue knowledge of all the blessed Saints,§. Sect. 4. That it shall be a great part of our heauenly happinesse to inioy the companie of our Sauiour Christ. and louing them as our selues, shal haue great ioy in their societie: so especially shall we know our Sauiour Iesus Christ, louing him aboue al the rest, yea, and more then we loue our selues, and taking vnconceiuable ioy in that vnion and communion, which we shall haue with him, in all that glory and happinesse, wherein he shall be farre preferred before all the sonnes of men. Of this speciall knowledge of Christ, himselfe speaketh. Father (saith he) I will that they which thou hast Iohn 17. 24. Vers. 3. giuen me, be with me, euen where I am, that they may behold my
glorie which thou hast giuē me. Yea, in this knowledge of him, he placeth a chiefe part of our heauenly happinesse, saying,Iob 19. 25. 27. that it is life eternall, to know God, and whom be hath sent • esus Christ. Of which happinesse, holy Iob assureth himselfe, where he saith, that he was not onely sure that his Redeemer liued, but also that he should see and behold him with his bodilie eies.
