By which knowledge of Christ, and fellowship with him, we shall haue inestimable ioy and comfort; for if Iohn the Baptist sprang for ioy in his mothers belly, at the presenceLuke 1. 14. of Christ in his first conception; if his earnest desire to see Christ in the flesh, made old Simeon wish the prolongingLuke 2. 29. 30. of his life; and hauing obtained his desire, and seene Christ his saluation, was most willing to depart in peace: If the eies of the disciples were blessed by Christs owne testimonie, becauseLuke 10. 22. 23. they had seene that, which many Prophets and Kings had desired to see, and yet could not, to wit, the Sauiour of the world clothed with our humane nature, and but in the estate of a seruant, despised of men, and contemptible in the world: And finally, if Peter, Iames, and Iohn, seeing but some smal sparkes of his glorie and maiestie in his trans • iguration,Matth. 17. 4. were so rauished with delight, that setting aside all worldly desires, they wished only the continuance of this ioy; then what inestimable pleasure, comfort, and reioycing shall wee haue, when we shal continually behold our Sauiour Christ in his glorie and maiestie, adorned in his kingly attire, accompanied with his blessed Saints and Angels, and sitting at the right hand of his Father, like a triumphant conquerour, hauing subdued and troden vnder foot all his and our enemies? especially considering that wee shall not be bare beholders onely of his glorie and happinesse, but shall communicate with him, as members of his bodie, in all his ioyes, and bee made partakers of all his glorie. O what rauishing ioy shall then possesse our soules, when as wee, who haue long been contracted to our Lord and husband, shall see that blessed time come, when we shall haue that roiall marriage between him and vs solemnized in the presence of God and his holy Angels, and shall haue the fruition of him, and all his happinesse,
when as wee shall not bee able to determine, whether the glorious maiestie, or the vnmatchable loue of our deare husband shall exceed one the other? What delight and comfort shall we then feele, when wee poore contemptible members, base, and inglorious in the world, shal be vnited to our most glorious head, Iesus Christ, and by vertue of this vnion with him, shall also be glorified, and communicate with him in all his felicitie, and heauenly ioy? O how shall at this day our hearts and soules be able to containe that pleasure and delight, when wee shall haue so neere societie and fellowship with our blessed Sauiour and Redeemer, who hath loued vs so dearely, that when we were bankrupts to Gods iustice, he became our surety, and discharged our debt to the vtmost farthing? when we were enemies, he wrought our reconciliation; when wee were condemned, hee procured our pardon; when wee were the slaues of sinne and Satan, hee powerfully redeemed vs; and when we were in the state of condemnation, and the very firebrands of hel fire, he brought vs into the state of saluation, and made vs the sonnes of God, and coheires with him in all his glory and heauenly happinesse. All which hee effected by humbling himselfe to the state of a seruant, when he inioyed with his Father all glorie and maiestie, and by suffering miseries and afflictions, hunger, wearinesse, griefe, and worldly contempt skornings, reuilings, buffettings, scourgings; and finally, that sharpe and shamefull death of the crosse, and his Fathers heauie displeasure, much more bitter and intollerable then all the rest of his bodily sufferings. O how then shall we reioyce in his loue, and in louing him againe, for all his grace and goodnes extended vnto vs?

div.head: CHAP. IX.
Of the fruition of God, and of those vnspeakeable ioyas which will arise from it.
div.p:
ANd thus haue I shewed what inestimable ioies§. Sect. 1. That as the Lord is the author, so also the chiefe matter of our heauenly ioyes. are prepared for the Saints, both in respect of the things within them, and without them; all which, though they are so great, that the heart of man cannot possibly conceiue them; yet are they all but little or nothing, in comparison of that incomprehensible ioy and happinesse, which we shal haue in the fruition of God himselfe, infinite in al goodnesse and perfection; whereby wee shal for euer inioy his presence, behold his face and glorie, and bee vnited vnto him in a blessed & holy communion, that so he may become1. Cor. 15. 28. al in al. Which ioy being like the author and obiect thereof, infinit and incomprehensible, it is not to be expected, that I should in the least measure, as it is in it owne nature, expresse it; seeing in regard of it infinit perfection, the heart of man cannot conceiue the least part thereof, much lesse his tongue or pen vtter it; onely I wil content my selfe to haue shadowed it out in some darke maner, and to discouer it by the light of the word, as it were a farre off, expecting the ful reuelation thereof in the great day of Gods appearing. First therefore we are to know, that as God is the chiefe author and cause of all our happines, electing vs to eternall life before the world was, creating vs vnto glorie, and graciouslie affording vnto vs al the meanes of our saluation; so also he is the chiefe obiect, and (as it were) materiall cause, and substance, of all our ioy and happinesse. And (as one saith) it is he, both whichAugust. crowneth vs with a glorious crowne, and is also himselfe this crowne of glorie; it is hee that promiseth, and who is also that which is promised, he is the rewarder, and hee also is our reward. And finally, he giueth vnto vs heauenly happinesse and blessednesse, and is also this blessednesse and felicitie it selfe. And thus the Lord promiseth vnto Abraham, not onely
that he would reward him greatly, but also that hee himselfeGenes. 15. 1. would be his exceeding great reward. And holy Dauid in manyPsalm. 16. 5. 11. places calleth the Lord his life, his light, his glorie, his strength, his portion, and the lot of his inheritance: and finally affirmeth, that when he should appeare, hee should beePsalm. 17. 15. throughly satisfied with his image, because in his presence is fulnesse of ioy, and pleasures at his right hand for euermore. To which purpose one saith, that it shall be our reward to seeBernard. meditat. deuot. cap. 4. God, to liue with God, to liue of God, to be with God, and to be in God, who shall be all in all; to haue God, who is the summum bonum, and chief good; for where the chief good is, there is the chiefe happines, the chiefe pleasure, true libertie, perfect charitie, eternall securitie, and secure eternity; there is true gladnes and reioycing, perfect knowledge, al fulnes, and al blessednes; there is peace, piety, goodnes, light, vertue, honestie, the ioy of continual mirth, sweetnesse, life eternal; glory, praise, rest, loue, and sweet concord. And this (namely, that God is our summum bonum, and chief happines) the very Heathens themselues from time to time haue confessed and acknowledged, as it were casie to shew, had not that ornamentMorn. de verit. relig. Christ. cap. 19. of true nobility, & excellent instrument of Gods glory, by his learned labors shewed this at large, and saued me this labor.

Now as the Lord is our reward and the perfection of our§. Sect. 2. That all ioy and happinesse accompanieth our fruition of God, as being the perfection and accomplishment of them all▪ ioy and happines; so we are further to know, that aboue all other rewards he is most excellent; and of all other ioyes, by infinit degrees most delightfull; for whereas other ioyes in heauen exceedingly please, it is he alone that can fully content vs: whereas others are inestimable and of great worth; it is he only who is al-sufficient, and being infinit in al goodnesse and perfection, doth giue vnto vs ful contentment, and compleate happines. And this is that which he himselfe saith vnto Abraham; I am God al-sufficient, walke before me and be Genes. 17. 1. thou vpright: and hereof it is, that hauing promised in the Reuelation to him that ouercommeth, that he shall inherit all Apoc. 21. 7. things, he sheweth how he shall be made thus compleate, saying, I will be his God, and he shall be my sonne. And indeed how can he want light, that hath this Sunne of righteousnes still shining vpon him? how can he lacke warmth, who is
continually heated with the flames of this diuine loue? how can he thirst, who hath this euer-springing fountaine which yeeldeth streames of the water of life? And in a word, how can he want any good who enioyeth the chiefe goodnes, in whom all vertue, knowledge, and whatsoeuer goodnes can be named, or desired, are most absolute, and in all fulnes and perfection? For (as one saith) his diuine beautie the AngelsAugust. de Triplici habitac. cap. 4. wonder at, by his power the dead are raised, of his wisdome there is no number, or measure, whose kingdome knoweth no end, whose glory cannot change, whose light so obscureth the Sunne, that in comparison thereof it is but darknes; who in sweetnes so far exceedeth honie, that being compared, it is as bitter as wormewood; whose face if the damned soules could behold, they would feele no punishment, no griefe or heauines; whose presence would change hell it selfe into a paradise of pleasure and delight. Wherby it appeareth,August. de Spiritu & Anima. cap. 65. not only that God is the chiefe and supreame cause and obiect of al our felicity and blessednes in the kingdome of heauen; but also that he is al-sufficient to make vs perfectly happie, as being our summum bonum, infinit in all goodnes and perfection. Now further we are to know, that the fruition of this God al-sufficient, and our chiefe and supreame good, is that which we call blessednes, and our heauenly happines. Of which fruition of God, there are made three degrees, or diuers manners: First when we enioy God in his creatures; in them seeing and vnderstanding his wisedome, power, and goodnes, in his creating, preseruing, gouerning and disposing of all the creatures in heauen and earth most wisely, mightily, and gratiously. To which purpose the Psalmist saith, that the heauens declare the glorie of God, and the firmament Psalme 19. 1. sheweth the worke of his hands: and the Apostle Paul more plainly affirmeth, that the inuisible things of God, that is, Rom. 1. 20▪ his eternall power and God-head, are seene in the creation of the world, being considered in his workes. Secondly, we are said to enioy him in our selues, and that diuersly in respect of the diuers faculties of our soules, as in our vnderstandings, when they are enlightned with the beames of his wisdome, and diuine knowledge, whereby we are enabled to know him, and
our selues, together with his will and workes; in our wils and desires, when he replenisheth them with perfect iustice and righteousnesse, whereby they are made conformable to his will (in which sense they are pronounced blessed, who hunger Matth. 5. 6. after righteousnesse, because they shall be satisfied) and inabled to refuse that which God disliketh, and to chuse that which he loueth. Finally, we enioy him in our heart and affections, when as louing him aboue all, and wholly depending vpon his power and goodnesse, we attaine vnto peace and tranquillitie of mind, and are replenished with all ioy and delight: in which respect we shall be most happie, when as our knowledge cannot puffe vs vp, by reason of our righteousnes, nor our righteousnes be distastefull and troublesome by reason of our ioy. And lastly, we are said to enioy1. Cor. 13. 12. God in himselfe, which of al the rest is most pleasing and delightfull; when we shall know him in his persons, nature, and attributes, not as in this life darkely, and through a glasse, but as the Apostle speaketh, face to face: for this (as our SauiourIohn▪ 17. 3. saith) is eternall life to know God, and whom he hath sent Iesus Christ. Neither shal this fruition consist in a bare knowledge of God the Father, his Sonne; and holy Spirit, but in that communion which we shall haue with them, whereby they wil become vnto vs al in al, as we shal see hereafter. And that not in a partie, or imperfect communion, whereby euery of the Saints, should haue their share in this blessed fruition; for God is a most perfect and indiuisible essence, so that they who inioy him, inioy him wholly, without any sharing and diuision. For as on the earth, euery one totally inioyeth the light of the Sun; and as a speech made among a multitude, is not diuided by words and syllables, but is wholly and intirely receiued of all the hearers: so much more may our God whose essence is most simple, pure, indiuisible, and omnipresent, not filling one place more then another with his presence, but all alike, whether they bee neere at hand, or more remote; communicate himselfe to bee inioyed totally and wholly, of all, and euery of the blessed Saints.

By al which it is cleare and manifest, that howsoeuer there§. Sect. 3. That the fruition of God must needs be the perfection of our • oy, seeing all goodnes, beautie and excellencie is contained, and vnited in him. • imis est aua
• s cui non suf
• icit Dominus. Bernard. in Coena Domini Serm. 7. are innumerable and inestimable ioyes in heauen, yet the
fruition of God is the chiefe, and the perfection of them all; with which alone, without all the rest wee should bee most perfectly blessed, and without which, though we had all the other, our happines should be maimed and imperfect: for inioying God infinit in all perfection, our hearts and soules shal be fully satisfied and replenished with ioy, and (as one saith) he is too too couetous, who is not sufficed with the fruition of God; and without him, though we had all other ioyes of heauen and earth, there would still remaine an emptines in the soule, which would keepe v • from full contentment, and make vs still seeke after more happinesse. Concerning the former; how can it be, but there must needs be perfection of ioy, where God himselfe our chiefe goodnes shal be inioyed? for if the beautie of vertue, being beheld and wel discerned, would (as one saith) stir vp in vs, a wonderful louePlato. and admiration of it; how much more wil the sight and fruition of God doe this, who is the fountaine of all vertue and goodnes, infinit in all glorie and perfection? If the Queene of Saba thought Salomons seruants happie, because they alwaies1. King. 10. 8. stood before him, and heard his wisdome; how much more blessed are they, who enioy Gods presence for euermore, who being a boūdlesse ocean of wisdome, from which those little drops distilled, can neuer be drie, but shal continually haue riuers and streames of diuine prudence flowing from him? If Moses attained vnto an extraordinarie measureExod. 33. 22. 23. of ioy and happines, when he was admitted to see Gods hinder parts, and some small beames of his infinit glory and maiestie; how happie and blessed shall we be, when we shall be admitted into his glorious presence, and continually see him face to face? If we so much desire to see, and see with ioy and admiration, men who are excellent in any kind, as those who are exceeding wise, valorous, strong, beautifull, learned, or indued with some extraordinarie parts, although they be but maimed and imperfect; then how shall we be rauished with ioy and holy wonder, when we shal both see and enioy God himselfe, in whom al excellencies do concurre, and that infinitly and in all fulnes and perfection? If we could find a man in whom the graces and good parts, not only of al other
men, but also of al the rest of the creatures, fully concurred, as the faith of Abraham, the piety of Dauid, ye loue of Ionathan, the wisdome of Salomon, the beautie of Absalon, the strength of Sampson, the sweetnes of odoriferous flowers, the brightnes of the Sun, &c. who would not admire his excellēcy, and think himself happy, if he might inioy his loue & cōpany? but al the goodnes, beauty, excellencie, and perfection of all the creatures ioyned together, is nothing in comparison of that, which we shal see and enioy in our al-sufficient Creator, they being al but little drops of this euer-springing fountain, smal sparks of this great flame, & lesse thē a graine of sand, in comparison of the whole earth & heauēs: seeing he hath in him al beautie, glory, & goodnes, which they haue but in smal portions; he hath yt in al perfectiō, which they haue imperfectly, and in some little degree; & infinitly aboue al measure, wheras they haue it but in their measure and proportion. Whereof it is that what excellencies and good parts are ascribed to the creatures (as we say in the concrete) as being properties and qualities of their nature & substāce, they are al attributed vnto God in the abstract, as being his very nature it selfe, and of his essence & being; so the creatures are called good, but the Creator goodnes it selfe; man is said to be wise, holy, iust, louing, when as he hath these graces & vertues imparted vnto him; but God is wisdome, holines, iustice, loue, not receiuing them from any other, but hauing them eternally in his owne nature and being. In which respect it is said, that there is none Matth. 19. 17. good but God: that he is 1. Tim. 1. 17. only wise: that there is none 1. Sam. 2. 2. holy as the Lord, yea none besides him: because none are so in their owne nature, and from themselues; but what they haue, they haue receiued it from God. From whence we may conclude, that if there be any beautie, excellencie, goodnesse and perfection in the creatures, it is infinitly more in the Creator, from whom they first had it: for if he could without impairing of his owne excellencie and substance, impart vnto his creatures, such goodnesse, beautie, and perfection, by his sole word, making them of nothing such as they are, and enriching them with so many good parts and properties, without impouerishing himselfe, or abating any whit of his owne
store; how glorious, how gratious, how beautifull and infinit in all persection is he in his owne nature and essence, which wanteth nothing, though he haue made his creatures to abound? To this purpose the author of the book of Wisdome saith: that though they had such pleasure in the beautie of their idols (as the Sun, Moone, and rest of the creatures) ye • should they haue knowne how much more excellent he is that Wisdome 13. 3. 4. 5. made them: for the first author of beautie hath created these things; or if they maruelled at the power and operation of them, yet should they haue perceiued thereby, how much he that made these things is mightier: for by the greatnes and the beautie of the creatures, the Creator being compared with them may bee considered. For if the singular parts of beautie and goodnes, being diuided and disperfed amongst the creatures, be so louely and delightfull; then what admirable loue and delight shall we haue in the chiefe goodnesse, in whom alone they are contained, compacted, and infinitly surpaffed and excelled? if life created be so pleasant, how much more is life the Creator? if health be so sweete and comfortable, howAugust. Medi
• at. cap. 18. much more is he that made health? if wisdome be louely, consisting in the knowledge of things created, how infinitly louely is that wisdome, which hath created them all of nothing? Do we therefore loue beautie in the creatures? we shal see it infinitely redoubled in the Creator, from which crystall fountaine these little drops haue flowed. Do we loue vertue and goodnes in men? they are infinit in the God of vertue and goodnes. Do we delight in wisdome? he is the God of al wisdome and knowledge, from which great light, men haue receiued these little sparkes. Do we desire honors, riches, and pleasures? why he is the God of all glorie, who satisfieth and filleth all with his hidden treasures; and in his presence is fulnesse of ioy, and at his right hand pleasures for euermore. Psalme 16. 11. In a word, whatsoeuer is good, pleasant, and desirable in all the creatures, it is conioyned and by infinite degrees surpassed in the Creator, from whom they haue had all their excellencie, without any diminution of his fulnes and perfection.

And thus it appeareth, that the perfection of our happinesse§. Sect. 4. That al the beauenly ioyes without the fruition of God could not make vs perfectly happie.
consisteth in the fruition of our summum bonum, and supreme good, which when wee enioy, wee can want nothing, and wanting him, can neuer be satisfied with al other good. For the heart and mind of man is of such large capacitie, that nothing can fill it but hee who being infinite did first make it. And because God alone is our summum bonum, and the supreme end of all our indeauours and desires; therefore if we should inioy al the world, and could engrosse all the pleasures of heauen and earth, wee should not rest satisfied and contented, because wee haue not attained vnto our end, and that chiefe and supreme good at which wee naturally aime in our desires. Againe, seeing none are blessed, but those who are perfectly satisfied and contented, and none thus satisfied, but they who enioy God, their summum bonum, who, as he freeth them from all euill, so also he replenisheth them with all good; therefore without this fruition of God, though we should haue neuer so much good, yet we should not attaine vnto full happinesse and felicity. So one saith, that whatsoeuer is lesse then God, though wee shouldAugust. de cognit. verae vitae. cap. 47. Quicquid nobis adest praeter Deum non est dulce. Nolumus omnia quae dedit. si non dat seipsum qui omnia dedit. Aupust. in Psal. 85 Psal. 73. 2 • . Psal. 144. 15. receiue it for our reward, wee should yet desire more, and they who haue not their desires satisfied, haue not attained vnto fulnesse of ioy. And therefore he concludeth in another place; that whatsoeuer is present when God is absent, is not sweet and comfortable; and that hee did not desire any, or all those things which God hath giuen, vnlesse he who gaue them, giue himselfe also. So that wee may say with Dauid: Whom haue I in heauen but thee? and I haue desired none in the earth with thee: and conclude with him, that they are truely blessed, not who abound with worldly plentie and prosperity, but who haue Iehouah to be their God.

div.head: CHAP. X.
Of the vision and sight of God, and of that communion which we shall haue with him.
div.p:
ANd thus haue I generally shewed that God is§. Sect. 1. Wherein the vision of God chiefly consisteth; and that it is not a darke sight, as in this lif • , but a cleere knowledge of him. the supreme cause and maine obiect of our heauenly happinesse, and that as in the fruition of him consisteth our chiefe blessednesse; so without him we can neuer attaine to true and compleate felicity. In the next place let vs somewhat intreate of the speciall parts of this fruition; which consist either in the vision, sight, and knowledge of God, or in that communion which we shall haue with him. Concerning the former, wee are said in heauen to enioy the vision of God, and to see him, when wee haue not onely in our vnderstanding such a perfect and cleere knowledge of him, his nature, attributes, person, will, and workes, as the creature is capable of, but when as thus knowing him, our hearts and affections doe adhere vnto him, in most seruent loue, reioycing in, and praising him, and conforming our selues in all things according to his will. Neither are wee to conceiue, that this vision is a bare and naked sight and knowledge, but such as is apprehensiue and operatiue, both in our affections and actions. For so these words of sense and knowledge do vsually in the Scriptures signifie, not a bare sight alone, and naked knowledge, whereby the obiect is apprehended in the sense and mind, but also the operations and functions of the will, heart, and affections, together with the effects and actions which doe follow and accompanie this sight and knowledge. So Dauid professeth that hee beleeueth to see the Psal. 27. 13. & 34. 12. goodnesse of the Lord in the land of the liuing: that is, to haue the benefit and fruition of it. And Christ saith, that he who beleeueth not, shall not see life; and contrariwise, that the faithfullIoh. 3. 36. shall not see death; whereby is ment, that they should not taste the ioy of the one, nor these the punishment of the other: and elsewhere, that his sheepe heare his voice, that is,
beleeue and obey it, in their heart, affections, and conuersation. And thus also we are said to see God, and to know him, not onely when in our vnderstandings wee conceiue some bare notions of his nature and attributes, but also when we apprehend and receiue him into our hearts, soules, and affectines, and inioying him, doe reioyce in his fruition. Whereby we vnderstand, not onely what this heauenly vision is, but also what is the chiefe obiect thereof, namely, the Lord himselfe, his nature, persons, glory and maiesty. And this is signified by the seeing of Gods face, of which the Scriptures make mention. Thus the Psalmist saith; I will behold thy face Psal. 17. 15. in righteousnesse, and when I awake I shall be satisfied with thine image. So it is said, that the faithfull shall see Gods face, and his Apo • . 22. 4. name shall be written in their foreheads: and the Apostle Iohn 1. Ioh. 3. 2. affirmeth, that we shall see him as he is. In this life, as we doe receiue the first fruits of our glorification, so answerablie we haue a vision and sight of God; but it is (as the Apostle speaketh) darke, as though it were through a glasse; and that either as wee see the wisedome, power, and goodnes of GodRom. 1. 20. 21. shining (though dimly) in the glasse of the creatures, which is our naturall vision and seeing of him, common vnto vs with the Gentiles and Heathens: or that symbolicall sight and vision, when as we haue some small glimpse of his glory, by some signes, shadowes, and darke resemblances; In which kind Moses is said to haue seene Gods hinder parts, that is,Exod. 33. 23. some small signes and apparances of his glorious presence;Esay 6▪ 1. 2. and Esay affirmeth, that he thus saw the Lord sitting vpon an high throne, and lifted vp, and the lower parts thereof filled the Temple, and the Seraphims stood vpon it. Or finally, the vision of faith, whereby we see God in his word, not onely described vnto vs in his attributes and persons, but also in that liuely image of his Sonne, in whom the glory of the Father shined, both in his heauenly doctrine, and most powerful miracles. In which sense Christ saith to Philip, he that hath seene Ioh. 14. 9. me, hath seene my Father. But in the life to come wee shall see God face to face: that is, with a cleere and manifest knowledge, and not in darke glasses, shadowes, and resemblances: but as he is. Not that we shall behold him in his full quantitie1. Ioh. 3. 2.
which is infinite, and therefore incomprehensible, but so much as the creature is capable of; and in his nature and attributes, knowing him in his wisedome, power, goodnesse, iustice and the rest (all shadowes and vailes being taken away) much more perfectly & clerely then Adam did before his fal. For as we know men by their faces, and are able therby to distinguish them from all others; so by that sight of God, whereby we shall with the cleere eyes of our vnderstandings know his substance, nature, and attributes, wee shall be able not onely to know him in himselfe, but also to distinguish him from all the creatures. Whereby we are not to conceiue that our knowledge of God in this life, and in the life to come shall be diuers in themselues, and differing in their substance and essence, but onely in degree and excellency; for so the Apostle saith, that now we know in part, that is, imperfectly and obscurely, but then face to face. Whereby1. Cor. 13. 11. he signifieth, that this knowledge of God in this life, is a part and beginning of the other, and not of a diuers kind and different nature. And that wee know and vnderstand as children: whereby is meant, that as children haue but a weake and imperfect knowledge, whereby they do but after a childish maner conceiue of high matters, as of kings, empires, forraine countries, State affaires, when they heare their parents talking of them, sometimes imitating them in their words and discourses, and not cleerely vnderstanding what they say; but when they come to riper age, they haue, in substance indeed and nature, the same vnderstanding and knowledge, but in farre greater growth, perfection and excellency; euen as they haue being men; the same bodies which they had in their infancie, but much more strong and perfect. And as we see the same sunne, with the same eyes, and after the same mane • , through a thicke mist or cloud, which we do in a cleere day, though much more obscurely and imperfectly: so shall we with the same vnderstandings, see the same God, after the same spiritual maner in heauen, as we doe on the earth, but yet in respect of the measure and degree, with much more excellencie, cleerenesse and perfection. For here we fee God and conceiue of the ioyes of his
kingdome, after a simple, weake, and childish maner, speaking of them as wee haue heard and read in the word of our heauenly Father, and not perfectly vnderstanding what wee say, because wanting experience and perfect vnderstanding of that which wee discourse of, wee are notable to comprehend it. But in the life to come we shall see God face to face, and know him as wee are knowne, that is, cleerely, experimentally, substantially, and essentially, without any darke riddles or shadowes of obscurity; without which vision and knowledge there could be ho perfection of happinesse. For then alone are we truely blessed, when as wee haue our wils and all our desires throughly satisfied; but it is impossible that we should bee thus satisfied and contented, vnlesse wee be filled with this diuine nature, in our vnderstandings apprehending, and with our wils, desires, and affections, louing and imbracing this most perfect substance, and diuine essence; seeing (as I haue said) their capacity is so large, that nothing but an infinite goodnesse can fill and satisfie them. Neither is it possible that our minds should bee contented and at quiet, when as we see many excellent effects, and doe not know the more excellent causes, and when as we behold and know the beautifull creatures, and are ignorant, or not throughly acquainted with the Creator himselfe, of infinite more beautie and perfection.

Whereby we are not grosly to conceiue, that we shall see§. Sect. 2. That our vision of God shall be spirituall, and how sar forth we may be said to see him with our bodily eyes; and that in him we shall haue the knowledge of all diuine mysteries. August. epist. 111. tom. 2. Gods nature and substance with our bodily eyes; for hee is spirituall and they corporall; but with the spirituall, and pure eyes of our minds and vnderstandings shall wee behold this pure, perfect and spirituall substance; neither can (as one saith) the essence of God bee seene with corporall eyes, for then should he bee also corporall, and visiblie circumscribed in a space or place, and not incomprehensible and omnipresent, but diuisible and circumscriptible: but the inuisible God is seene inuisiblie, that is, by that part of our nature which is inuisible; to wit, a pure and vndefiled mind or soule. Notwithstanding though wee cannot see God essentially with our bodily eyes; yet shall we accidentally behold him in his visible creatures, in whose glorified bodies,
his glory, wisedome, and power shall cleerely shine. And though wee cannot see the Deitie or diuine nature, because in it owne essence it is spirituall and inuisible, yet shall wee see God, in that liuely image of his sonne and our Sauiour Iesus Christ, who is God and man. In which sense Iob saith, that he shall se • God in his flesh, that is, Christ Iesus his redeemet,Iob 19. 27. and in him as his perfect image and liuely picture, in whom all the fulnesse of the Godhead dwelleth bodily, as the ApostleCol. • . 9. speaketh, shall wee see the Father and his holy spirit. And as we cannot in this life see the substance and essence of our soules with our bodily eyes; but yet can with them behold them in the functions, operations, and actions which they exercise in the body; so though we cannot visiblie and sensiblie see the inuisible and incomprehensible God in his owne spirituall nature and being; yet may wee behold him in his creatures, exercising in them his wisedome, power, and goodnesse, especially in that liuely character, and perfect paterne, his son Iesus Christ. But our chiefe vision and knowledge of God shall be spirituall in our soule, mind, and vnderstanding, wherewith wee shall cleerely behold Gods essence and nature, in all his attributes and perfections, and also his persons, conceiuing the great mysterie of the Trinitie, the Father, Son, and holy Spirit, in the Vnity of their most simple and vndiuided nature; and cleerely knowing the eternal generatiō of the Son by the Father, & the proceeding of the holy Spirit, and what distinction and difference there is betweene them. Then shal we know how al things in God are one and the same (except only the relation of the persons one to another) and that there is no diuersitie of faculties, but one pure and perfect essence, nor his wisedome, goodnesse, iustice, mercy, and the rest of the attributes different the one from the other, but all one and the same in God, yea of God, as being all of his essence and being. Then shall we vnderstand how God is wholly euery where, & yet without place, great without quantitie, & good without quality. Then shall we know those great mysteries of Christs two natures conioyned in the same person in the hypostaticall vnion, and of the vnion of our bodies with our head Christ, by the same
spirit dwelling in vs; whereby wee become flesh of his flesh, and bone of his bones, though wee be farre remote the one from the other; then shall we be acquainted with the causes of Gods eternall counsell in our election, creation, redemption, & in the gathering and gouerning of his Church, with all other his works of wonder. Then shal we know the spiritual substances of Angels, the nature, essence, & beginning of our owne soules; together with the hidden formes of other creatures. In a word, euery mysterie or secret whatsoeuer which is profitable, and the knowledge therof by vs desired, shall there be vnderstood of vs; seeing blessednes consisteth in full contentment, and we cannot rest quiet & content, vnlesse our desires be perfectly satisfied. Al which excellent and bottomlesse mysteries shall not grow stale and common vnto the Saints as soone as they haue conceiued them, but for euer remaine new and wonderfull; neither shall they procure in the beholders lesse admiration and wonder after manyAugust. de triplici habitaculo. cap. 4. 6. thousand yeeres beholding them, then at their first illumination and acquaintance with them. So that being illuminated with that diuine light of Gods holy spirit, wee shall not only see God, but by him his workes and creatures; and as in this life wee see God in the creatures, so in the life to come, we shall see the creatures in and by God; for then hee alone shall be our sunne which shall giue vs all our light, asApoc. 21. 23. the holy Ghost speaketh. And as in this world wherin things are sensible, we haue our power of seeing the creatures from the benefit of the sunne inlightning the ayre, and the obiect, that we may behold and discerne it; so God the intelligible sunne of the world, with the beames and light of his holie spirit, doth so illighten the minds of the blessed, that thereby they are inabled to see his owne face and essence, will, and counsels, with open and cleere view, and also his creatures and workes of wonder which he hath made for our delight and admiration, and for his owne praise and glorie. By all which it appeareth that one of the greatest parts of our heauenly happinesse, consisteth in our vision and ioyfull knowledge of God, whereby wee shall not onely know himselfe, but his creatures and workes of excellencie, in and by the
light of his spirit. So our Sauiour saith, that the pure in heart are Matth. 5. 8. blessed, because they shall see God: and that Ioh. 17. 3. eternall life cōsisteth in the knowledge of God, and his sonne Christ. So the holy Apostles Paul and Iohn, doe make it a chiefe part of our happinesse, that we shall 1. Cor. 13. 12. see God face to face, know him as we are knowne, and 1. Ioh. 3. 2. see him as he is. And the Prophet Dauid saith, that beholding Gods face in righteousnes, he should be Psal. 17. 15. satisfied with his image. And hence it is that our Sauiour earnestly desiring the happinesse of his seruants, doth intreate of his Father, that those whom he had Ioh. 17. 24. giuen him might be with him, and behold his glorie. And this standeth with good reason that this vision and knowledge of God should be a chiefe and principall part of our happinesse; first, because our vnderstanding being the chiefest facultie of the chiefest part of man, it must needs be a chiefe part of our ioy and glorie to haue it satisfied and contented. But how can it be satisfied, if seeing excellent effects, it doe not see the cause; and if knowing the rare workes of God, it doe not also know the workman? Againe, if there should be in heauen no true knowledge of God, there could be no loue of him, and consequently no pleasure and delight: for howsoeuer we may loue an euill thing, yet wee cannot loue a thing vnknowne; and if wee doe not loue it, we take no comfort or ioy in the being of it. So that take away knowledge, and take away loue and delight; and contrariwise, presuppose excellencie and perfection of the obiect, and the greater our knowledge is, the greater will be our loue, the greater also our pleasure and contentment in the fruition of it.

The other part of our fruition of God, is our communion§. Sect. 3. Of that communion which we shall haue with God in the kingdome of heauen. with him; neither shall wee onely see and behold him in all his goodnes, glorie, and maiestie, but we shall also in a most blessed manner be vnited vnto him, and communicate with him in all his happinesse, which is the supreme end of our creation and redemption, and the very perfection of our glorification. For therefore did the Lord create vs according to his own image, & conformable to himself in wisedom, righteousnes and holines, that he might dwell with vs, & in vs, as in his holy temple and habitation, and that wee might
haue communion with him in all his excellencies and perfections. And when this communion was dissolued and broken off by the fall of our first parents, and our sinnes had separated betweene our God and vs, because our bodies andEsay 59. 2. soules being corrupted and defiled with sin and wickednes, were more fit to be the habitations and dwelling places of the wicked and vncleane spirits, then the temples of the holy Ghost; then the Lord louing vs as his creatures ordained to glorie, with an eternall loue, and taking compassion of our miserable condition, sent his sonne into the world to bee our mediatour, and to repaire this communion betweene him and vs, by taking our nature vpon him, and vniting it to the diuine nature, that so it being vnited to his Deitie, and we to his Humanitie, by this mediation and bond we might be reunited vnto him, and that much more perfectly then in our first creation. So that the bond of our vnion with God is our Sauiour Christ, who being God and man, by his humane nature assumed, vniteth vs to God, and by his diuine nature assuming, vniteth God vnto vs, and by vertue of this vnion maketh vs partakers of God, and to haue communion with him in all his goodnesse and diuine excellencies, and to become againe the habitations of God, and the temples of his holy spirit. Now the meanes whereby we are vnited vnto Christ, he becomming our head, and we the members of his bodie, are not onely his assuming of our nature, but also our receiuing of his spirit, whereby being vnited vnto Christ, and becomming one with him, as the head & members of the body are one, because they are informed with the same soule, wee are quickned thereby and doe liue the Gal. 2. 20. Col. 3. 3. 4. life of Christ, as the Apostle speaketh. So it is said, that wee Ephe. 2. 22. are built together to be the habitation of God by the spirit, that 1. Cor. 12. 13. by one spirit we are baptized into one body, that 1. Cor. 6. 17. he who is ioyned with the Lord, is one spirit with him; and contrariwise, that Rom. 8. 9. he who hath not the spirit of Christ, the same is none of his. The which communion betweene God and vs through Iesus Christ, is begun in this life, truly, though in respect of the degree, it be weake and imperfect: for as we haue receiued but the first fruites of the spirit, so wee haue but a small and
weake entrance into this communion, and that by certaine inferiour meanes and instruments. For first by baptisme wee are outwardly and sacramentally ingrafted into the body of Christ, and after by the preaching of the Gospell, made effectuall by the inward operation of Gods holy spirit, a liuely faith is begun in vs, wherby we applie vnto our selues Christ and all his benefits, and so haue communion and fellowship with him. The which vnion and communion is more and more confirmed by the receiuing of the Lords Supper, because by it our faith, which is on our part the bond thereof, is strengthened and increased.

But howsoeuer this communion with God and his sonne§. Sect. 4. That our communion with God shall be much more excellent and perfect then it is in this life. Christ, be the same in nature and substance, with that which we haue with them in this life, yet doe they exceedingly differ in the quantitie and degree, in the inferiour meanes which God vseth to haue communion with vs, and in the bond on our part, whereby wee are vnited vnto Christ. For then we hauing fulnes of the spirit, shall be fully and perfectly vnited vnto our head and Sauiour, and through him vnto God; inioying him in a neere, excellent, and vnspeakeable manner. And whereas in this life God communicateth vnto vs himselfe, his mercie, and goodnesse, by inferiour meanes, and secondarie causes; as his spirituall graces, by the meanes and ministerie of his word and Sacraments; his temporall benefits tending to our preseruation, and the maintenance of our liues, by his creatures, as meate, drinke, clothing, the sun, ayre, earth, and the rest; after this life these inferious causes and meanes shall cease, and God without them shall be all in all, supplying vs with all things which we can desire, immediatly by his owne al-sufficiencie, and perfecting our happinesse by himselfe alone, without any helpes or inferiour instruments. Finally, the bond of our vnion with Christ in thisHeb. 11. 1. life, is a true faith, which in the life to come shall cease, and we shall be vnited vnto him, and through him vnto God immediatly by his spirit, which shall dwell in vs. And on our part, in stead of faith, we shal be vnited vnto the blessed Trinitie, by that perfect vision and knowledge of God, it being the nature of true and effectuall knowledge, to comprehend
and (as it were) to infold as much as may bee the obiect or thing knowne, either receiuing it selfe, or the species and forme thereof into the mind and vnderstanding: and by that perfect loue, which we shall haue of God the Father, his Sonne, and holy spirit, the nature whereof is, to transforme (as much as may be) the party louing into the thing beloued, and to make all things common betweene them. Whereby we may partly, and in some darke manner vnderstand, what that diuine and holy vnion betweene God and vs shall be in the life to come: namely, a communion with God, in all his goodnesse and perfections, through the spirit of God dwelling in vs, vniting vs first vnto Christ, and in him to God the Father; and through our knowledge and loue of God, seeing and inioying him, whereby we shall become the habitations and temples of the Deitie, in which it will eternally dwell, and God shall be come vnto vs all in all, immediately quickning, preseruing, and glorifying vs by himselfe, without the helpe and ministerie of inferiour meanes. And of this vnion, the scriptures speake plentifully. For so the Apostle Peter saith, that we shall be made partakers of 2. Pet. 1. 4. the diuine nature. And our Sauiour Christ praieth for all his elect, that they may be all one, as he and his Father were one: Iohn 17. 21. I pray (saith he) for all that shall beleeue in me, that they all may be one, as thou O Father art in me, and I in thee, euen that they may bee also one in vs. And in this respect, they are said to bee the Temples of God, in which he dwelleth. 2. Cor. 6. 16. Yee are (saith the Apostle) the temple of the liuing God; as God hath said, I will dwell among them, and walke there: I will be their God, and they shall be my people. So elsewhere he saith, that Ephes. 2. 22. we are built together to be the habitation of God by the spirit. And this is the voice of God from heauen, Apoc. 21. 4. §. Sect. 5. Of the excellent fruits which will accompanie our communion with God; and namely, that hee will be vnto vs all in all.
Behold the Tabernacle of God is with men, and he will dwell with them, and they shall be his people, and God himselfe shall be their God with them.

And this is that communion which the glorified Saints shall haue with God and our Sauiour Christ, the fruits and benefits whereof are infinit and inestimable: for communicating with God, who is infinit in al perfections, in his goodnesse, glorie, and excellencie, we shall abound with all blessings
which our hearts can desire, and farre aboue all which we can conceiue; for whether it be glory, riches, pleasures, beautie, loue, wisdome, or whatsoeuer other excellencies we can conceiue, we shall find them infinitely contained in the fountaine and treasurie of all goodnesse. Againe, being vnited vnto God, and communicating with him in the vertue and power of his holy spirit, we shall be quickned thereby, and liue the life of God, in puritie, eternitie, and all perfection, not in the quantitie, for God is infinit in all good, but 〈◊〉 qualitie and similitude, according to our measure and proportion. To which purpose one saith, that, as the soule is theAugust. de cotnit. verae vitae, lib. cap. 31. Ʋt vita carnis anima est: ita vita beat • hominis deus est. Psalm. 144. 15. August. de ciuit. dei lib. 19. cap. 26. 1. Cor. 15. 23. life of the bodie; so God is the life of the soule; and as the bodie is dead, when it hath not the soule, so the soule is dead when it wanteth God. And as the blind man is said to haue dead eies, when they are depriued of light and sight; so the soule is dead, if it doe not inioy God, the life of blessednesse. Furthermore by vertue of this communion it commeth to passe, that God al-sufficient is vnto vs all in all, as the Apostle speaketh, that is, doth free vs from all euill, and replenish and furnish vs with all good, which our hearts can desire, and that immediately by himselfe, and not by secondarie helpes, and inferiour meanes, as he doth in this life. To which purpose elsewhere he desireth, that the Ephesians might know the loue of Christ, which passeth all knowledge; that they might bee silled Ephes. 3. 19. with all fulnesse of God. In this life, God is not thus al in all, as he will be in the life to come, partly because he vseth for the procuring of our good, many meanes and instruments by which he worketh; and partly because he doth not giue vnto vs all things in any excellencie and perfection; in which respect it is truly said, that Gods gifts are not now all in all, butHieron. epist. 37. ad Admand. presbyt. some in euery man, as Wisdome in Salomon, pietie in Dauid, patience in Iob, and so in the rest; but in our heauenly happinesse, when God shall be all in all, we shall excel in all goodnes, vertue, glorie and perfection. Neither shall wee then need any thing, because we shall inioy God al-sufficient, who will by himselfe supplie all our wants, and grant vnto vs all our wishes. So the Apostle saith, that in the heauenly Ierusalem,Apoc. 21. 22. 23. there shall bee no temple, for the Lord God al-mightie, and the
Lamb shall be the temple of it, & we shal worship God in God: nor Sunne or Moone to shine in it, for the glorie of the Lord shall light it, and the Lambe shall be the light of it. And therefore we shall no more need these worldly lights, then we need the light of a candle, when the Sunne shineth. We shall not need the Word and Sacraments, as meanes wherby we may more firmely be vnited vnto God; for then God will communicate himselfe vnto vs immediately without these secondarie and inferiour helps. Neither shall we need food, apparell, sleepe, and other meanes of preseruing life, seeing God will immediately quicken vs, by his holy spirit dwelling in vs. And this shall be the perfection of our heauenly happinesse, that God most wise, omnipotent, and al-sufficient, shal by himselfe free and preserue vs from euil, and fil and furnish vs with al good: and though when wee haue spoken neuer so much of this eternall blessednesse, wee cannot attaine vnto the excellencieEccles. 43. 27. thereof, yet let vs know, that this is the summe of all, that God is all, as the sonne of Syrach speaketh. Finally, by our communion with God, we shall become as like vnto him, as a finit creature may resemble the infinit Creatour; like in goodnesse, like in glory, like in eternitie, and in all perfection; for so the Apostle Paul saith, that we shall all behold as in a mirrour, 2. Cor. 3. 18. the glory of the Lord with open face, and shall be changed into the same image from glorie to glorie, as by the spirit of the Lord. And the Apostle Iohn saith, that when he shall appeare, we shall be like vnto him, because we shall see him as he is. For as a drop of waterCyprian. de singular. cleric. being put into a vessell of wine, hath it owne nature altered, and receiueth both the taste and colour of the wine: And as iron lying long in the fire, retaining it owne substance, receiueth the fires properties of light and heate, and becommeth like vnto it: And as the Sunne beames shining in the aire, do make it bright and cleare, like the Sunne it selfe: And finally, as a glasse hauing the Sun shining on it, retaineth in it a liuely image of the Sunne both in figure and light: so the faithfull being conuersant with God vnto all eternitie, shal be, as it were, swallowed vp of that infinit excellencie; and though they retaine their owne nature and substance, yet shal they bee so indued with diuine qualities, that they shal
be liuely images, and, as it were, little models of Gods infinit goodnesse, glorie and perfection. And to conclude all in a word, by this communion we shall attaine vnto perfect blessednesse, wee hauing in God whatsoeuer wee desire. For (as one saith) What seekest thou that is not in him? What desirestBernard. de miseria humana serm. thou besides him? What pleaseth thee without him? Hee hath made all, hee hath all, hee is all. Whatsoeuer good thing thou desirest, whatsoeuer beautifull thing thou likest, whatsoeuer sweet and delightfull thing thou requirest, in him thou shalt find it, and in him thou shalt inioy it. If thou wilt reioyce, he is ioy; if thou wilt striue, hee is the garland; if thou wilt be crowned, he is the crowne; if thou wilt ouercome, he is the victorie; if thou desire power, he is omnipotent; if fortitude, he is a God of strength; if righteousnes, he is iustice it selfe; if prudence, he is the fountaine of wisdome; if charitie, hee is loue; if riches, he is a treasure that can neuer faile; if thou wouldest be beautifull, he is beautie it selfe; if thou seekest honor, he is a God of glory and maiestie; if peace, he is peace eternall; if fulnesse of all good, he is an infinit and inexhaustable goodnesse, and whatsoeuer good thou canst desire, this summum bonum, and chiefe good shal replenish thee with it.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
Of our perfect loue of God, our vnwearied delight in praising him; our perpetuall Sabbath, continuall ioy, and reioycing in the fruition of God; and of the eternitie of all this our happinesse.
div.p:
BVt seeing it were infinite to stand in such particulars;§. Sect. 1. That we shall most perfectly loue God, and be most happie in this our loue. because God, whom we inioy, is infinite in all goodnesse and perfection; therefore leauing all the rest of the fruits which our communion with God will yeeld vnto vs; I will only insist in that heauenlie loue, and the fruits thereof, wherewith being vnited vnto God, we
shall loue him, and hee vs; which is the bond of our vnion with him, and the very perfection of our happinesse. For when wee shall see Gods excellencies and perfections, and communicate with him in all his happinesse, and call to mind the infinite loue wherewith he hath alwaies loued vs, chusing vs vnto life before we were, creating vs according to his owne image vnto glorie, sustaining vs by his power and prouidence from time to time, and preseruing and protecting vs in the middest of innumerable dangers; redeeming vs by giuing his onely sonne, as the price of our redemption; calling vs by his word and spirit, to the participation of him, and all his benefits; iustifying, sanctifying, and finally, imparting vnto vs the ioies of heauen, yea, himself, his glory, goodnesse, and eternall happinesse to bee inioyed of vs; then will this exceeding loue of God inflame our hearts with loue towards him againe, fill and replenish them with infinite ioy in his fruition, and make vs to take our whole delight in thinking, speaking, and doing whatsoeuer wee know may bee pleasing and acceptable vnto him: then shall it bee our pleasure to thinke and speake of his mercies and goodnesse, to sing his praises, and with al our might to extoll and magnifie his beautie and excellencie in himselfe, and his benefits and blessednes communicated vnto vs: then shall not his commandements be grieuous vnto vs, but we shall performe them with all alacritie, ioy and comfort: then shall wee (as one saith) haue an holy otium, and goodAugust. de ciuit. dei. lib. 22. cap. 30. leisure to contemplate Gods diuine excellencies, and seeing them, we shall loue them, and louing shall praise them. And this shall bee our end without end; for what other end haue we, but to come to that Kingdome which hath no end? then being freed from al euil, and fully replenished with al good, we shall contemplate and behold Gods beautie and goodnesse,August. de spiritu & anima cap. 65. which doth replenish and fill vs; and he shall be the end of all our desires, whom wee shall see without end, loue without loathing, and praise without wearines. Of all whichIpse facit vt desideres; ipse est quod desideras. Causa diligendi deum deus est. loue and ioy the Lord himself is the sole author, efficient, obiect, end and fruit. For first in our creation, he wrought in vs this facultie or affection of loue, wherby man desireth to imbrace
and vnite vnto himselfe the thing beloued▪ that so Ipse dat occasionem, ipse creat • ffectionem, desiderium ipse consummat. Bernard. de dilig. deo tract. inioying it, hee may rest contented, and reioyce in this fruition. And that to this maine end, that wee might destre, imbrace, and bee vnited with all our hearts, wils and affections, vnto himselfe our supreme good, who i • infinite in all beautie and perfection, and so by this bond of loue become one with him. For as the Apostle saith, God 1. Iohn 4. 16. is loue, and hee that dwelleth in loue, dwelleth in God, and God in him. So the Lord is the efficient cause of our loue, whilest hee communicateth himselfe vnto vs, who is worthie of all loue, and with the infinit flames of his loue towards vs, doth inflame our hearts with loue towards him: and the obiect likewise of our affection, being most louely and full of all beautie, excellencie, and affection. And finally, he is the supreme end, and from him alone haue we all the fruit of our loue, whilest imbracing him in our harts and affections, who containeth all good and perfection, we are fullie satisfied, replenished with delight, and made thereby most happie and blessed. For seeing it is the nature of loue to vnite the person louing, with the thing beloued, yea, to transforme him as much as may be, into the same nature, and to adorne him with the same excellencies which it affecteth: and seeing our loue of God shall be so perfect, that we shal loue him with all the powers of our soules, much more ardently then we doe our selues; hereof it will come to passe, that wee shall much more reioyce in his glory and blessednes, then in our owne; and the fuller our hearts be with his loue, the more ioy shall we haue in beholding his felicitie. As therefore we loue God because he communicateth vnto vs heauenly happinesse, so shall we be most happie, because we loue him. For then are we perfectly blessed, when we haue the full fruition of our summum bonum, and chiefe happinesse; and the chiefe meanes, whereby we imbrace and inioy it, is, when our wils desire it, and our hearts and affections are set vpon it. And as wee are thus happie and blessed, because wee shall perfectlie loue the Lord, so much more, because he will loue vs, both because his loue is infinit, and far beyond all degrees of comparison surpassing ours, and also because it is actiue, operatiue,
and most powerfull to communicate vnto vs all goodnesse and perfection; for louing our being, he causeth vs to be; louing vs by his grace, he communicateth grace vnto vs; louing vs vnto glorie and eternall happines, he doth by this loue glorifie vs, and make vs happle. Wherein the loue of God infinitly exceedeth the loue of men: for they loue one another, because they find them worthie their loue, as being beautifull, good, vertuous, and indued with good parts; but God by his louing vs, maketh vs worthie his loue; and doth not therefore first loue vs, because we are good, beautifull, and full of vertue, and perfection, bu • because he loueth vs, he imparteth vnto vs beautie, vertue, goodnes, and all good parts, framing the obiect of his loue to his owne mind, that he may eternally delight in louing of it, being fitted and made worthie of his loue and fauour.

And because this shall be our continuall exercise to contemplate§. Sect. 3. That we shall keepe an eternal Sabbath vnto God. Gods infinit beautie, glorie, and perfections, hereof it will come to passe, that we shall keepe an eternall Sabbath, and perpetuall rest vnto the Lord, for his glorie and our own infinit ioy and comfort. Neither is it to be thought, that in this heauenly happinesse, we shall spend our time in slothfull ease, and idle rest, which is more tedious and lothsome then the painfullest labour; but that we shall wholly rest from sinne, and performe vnto God, pure and perfect seruice; and also from the fruits of sinne, as the troubles andEsay 66. 23. grieuances of this life, our painfull labours, wearines of bodie, and cares of mind; and enioy peaceable quietnes in the vision and fruition of God, without any trouble, care, or other molestation. So the Apostle Paul saith, that the Lord2. Thess. 1. 7. at his appearing, will free vs from our troubles, and giue vnto vs rest: and elsewhere he affirmeth, that there remaineth a Hebr. 4. 9. 10. rest to the people of God: for he that is entred into his rest, hath also ceased from his owne workes, as God from his: And the Apostle Iohn telleth vs that in our heauenly happines, there shall be no more sorrow, nor crying, nor paine, because God shall Apocal. 21. 4. wipe all teares from our eyes. And this is the perfection of
that rest, which our Sauiour promiseth. Take my yoke on you Matth. 11. 29. (saith he) and learne of me, that I am meeke and lowly in heart, and you shall findrest to your soules. Besides, we shall rest in our wils and desires, and no more (as in this life) couet after better, or other things; because hauing attained vnto the fruition of our summum bonum, and perfection of happines, we shall be throughly, and fully satisfied, there being nothing in heauen or in earth which we can desire more: for as in nature rest is the end of motion, and the appetite ceaseth as being satisfied, when the matter hath attained his desired forme: and as the bodie resteth, when it is come vnto the place vnto which it trauelled: so our soules endeuouring to obtaine those things which they loue and desire, that being thereby fully satisfied and contented, they may rest and reioyce in their fruition, hauing attained vnto the fruition of God, and that heauenly happines, and infinit ioy in his presence, and being satiate without satietie with his goodnesse and perfection, do peacefully and most ioyfully rest in this blessed communion with him.

For with this rest there shall be ioyned all peace, comfort,§. Sect. 4. That in our heauenly happinesse we shall haue all ioy, comfort, peace, and reioycing in God. ioy, and reioycing in God, and in the fruition of our heauenly happines, which is (as it were) the top of our perfectiō, and the haruest of our glorie: for as the sight and presence of God, is the root of all our felicitie and blessednes, the loue and fruition of him, the bodie, boughes and branches of this tree of life eternall; so this ioy and gladnes, reioycing and triumphing in God, our summum bonum, shall be the fruit vpon which we shall feed to our euerlasting comfort: when as seeing, inioying, louing, praising, and resting in him; we shall take infinit pleasure and delight in the sight of his beautie and glorie, in the taste of his sweetnes and bountie, and in the fruition of his goodnes and perfection. And hence it is, that our Sauiour Christ calleth our heauenly happines by theMatth. 25. 21. name of ioy: Enter (saith he) into thy masters ioy; and the Psalmist, fulnes of ioy and eternall pleasures; and that they are describedPsalme 16. 11. by the actions of pleasure which we vse in this life, as eating, drinking, singing, playing on instruments and such like: to note vnto vs, that our sweet repose in God, accompanied
with all these ioyes, comforts and delights, is the consummation and perfection of all our happines: for as in this life God hath endued man with such a nature, that his will, heart and affections, embracing their loued and liked obiects, he is sweetly affected with them, and hath his heart opened with ioy, that (as much as may be) it may receiue them into it, and so reioyce in their fruition; with which ioy and gladnes the heart is cheared, the health preserued, and the life prolonged; so he retaining still his nature, and naturall faculties, though in farre greater excellencie and perfection, doth, when he seeth his summum bonum and chiefe happines, God infinit in all perfection, with his will and soule embrace this most beloued obiect, and hauing his heart with this heauenly vision, filled with all ioy and gladnesse, it doth more and more dilate and enlarge it, to make an open entrance and passage, for this chiefe good which it most dearely loueth, that by a more full fruition of it, there may be still greater cause of glorying and reioycing. And this is that peace and infinit ioy which is begun in all the faithfull, euen in this life; when as knowing God in Christ, and being assured by faith of the pardon of our sins, of our reconciliation, and recouery of his loue and fauour, by our Sauiours perfect and al-sufficient satisfaction, and of those future ioyes which in our heauenly countrie are prepared and reserued for vs; we do ioy and reioyce in this knowledge and assurance, not only when we enioy worldly prosperitie, but also in our greatest afflictions and persecutions. Neither is the ioy and peaceRom. 5. 1. 3. of the faithfull in earth, of a diuers kind, and different nature to that which the Saints shall haue in heauen; for the whole kingdome of God, comprising both the kingdome of grace, and the kingdome of glorie, is righteousnesse, peace, Rom. 14. 17. and ioy in the holy Ghost, as the Apostle speaketh: but the difference betweene them, is, in their degree and quantitie; for as the knowledge, fruition, and loue of God is weake and imperfect in this life; so also is our peace and ioy; besides that it is continually molested and disturbed, with many cares, feares, and griefes, arising both from the things without vs, and within vs; from all which imperfections and troubles
we being perfectly freed is our heauenly 〈◊◊〉 , shall also attaine vnto perfect peace, and compleate fulnes of ioy and comfort; so unit shall not bee like our worldly ioy, 〈◊〉 suit; outward, and 〈◊〉 with griefe and sorrow, according to the saying of the Wise man,
〈◊〉 loughing the Pro • . 14. 13. heart is sorro full and the end of that 〈◊〉 his heau 〈…〉 esse, but kindly, heartie, pure and sincere, without the mixture of either griese or miserie; not tickle and inconstant, reioycing and mourning almost with the • ame breath, but most constant and durable, permanent and continuall, being free, both from end, and all distraction and perturbation: not caused by bitter quippes and biting girds, nor yet by foolish iesting, and filthie speaking; but spirituall, graue and holy, hauing a farre different root from which it springeth, namely, the fruition of God; and our heauenly happines. Finally, our ioyes shall not like the pleasures of the world, become tedious in their vse, and loathsome if there be no • continually 〈◊〉 varietie, but shall constantly remaine sweet and pleasant, bringing fulnesse without loathing and 〈◊〉 without 〈◊〉 . Now what shall be the subiect and cause of this our ioy; so infinite, and so endlesse. I haue in part shewed, namely, because we shall be freed from all euill, and replenished with all good, hauing our minds enlightned, our wil • reformed, our consciences purged, and purified, our affections sanctified, our whole man perfectly glorified. And also because we shall enioy the societie of the Angels and 〈◊〉 , our fellowship with the So • ne of God, and our Sauiour, whose excellencies in himselfe and benefits deriued to vs, we shall behold and admire; and admiring, againe contemplate: our communion also with the Spirit of God dwelling in vs; which being such a comforter, and infusing such ioy into our hearts in this life, that enableth vs to endure not only with patience, but with comfort and reioycing all troubles and tortures, afflictions, and persecutions; with what infinit ioy will it fill vs in the world to come in the • uition of God, and all his benefit. Vnto which some also adde that exceeding ioy, which the Saints shall haue, when they see Gods and their enemies troden vnder foot,
and bearing 〈◊〉 punishments for their 〈◊〉 , 〈◊〉 of the hatted of their persons, and desire of reuenge, but because God is glorified 〈◊〉 the execution of iustice, and 〈◊〉
fying his threatninge, according to that of the Psalmist; The rights 〈1 line〉
