〈1 line〉 there it a fruit for the righteous, doubtlesse there is a God that iudggeth the earth an example whereof we haue in the Saints, reioycing and praising God, because he had shewed his truth, and executed his righteousnesse, in the punishment and destruction of the whore of Babylon.Apoc. 19. 1 • .

All which their ioy is made most perfect and compleat,§. Sect. 5. That the ioyes of heauen shall be eternall and euerlasting. Ioh. 16. 22. because it shall not continue onely for a time, but remaine and endure for euer and euer; for the ioy which our Sauiour will giue vnto vs, no man shall be able to take it from •• . And this is the last point which I propounded, without which all the rest were maimed and vnperfect; for though our heauenly happinesse were in it selfe neuer so compleat and absolute in all perfections, yet if it were not also permanent and euerlasting, and infinite in time, as well as incomprehensible in quantitie, we could not be said to be perfectly happie, and truely blessed. For though we were sure they should continue many hundred thousand of yeeres, yet if wee also knew, that they would then end and leaue vs, wee should bee as much discontented, that the time would come when as we should be depriued of them, as comforted in their present fruition; yea the greater and more excellent our ioyes should be whilest we haue them, the greater would in this respect our sorrow and griefe be, to thinke that we should once bee dispolled of them; whereas now finding them for deepresent infinite, and in respect of the time to come endlesse, nothing can be added to their perfection. But the eternitie ofEsa. 60. 15 & 65. 18. these ioyes may as cleerely be proued out of the holy Scriptures, as their vnconceiueable excellencie. So the Psalmist saith, that in Gods Psal. 16. 11. presence is fulnesse of 〈◊〉 and it his right hand pleasures for ouer 〈…〉 . And our Sauiour promiseth that they who Ioh. 6. 51. &
• ate of 〈◊〉 end of life 〈◊◊〉 for euen: and saith, that it is 17. 3. life 〈◊◊〉 to 〈◊〉 God and his sonne Christ. And
in this the Apostle maketh an opposition betweene the things of this life, and the life to come; In that the 1. Ioh. 2. 17. world passeth away, and the lusts thereof; but he that fulfilleth the will of God abideth euer. So the kingdome of glory is said to bee so constant and permanent that it cannot be shaken, and hath the epithete of eternitie, oftentimes attributed vnto it: thus it is called Heb. 12. 28. eternall glory, vnto which the God of all grace hath called vs by Iesus Christ; and an 1. Pet. 5. 10. eternall inheritance, which can neuer fade nor perish: So the Apostle faith, that Heb. 9. 15. Christ was appointed to be our mediatour, that through his death those which are called, might receiue the promise of an eternall inheritance. And the Apostle Peter telleth vs, that we haue 1. Pet. 1. 4. an inheritance, immortall, and vndefiled, and that fadeth not away, reserued in heauen for vs. And in this respect the estate of the faithfull, is by the Psalmist made much more excellent then the state of the wicked; that whereas these with all their power and might shall be quite ruined and ouerthrowne, the iust are vpholden by God, and shall haue an Psal. 37. 17. 18. inheritance which shall be perpetuall. Finally, the kingdome of our Sauiour Christ is said to bee eternall, and consequently his subiects ouer whom he raigneth must liue eternally with him: and lest we should thinke that hee continuing in his regencie, may make choice of other subiects, they also are specified to be the house of Iacob, that is, his Church, and faithfull, the true posterity of Abraham according to the promise. For so the Angell of God saith vnto the blessed virgin: Luk. 1. 33. Dan. 7. 27. He shall reigne ouer the house of Iacob for euer, and of his kingdome shall be no end. And to put the matter out of all doubt, that we also shal reign with him; it is not only said in the Scriptures, that we shal be 1. Cor. 15. 53. 2. Tim. 1. 10. incorruptible & immortal; but more precisely, that we Apoc. 22. 5. shall reigne in this kingdome of glory for euermore. Foolish therefore is the dreame and dotage of those heretiques, who imagined that this heauenly glory and happinesse should continue but a thousand yeeres; seeing the Scriptures so plentifully proue, that they shall be endlesse and euerlasting. And as weake and feeble is their ground and foundation, whereupon they build their vaine opinion; namely, because it is said in the Reuelation, that the faithfull shall reigne
with God and our Sauiour Christ a thousand yeeres: which is not to be vnderstood of the kingdome of glory in heauen, but of the kingdome of grace in earth, as the words immediately going before, specially limiting it to the first resurrection, which is our regeneration, whereby in this world we rise from the death of sinne, to holinesse and newnesse ofApoc. 20. • . 6. life, doe plainely shew. So that notwithstanding their foolish and vngrounded assertion we may conclude, that as the ioyes of heauen are in their quantity and quality most excellent and vnspeakeable, infinite and incomprehensible; so also in respect of time they are endlesse and euerlasting, not onely in themselues, but also vnto vs, seeing they shall neuer be taken from vs, not we from them; but after many thousand millions of yeeres expired, they shall bee as farre from their end as the first day when we entred into them. For otherwise wee should not attaine vnto perfect felicitie▪ and compleat blessednesse, which the Scriptures so often do promise vnto vs; seeing it comprehendeth not onely an infinite quantitie and measure of happinesse, but also an euerlasting time, and a perpetuall continuance of this glory and felicity, without the assurance whereof we could neuer be secure, nor our hearts and desires fully satisfied, and without which securitie and satietie there can be no perfect blessednesse and felicitie.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
Of the vses of the former doctrine concerning the ioyes of heauen.
div.p:
ANd thus haue I darkely shadowed out the§. Sect. 1. That we should spend our time rather in getting assurance of these heauenly ioyes, then in curious inquiring after them. 1. Cor. 2. 9. ioyes of heauen, which no mortall man can describe according to their glory and full perfection: for as the Apostle hath taught vs, the things which God hath prepared for all those that loue him, are such, as neither eye hath seene, nor eare hath heard, nor heart conceiued. And as another saith, so innumerable and incomprehensible be these euerlasting ioyes
of Gods kingdome, that al the Arethmeticians in the worldThom. Aquin. de veri. theolog. lib. 7. c • p. vlt. cannot sufficiently number them, nor Geometricians measure them; nor all the Grammarians, Logicians, and Rhetoricians, to the full expresse them. That therefore you may somewhat supplie that wherein the former description is defectiue, call to mind all those ioyes which you haue euer seene, and say with your selues, that they are not these, but farre greater, because your eyes haue beheld them: recall to your memories all those delights and comforts, which you haue euer beene told of, and then withall thinke that they are not these, but much more excellent, because your eares haue heard them; yea faine in your imaginations, whatsoeuer glory and happinesse your mind can conceiue and comprehend, and conclude with ioy, that they are not these, but much more admirable and incomprehensible, because your heart and soule hath been able to conceiue them; seeing the Apostle hath plainely told vs, that these heauenly ioyes are so infinite, and farre aboue all humane reach, that neither the eye, eare, nor heart, haue seene, heard, or conceiued the least part of this diuine glorie, and surpassing excellencie. And therefore seeing they cannot perfectly bee knowne before they be enioyed, let vs not (as many doe) spend our time in curious questions, and busie our selues in searching what is done in heauen, and what are the particular degrees of euerie ones glory, neglecting in the meane time the way which should bring vs vnto this happinesse; but considering that this kingdome is a garland and crowne1. Cor. 14. 24. of glorie, which none obtaine but they who run a race; let vs not foolishly stand still and loiter, enquiring after those hidden and vnknowne iewels, wherewith this crowne is enriched and adorned; but let vs first runne this race, that wee may be assured that wee shall obtaine it, and then shall wee haue time and leasure enough to consider of it worth and excellency. Now is the time wherein we must striue against the enemies of our saluation, that hauing the victorie, wee may receiue the crowne of glorie; and as the Apostle saith, if any man striue for a masterie, hee is not crowned except hee striue as he ought to doe. Now is our seed time, and hereafter
• . Tim. • . 5. 6.
〈1 line〉 saluation are not few and feeble, 〈◊〉 many and potent, euen principalities, powers, gouernours and great princes, as the Apostle calleth them▪ who are no • easily ouercome, vnlesseEph. 6. 12. we • e armed with the spirituall 〈◊〉 , and fight couragiously vnto the end▪ and that our way to heauen is not by a faire and pleasant sea, vpon which wee might faile, though we spend our time in▪ sleeping, and attaine vnto the hauen by other mens labours before we are aware; but a iourney by land • and that the way which wee trauell, is not champion, and delightfull to the old Adam, but (as our▪ SauiourMat. 7. 13. 14. Act. 14. 22. 2. Tim. 3. 12. calleth it) a narrow and afflicted path▪ in it selfe rough▪ and full of rubs, and beset on all sides with the thornes of afflictions, and▪ briars of tribulations, which are likely to discourage vs that wee will not, or hinder vs that wee cannot goe forward to our: iourneyes • nd▪ vnlesse wee breake through them with a magnanimous •• irit▪ and christian resolution. The gate which ent • eth into this heauenly paradise, is (as Christ also telleth vs) so strai •• and vneasie for entrance, that we must striue (if we will haue any passage) to enter in 〈…〉 and that not according to our owne superstitions, but Gods direction; for as much as • ee saith in another place▪ many shall seeke to enter in, but shall not be able. And (as the ApostleLuk. 13. 24. • . Pet. 4. 18. speaketh) if the righteous be scar •• ly saued; that is, not without great paines and difficultie, where shall the vngodly and §. Sect. 2. That the difficulty in obtai
• ing the ioyes of heauen should not discourage vs, but make vs more iouragious in taking 〈◊〉
Rom. 8. 18. sinner appeare?

But yet let not this labour and vneasie passage discourage and hinder vs from entring or going forward in this difficult and afflicted way, seeing if wee take the paines which God hath prescribed, we shall most certainly obtaine the reward▪ and when we enioy i • we shall be sure to finde it worth our labour▪ for the Apostle telleth vs▪ that the affliction • of th • present life are not worthie▪ he glorie which shall be showed vnto
vs; because (as else where he speaketh) these light and momentanie 2. Cor. 4. 17. afflictions, shall cause vnto vs a farre most excellent, and an eternall waeight of glorie. Yea rather let vs with greater courage and resolution, passe through all dangers, and endure all paines and labour, that we may attaine vnto this eternall rest and glorious kingdome. For if men for the obtaining of a corruptible crowne, are content to oppresse themselues with cares, to endure all labours, to runne a thousand desperate courses, and euen to hazard their owne soules; yea if they be willing for the smallest preferments and profits of a kingdome, to trauell by sea and land, to spend their strength, and consume their bodies, and to indanger themselues daily to many deaths, though (as I haue shewed) they are but of small worth, and lesse certaintie for their continuance; what cares, dangers, and labours should wee thinke too much for the obtaining of a crowne, which is most glorious and incorruptible, and a kingdome without end? But yet alas, such is either the great infidelitie of men, that they doe not beleeue these things, though God who is truth it selfe doe promise them; or their negligence, that they neuer so much as thinke and meditate vpon them; or their securitie and presumption, that they hope to obtaine this kingdome whether they seeke it or no; or finally, such is their prophanenes and carnall follie, that they esteeme these earthly and momentanie trifles, vaine honours, vncertaine riches, and brutish pleasures, more then these vnspeakable ioyes and euerlasting glorie. For that they stand thus affected, it may plainly appeare by their practise and our daily experience. For whereas if any man of credit should promise vnto them, I will not say a kingdome, but some small profit, pleasure, or preferment, vpon condition that they will take some paines in suing and seeking to obtaine it; how readily and earnestly will they become seekers and suers, that they may inrich themselues with these earthly benefits? but when Christ the eternall veritie, who neuer sailed of his word, offereth this heauenly kingdome of his free grace, as a reward of their paines, if they will labour to obtaine it; how little doe they regard it? how slowly doe they seeke it? thereby shewing manifestly
that either they doe not beleeue Gods promise; or doe so basely esteeme the thing promised, that they preferre before it these worldly trifles and worthlesse vanities. If an earthly King should promise to his subiect some great treasures and high preferments; on this condition, that he shew himselfe dutifull and obedient, in performing some of his lawfull commandements; with how great care and diligence would hee yeeld obedience? and how much more if he should promise, yea and confirme it by his hand, seale, and oath, that hee would adopt him for his sonne, and make him heire apparant of his kingdome? But when God thus promiseth his heauenly benefits, and offereth vnto vs his kingdom of glorie, and to make vs heires of this eternal inheritance, if wee will bestow any paines in seeking of it; how • ew are the number that regard his promises, or bestow any labour in attaining to this assurance? and yet there is great difference, both in respect of the persons promising, & the things promised. For a King being mortal, and mutable, may either die, and so cannot; or change his minde vpon some displeasure, and so will not performe his promise; or though neither of these fall out, hee may die to whom the promise is made, before him that made it, and so neuer come to inherit the kingdome: But God is immortall and immutable, and as he cannot die, so he cannot be changed, and therefore will most certainly performe his promise, if wee performe the condition of our dutie and obedience. And againe, there is great difference between the things promises, euen as great, as is betweene heauen and earth, a substance and a shadow, momentany pleasure, and euerlasting ioy, betweene a flitting and fading kingdome, incumbred with many croffes and afflictions, and a kingdome absolute in all perfection, infinite, endlesse, replenished with all glorie, ioy and riches, and obnoxious to no trouble and incumbrance.

But let vs, who haue see no some small shadow and resemblance§. Sect. 3. Of the meanes whereby wee may be assured to attaine vnto our heauenly ioyes. of this heauenly happinesse; and most perfect glorie, auoid, and not suffer our selues to be carried away, with this common streame of worldly dotage; but as farre as wee see the eternall ioyes of heauen, to exceed the momentanie pleasures
which are in earth, so much let our loue, care, & paines exceed in desiring and seeking to obtaine them. And that wee may not spend our paines in the trauelling of a wrong way, and so in the end complaine that we haue laboured in vaine, let vs make choice of that only way Iesus Christ, desiring to be true members ingrafted into his glorious bodieIoh. 14. 6. by a liuely faith, that so in him we may be the sonnes of God, and the adopted heires of his glorious kingdome. Let vs adioyne our selues to the kingdome of grace, professing our subiection vnto God, and communicating with the rest of the Saints in the exercises of the true religion; as calling vpon God, hearing his word, receiuing his Sacraments, and submitting our selues to be ordred and ruled by the outward discipline and gouernment of the Church. Yea we must not only outwardly professe our selues the subiects and seruants of God, but wee must also liue like his subiects in obedience to his will •• d word. For in vaine doe we draw neere vnto God Matth. 15. 8. with our lips, if our hearts be farre from him; in vaine we heare the word, vnlesse wee obey it; in vaine doe we receiue the Sacraments with our hand and mouth, vnlesse wee also receiue, and applie Christ vnto vs with a true faith, and shew the vigour and vertue of this holy vnion in our vnfained repentance, dying vnto sinne, and rising againe to newnes of life; in vaine doe wee submit our selues to the outward gouernment of the Church, vnlesse also Christ doe inwardly raigne and rule in vs by the scepter of his word and holy spirit: finally, in vaine doe we professe our selues Gods subiects and seruants, if wee liue like the seruants of sinne, and slaues of Satan. Whereas contrariwise, if wee so liue in holy obedience to Gods will, with faith and a good conscience, as we may be assured thereby, that wee are true members of the kingdome of grace, we may also be ascertained, that we shall be heires of the kingdome of glorie, this being the porch or suburbs whereby we enter into our heauenly mansions, and the new Ierusalem, the citie of God. In a word, if euer wee thinke to raigne triumphantly in the kingdome of heauen, and to haue our portion and share in that eternall glorie; we must haue the kingdome of God begun in vs in this life, and
be replenished with the gifts and graces of his holy spirit: for as the Apostle teacheth vs, Rom. 14. 17. the kingdome of God is righteousnesse, and peace, and ioy in the holy ghost. If wee meane to haue Christ Iesus liuing in vs vnto glory, we must liue in him vnto grace and holinesse; so as we may say with the Apostle, that Gal. 2. 20. we liue no more now, but Christ liueth in vs, and in that we now liue in the flesh, we liue by the faith in the sonne of God; for there is none shall eternally liue in heauen, in whom life eternall is not begun on earth, because none shall bee saued but they who haue saith; and he that Ioh. 5. 24. beleeueth hath euerlasting life, and hath passed from death to life, already, as our Sauiour speaketh. Finally, if we would haue any hope to liue that life of glory and happines, we must first liue the life of grace and holines. If we would be Psal. 17. 15. satisfied with Gods image, we must behold his face in righteousnes; if we would be Psal. 31. 19. partakers of Gods goodnesse in the world to come, wee must in this life be indued with his feare; if wee would haue the fruition of God Gen. 17. 1. al-sufficient, wee must walke before him and be vpright. If wee would ascend into the Psal. 15. 1. 2. 3. & 24. 3. 4. mountaine of the Lord, and stand in the place of his holinesse, we must haue innocent hands, and a pure heart; and find in our selues conformitie with that excellent description, which the Lord himselfe maketh vnto the Psalmist, of an heauenly inhabitant; if wee would not let the Apoc. 20. 6. second death take hold of vs, but contrariwise attaine vnto heauenly blessednesse, we must haue our part in the first resurrection; and to conclude this point, if we would be like our Sauiour Christ when he appeareth, and would 1. Ioh. 3. 3. see God as he is, whose vision, as I haue shewed, is our chiefe felicitie, we must, as the Apostle telleth vs, purge our selues, euen as he is pure; for without holinesse wee shall neuer see God: and if we remaine in our vncleannesse, and pollution of sinne, we shall neuer find entrance into the Apoc. 21. 27. city of God, nor bee admitted as inhabitants of the kingdome of heauen, which as much excelleth in puritie and perfection, as in glory, happinesse, and vnspeakeable ioyes.

And thus haue I, through the gracious assistance of Gods§. Sect. 4. The conclusion of the booke, enforcing from that which hath beene said, the contempt of the world. holy spirit, finished this part also of the Christian Warfare, wherein I haue indeauoured to arme euery man against the
tentations of worldly prosperitie; by shewing and proouing that the world and worldly things are base and contemptible, and not worthie any loue and esteeme, in comparison of Gods spirituall graces and heauenly ioyes. For if these earthly things which carnall worldlings doe so much affect, bee vaine and worthles, and Gods spiritual graces, and heauenly ioyes be most excellent and precious; they vnprofitable euen in this life, and these most beneficiall both in this life, and the life to come; if they in themselues are miserable comforters, and bring many other miseries attending on them, and these most sweete and delightfull, without the mixture of any euil; if they be vnceraine to be gotten by those who loue them, and fugitiue to those who most run after them, and these most assuredly obtained by those who desire them, and vse the meanes whereby they may inioy them; if they be as vncertain in their possession, as in their pursuit, being euery day readie to leaue their owners, or their owners to leaue them, and these most constant, permanent and eternall▪ finally, if they through our corruption abusing them, doe so much hurt vs, being the causes, occasions, and instruments of so manifold euils; and these so much benefit vs, adorning vs with all glory, inriching vs with al good, replenishing vs, both in our soules and bodies with all ioyes, pleasures and delights, and making vs in all respects truly happie, and eternally blessed: what doting folly and franticke madnesse is it, either in our iudgements or affections, to preferre the worlds base, worthlesse and momentany trifles, before these inestimable iewels, and heauenly treasures? We account him a child or a foole, who wil preferre a counter before a kingdome, a shadow before a substance, and euery base trifle, before his patrimonie and inheritance: and we both wonder and laugh at the simplicitie of the barbarous nations, who will exchange their gold and pearles, for a knife or glasse; but how much more absurd and ridiculous is their follie and madnesse, who preferre earth before heauē, mammon before God, and the vaine pleasures of sin, which last but for a season, before the Kingdome of glorie, and those vnspeakeable ioyes which shal neuer end? Let vs therefore beware of this worldly frensle;
and seeing we professe the name of Christ, & boast our selues of our heauenly hopes, as though wee were assured of them, and expected eternal crownes and kingdomes, let vs be ashamed that our practise should bewray our iudgements & affections, manifestly showing by our neglect of things spirituall and eternal, and by our earnest & incessant seeking of things momentanie and temporall, that we more esteeme earth then heauen, and desire more the short possession of these worldly vanities, then the euerlasting fruition of God himselfe, and those glorious ioyes of his heauenly Kingdome. We know that those who haue fed on dainties▪ do loath ye tast of grosser meats; and that when the Sun shineth vpon the fire, it maketh the light thereof like vnto a painted colour, and much abateth of it heate, if it doe not quite extinguish it: and so let vs who haue tasted how good God is, and the most delicate sweetnesse of those heauenly ioyes, learne to loath the swinish husks of filthie pleasures, and the windie pulfe of worldly honours; and seeing the diuine light of that heauenly glorie hath shined vnto vs, let it dim the light of carnall reason, and abate, if not extinguish, the flame and fire of our earthly concupiscence. For this is the end, as the Apostle teacheth vs, why the Lord in mercie hath caused his truth to shine vnto vs, and to inlighten our minds with those glorious raies. The Tit. 2. 11. 12. grace of God (saith he) that bringeth saluation vnto all m • n hath appeared, and teacheth vs, that we should denie vngodlinesse, and worldly lusts, and that we should liue soberly, and righteously, and godly in this present world. Let vs not too much esteeme and affect this state of mortality, seeing we our selues are immortall, nor value these earthly things at high rates, as though they were parts and members of our bodies, but onelie account of them as haires, nailes, and other excrements, making a fit proportion of them to serue for ornament, and vse, but cutting them off (at least in our harts and affections) when being more then needs, they grow superfluous. Wee are pilgrims on earth, and therefore let our hearts be specially set and fixed on our heauenly countrie; we are to runne a race for no lesse a prize, then the crowne of glory, and therfore let vs so run, that we may obtaine, and as the Apostle exhorteth1. Cor. 9. 23. 24.
vs, let vs cast away euery thing that presseth downe, and Heb. 12. 1. the sinne that hangeth so fast on, and run with patience the race that is set before vs. We are now fighting in a spirituall warfare: and (as the Apostle saith) no man that warreth, intangleth 2. Tim. 20. 4. himselfe with the affaires of this life, because he would please him who hath chosen him to be a souldier. We are now contending for victorie, and wrastling not with flesh and blood, but against Ephes. 6. 12. principalities, powers, and worldly gouernours. Let vs therefore so fight and striue, that wee may haue a glorious conquest ouer the spirituall enemies of our saluation, and so obtaine the crowne of victorie, which God hath promised vs, euen that glorious felicitie, and eternal happines of his heauenly Kingdom. The which he grant vnto vs which hath dearely bought it for vs, Iesus Christ the righteous, to whom with the Father, and his holy spirit, one true, inuisible, most glorious, most gracious, and only wise God, be ascribed of vs, and of his whole Church, al honour and glory, praise and thanksgiuing, power, maiestie and dominion, both now and for euermore. Amen.
